webTitle: Rangers win through in Champions League

fields.headline: Advocaat sounds alarm after a stroll in the night
fields.standfirst: Rangers win 4-1 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Rangers moved closer to the Champions League at virtually walking pace last night in Lithuania as Zalgiris Kaunas failed to disturb them in this second qualifying round return.
fields.body:
Rangers moved closer to the Champions League at virtually walking pace last night in Lithuania as Zalgiris Kaunas failed to disturb them in this second qualifying round return.

The real work for Rangers was done a week before at Ibrox in a 4-1 victory. But what worries Dick Advocaat is that his side did not convert any of their chances - and that failing could well be punished in Denmark next week.

"I think the players realise that we cannot repeat what we showed today," Advocaat said. "We still have a long way to go."

Herfolge entertain Rangers in the first leg of a tie to decide who enters the group phase of a competition in which success is vital for Rangers.

Rangers scored with five minutes left when a Bert Konterman header was disallowed for a foul and could easily have lost the game but for Giovanni van Bronckhorst heading a late effort off the line.

Billy Dodds was quickly involved, setting up Rod Wallace after five minutes. Wallace just failed to clip the ball beyond the advancing Gytis Padimanskas.

Rangers missed an even better chance in the ninth minute when Fernando Ricksen was clean through, only to strike the bar. From the rebound Wallace headed over an open goal.

It was half an hour before the Lithuanians threatened, Audirus Zuta - who scored their goal at Ibrox - escaped but shot straight at Stefan Klos. For Rangers, Wallace sent another good chance just wide after 47 minutes.

Zalgiris Kaunas (3-5-2): Padimanskas; Dedura, Kancelskis, Zelmikas; Danilicevas, Guodeikis, Dezykornodas, Mika, Regelskis; Ksanavicius, A Zuta.

Rangers (4-4-2): Klos; Ricksen, Konterman, Amoruso, Vidmar (Porrini, h-t); Ferguson, Reyna, Van Bronckhorst, Tugay; Dodds, Wallace.

Referee: F de Bleckere (Belgium).

webTitle: European exit points to a long, hard road for Bradford

fields.headline: European exit points to a long, hard road for Bradford
fields.standfirst: Ugarov 68,75, Tarasov 83 (Agg: 0-4 )
fields.trailText: Bradford City can focus all their attention on the Premiership after their exit from the Intertoto Cup last night.
fields.body:
Bradford City can focus all their attention on the Premiership after their exit from the Intertoto Cup last night.

Worryingly for their new manager Chris Hutchings, they succumbed in a manner which indicates they will face another season of struggle.

St Petersburg, modestly talented but always lively and mobile, are a far cry from the opposition which awaits City this season. Yet the Russian side were always in control of this tie and thoroughly warranted a victory helped by two goals from Denis Ugarov.

Leading 1-0 from the first leg, St Petersburg effectively ended City's unconvincing resistance when Ugarov headed in an overdue goal in the 68th minute.

The midfielder's second was hooked in while he was grounded near the line and the effort was briefly threatened when a linesman raised his flag for offside before changing his mind. The protests of the City players were fruitless, earning Dean Windass a booking.

Ugarov spurned the chance of a hat-trick after a sweeping move seven minutes from the end. He selflessly set up the substitute Yevgeny Tarasov. His side had threatened to decide the tie much earlier, notably through their leading scorer Gennadiy Popovich.

The Russians were only troubled once, when Vlachslav Malaseev alertly saved a 52nd minute header from Lee Mills.

Bradford City: (4-3-3) Clarke; Halle, O'Brien, Atherton, Nolan; Hopkin, McCall, Whalley (Lawrence, 82min); Mill, Blake (Beagrie, 73), Windass.

Zenit St Petersburg: (4-5-1) Malaseev; Lepekkin (Vernidub, 85), Katulsky, Nedorezov, Zvetkov; Ossipov, Ugarov, Kobelev (Archavine, 32), Gorovoi, Spivak; Popovich (Tarasov, h-t).

Referee: M Radoman (Yugoslavia).

webTitle: Villa suffer Schoch treatment

fields.headline: Villa suffer Schoch treatment
fields.standfirst:
Barry 45pen | McCarthy 11, 58
Agg 1-3
fields.trailText: The tortuous route for Uefa Cup qualification sought by Aston Villa took them down a cul-de-sac on a night of ordinary football and extraordinary refereeing.
fields.body:
The tortuous route for Uefa Cup qualification sought by Aston Villa took them down a cul-de-sac on a night of ordinary football and extraordinary refereeing.

Villa's aspirations of entertaining serious European competition next season were ended by two goals from the South African international Benni McCarthy and their own inability to convert possession into goals.

But the occasion will be remembered more for the haphazard performance of the Swiss referee Dieter Schoch than anything else. Both teams had players controversially sent off - Ian Taylor and Alan Thompson going for Villa and Juan Velasco for Celta - the home side were awarded two penalties and the referee blew for time early only to restart play with a bounce-up.

At times it was farcical. At other times it was pure comedy. But John Gregory will not be laughing this morning.

McCarthy exploited some loose marking to drill Gustavo Lopez's through-ball beyond David James after 10 minutes and for long spells of an uncomfortable opening period Villa could find no answers to the Spanish inquisition.

The referee made seven bookings in the first half, inexplicably sent off Celta's Velasco after 24 minutes and threatened to expel their coach Victor Fernandez from his dugout for his protests.

Schoch then spotted an elbow on Gareth Southgate to award Villa a dubious penalty, only for Paul Merson to see his effort saved by Jose Pinto.

Then, in first-half stoppage time, Steve Stone got a kick in the solar plexus from Juanfran and Villa were awarded their second penalty in 90 seconds.

This time Gareth Barry converted the kick to enhance Villa hopes of mounting what had seemed like an improbable comeback.

Within three minutes of the restart, however, Villa's numerical advantage was wiped out, Taylor receiving his second yellow card after Schoch had ruled that the midfielder had dived.

Then, in the 58th minute, Celta emerged from a sustained spell of Villa pressure to re-establish their lead. Lopez took a corner from the left and McCarthy rose unchallenged to head his second of the night.

Aston Villa (3-5-2): James; Samuel (Hendrie 33min), Southgate, Barry; Stone (Thompson 45), Merson, Taylor, Boateng, Wright; Walker, Joachim (Cooke, 75).

Celta Vigo (4-5-1): Pinto; Velasco, Caceres, Sergio, Juanfran; Lopez (Jesuli, 74), Doriva, Giovanella, Karpin, Tomas (Djorovic 30; Coira, 51); McCarthy.

Referee : D Schoch (Switzerland)

webTitle: Hodgson quits as players are sold

fields.headline: Hodgson quits as players are sold
fields.trailText: Darlington's chairman, former burglar and safe-cracker George Reynolds, has been robbed of his manager Daviv Hodgson after a row over the sale of the club's best players.
fields.body:
Darlington's chairman George Reynolds might reflect that his past came back to haunt him yesterday. The former burglar and safe-cracker found himself robbed of his manager 10 days before the start of the season when David Hodgson resigned after a row over the sale of the club's best players.

Hodgson and his assistant Ian Butterworth walked out of the Third Division side after seeing several of the team who reached last season's play-off final sold and not replaced.

Hodgson is understood to have resigned yesterday morning, followed about an hour later by Butterworth, after the new captain Martin Gray was given permission to hold talks with Darlington's north-east rivals Hartlepool.

"Players have been sold and that tells its own story," a friend said on behalf of Hodgson, the former Middlesbrough and Liverpool forward who was appointed in November 1996.

Tensions at Feethams have been high of late, not only because of the transfers but because the multi-millionaire Reynolds cut the players' bonuses and made public the wages of the club's highest earner, Neil Heaney, who has since joined Dundee United.

That was part of Reynolds' campaign against players' spiralling pay. He wrote to his 71 fellow Nationwide League chairman asking for their support but found himself in conflict with his players and facing protests from fans.

Reynolds was said by one player to have been "intimidating" and "insulting" during a meeting to discuss bonuses, "picking on us individually in an attempt to get us to crack".

Gary Bennett has taken over as manager, assisted by the former Sunderland keeper Jim Montgomery, after Butterworth turned down the post. "Lucky losers" in last season's FA Cup after the withdrawal of Manchester United, Darlington were unlucky losers to Peterborough in the play-off final and are the major bookmakers' favourites this season.

As well as campaigning to cut wages, Reynolds supports reduced ticket prices for fans and pledged to freeze charges for 20 years when he took over Darlington last summer.

He is having a 10,000-seat stadium built and has paid off debts of more than £5m.

Hodgson himself said he was owed about £2m before Reynolds' arrival, the result of mounting interest on money he lent the club and was not repaid, but claimed he wrote it off when offered a "generous" contract which he shook on but never signed.

webTitle: Pop review: Michelle Shocked

fields.headline: Super trouper
fields.standfirst:
Michelle Shocked


The Lowry, Salford****
fields.trailText:
Michelle Shocked
The Lowry, Salford****
fields.body:
Back in the 80s, Michelle Shocked was marketed as a spiky-haired misfit, a post-punk political activist who had lived on the streets for a while and got up to no good. The cover of her best-known album, Short Sharp Shocked, pictured her being arrested during a demonstration in San Francisco. Since then, she's had other battles to fight. A three-and-a-half-year wrangle with her former label, Mercury Records, saw her recover the rights to her own songs, but the ordeal proved so bitter that she vowed never to sign again.

Instead, the emphasis is on playing live, and a relaxed and diverse set opened with Anchorage as Fiachna O' Braonain, the slightly batty guitarist from Hothouse Flowers, addressed the strings with such delicacy that you could hear every note resound. This versatility was matched throughout by the extraordinary range of Shocked's voice: from country drawl to bluesy slur, and spoken word to gospel grandiosity.

Hopping from foot to foot like a mischievous elf, Michele Gazich provided quirky accompaniment on the electric fiddle. This former orchestra member from Turin worked up a rapport with Shocked, mimicking the nuances of her voice with clever effect.

With Richard Armstrong adding bass, vocals, and a sleazy muted trumpet, the band were in full swing for If Love Was a Train. A simple arrangement built up in intensity as a metallic guitar and choppy violin led to a middle-eight for which the band turned their backs on the audience and, well, wiggled. Suffice to say, Shocked's slow, rhythmic hip sway was the most convincing.

Taking requests, the sultry, long-haired singer led us through Blackberry Blossom and Secret to a Long Life, her every head-shake, smirk and aside adding theatre along the way. She may have been a fighter once but she's a true entertainer now.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: CBI and TUC appeal for steady interest rate

fields.headline: CBI and TUC appeal for steady interest rate
fields.standfirst:
Manufacturing is 'fragile'

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Industry leaders and trade unionists today call on the Bank of England to keep rates steady, saying that the economy is slowing down fast enough to keep inflation at the government's 2.5% target.
fields.body:
Industry leaders and trade unionists today call on the Bank of England to keep rates steady, saying that the economy is slowing down fast enough to keep inflation at the government's 2.5% target.

Their plea to maintain rates at 6% for the sixth month in a row came as new figures showed a modest recovery for high street retailers last month, after a bad performance in June.

The Confederation of British Industry reported that 47% of the retailers it polled reported higher sales last month, while 23% reported falls, giving a positive balance of 24% - an improvement on the balance of 15% recorded in June.

Underlying growth is slowing down, according to the three month on three month average, which smooths out erratic monthly movements. Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser, said: "The latest survey strengthens our view that the MPC should leave interest rates on hold."

The Trades Union Congress said the Bank's monetary policy committee should consider the fragile state of the manufacturing sector.

"Manufacturers trying hard to stay afloat will be keen for interest rates to stay the same for another month," said Brendan Barber, TUC deputy general secretary.

The majority of economists - 25 out of 33 polled by Reuters last week - see rates staying on hold when the decision is announced at midday today.

Analysts said the recovery in July sales was no surprise after the dip in the June figures.

"After the near euphoria of May and the gloom of June, we have a near normal survey," said Geoffrey Dicks, UK econ omist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. "This does not stop the CBI from making its ritual request for unchanged rates. What they ignore is that price stability or even deflation, is needed on the high street to offset higher inflation in the services sector if we are to keep overall inflation at target."

Some analysts said yesterday's figures suggested the slowdown was not yet sharp enough.

Michael Saunders of Schroders Salomon Smith Barney said: "Consumer spending is not slowing enough. We are still looking for a hike. At some point they'll have to raise rates." He added however that this did not necessarily need to take place this month.

Since the MPC last met, official figures showing a sharp increase in growth in the second quarter have strengthened the case of those on the MPC calling for another rate rise.

However, wage inflation has eased and the housing market appears to have slowed down, which will boost the case for MPC members, who believe inflation is already under control.

webTitle: Notebook: MPC setting the cost of borrowing

fields.headline: MPC's hawks may fly high
fields.standfirst:
Do not rule out a rise in rates

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite the stated aim of making monetary policy boring and predictable, Bank of England deputy governor Mervyn King and his colleagues on the monetary policy committee have a habit of taking the markets by surprise when it comes to setting the cost of borrowing.
fields.body:
Despite the stated aim of making monetary policy boring and predictable, Bank of England deputy governor Mervyn King and his colleagues on the monetary policy committee have a habit of taking the markets by surprise when it comes to setting the cost of borrowing.

They did so last September when the current cycle of rising interest rates began and in late 1998 and early 1999, when the speed and the extent of rate reductions designed to ward off Asian financial flu caught people off guard. Today's meeting of the committee could be another occasion when the City consensus proves to be a display of complacency.

The arguments for no change outnumber those in favour of an increase in borrowing costs. Since the last meeting, in July, average earnings growth has dropped to 4%, sterling has appreciated by 2%, core retail price inflation remains stable at well below the target, the main quarterly business surveys point to slower growth ahead and the government's spending review did no more than deliver the scale of increases promised in the Budget in March.

This adds up to a powerful case for continuing to do nothing for the sixth month in a row. It might even embolden the more dovish members of the committee - notably DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani - to begin pressing the case for lower interest rates.

However, against the deflationary forces at work there is one potentially inflationary factor that might outweigh them all: unexpectedly strong growth in the second quarter. The projection in the MPC's May inflation report assumed a GDP increase of 0.7%, against an actual 0.9%. The stronger than expected outcome could be enough to persuade the committee's waverers of the past few months, led by the governor, Sir Eddie George, to side with the hawks - Mr King, John Vickers and Steve Nickell - who are all concerned about the underlying resilience of consumer demand. Such a shift of the middle ground on the nine-member committee would secure a clear majority for higher rates.

True, both the first and second quarter GDP figures were distorted by erratic energy output which, if stripped out, convey a much more stable picture of growth. But in the past whenever the first estimate of GDP has recorded growth at an annualised rate of more than 3% (in the second quarter of this year it was 3.6%), the MPC has always raised interest rates at the first opportunity as insurance against overheating.

While the MPC could easily decide to wait another month or two for more data about how the economy is performing, it is equally true that if a majority on the committee is convinced further rate rises will be needed at some point to restrain growth, a move to higher borrowing costs now might ensure the peak in rates is much lower than it might otherwise be.

Slow service

It is high time that somebody took the shadow strategic rail authority to task for abrogating its responsibilities to passengers. Today's welcome report by the national audit office is the first serious study of the ineffectiveness of the SSRA, Labour's son of British Rail, which has been struggling for life since Tony Blair was elected.

The SSRA, which should finally be given teeth in the government's transport legislation this autumn, is not the body it has been cracked up to be.

To be fair, it is supposed to be the highly active offspring of an unwanted creature of the last government, the rail franchise regulator.This was the unfortunate body given the difficult task of shelling out franchises as quickly as possible to anybody who asked, without bothering to ensure passengers were properly protected.

The SSRA says it will be tougher and more demanding, but there are few signs yet that it is happy with its new mantle, and the NAO's report quite rightly suggests new methods to make it more passenger friendly.

The SSRA's current problem is its deafening silence on strategy. It has been an entity for almost 18 months, but of a strategy for an industry which is experiencing the biggest boom since the end of the second world war there is no sight or sound.

The NAO report does not mention this, but the SSRA has approached its task the wrong way round. Instead of producing a panacea for the railways, by acting as the lead organisation, it has simply asked the rail companies to come forward with new bids.

It has hidden behind the excuse that it could not produce a strategy until the government had issued its 10-year transport plan, When this came late last month, it wielded such a broad brush on money and policy that it could not seriously have influenced the SSRA's thinking.

We will not see the fruit of the SSRA's labours until the autumn, which leaves the train companies as confused as the passengers.

The stronger than expected outcome could be enough to persuade the committee's waverers of the past few months, led by the governor, Sir Eddie George, to side with the hawks - Mr King, John Vickers and Steve Nickell - who are all concerned about the underlying resilience of consumer demand. Such a shift of the middle ground on the nine-member committee would secure a clear majority for higher rates. True, both the first and second quarter GDP figures were distorted by erratic energy output which, if stripped out, convey a much more stable picture of growth. But in the past whenever the first estimate of GDP has recorded growth at an annualised rate of more than 3% (in the second quarter of this year it was 3.6%), the MPC has always raised interest rates at the first opportunity as insurance against overheating. While the MPC could easily decide to wait another month or two for more data about how the economy is performing, it is equally true that if a majority on the committee is convinced further rate rises will be needed at some point to restrain growth, a move to higher borrowing costs now might ensure the peak in rates is much lower than it might otherwise be. Slow service It is high time that somebody took the shadow strategic rail authority to task for abrogating its responsibilities to passengers. Today's welcome report by the national audit office is the first serious study of the ineffectiveness of the SSRA, Labour's son of British Rail, which has been struggling for life since Tony Blair was elected. The SSRA, which should finally be given teeth in the government's transport legislation this autumn, is not the body it has been cracked up to be. To be fair, it is supposed to be the highly active offspring of an unwanted creature of the last government, the rail franchise regulator.This was the unfortunate body given the difficult task of shelling out franchises as quickly as possible to anybody who asked, without bothering to ensure passengers were properly protected. The SSRA says it will be tougher and more demanding, but there are few signs yet that it is happy with its new mantle, and the NAO's report quite rightly suggests new methods to make it more passenger friendly. The SSRA's current problem is its deafening silence on strategy. It has been an entity for almost 18 months, but of a strategy for an industry which is experiencing the biggest boom since the end of the second world war there is no sight or sound. The NAO report does not mention this, but the SSRA has approached its task the wrong way round. Instead of producing a panacea for the railways, by acting as the lead organisation, it has simply asked the rail companies to come forward with new bids. It has hidden behind the excuse that it could not produce a strategy until the government had issued its 10-year transport plan, When this came late last month, it wielded such a broad brush on money and policy that it could not seriously have influenced the SSRA's thinking. We will not see the fruit of the SSRA's labours until the autumn, which leaves the train companies as confused as the passengers.

webTitle: Woolwich leaves door open to merger talks

fields.headline: Woolwich leaves door open to merger talks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Woolwich yesterday kept a door open to merger talks and challenged rivals to match its disclosure about customers' take-up of new products.
fields.body:
Woolwich yesterday kept a door open to merger talks and challenged rivals to match its disclosure about customers' take-up of new products.

The former building society claimed that the 290,000 customers of its flexible current account-cum-mortgage product Open Plan between them had 750,000 Woolwich products. About 110,000 of those customers are new to the bank.

Such cross-selling is the aim of many banks and John Stewart, the chief executive, claimed the figures showed the bank was "delivering".

"We're putting customers on. Will other banks give the same information about customers?" Mr Stewart said.

The £30m development costs of Open Plan, whose products will compete with those planned by Halifax's Intelligent Finance, were yesterday cited as the reason for the 8% fall in Woolwich's pre-tax profits to £232m.

Mr Stewart dismissed recent safety scares about the security of net banking, provoked by breaches at Barclays. He said the issue was not deterring customers for the internet, telephone, branch and Wap phone service.

Presenting its profits figures for the first six months of the year, the bank produced breakdowns which showed that Open Plan customers held 3.7 Woolwich products each, mostly savings accounts but also mortgages, loans, credit cards and life insurance.

It also claimed to be taking a 36% share of all mortgage applications for its new product Open Plan Offset which allows customers to offset their mortgage costs against current account and savings balances.

Mr Stewart said that while the bank was "probably even more confident about going on [independently]" he was aware of many City analysts' comments that while they believe its strategy was sound they harbour reservations about the size of the bank.

"There's no point being silly about it [speculation over mergers]," Mr Stewart said. But he made it clear that the bank felt under no pressure to do a deal, while agreeing "there's a place for consolidation".

The bank, which is protected against hostile takeovers for another two years, floated on the stock market three years ago at 368.5p and like many of its peers is now struggling with its share price which yesterday closed at 257p, up 6.5p.

Mr Stewart said he felt protected by the fact that Woolwich's shares were trading at a premium to other mortgage banks. The bank will pay a 4.4p interim dividend.

webTitle: Pop review: Tom McRae.

fields.headline: The second coming
fields.standfirst:
Tom McRae
12 Bar Club, London ****
fields.trailText:
Tom McRae
12 Bar Club, London ****
fields.body:
Judging by the praise already given to Tom McRae, a young singer-songwriter who has yet to release a single, we are about to witness the second coming. He has been compared to Bob Dylan, Nick Drake and just about anyone else who ever held a guitar. The only thing McRae hasn't been allowed to be is himself.

Until tonight. Alone on a tiny stage surrounded by intrigued faces, McRea is surprisingly confident. As he begins Bloodless and his soaring vocals reach the roof, you can feel the crowd start to breathe again in the sweltering heat. McRae has a beautiful voice that acquires a raw but controlled power live. Gentle and fragile in recordings, it is blistering tonight. And while You Cut Her Hair and Boy With the Bubblegum are tender, there's no mistaking a sense of rage. It's as though McRae needs to channel his frustration through songs to swoon, to or else he'd just scream. With the voice of an angel, he sings, "If words could kill, it would spell out your name", and you believe him.

The songs are romantic but realistic. While in a laid-back, folk tradition, they have no Richard Thompson-type stylings. References to high-rises and cocaine set McRae firmly in the present. And he isn't precious about his talent. He's an odd mix of lad and artist, joking with the sold-out crowd before tearing open our hearts. "Thanks for coming down," he says, "those of you that could get in." He pauses. "I've always wanted to say that."

At Ronnie Scott's, Birmingham (0121-643 4525), tomorrow, and touring. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Three directors go after brokerage finds lapses

fields.headline: Three directors go after brokerage finds lapses
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Three directors have abruptly left Capel Cure Sharp, one of Britain's biggest private client stockbroking firms, after the discovery of long-standing lapses in accounting procedures.
fields.body:
Three directors have abruptly left Capel Cure Sharp, one of Britain's biggest private client stockbroking firms, after the discovery of long-standing lapses in accounting procedures.

The three include development director Mike Jones, a high-profile figure in the City who recently became chairman of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers.

Capel Cure Sharp said Mr Jones, 57, "retired" on Tuesday, while finance director Chris Blatchly and compliance director Chris Kingston "resigned". The firm said all three left in connection with the irregularities.

The company refused to give details of the problem although there were suggestions in the City that it related to reports to the regulator, the financial services authority.

A bank account containing the company's money was not balancing properly, perhaps by only small amounts, and this was not noted in regular reports to the regulator.

This situation continued through much of 1999, but there is no suggestion that there were any attempts at personal gain. Insiders said the departing directors had accepted responsibility for the lapses, although none of the three was available for comment.

An investigation into the irregularities is continuing, but insiders said that further action was unlikely.

Mr Jones, who was managing director of Capel Cure Sharp until recently, has been working in the City since 1959. He is a fellow of the Securities Institute and has served on the Bank of England's steering committee overseeing Crest, the automated trading system.

His departure was greeted with shock among colleagues. Angela Knight, chief executive of the Association of Private Client Stockbrokers, said: "I was surprised, obviously. Mike's knowledge is widely respected in the financial community. He is a man for whom people have both respect and affection."

He will have to resign as chairman of the trade body, which requires officers to be board-level directors of investment firms.

Capel Cure Sharp is owned by the South African group Old Mutual.

webTitle: Pop review: The Jayhawks

fields.headline: Scintillating moments
fields.standfirst:
The Jayhawks
Shepherds Bush Empire, London***
fields.trailText:
The Jayhawks
Shepherds Bush Empire, London***
fields.body:
Although easily pigeonholed under "country rock", the Jayhawks have a few more weapons in their armoury than that. Lurking behind their easy-rolling exterior is a passion for grandiose pop and enormous ballads with weepy, diaphanous choruses. A Break in the Clouds, for instance, is a dead ringer for the Hollies in their Air That I Breathe phase, with its singing guitars and high, soaring harmonies. Confusingly, the song's title bears no relation to its signature line, "It's like cool cool water running down my back". In Better Than Being Alone, the band concoct a perfect pop and country crossover with whipped cream on top.

The Jayhawks' singer, guitarist and chief songwriter, Gary Louris, took the stage in a brilliant white shirt and matching trousers. Combined with his frizzy hair and steel-framed glasses, it made him look like a showbiz preacher from Las Vegas, keen to convert his flock by laying on the healing powers of vintage pop music, perhaps with a perm and manicure on the side. Around him, the band offered sympathetic support, with drummer Tim O'Reagan making occasional forays on lead vocal (notably on a twanged-up version of the venerable Tom Rush tune, Driving Wheel), and Jen Gunderman adding layers of sweeping string-synth or clanging piano as the occasion requires.

Still, while the Jayhawks usually make an agreeable noise, they are prone to lapsing into fallow periods of nondescript off-the-peg rockism. Particularly damaging is their habit of falling back into a lazy pastiche of Crazy Horse while Louris reels off swaths of characterless guitar soloing (there is an unbridgeable gulf between being able to play the guitar and doing something interesting with it). Somehow, the thump-and-plod beat that Crazy Horse have perfected doesn't work for anybody else, probably because they have the incalculable advantages of Neil Young's songs and Neil Young on lead guitar.

So, while the Jayhawks can scintillate intermittently, ultimately they struggle to find a voice they can call their own. "I'm gonna be a big star someday," wailed Louris, as the set charged to its climax. Not just at the moment, I don't think.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Standard Chartered cuts staff by 6,000

fields.headline: Standard Chartered cuts staff by 6,000
fields.standfirst: Shares fall 10% despite rise in profits
fields.trailText: More than 6,000 jobs around the world are to be axed by Standard Chartered under a plan for "radical" restructuring of the emerging markets bank which will cost £480m.
fields.body:
More than 6,000 jobs around the world are to be axed by Standard Chartered under a plan for "radical" restructuring of the emerging markets bank which will cost £480m.

The size of the restructuring charge, which is to be spread over three years, shocked the the stock market where its shares fell 10% to £8.52.

Speaking as the bank reported a 31% rise in first-half pre-tax profits to £356m, Rana Talwar, chief executive, said the market's surprise at the size of the charge was good news because it showed the radical nature of the restructuring.

The bank intends to reduce all its processing centres in the 50 countries around the world in which its operates into "two or three hubs".

The aim, Mr Talwar said, was change the bank from a relatively old-fashioned one to an efficient and well managed one. The restructuring is expected to produce cost savings of £71m next year and £170m each year from 2003.

After a turbulent period during the Asian economic crisis in 1997 and 1998, Standard Chartered yesterday said the rise in profits reflected the improving economic environment in which was now operating.

It provisions against bad and doubtful debtors fell - although not by as much as the City would have liked - by 32% to £164m and Sir Patrick Gillam, Standard Chartered's chairman, said he saw scope for additional releases in the future.

While provisions for bad debts have fallen in most of the countries in which its operates, the bank has set aside an extra £22m for Africa as a result of the "deteriorating economic and political situation in Zimbabwe" where Robert Mugabe's government is pledging to resettle black families into white-owned farms.

The bank has spent more than £1.7bn on a number of acquisitions during the year, most recently of Grindlays which boosts its position in the Middle East and south Asia, particularly in India.

It remains on the look out for acquisitions, particularly in Taiwan, but does not intended to seek out another major deal in Indonesia to replace the ill-fated attempt to buy Bank Bali last year which led to local protests.

The core of the bank's business is in Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia. It has a relatively small operation in Britain - which will shrink further when it sells its Chartered Trust leasing business.

The leasing operation, which was put up for sale in May, had, according to Sir Patrick, received a number of interesting offers and the bank anticipated making an announcement about the sale in the next four to six weeks.

Without Chartered Trust, the bank employs approximately 2,000 people in Britain, many of whom are expected to be spared during the job cuts over the coming three years.

Some of the job cuts can be expected as a result of the integration of Grindlays with existing Standard Chartered operations but the bank was not specific about other regions in which the cuts would be made to its 33,000 workforce.

With the bulk of its business outside Britain despite being headquartered and listed in London, it is considering reporting its results in US dollars, a move already adopted by HSBC, the other London-based bank with a vast international operation. The bank's shareholders gave it approval for the move at its annual meeting this year.

One leading banking analyst said the bank's shares had been unnerved by the scale of the provisions and the fact that in comparison with HSBC the reduction its provisions against bad debt was not as great.

It announced a 10% rise in dividend to 7.425p.

webTitle: Link pensions to pay, say MPs

fields.headline: Link pensions to pay, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday backed calls for the basic state pension to be raised in line with earnings, not merely with prices, and argued that single pensioners should get at least £90 a week.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday backed calls for the basic state pension to be raised in line with earnings, not merely with prices, and argued that single pensioners should get at least £90 a week.

Pension lobbyists like Help the Aged and Age Concern applauded the stance taken by the social security select committee, chaired by the Liberal Democrat, Archy Kirkwood.

At the moment, single pensioners get a minimum income guarantee (MIG) of £78.45.

But the cross-party committee went some way to meeting the much-criticised approach of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and Alistair Darling, the social security secretary. They are targeting extra help on the most needy, despite the flak they have taken.

"The government should raise the level of retirement pension for those aged 80, so that it is, and remains, at the equivalent level of the minimum income guarantee," the MPs said.

They noted that "the oldest look set to remain among the poorest, and particularly the oldest women".

But they implicitly rejected Mr Brown's insistence that the basic, non-means-tested pension rise by only the inflation rate.

The 75p rise which resulted in April prompted widespread anger among pensioners, many of whom regard the pension as a right for which their taxes have paid - and see the MIG top-up as charity.

Ministers are struggling to persuade 500,000 eligible pensioners to claim MIG (a campaign the committee endorsed) and are devising a tax credit for pensioners to help those with some savings which take them a little above the MIG level.

It is a sore point among those who have tried to provide for themselves.

The MPs' inquiry concluded that raising the basic state pension is "inevitable" and should be done "sooner rather than later".

It is affordable, the MPs in sist. They also called for more research, not least on ethnic poverty in old age.

The committee argued: "Moreover, if it is right for the minimum income guarantee (MIG) to be linked to earnings, so too must both components of the state pension, if we wish pensioners to share equally in the rising prosperity of the nation."

With an election looming and "grey power" on the march, the MPs may now be pushing an open door.

Mr Darling's deputy, Jeff Rooker, who had admitted in evidence to the committee that he could not live on £78.45, said that the committee had been "quite right" to tackle the issue. He promised a response before November. It could come at Labour's party conference in October where pensions will be a hot issue for unions like the GMB which backed off a confrontation in return for promises of action by Mr Brown.

"It looks as though they [the MPs] have taken on the reality of looking at pensioner incomes in total and not hanging everything on the basic state pension," said Mr Rooker.

Ministers have spent £6.5bn since 1997, £2bn more on pensions than would have been the case if they had simply restored the earnings link. But they have been given little political credit.

The average pensioner income is £132 per week, includ ing occupational, private and state pensions.

Mr Brown's enhanced winter fuel payments of £150 will increase pensions by £3 a week for 10m pensioners, though it is not means tested and will go to dukes as well as retired dustmen. The free television licence for over-75s is also universal.

Backed by Labour MPs on his committee yesterday, Mr Kirkwood said: "We are nailing our colours to the mast.

"We are saying to the government, if they don't think £90 is modest, they should work out what the figure should be. That should be the target and it should be achieved in the minimum time possible."

The free television licence for over-75s is also universal. Backed by Labour MPs on his committee yesterday, Mr Kirkwood said: "We are nailing our colours to the mast. "We are saying to the government, if they don't think £90 is modest, they should work out what the figure should be. That should be the target and it should be achieved in the minimum time possible."

webTitle: Proms review: Royal Philarmonic Orchestra/Daniele Gatti

fields.headline: Rhythm and romance
fields.standfirst:
Royal Philharmonic Orchestra/Gatti
Royal Albert Hall, London****
fields.trailText:
Royal Philharmonic Orchestra/Gatti
Royal Albert Hall, London****
fields.body:
Since being appointed music director in 1996, Daniele Gatti has turned the once lacklustre RPO into a force to be reckoned with. Their Prom found them on blistering form in a programme of Prokofiev and Shostakovich, which proved a riveting evening despite the occasional idiosyncrasy. The final item consisted of extracts from Romeo and Juliet - a conflation, in fact, of the first two orchestral suites which Prokofiev prepared before the ballet's 1940 premiere. Gatti fuses the various movements into a narrative whole, which might displease some purists, but which makes compelling listening. The rich, sensual RPO sound and Gatti's fondness for extreme dynamics and tempi are telling in this music. The lovers' passion is kindled into tremulous life in the ballroom scene before Gatti plunges into an account of the balcony pas de deux which is flagrantly erotic, almost brutally sexual. Around them swirls the sectarian violence, which Gatti infuses with thrilling terror.

The whole grabs you from start to finish despite the occasional flaw. Tybalt's death is taken at such a lick that the players occasionally seem hard pressed to get all the notes in. The famous Montagues and Capulets sequence came unstuck balance-wise in places with the brass and percussion occasionally drowning out the strings. A similar weight pervaded the Classical Symphony, which came over as anything but the usual volatile jeu d'esprit. Gatti favours slower tempi than most conductors and fills the symphony with a nostalgic sweetness, only allowing irony to punctuate the gavotte, a quiet reminder, perhaps, that the work dates from 1917, when revolution was in the air and the classical world was about to vanish for good.

In between came Shostakovich's great, controversial First Violin Concerto with the glorious, glamorous Vedim Repin as soloist. It ranks among the most bitter of Shostakovich's outpourings during the Stalinist years, a strange, unique entanglement of threnody, rage and grotesque bravado. The demands it makes on the soloist are formidable. Repin, who has made the work his own of late, is superb throughout, whether conveying the morose stillness of the central passacaglia, mourning lyrically in the opening nocturne or swirling through the scherzo with almost demonic fury. During the awesome cadenza, the audience held its breath and you could have heard the proverbial pin drop. Gatti's conducting is dark, febrile and tense throughout. He isn't well known as a Shostakovich interpreter. After this, he should be.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: ICL scraps float plan

fields.headline: ICL scraps float plan
fields.standfirst:
Chief executive quits after Fujitsu takes fright at decline of investor confidence
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The backlash against internet and hi-tech stocks claimed another high profile victim yesterday when the Japanese electronics group Fujitsu abandoned plans for the £5bn stock market flotation of its British subsidiary ICL.
fields.body:
The backlash against internet and hi-tech stocks claimed another high profile victim yesterday when the Japanese electronics group Fujitsu abandoned plans for the £5bn stock market flotation of its British subsidiary ICL.

Keith Todd, ICL's chief executive, has resigned after insisting for the past two years that the business would refloat in 2000 come what may.

Mr Todd ended a 13-year association with the company on Friday by clearing his desk after the Fujitsu-dominated ICL board decided to postpone the flotation "indefinitely".

"In the light of Keith Todd's close identification with the flotation of ICL, he had tendered his resignation as chief executive," a statement from ICL said.

ICL would have been one of the stock market's largest listed technology companies but now finds itself placed amid a growing band of hi-tech businesses suffering as a result of the sharp turn in investors' sentiment.

As recently as May Mr Todd was maintaining that the flotation of ICL would go ahead and that "substantive" businesses would not be affected by the market correction.

A statement from Fujitsu said the decision to suspend the flotation indefinitely had been taken "in the light of current difficult trading conditions in the IT industry and the company's financial performance".

It is thought that ICL insiders have been disappointed by the relatively static revenue growth and widening losses, despite a reduction in staff numbers.

The planned summer flotations of two subsidiary businesses have also been delayed, while the IT services sector has been hit by a wave of profit warnings.

A Y2K-related slowdown in business had taken longer than anticipated to recede, a spokesman added.

"The board felt that a flotation would be a distraction from the more important task at hand of building sustained growth and' profitability." UBS Warburg was ready to underwrite the issue in the fourth quarter of this year.

ICL in April announced costly plans to transform the company into one focused on e-business - just a month after the sea change in attitudes to the internet.

The plans involved ICL altering the focus of its core business from the manufacture of computers and hard ware, and retraining its entire 22,000 strong workforce in e-business skills.

Despite yesterday's setback ICL said it was still considering the £1bn flotation of its Nordic company ICL Invia on the Helsinki exchange. It might also still seek a listing in London for Knowledgepool, its e-learning business.

Analysts believe ICL could now be forced to mount a radical disposal programme to unlock "hidden value" and give individual divisions greater autonomy.

"We hope that Fujitsu will belatedly realise this," said Richard Holway of Holway Research. "If they retain the status quo - as they have done for so many years - they will just preside over a slowly dying offspring. Surely no parent wants to see that?" Guardian IT and Technology plc have already been successfully spun-out of ICL.

Mr Todd is temporarily replaced in his £600,000 a year job by Richard Christou, commercial and legal affairs director.

ICL said the search for a full-time replacement was under way. Mr Todd was promoted from finance director to chief executive five years ago when then chief executive Peter Bonfield was poached to take the top job at BT.

13 years disappear with one keystroke

Keith Todd may have found it a tough task transforming ICL from lumbering computer hardware manufacturer into nimble e-business group but some things have got faster within one of Britain's largest technology companies.

By lunchtime yesterday Mr Todd's 13 years of service with the group had been consigned to history and the management team section on ICL's lavish corporate website made no reference to him.

Mr Todd, an accountant by training, began his career with the Royal Ordnance Factories.

He joined ICL as finance director in August 1987, having held a similar position at Marconi. Before that Mr Todd spent five years as chief financial officer of Cincinnati Electronics in the US.

When Peter Bonfield left ICL in 1995 to become chief executive of BT, Mr Todd stepped up to take the top job.

One of the tasks that has tested Mr Todd most is the on-off £1bn Horizon project to install touch-screen computer technology in 19,000 Post Office outlets nationwide. It has been hampered by the government changing its mind about what kind of system is wanted. It is due for completion in spring 2001, giving the Post Office Europe's largest secure retail/banking computer network.

Since 1998 the well-liked boss has been promising that ICL would be floated on the stock exchange by the end of 2000.

When parent company Fujitsu decided that ICL was not ready to float it was inevitable that Mr Todd would go.

He will also resign from the board of lottery operator Camelot Group, where he is ICL's representative.

 Foundering fortunes

Oversold dot.com companies that failed to take off:

March:

Shares in Lastminute.com plummet after arguably the most hyped flotation the stock market had witnessed. Critics pointed out that it generated turnover from commissions of £190,000 -and was at one stage valued at £1bn. The sell off of technology stocks begins, triggered by nervousness on Wall Street.

April:

Nina Brink, chair of pan-European internet group World Online resigns after it emerged she sold a large part of her holding before the company's flotation, causing the shares to plunge shortly after. The technology sell off gathers pace.

May:

Fashion retailer Boo.com becomes the highest profile casualty so far when it collapses after eating up £80m of its investors' money.

June:

Filmgroup, an internet-based video on demand company, pulls its flotation at the 11th hour.

Amazon.com shares lose more than 20% of their value in a single day as Wall Street analysts issue doubts about its long-term prospects.

July:

Natural health website Clickmango closes. Letsbuyit.com joins the market but at the third attempt and with a valuation of £300m instead of the £1bn first mooted.

Rupert Murdoch's News International disbands its new media division.

webTitle: Dot.gone

fields.headline: Dot.gone
fields.trailText: 3 August: When an short-lived internet company is taken over are you entitled to a full redundancy package?
fields.body:
The problem

When the internet company I worked for were bought out I was told to tender my resignation or face the sack for under performance.

I had completed my three month probationary period so could you tell me what my rights are. This happened to four of my work mates, even though one turned over half a million in one deal.

The solution

Unfortunately, I don't believe you have many rights - not because the company was taken over, but because you have only worked there for three months. It is very difficult to bring a claim of unfair dismissal after such a short time. However, your firm is obliged to give you one week's notice.

Having said that, I don't know all the details and I thus suggest that it is worth taking legal advice. For instance, there are several instances (such as reasons connected with discrimination) whereby dismissal is automatically unfair, even though you have been there for under a year. Your local ACAS public enquiry point (in the phone book) will be able to advise further.

Unfortunately, there is very little you can do to stop this happening again. If you joined a union, then they could help bring pressure on a company that acts like this, and could also offer you legal advice. However, you cannot join a union now and expect help with a pre-existing problem.

My advice is to put this one down to experience and go and find a job with a firm that deserves you.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Chilean court fails to decide whether Pinochet should stand trial

fields.headline: Chilean court fails to decide whether Pinochet should stand trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Chile's Supreme Court said Tuesday that it postponed making a decision on whether to strip General Augusto  Pinochet of his immunity, clearing the way for him to stand trial on human rights charges.
fields.body:
Chile's Supreme Court said Tuesday that it postponed making a decision on whether to strip General Augusto Pinochet of his immunity, clearing the way for him to stand trial on human rights charges.

But the Chilean media reported later that the justices had agreed to rule against Pinochet but decided not to announce their verdict until later. After meeting behind closed doors for nearly four hours, the 20 justices put off a final decision until at least next week. No date was set for a new session, said court secretary Carlos Meneses.

"We have made progress but it was not possible to make a decision," said Justice Guillermo Navas.

But several radio stations and a local Internet newspaper, El Mostrador, quoted anonymous court sources as saying that the justices voted 11-9 against Pinochet but decided not to make an announcement until the legal text of the ruling was written.

The Pinochet side was invigorated by the apparent division among the justices, said Ricardo Rivadeneira, the former dictator's attorney.

"We have waited for justice for 26 years. We can wait yet another week," said Viviana Diaz, president of an organization of relatives of dissidents who disappeared after being arrested by Pinochet's secret police.

The justices' meeting prompted small but noisy groups of pro- and anti-Pinochet demonstrators to gather outside the courthouse, exchanging insults across the street where police had blocked traffic.

At one point, several anti-Pinochet demonstrators dressed in black lay on the ground on a nearby street, blocking traffic.

The pro-Pinochet demonstrators burned a Spanish flag. A Spanish judge, Baltasar Garzon, issued the warrant that kept Pinochet under house arrest in London for 16 months until last March. He was released after British doctors said he was mentally and physically unfit to stand trial.

Even if the Supreme Court decides to lift Pinochet's immunity, it remains unclear whether the ailing general who still so dramatically divides Chilean society would ever face trial.

Pinochet faces 153 criminal complaints and judge Juan Guzman is seeking his trial in one of them, the so-called "caravan of death", a military squad that summarily executed 72 political prisoners in several cities shortly after Pinochet's bloody 1973 coup.

Even if the court rules against Pinochet, plaintiffs' lawyer Hugo Gutierrez said he was not sure if he would immediately seek an indictment. Gutierrez and other anti-Pinochet lawyers and activists have said it would satisfy them just to see Pinochet stripped of immunity.

webTitle: Weah and Wanchope join Royle family

fields.headline: Weah and Wanchope join Royle family
fields.trailText: Manchester City signalled their intention to re-establish themselves among England's leading clubs yesterday by signing the former world player of the year George Weah and agreeing a £4.5m deal with West Ham United for Paulo Wanchope.
fields.body:
Manchester City signalled their intention to re-establish themselves among England's leading clubs yesterday by signing the former world player of the year George Weah and agreeing a £4.5m deal with West Ham United for Paulo Wanchope.

Just as City's supporters were showing the first signs of edginess about the club's lack of summer business, their manager Joe Royle re-invigorated the feelgood factor from winning successive promotions by finalising an audacious deal that will make Weah the highest-paid player in the club's history.

After being released by Milan at the end of last week and failing to broker a transfer to Roma, the 33-year-old Liberian international striker flew into Manchester yesterday to negotiate a two-year contract worth around £30,000 a week - about three times as much as City's other top earners.

"This is a great club with a good history," said Weah. "With the mentality they showed in the First Division last season I'm sure we can do well in the Premiership.

"I had other options but this club really appealed to me. They made it obvious they wanted me and did everything they could to get me. Now I will do everything I can to try to help us into Europe. I have got plenty left and I want the world to know what I am capable of.

"From my time at Chelsea I know how much they love the game in England and I know that this club has great fans. Together I'm sure we can be a success."

Royle has been looking to bolster his attacking options all summer and the arrival of a player of Weah's standing is further evidence that City's ambitions lie beyond consolidating their status in the top division.

"With no disrespect to Fulham, a player with George's curriculum vitae should be displaying his talents in the Premiership," said Royle.

"Two years with Paris St-Germain and seven with AC Milan speaks for itself and he proved to everyone during his spell at Chelsea last season that he still has a lot to offer at the highest level. He is as fit as he has ever been and he will be a wonderful acquisition for this club over the next two years."

Royle confidently expects to follow up arguably the biggest signing in City's history by concluding a deal for Wanchope within the next 48 hours and is still optimistic of luring Ugo Ehiogu to Maine Road after lodging a £7m bid with Aston Villa.

Wanchope, 24, has been made surplus to requirements at West Ham after a turbulent year in which he scored 17 goals but was repeatedly barracked by the club's supporters.

"Paulo was idolised at Derby but for some reason never built up the same rapport with West Ham's fans," said Royle. "I find that difficult to understand because he scored a lot of goals and is capable of moments of brilliance.

"We have had a bid accepted and I want to get the deal wrapped up as soon as possible because I know that Bradford City and Celtic are waiting in the wings."

Bradford, however, do not possess the financial clout to compete in a bidding war and have turned their attentions to luring Middlesbrough's striker Brian Deane to Valley Parade.

webTitle: Villa gain Ginola but post a loss

fields.headline: Villa gain Ginola but post a loss
fields.trailText: Aston Villa yesterday suggested they intend to spend their way out of a financial hole by unveiling their new signings David Ginola and Alpay Ozalan within hours of reporting a £4.8m loss on last season. The deficit represents an astonishing £25m turnaround in financial fortunes as it follows a £20m profit the previous year.
fields.body:
Aston Villa yesterday suggested they intend to spend their way out of a financial hole by unveiling their new signings David Ginola and Alpay Ozalan within hours of reporting a £4.8m loss on last season. The deficit represents an astonishing £25m turnaround in financial fortunes as it follows a £20m profit the previous year.

Doug Ellis, the chairman and major shareholder, blames escalating players' wages and falling attendances: the wage bill rose by 24% to £21.6m and average Premiership gates fell 5,000.

"Even the most successful club in Europe at present has stated it is unable to meet the demands in respect of some players' salaries and transfer fees," Ellis said.

Nevertheless that has not prevented Villa from paying £5.5m for the Turkey defender Alpay and handing Tottenham a £3m cheque for the 33-year-old Frenchman.

The outlay almost matches the club's assets of £8m in the accounts but Ginola's reported £30,000-a-week wage packet will only serve to inflate the salary bill.

But judging by the number of claret-and-blue shirts bearing Ginola's name and the famous No14 being worn by many of the 500-plus crowd who turned up to welcome him to Villa Park, the club shop is already feeling the benefit of his signing.

For the manager John Gregory, though, that is not the point of the exercise.

"David Ginola is here not to put bums on seats or sell a few extra shirts in the club shop," he said. "He's here to play in the team and be a big influence on it. I realised before the Cup final that the side lacked a little bit of flair and having someone who can win us a game on his own. Our performance at Wembley only confirmed it and that's what Ginola is here for."

Paying £3m for a 33-year-old does not worry Gregory. "It's not like 10 to 15 years ago when players reached the end of the road when they turned 30," he said. "They look after themselves a lot better today than they ever did. And not only has David Ginola looked after himself, he also brings a wealth of experience."

The signing ends a summer-long quest for Gregory, which, according to Ginola, is a triumph for his new manager's persistence. "A day did not go by in the summer when John Gregory failed to phone my agent and ask 'Is he going to sign?'," he said. "That made me feel very wanted. So did the fact that Villa were the only club willing to pay Tottenham the fee they wanted. I've worn the No14 shirt at both Newcastle and Tottenham and John said he'd kept it free for me at Villa. So that was nice."

Though the club's coffers are set to receive a boost from the sale of those shirts, the Aston Villa Independent Shareholders' Association has called for shareholders to vote against the announced dividend of 8.8p a share. That includes Ellis, whose near-4m shareholding would earn enough to pay Ginola for 11 weeks.

"We are the world champions for grooming young players for other European clubs, and I regret the pillaging of kids from the French youth system," said the Toulouse president Jacques Rubio. "We have to live with an unfair situation in France and we don't have the financial facilities to hold on to our young players."

Sabathier admitted: "Aston Villa offered me a salary of between 10,000 and 15,000 francs [£950-£1,400] per month plus board and lodgings. Toulouse could only offer 1,500 francs per month."

webTitle: Smith deposes Coppell in latest Palace revolution

fields.headline: Smith deposes Coppell in latest Palace revolution
fields.trailText: Few would have quibbled if Steve Coppell had been named manager of the year last May, so it hardly seems conceivable that he is not a manager at all this morning. Less than two weeks before the start of Crystal Palace's season, Coppell was replaced at the helm yesterday by Alan Smith. How typically Palace.
fields.body:
Few would have quibbled if Steve Coppell had been named manager of the year last May, so it hardly seems conceivable that he is not a manager at all this morning. Less than two weeks before the start of Crystal Palace's season, Coppell was replaced at the helm yesterday by Alan Smith. How typically Palace.

Smith was lured from his post as Fulham's academy director for a second spell in charge at Selhurst Park after a meeting between Coppell and Palace's new chairman Simon Jordan on Sunday.

Their discussions came after a 6-0 defeat at Millwall in a friendly the day before. And although it is never easy to get to the bottom of Coppell's departures - his brief and bizarre stint at Manchester City proves that - both parties insisted they had reached a mutual, amicable decision.

Crucial to the parting of the ways seems to have been a shift in atmosphere and philosophy since Jordan's takeover last month, which pulled the club out of 15 months of administration.

Coppell has found he is no longer "100% my own boss" and also admitted he would have been "too loyal" to the players who served him so well last season to avoid relegation from the First Division.

Jordan feels it is inspiration rather than martyrdom which is required now, and appears to see Coppell as a wonderful battler but not as the winner he wants in more stable times.

The embarrassment at Millwall, coming after heavy defeats by Crawley and Reading, must have filled Jordan - a Palace fan - with the fear that he would soon be seen as another Mark Goldberg.

"I think the fans will accept a winning mentality," said Jordan, who made his millions from the mobile phone business. "Yes, Steve Coppell provided them with a team last season that performed fantastically against the odds. But the reality is that this is a different season and with respect to Steve - who I have great admiration for - you are only as good as your last result.

"We have 15,000 fantastic fans who deserve more than they have got from this club in the last 20 years, whether it be under owners that came in who haven't got a clue or owners that have gone out with an enormous amount of money. There is an opportunity for this club to be successful. I am not going to waste it and neither is the management team."

The team comprises Smith, who worked under Coppell at Palace for more than a decade before succeeding him for the first time in 1993, and the coaches Glenn Cockerill, one of Smith's assistants at Fulham, and Ray Houghton, one of Smith's old Palace signings.

During his first spell, Smith led Palace to the First Division title and reached two cup semi-finals before leaving in 1995 after relegation and a public spat with Ron Noades.

"I would be a liar to say I don't feel a bit uncomfortable replacing Steve," Smith said. "Our relationship goes back about 15 years. I've spoken to him and I know he will leave a hole. He's done a fantastic job."

Coppell said his third spell at Palace would be his last but is expected to stay in football. He said: "For the last couple of years I have been 100% my own boss. I made every football decision. It was a personal utopia. Simon came in the summer and I came to the conclusion that leaving was in the best interests of Simon and Palace.

"It's best he has his own men ... I would have been too loyal to the players who worked so hard for me last year. It needs a cold, clinical eye."

webTitle: Blades suddenly blunted

fields.headline: Blades suddenly blunted
fields.trailText: Sheffield United have discovered that their new signing Patrick Suffo is banned worldwide.
fields.body:
Sheffield United have discovered that their new signing Patrick Suffo is banned worldwide.

The Cameroon international striker, signed from Nantes for £150,000, has been banned by Fifa until November after an incident with a referee in a reserve match for the French club.

United's manager Neil Warnock, who had believed the ban applied only to France, said: "We are asking Fifa to reduce the length of the ban from eight months to six."

Leeds's hopes of signing the Norway international John Arne Riise were last night on the brink of collapse after Monaco increased their valuation at the last minute.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale had agreed a fee, believed to be about £4m, with the French champions for the 19-year-old midfielder, who can also play in defence, and said that "unless they lower [the price] the deal is dead".

Charlton have signed Bulgaria's right-back Radostin Kishishev, 26, for £300,000, which could rise to £1.8m depending on appearances.

Portsmouth have signed Nottingham Forest's former England Under-21 midfielder Nigel Quashie, 22, for £800,000.

webTitle: The best technical hitch scene: The Perfect Storm

fields.headline: The best technical hitch scene: The Perfect Storm
fields.trailText: Miles out to sea, having made an enormous catch, the swordfishermen of the Andrea Gail stand on deck, triumphant. Suddenly, engineer Mike "Bugsy" Moran (John Hawkes) emerges from the bowels of the ship, panic on his face.
fields.body:
Miles out to sea, having made an enormous catch, the swordfishermen of the Andrea Gail stand on deck, triumphant. Suddenly, engineer Mike "Bugsy" Moran (John Hawkes) emerges from the bowels of the ship, panic on his face.

"Captain!"

The skipper, Billy Tyne (George Clooney), looks up.

"The ice machine's had it!"

"You checked the evaporator?"

"Yeah."

"Frion?"

"Plenty - but nowhere to flow."

"So, use a little spit and glue dammit!"

"I did. She's fried, skip. I told Brown to get a new one, but he goes for another overhaul."

Overhearing, the rest of the crew begin to look worried. Tyne turns to address them.

"The ice machine's gone."

The crew groan in unison.

"OK, we've got good ice on them now. We seal the fish, and with a little bit of luck we'll deliver them."

Tyne turns to Bobby Shatford (Mark Wahlberg).

"Pull up the net - we're going home."

The crew erupt in cheers.

See also: Robocop, Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory, Making Mr Right

Don't see also: Wild Wild West, Rollercoaster

Pointless trivia: Perfect Storm director Wolfgang Petersen used three days worth of footage of Hurricane Floyd for the film's various special effects.

webTitle: Windies await England's dogged duo

fields.headline: Windies await England's dogged duo
fields.standfirst: Atherton and Stewart are in the centurion mood
fields.trailText: David Hopps finds Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart in the centurion mood.
fields.body:
Michael Atherton and Alec Stewart have never really given the impression of being a double act. Long after their retirement they will be most easily remembered for great individual achievements, courageous stances often made against insurmountable odds. They automatically come to mind standing alone.

But fate has decreed that by both reaching their 100th Test together, in the third Test against West Indies which starts tomorrow, they might as well be joined at the hip. And it is a wonderfully fortunate thing that they have reached the mark simultaneously, because the double celebration should jolt everybody into recognising what a monumental contribution they have made.

There are many ways to regard Atherton and Stewart, and the one that has been understandably favoured over recent days is to present them as opposites: Atherton naturally rebellious, disordered, slightly scruffy, the Cambridge University boy; Stewart the respecter of authority, supremely organised, obsessively smart, from the university of life.

But Manchester is the time to stress not what sets them apart but what unites them. As they conducted a series of media interviews together yesterday, what came through time and again was the fact that they are survivors. With their ability has come a mental strength given to few. Without that, both would already have conceded the fight.

It is Atherton, not daring to look ahead too far and knowing that his long-standing back problem could deteriorate without warning, who senses that, even at five years younger than Stewart, he may be the first to go.

"It looks like Vaughan and Trescothick are probably going to be earmarked to take the job," he said. "Stewy is probably going to be more difficult to replace, because he serves as the all-rounder in the side and we have struggled to produce all-rounders."

What Atherton and Stewart look for in the top-order batsmen who might one day replace them is that same mental strength. "The mental side is so important," Stewart said, "and what stood out about Marcus in the NatWest series was how he immediately looked at home in the international set-up. Other people never really settle." Atherton, after batting with Vaughan at Lord's, recognised similar steel.

Atherton was once again invited to pay tribute to Stewart yesterday and his testament was well meant but predictably wry. Repetition soon bores him. "I'll remember his fitness, his mental strength and his aggression at the crease," he said. Then the abandoned Test on a dangerous pitch in Jamaica came to mind. "That nine not out was pretty good too."

Stewart on Atherton was equally respectful, virtually a set speech from which upbringing tells him it would be wrong to stray. "To open for England for so long, and on so many surfaces, speaks volumes for what standard of player he is," he said. "He never gives his wicket away, and leads from the front whether as a person or a cricketer. He remains the one English wicket that everyone wants to take."

By rights, Old Trafford should be packed to offer Stewart and Atherton the accolade they richly deserve, all the more so because this is Atherton's home ground. But, although the second and third days are virtually sold out, only 9,500 tickets have been sold for tomorrow. A half-full ground, especially only a few weeks after England's heroics at Lord's, will question whether Lancashire's much-touted affinity for cricket is still all it is cracked up to be.

Atherton recalled last week that when he made his Test debut against Australia at Trent Bridge 11 years ago a senior England player told him: "You play your first game for love and the rest for money."

Stewart and Atherton, with pride and stubbornness, with a hatred of defeat and the determination to build England brick by brick, have done much to change that culture. England have not achieved a long run of success during their careers, and probably never will. But if the day finally comes, both can be proud of the part they have played.

webTitle: Gordon Brown 'to wed tomorrow'

fields.headline: Gordon Brown 'to wed tomorrow'
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown and his girlfriend Sarah Macaulay are to be married tomorrow in his Dunfermline East constituency, it was announced tonight.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown and his girlfriend Sarah Macaulay are to be married tomorrow in his Dunfermline East constituency, it was announced tonight.

In a statement issued by his special adviser, Mr Brown said the couple were "absolutely delighted".

The statement read: "Sarah Macaulay and Gordon Brown are to be married tomorrow. The ceremony will be held in Mr Brown's constituency.

"It will be conducted by the local Church of Scotland minister. The religious service and reception will be a small family event."

The statement continued: "Gordon and Sarah will hold a party for friends and colleagues when they return in September."

Mr Brown said: "We are absolutely delighted and very happy."

The couple began dating in early 1994.

But despite widespread speculation about their relationship, there was no hint that wedding plans were being drawn up before tonight's surprise announcement.

webTitle: Woolmer brings stability to Warwickshire

fields.headline: Woolmer makes Ostler stable
fields.standfirst: Warwickshire 244-6 v Nottinghamshire
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 244-6 v Nottinghamshire.
fields.body:
Bob Woolmer has made a relatively low-key return to county cricket this summer, mainly because in his absence Warwickshire failed to qualify for the First Division in either the County Championship or the National League. But Dominic Ostler has certainly benefited from his impact.

Ostler, who was once viewed as future Test material, endured a miserable couple of years under Woolmer's predecessor Phil Neale, making only seven championship appearances last summer.

There were even doubts about whether he would receive a new contract, and with it the benefit he was due after receiving his cap in 1991. But Woolmer's return has again brought the best out of the 30-year-old, who has scored 800 first-class runs and continued his excellent one-day form yesterday with an unbeaten 79 from 92 balls to steer Warwickshire to 244 for six against Nottinghamshire.

Neil Smith did not have to think long before choosing to bat on a beautiful evening and an ideal one-day pitch and it became obvious that the outfield was billiard-table fast too as Nick Knight and Anurag Singh put on 91 in 16 overs.

Nottinghamshire's four seamers all struggled and it took the introduction of Richard Stemp to break the stand, as Singh was acrobatically caught by Jason Gallian at cover and Knight taken on the boundary by David Lucas. But Ostler and Trevor Penney kept up the momentum by putting on 67 from 14 overs.

The Outlaws did not help themselves by offering each of the top four batsmen a life, Ostler's the simplest as Lucas grassed a sitter when he had scored 37. Stemp returned to dismiss Dougie Brown and Michael Powell, both reverse sweeping, and Usman Afzaal took the other two wickets to complete a left-arm monopoly, although he too was launched over long-on by Ostler.

webTitle: Cronje's pastor warns against cash-in

fields.headline: Cronje's pastor warns against cash-in
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje's confidant, Pastor Ray McCauley, has publicly pleaded with the disgraced former South Africa captain not to cash in on the match-fixing scandal that caused his sporting downfall. Cronje recently signed with the leading British celebrity agent Max Clifford, aiming to maximise his income from book deals and interviews.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje's confidant, Pastor Ray McCauley, has publicly pleaded with the disgraced former South Africa captain not to cash in on the match-fixing scandal that caused his sporting downfall. Cronje recently signed with the leading British celebrity agent Max Clifford, aiming to maximise his income from book deals and interviews.

McCauley has spoken of his shock on hearing that Cronje had hired Clifford, and intends to telephone him to urge him to reconsider. He said: "My advice to him would be stop, stop right now."

"I hope that he just re-evaluates the whole thing and begins to understand that maybe he needs to put [first] the people of South Africa and what he needs to do for them and for his fans in particular, rather than the money. South Africa slumped to a second-innings score of 192 for eight at the end of the third day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Kandy, a lead of only 137. The only bright note was the form of Jacques Kallis, who hit 87, as Sri Lanka's spinners dominated. Earlier the hosts reached 308 in their first innings. South Africa must win this match to level the three-Test series.
