webTitle: The unreal deal

fields.headline: The unreal deal
fields.standfirst: Blackheads, wrinkles and boyfriend trouble - it's not easy being a computer-generated TV star. But, explains Ed Waller, the virtual celebrity is here to stay
fields.trailText: Blackheads, wrinkles and boyfriend trouble - it's not easy being a computer-generated TV star. But, explains Ed Waller, the virtual celebrity is here to stay.
fields.body:
Remember Max Headroom, the quintessentially 80s robot TV presenter? Well he's back - or at least his offspring are. Computer-generated presenters are now big business, and are destined to grace TV screens, websites, Wap phones, cash points and anything else that'll be taking up precious viewing time in the future.

The world has already been introduced to that green-haired beauty, Ananova. Her designers, like latter-day Dr Frankensteins, built her from the cadavers of existing female talent like Kylie, Posh Spice and Carol Vorderman - a ménage à trois to liven up the dullest newscast. Ananova currently reads low-spec news from her own website, and was recently sold to Orange for £95m cash. Earlier this year, meanwhile, Channel 5 unveiled their own effort, Vandrea, based on ITN's Andrea Catherwood. She'll soon be delivering daytime bulletins as a way to attract all those Lara Croft fans who perhaps have trouble relating to the overpowering femininity of the real Ms Catherwood.

Now the eggheads who sired Ananova have given her a sister - TMmy (pronounced Timmy). She's half Hispanic, half Oriental and, unlike her somewhat tepid sister, she's been imbued with what appears to be a personality. "Wild, outspoken and likes adventure", goes the PR puff. "Not afraid to cause a stir, laughs at life's challenges." Etcetera.

Much suspension of disbelief will be required, but she's set to blossom into a fully-fledged celebrity, fronting online channel Worldart's webcasts from the Edinburgh Festival Revue from this Saturday. Big screens in Covent Garden and Leicester Square will carry her shows, and she's also negotiating a deal to anchor a forthcoming digital TV channel.

Some may think that the goggle box is already filled with two- dimensional characters bereft of personality, but this trend for artificial humans goes beyond TV. In advertising, Kate and Claudia are being usurped by Lara and Trina - that virtual cuties who recently tried to sell us bras. In the manufactured world of pop, such creations might seem burdened with a little too much character, but nevertheless they're busy colonising there too. Last year, E-Cyas stormed up the German charts with Are You Real? despite the fact he wasn't. And this month the UK will hear the first single from T-Babe, a cyber-popster seemingly inspired by Brigitte Nielsen.

The silver screen, too, has long been peopled by what Hollywood is calling "synthespians". The trend that began with Titanic's digital extras has gone on to bring Oliver Reed back from the dead in Gladiator, and continues with Mystique, a character in the forthcoming X-Men. Extras and stuntmen are usually the first to go, but several major Hollywood names, like Tom Cruise and Kevin Bacon, have also allowed digital doppelgängers to be used in their stead.

There are even casting agents in Tinseltown wholly devoted to providing virtual actors, with plans afoot to stage the comeback to end all comebacks: Marilyn Monroe's first screen role for 38 years. Legal battles are, of course, already raging about rights to afterlives but, like everything in the Dream Factory, death is now just something else to be negotiated around.

Meanwhile, UK teen channel Trouble has taken the whole thing one step further with its Flash Boyfriend. A visit to the site leads to an accidental meeting with a hunky-yet-sensitive animation called Max. You swap email addresses and pretty soon you're embroiled in the minutiae of his so-called life, being encouraged to emotionally bond with a toon, as a way of boosting the site's hit rate. Via email, Max flirts away and, if you play your cards right, you even get to do a spot of interactive snogging.

The channel will soon have him texting his flock's mobiles with more chat-up lines and, so far, 35,000 registered girlfriends have fallen for Max's cyber charms. For lonely guys, there's Online Caroline, designed to resemble a real girlcam site, but whose automated host is far more responsive than any girlcam hosts. She chats you up, confides in you and prepares meals for you, suggesting you cook the same meal at home so you can eat "together".

The fathers of these creations are careful to avoid making their creations too perfect and thus unreal. Caroline, for instance, comes complete with boyfriend trouble, and T-Babe gets the odd blackhead (with wrinkles to be phased in). Soon businessmen in smoke-filled rooms will no doubt decide whether E-Cyas should get off with T-Babe, for a virtual wedding à la Posh 'n' Becks, while Hello! and OK! do Ananova photoshoots and tabloids run TMmy's my-drugs-hell stories.

It will surely be an important moment in the history of TV when we turn on our sets to find a chatshow in which the host and guests are all non-existent virtual characters, talking about their non-existent virtual lives - although perhaps we reached that point long ago.

webTitle: NatWest to offer accounts for financially excluded

fields.headline: NatWest to offer accounts for financially excluded
fields.standfirst:
Royal Bank of Scotland promises to pamper customers as consumer group attacks rival

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: NatWest plans to respond to the Treasury's call to set up basic accounts for the financially excluded by marketing them through credit unions.
fields.body:
NatWest plans to respond to the Treasury's call to set up basic accounts for the financially excluded by marketing them through credit unions.

The accounts, which will be known as Step, must be ready by October to meet Treasury demands, which also require the banks to market them actively to people who do not have bank accounts.

However, the Step accounts will not be available in post offices, where the government is trying to encourage the banks to participate in a "universal bank".

Details of the account emerged as Royal Bank of Scotland released its first set of figures since winning the marathon battle for control of NatWest this year.

On a pro-forma basis, treating NatWest as if it had been part of the group last year, profits rose from £1.3bn to £1.5bn at the pre-tax level in the six months to the end of June, helping the shares rise 10% to £11.70 yesterday. Excluding goodwill and integration costs, profits were up 23% to £2bn.

Royal Bank repeated its promise not to close any more NatWest branches, 500 of which will be refurbished to rid them of their 1980s image.

Gordon Pell, who runs Royal Bank's retail banking operations, said lino is to be replaced with carpets and more modern furniture introduced.

The remuneration of staff in NatWest branches was altered in June, with pay weighted two-thirds on sales performance and one-third on service. Since then, sales have increased by 30% to 40%, Mr Pell said.

Royal Bank denied it had lost NatWest customers after the takeover, although it admitted that 25% of staff were suffering from low morale.

Fred Goodwin, Royal Bank's chief executive, insisted the bank had had no "bad surprises" since the takeover. "We tried quite hard to find them," he said.

He conceded that there was uncertainty in some of the processing centres - six of which are earmarked for closure, with more to come.

Up to 18,000 jobs are scheduled to be shed by March 2003, with 7,500 already gone in the three months since Royal Bank took control.

A further 2,500 job cuts are planned for this year under a plan to save £1.3bn in costs.

The bank indicated yesterday that there might be further expansion deals before its three-year integration with NatWest is over.

Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro, said Royal Bank's management had a good track record and the market had probably been too sceptical about its ability to deliver the promises it made during the takeover.

Royal Bank will pay an interim dividend of 9.6p.

webTitle: 'Common ground' found as Sarah's parents meet critics of newspaper campaign

fields.headline: 'Common ground' found as Sarah's parents meet critics of newspaper campaign
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: The parents of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne today met critics of the News of the World's "name and shame" campaign to explain why they support it.
fields.body:
The parents of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne today met critics of the News of the World's "name and shame" campaign to explain why they support it.

Sara and Michael Payne met pressure groups and News of the World executives at News International's offices in Wapping, east London, to discuss the paper's decision to publish photographs and details of convicted sex offenders.

After the four-hour meeting, all said they had reached "common ground" - all parties aimed to protect children from paedophiles.

Groups opposed to the News of the World's campaign with representatives at the meeting included the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, the Association of Chief Police Officers, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and the Suzy Lamplugh Trust.

But the Paynes, from Hersham, Surrey, have backed the campaign and say parents have the right to know if paedophiles live in their area.

After the meeting, a spokesman for the newspaper said "common ground" had been established, and that "a period of reflection" would now take place during which "contact would be maintained" between the various parties. "We have a common aim - to protect the interests of children."

Mrs Payne said it had been a "very informative meeting" during which they had found "a lot of common ground" and "agreed on a lot of issues". "We all have a common goal, and that's to protect the children of this country from those who might harm them," she said.

The meeting took place a day after police released a man they had arrested in connection with Sarah's murder for the second time in a month. Roy Whiting, 41, was first arrested within a day of the eight-year-old's disappearance from fields near East Preston, West Sussex, on July 1. He was questioned for the second time about the eight-year-old girl following his arrest on Monday, but released to the prison service, which is holding him on unrelated charges.

webTitle: USA tests out naming-and-shaming law

fields.headline: USA tests out naming-and-shaming law
fields.standfirst: As the row over naming sex offenders continues, Derek Brown looks at a scheme in the USA that provides the public with just such information
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 5.15pm: As the row over naming sex offenders continues, Derek Brown looks at a scheme in the USA that provides the public with just such information.
fields.body:
The row over the News of the World's name-and-shame campaign is a transatlantic version of a fierce controversy in the United States, where law agencies are obliged to make information about sex offenders available to the public.

The legislation, which can brand sex offenders for life, is commonly known as Megan's Law. It was signed by President Clinton four years ago, and is undoubtedly one of his more popular measures.

The law takes its name from Megan Kanka, who was just seven when she was raped and murdered by a neighbour in New Jersey 1994. Long before Jesse Timmendequas was convicted and sentenced to death for her killing in mid-1997, the case had sparked a national campaign spearheaded by Megan's parents.

They argued that they had been unable to protect their daughter adequately, because they had never been told that Timmendequas was a serial offender.

He also had a record of sexual abuse in his own childhood and, according to defence attorneys, was "a pathetically sick man". The laws for registering sex offenders vary slightly from state to state, though there is a federal law setting down minimum levels of information that must be made available to the public.

Broadly, convicted offenders are graded in three categories, according to how likely they are to re-offend. Police and other law enforcement agencies must maintain a register of such offenders and make it available to organisations and members of the public.

The law is very specific that the information must not be used in any vigilante activity. Groups that support the legislation reinforce the point by urging their supporters not to undermine the pro-registration movement by harassing offenders.

Though Megan's Law is popular, many Americans are queasy about its implications for human rights, especially the right of privacy. Legal arguments have raged about the measure's constitutionality, and whether organisations have the right to discriminate against known offenders.

There is also a widespread fear that publicly available registers of sex criminals could become instant mailing-lists for pornographers and paedophile groups.

In all, there are said to be around 325,000 convicted sex offenders in the USA - roughly three times as many as the News of the World claims there are in Britain. Their identities and locations are, in theory, available to all, though states require a search fee from inquirers.

In at least 15 states, the registers have been put on the internet. In most cases, surfers can enter the sites without themselves registering, and search for offender by name or district.

webTitle: GMC cleared of race bias charge

fields.headline: GMC cleared of race bias charge
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An independent report will today clear the General Medical Council of discriminating against black and Asian doctors despite finding that more than half of those called before its highest disciplinary committee were from overseas.
fields.body:
An independent report will today clear the General Medical Council of discriminating against black and Asian doctors despite finding that more than half of those called before its highest disciplinary committee were from overseas.

The two-year investigation found that 54% of doctors who appeared before the council's professional conduct committee last year had obtained qualifications to practise from abroad. Most of these were trained in the Indian subcontinent, with only five coming from Europe.

The report identified a lack of consistency in the complaints procedure, "obscure" decision-making, and an unclear definition of misconduct. But it found "no evidence of racial bias" on the part of the council.

Last year, 50% of overseas-qualified doctors who appeared before the PCC were struck off the medical register. This compares with just 38% of UK-qualified doctors who appeared before the committee, the report said.

While the overall number of complaints received about overseas qualified doctors was roughly representative of the group as a proportion of the medical profession (about 27%-29%), the number of cases which were then referred up to the PCC was extremely disproportionate. The study found this bias "impossible to explain".

The report's author, Isobel Allen, said yesterday that the explanation for this apparent bias was likely to be complex.

One controversial theory is that an influx of doctors from former British colonies during the 1950s and 1960s, at a time when licensing was not as strict as it is today, could be a contributory factor.

Another suggestion is that many overseas qualified doctors work in isolated conditions under great pressure, often as locums or in run down inner city areas, where they lack support .

The GMC said that the number of doctors struck off last year was very small (29). It refused to be drawn on the high proportion of overseas trained doctors who have been subject to disciplinary action.

The report is the second Policy Studies Institute study to look at the GMC's disciplinary procedures in five years.

Its findings are considered unsatisfactory by Surendra Kumar, chairman of the Overseas Doctors' Association, which represents the 23,000 doctors from ethnic minority communities practising in Britain.

He said: "It seems that the council has accepted there is an anomaly here. But if they do not explain how it has come about we cannot accept their conclusion that there is no institutionalised racism within the GMC."

One of the obstacles confronting Professor Allen's investigation was the lack of clear or consistent accounts of disciplinary procedure. In some cases there had been no record kept of the reasons behind PCC decisions.

Today's report will provide 18 recommendations to standardise the complaints procedure.

The GMC has been under siege for some time over complaints from doctors about delays and errors in dealing with serious allegations against them. In June the British Medical Association's annual conference backed a motion of no confidence in the council.

In some cases there had been no record kept of the reasons behind PCC decisions. Today's report will provide 18 recommendations to standardise the complaints procedure. The GMC has been under siege for some time over complaints from doctors about delays and errors in dealing with serious allegations against them. In June the British Medical Association's annual conference backed a motion of no confidence in the council.

webTitle: Analysis: Why Pakistan is advertising its nuclear wares

fields.headline: Why Pakistan is advertising its nuclear wares
fields.standfirst: Islamabad is signalling that it could start selling nuclear material for the first time just as it runs into new trouble over Kashmir, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad
fields.trailText: The Pakistani military regime is signalling that it could start selling nuclear material for the first time just as it runs into new trouble over Kashmir, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad.
fields.body:
Long before Pakistan tested its first atomic devices in the deserts of Baluchistan two years ago, its nuclear intentions had been a source of international concern.

Now the military regime has used the country's newspapers to publish a document which is styled as being a form to be filled in by anybody seeking permission to export nuclear materials and equipment.

Under the headline "Nuclear Substances Category (please tick)" the form lists 17 radioactive substances including depleted uranium, enriched uranium, plutonium and tritium which it claims will be considered for export.

In addition, it says, equipment including nuclear reactors and reactor control systems will be considered. All exports are to be for peaceful use only, it insists, and the export of fissionable material - which includes enriched uranium and plutonium - is banned.

Pakistan's administration says the form is simply an attempt at transparency to prove there is a clear system of control over the nuclear industry.

But it seems unlikely that the country's rulers actually expect a potential exporter to cut out the form, tick appropriate categories and send in the request for permission to export such sensitive material.

While some analysts are saying that publication of the form could be read as a sign that the regime hoped to use nuclear exports for the first time to salvage the economy, there is also the suspicion that the timing of publication is no coincidence.

Pakistan's main flashpoint with India has just sparked again, with Pakistani-backed militants under suspicion for a new spate of murders in Kashmir. Islamabad may feel this is a moment to send a less-than-subtle warning to its neighbours and the world against leaning on Pakistan - by reminding them that it is a nuclear state.

Although it was just two years ago that Pakistan held its first publicly announced test explosions of devices it said could be used in nuclear weapons, its nuclear industry has been growing for 30 years. The country's first nuclear reactor was built with Canadian help in the southern port city of Karachi in 1971.

A second and much larger reactor, this time built with help from China, went into operation last month. There are at least two uranium enrichment plants and two plutonium reprocessing plants in the country, as well as a nuclear research reactor reported to be making plutonium for warheads.

The country is refusing to sign the international nuclear non-proliferation treaty (in common with Israel, India and China, to name just three). And there is no doubting the pride Pakistanis feel in their nuclear status. Statues of missiles and even of Chagai mountain, the site of the 1998 nuclear tests, adorn roundabouts and road junctions in cities across Pakistan.

Implicit in the newspaper forms is a second warning: that Pakistan should not be trifled with by larger powers, because it could retaliate by deciding to sell nuclear-related materials to rogue states.

Islamabad has always promised not to sell its nuclear know-how, and it says there have been no exports of nuclear materials in the past.

The country is clearly nervous about any international backlash over the new killings in Kashmir - killings whose timing is probably no accident either, coming as they have just as peace talks involving India were scheduled.

Pakistan has been struggling to improve its reputation after last summer's debacle in which a fourth war with India seemed close to being ignited by an incursion along the frontier with Kashmir, over which India has formal sovereignty.

Pakistan's economy is in a bad state and the military regime, which seized power in a coup in October, is well aware that a recovery is needed for any other reforms to succeed. Some 80% of Pakistan's annual budget is swallowed up by military spending and loan repayments.

The army says it is cracking down on corruption to reclaim unpaid loans and money lost to bribery; it is also launching a drive to get taxes collected.

Islamabad is still waiting for the International Monetary Fund to release a $1.6bn loan that has been frozen since the coup. Reports here say that loan money may be held back until at least November.

webTitle: Coventry sign Thompson for £2.5m

fields.headline: Coventry sign Thompson for £2.5m
fields.trailText: Coventry have signed Liverpool midfielder David Thompson for £2.5m. The 22 year-old England U-21 international agreed personal terms earlier today will sign a four-year deal providing he passes a medical on Thursday.
fields.body:
Coventry have signed Liverpool midfielder David Thompson for £2.5m. The 22 year-old England U-21 international agreed personal terms earlier today will sign a four-year deal providing he passes a medical on Thursday.

Thompson, who had also been linked with Bradford and Sunderland, was not named in Liverpool's squad for this week's Belfast Carlsberg tournament because of an Achilles injury. But he is expected to link up with the Coventry team on their tour of Belgium and Holland.

After announcing the signing Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson admitted he had been tracking Thompson for almost six months. "This is not something that's an immediate reaction to Robbie's departure," confirmed Richardson. "We've had an eye on him for some time. But I think it's only the recent acquisitions that have persuaded Liverpool to let David go.

But Richardson hopes today's signing will be just first of a three signings before the new season. "He's the first one of three specific targets that we've made," he said. "He's the first one in and hopefully we'll have some more news over the next week or so."

webTitle: Expect West Indies to bounce back with fire

fields.headline: Expect West Indies to bounce back with fire
fields.standfirst: One month on from Lord's, the third Test is finally here. Orin Gordon assesses the effect of the intervening four weeks on England and West Indies
fields.trailText: If a week is a long time in politics, how can we describe the four-week break between the second and the third Test matches? It feels like a completely new series, and in a sense it is. With one win each for West Indies and England, they're effectively embarking on a three-Test rubber at Old Trafford tomorrow. The abysmal scheduling by the England and Wales Cricket Board has taken the life out of a series that was very nicely poised before the players trooped off to play the triangular one-day competition.
fields.body:
If a week is a long time in politics, how can we describe the four-week break between the second and the third Test matches? It feels like a completely new series, and in a sense it is. With one win each for West Indies and England, they're effectively embarking on a three-Test rubber at Old Trafford tomorrow. The abysmal scheduling by the England and Wales Cricket Board has taken the life out of a series that was very nicely poised before the players trooped off to play the triangular one-day competition.

It is a break that England are more likely to regret than the West Indies. Their team for the one-day matches may have been different, but their performances did show that they had the greater momentum, and that the Windies' 54 all out at Lords had completely shaken their confidence. The likelihood is that England would have won any Test that followed soon after Lord's. My feeling is that before this tour began the Windies would have settled for losing the one-day competition and winning the Tests.

What they will be deeply unhappy with is their insipid performances in the triangular tournament. They've shown encouraging signs of recovery since the year began, but losing is still habitual for this bunch and they know it. They lost ten consecutive overseas Tests before Edgbaston and they dropped four matches in a row in the triangular tournament, indicating a fragile mental state. No wonder they celebrated their solitary limited-overs win at Trent Bridge as if they'd won the World Cup.

That narrow victory was important in breaking their duck in the limited-overs competition, but of much greater value in preparing them for what they saw back then as the important battles ahead at Old Trafford, Headingley and The Oval. England not only lost a match they should have won - they took their fingers off the Windies' throats. Hussain's men do look a hungrier, more efficient bunch than they did at the start of the tour, but there are several points worth considering.

The first is that Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh are back to lead the bowling attack. Ambrose spent the one-dayers putting his feet up in Antigua, and Walsh too had limited involvement. Few bowlers raise themselves for the big matches as much as these two, and although Ambrose has looked rusty after his break, they'll really test England at Old Trafford. The poor quality of the support act is a concern that can wait for now - first there's a series to be won (perhaps saved) and they can do it.

The second reason why the Windies cannot be discounted is that they confront an England that has yet again made changes. No matter how deserving Marcus Trescothick and others are of their selection, each new line-up is a message sent to the Windies that England have little confidence in their non-established players. Psychologically, this sort of message has always played into West Indian hands. Ambrose and Walsh would like nothing more than the sight of yet another debutant. In a funny way, they'll prefer bowling to Trescothick, even though he's been a revelation in the one-day matches, than they would to Mark Ramprakash who's failed in the Tests.

Wavell Hinds, the new batting find, is running into form and Ridley Jacobs is at last showing that Alec Stewart is not the only keeper who can bat. However the identity of Sherwin Campbell's opening partner remains as difficult as ever to determine (I go for Chris Gayle), and middle-order lynchpin Shiv Chanderpaul is injured. Brian Lara's form is difficult to determine, although he played a couple of fine innings in the one-dayers. Jimmy Adams has gone off the boil since scoring 98 in Birmingham.

As defeat followed defeat during West Indies' demoralising run, the captain bravely kept repeating the management's mantra about going back to the drawing board and doing the basics better - it got to the point where I said to myself: I'll scream if he says that one more time. They did that for five matches in succession - the Lord's Test and the first four completed one-day matches - so presumably they know what the problems are. Now all that remains is to go out there and win. Simple really.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous Anglo-Caribbean View, on MCC's decision to ban drums, whistles and flags from Lord's, click here.

webTitle: General's call to arms thrills the faithful

fields.headline: General's call to arms thrills the faithful
fields.standfirst:
Republican convention Powell's speech reflects the gap between the party's record on race and its new image

Full text of speech

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Full text of speech
fields.body:
General Colin Powell re-emerged yesterday as America's most potent unifying figure after an impassioned address to the Republican national convention, in which the black Gulf war hero challenged his party to don "the mantle of Lincoln" and embrace minorities.

General Powell's appearance was part of a carefully orchestrated lineup, heavily weighted with blacks and Hispanics, intended to promote the presidential candidate, George W Bush, as a new, culturally sensitive breed of Republican.

The general's powerful oratory, however, also served as a reminder of his towering national stature in comparison with either of the presidential candidates; his popularity rating stands at 81%, nearly 20 points ahead of Mr Bush, and more than 30 points clear of the Democratic contender, Vice-President Al Gore.

His performance late on Monday night, which electrified the crowd in the Philadelphia convention hall, once more raised the question of whether the Harlem-born general might be persuaded to run for president.

The former chairman of the joint chiefs of staff opted not to enter the 1996 race, despite wide support, mainly because his wife, Alma, feared that their family life would be shattered. But the Republicans are confident that Gen Powell would accept a senior cabinet post in a Bush administration, a possibility that the Texas governor hinted at, saying: "I hope his greatest service to America might still lie ahead."

The general's capabilities as a political leader were made plain by the delirious reception he received from the Republican faithful, who found themselves standing and applauding views diametrically opposed to theirs on education, government spending, affirmative action and the role of big business in politics.

The contrast bluntly posed the dilemma facing a party leadership seeking to portray a moderate, all-inclusive image while simultaneously maintaining a highly conservative activist power base.

The general, viewed as one of the architects of the victory in the Gulf war, called for greater expenditure on schools, and a dialogue with US black leaders, including radicals, not just in an election year.

But his most controversial moment came when he suggested that Republican hypocrisy was contributing to the widespread cynicism prevalent among minorities.

"Some in our party miss no opportunity to roundly and loudly condemn affirmative action that helped a few thousand black kids get an education, but hardly a whimper is heard from them over affirmative action for lobbyists who load our federal tax codes with preferences for special interests," he said.

The remarks represented a dual challenge to Republican orthodoxy. They were an undisguised attack on the power wielded by corporate special interests, whose role in US politics is defended by most Republicans as an extension of the right to free speech.

The general's address also confronted most Republican activists' deep-seated opposition to affirmative action programmes designed to promote minorities.

The 2000 official party platform states: "We will attain our nation's goal of equal opportunity without quotas or other forms of preferential treatment."

Questioned later about this divergentce of views, General Powell simply said he had not read the platform document, which he described as "less and less relevant" to the party's actual policies. His remarks reflected the gap between the Republican party members on the podium this week, and those milling around on the convention floor.

The two groups appeared to represent two different countries: The public face was that of a multi-ethnic melting pot, in which black or Hispanic Republicans were close to a majority; the latter was a near-monochrome assembly, where 96% of the delegates were white.

Neither version of the party was representative. In a New York Times survey this week, Republican delegates expressed opinions far to the right of the rank and file on almost every issue from affirmative action to gun control.

On the podium, meanwhile, one minority representative after another came to the microphone: A 10-year-old native American girl sang the national anthem, and a rabbi provided the prayers; there were hip-hop and rock performances and at one point the hall took on the spirit of a revivalist meeting with a black gospel choir and a video address from the preacher of a black Philadelphia church.

However, according to David Bositis, a political analyst at the Joint Centre for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, the multi-hued presentation had little to do with courting minorities.

"It's not intended for black Americans," said Mr Bositis, the author of a study published this week called Blacks and the 2000 Republican National Convention.

"What the Republicans are doing is aimed more at white Americans. Bush wants to differentiate himself from the Republicans in Congress, and what better way than reaching out to African Americans," he said.

Nevertheless, Mr Bositis argued, the spin itself was encouraging. "For the last 30 years, the Republicans have been using race negatively to elect candidates, especially in the south. All of a sudden the Republicans are using race positively. [Moderates] do not want someone who's negative on race. It says something very significant about America as a whole."

The general's address also confronted most Republican activists' deep-seated opposition to affirmative action programmes designed to promote minorities. The 2000 official party platform states: "We will attain our nation's goal of equal opportunity without quotas or other forms of preferential treatment." Questioned later about this divergentce of views, General Powell simply said he had not read the platform document, which he described as "less and less relevant" to the party's actual policies. His remarks reflected the gap between the Republican party members on the podium this week, and those milling around on the convention floor. The two groups appeared to represent two different countries: The public face was that of a multi-ethnic melting pot, in which black or Hispanic Republicans were close to a majority; the latter was a near-monochrome assembly, where 96% of the delegates were white. Neither version of the party was representative. In a New York Times survey this week, Republican delegates expressed opinions far to the right of the rank and file on almost every issue from affirmative action to gun control. On the podium, meanwhile, one minority representative after another came to the microphone: A 10-year-old native American girl sang the national anthem, and a rabbi provided the prayers; there were hip-hop and rock performances and at one point the hall took on the spirit of a revivalist meeting with a black gospel choir and a video address from the preacher of a black Philadelphia church. However, according to David Bositis, a political analyst at the Joint Centre for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, the multi-hued presentation had little to do with courting minorities. "It's not intended for black Americans," said Mr Bositis, the author of a study published this week called Blacks and the 2000 Republican National Convention. "What the Republicans are doing is aimed more at white Americans. Bush wants to differentiate himself from the Republicans in Congress, and what better way than reaching out to African Americans," he said. Nevertheless, Mr Bositis argued, the spin itself was encouraging. "For the last 30 years, the Republicans have been using race negatively to elect candidates, especially in the south. All of a sudden the Republicans are using race positively. [Moderates] do not want someone who's negative on race. It says something very significant about America as a whole."

webTitle: Middlesex's Lord's prayer unanswered

fields.headline: Middlesex's Lord's prayer unanswered
fields.trailText: Last week, this column bemoaned the lot of the Northants fan. It did so with the sort of introspection common to the long-suffering. It was a selfish piece. And as such it failed to spot that there is, currently, a worse fate in county cricket. Middlesex supporters, I salute you.
fields.body:
Last week, this column bemoaned the lot of the Northants fan. It did so with the sort of introspection common to the long-suffering. It was a selfish piece. And as such it failed to spot that there is, currently, a worse fate in county cricket. Middlesex supporters, I salute you.

Before this season, crises at Lord's usually involved the national side. Not any more. England have won their two Tests there this summer plus the NatWest series, while Middlesex have won just one match at home (sorry, MCC's home) all season. And their record isn't much better anywhere else: recent attempts to take Championship cricket to Southgate ended in two defeats, a draw and an eight-point penalty for an unsuitable pitch. Even though the ECB have since given the points back, Middlesex are still bottom of Division 2. And last week they became only the third first-class side to lose a one-day game to Hampshire.

The decline has been alarmingly swift. Middlesex won the Championship in 1993, and finished in the top four in three of the next four seasons. But in 1998 they slumped to 17th, and last season rose just one place to 16th. The retirement of Gatting (as much a part of the Lord's furniture as Old Father Time), the loss of other influential senior players (Desmond Haynes retired, John Emburey moved to Northants), and disquiet over the coaching methods of Queenslander John Buchanan (so bad that Australia promptly hired him instead) were all taking their toll.

The struggle continues. The main reason has been that Middlesex rely on three bowlers and three batsmen - the team contains more padding than Gatting's post-prandial girth.

Angus Fraser (30 Championship wickets at 23.73) has been as metronomic as ever and almost forced his way back into the England team against his favourite opponents, West Indies. Phil Tufnell has done pretty well too: 39 wickets at 24.87 in 458 overs (only Warwickshire's Ashley Giles has bowled more). He's still the best spinner England have. Richard Johnson (32 at 28.71) is the third member of a three-pronged attack. Between them they have picked up 101 Championship wickets. The rest have managed 45.

In the batting, Mark Ramprakash has made a triumphant return (click here to see his run of good form) to the middle order, scoring 446 runs at 111.50 in his last five first-class innings. Justin Langer is averaging 47.11, and opener Andrew Strauss, born in Johannesburg, bred at Radley and Durham University, has also been a success, earning a rave review from Ramprakash in the national press. No other player averages more than 25.

But even this doesn't tell the whole story. Ramps, on England duty, wasn't around to score many runs at the start of the season. And Langer has faded after a blistering purple patch in which he scored 469 in six innings - his last 13 innings in all competitions have produced just 225 runs. Fraser has yet to take a five-for this summer, and Tufnell isn't quite as effective as he was when he and Emburey used to winkle sides out in their differing styles. In 1993 they combined to take 127 Championship wickets; two years later that figure rose to 142. Tufnell needs a partner, and Keith Dutch, with his offbreaks, is more willing than able. As for Johnson, he's never quite been the same since being forced out of England's 1995-96 tour of South Africa with a back injury.

Of the rest, Owais Shah (431 runs at 23.94) has again been a let-down. He captained England to victory in the 1998 Under-19 World Cup but is one of a batch of young players who seem to find their enthusiasm dulled by the daily grind of the circuit. The batting of Paul Weekes (239 at 19.91) has disintegrated, Mike Roseberry (248 at 24.80) has not been the same since Haynes retired, and Dutch has had one outstanding game (55 and 91 and 6-52 v Essex) and little else.

Games against Middlesex now lack the sparkle of old. Opposition batsmen used to worry about the hostility of Wayne Daniel, the accuracy of Mike Selvey, the wiles of Phil Edmonds and the parsimony of Emburey. The bowlers would have to get past Gatting, Wilf Slack and Haynes. The captain would have to out-think Mike Brearley.

Times have changed. So have Middlesex.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Ask the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer
fields.trailText: Where did Pele play club football during his long career and what was his record of appearances and goals scored? asks Gary Pritchard.
fields.body:
Where did Pele play club football during his long career and what was his record of appearances and goals scored? asks Gary Pritchard.

You'd better sit down, because some of these statistics are frightening. Edson Arantes do Nascimento played his club football for Santos, scoring 1,088 goals in 1,114 appearances between 1956 and 1974, and winning six national titles along the way.

During this time he also scored 18 goals in 19 games for assorted representative sides: Sao Paulo in the state championships, Santos/Vasco da Gama selections and Professional Footballers Association teams. In addition, Mr Pele led the Brazilian Army team to the 1959 South American Military Championship, scoring 14 goals in 10 games.

The Brazilian legend (92 caps, 77 goals, 3 World Cups) came out of retirement in 1975 to play for the New York Cosmos in the North American Soccer League. He scored 55 times in 105 games in the States, winning the 1977 NASL title before retiring for good that October in a testimonial against his old team Santos - he played for both sides that day, swapping shirts at half-time.

Pele leaves a record which is, frankly, not bad. He scored 1,282 goals in 1,324 professional games, an average of 0.939 goals per match. He also had 93 hat-tricks and scored 4 goals or more 37 times. Honestly, it's enough to make you sick.

In a previous KU (Wednesday July 12), we quoted a Premier League spokeswoman who insisted that only three non-EU players could play for a team in one match. Since then we've had several emails - mainly from Leeds and West Ham fans - claiming she got it wrong. In particular, Paul Salmon is sure that last season he saw the Hammers play Feuer (USA), Margas (Chile), Foe (Cameroon), Wanchope (Costa Rica) and Stimac (Croatia) in the same match. Is he right, he asks?

"No!" says the very same Premier League spokeswoman after consulting her records. "We're very thorough. No game has sneaked through." However, she does point out why there may be some confusion. Basically, it is more accurate to say that a club can play a maximum of three players who don't have EU work permits. So although West Ham did play four of the players Paul mentions in one game last season, they didn't break any law - because Ian Feuer holds a French passport and so didn't need an EU work permit. Hope that clears things up.

Last week Lee Calvert claimed Liverpool were a Protestant club and Everton were Catholic. Since then half of Merseyside has written in to have their say.

According to Emma Cooney, Lee is just plain wrong. "It's true that Liverpool has Orange parades, but despite this I wouldn't exactly describe the city as divided along sectarian lines, and certainly not in football terms," she says. "I've heard people describe Everton as the Catholic team and Liverpool as the Protestant team - but only those from outside Liverpool!

"From my own experience - I'm from Liverpool, a Liverpool fan and Catholic, as is the rest of my family with the exception of my Grandad who's Catholic as I am but an Everton fan (we're still trying to get him treatment) - this is a myth."

But Lee is supported by Gordon Smith, who says that Tommy Smith (a Catholic and no relation) was threatened by his headmaster and told not to sign for Liverpool as it was a Protestant club. And Gerry McGregor says that Everton are the Catholic club because of their strong connections to the Republic of Ireland. "This is mostly historic - several Irish international players played for Everton before and after the last World War. And in recent years a Dublin club has been supported by Everton as a nursery club."

Why are Celtic called the Bhoys? asked an inquisitive Dan Reid. We weren't sure, but a Celtic spokesman told us (see KU July 5) that the first tangible bit of evidence is a postcard from the turn of the century which refers to the Celtic team of the time as "the bould bhoys". Therefore, he said, the word "bhoys" is almost certainly a misspelling the word "boys".

But hats off to PJ Killian, who points out the word is much older than that. "Bhoys (or sometimes B'hoys, not to mention their counterparts, the lovely G'hurls) was a common American slang term for Irish immigrants at least as far back as the late 1840s," he says.

"From the use of the term in contemporary newspapers, it appears to have been a mildly derogatory term with connotations of shiftlessness and drunkenness. While there's not necessarily a connection to Celtic there, the parallels are striking, and even if the term didn't reach Scotland until later, your postcard writer is at least 50 years too late to be the first."

Why have England traditionally played in white shirts and blue shorts, when the flag of St. George is white and red? asked a puzzled Rob Hancock last week.

"When I played rugby, traditionally there used to be a choice of three colours for shorts - black, white, and navy blue. It's only recently that other colours have appeared," says Gerard Sugrue. "My guess would be that in the past when international football teams began to select their colours the same restricted choice was available.

"This doesn't explain why England chose navy blue over black or white. Possibly blue seemed the next best choice given that it appears in the Union Flag - which has long been regarded by English people as the English flag rather than the flag of the UK." It sounds a reasonable argument to us - does anyone know different?

"I have a vivid memory of Socrates taking a penalty and bursting the net. Did it ever happen - or was it just the work of an over excited brain whilst sleeping? And if Socrates did not burst the net, has anyone else achieved such a feat?" wondered Jonathon Norman.

"I don't know about players bursting the net with penalties in real life, but Scottish striker Hamish Balfour (star of the cartoon strip Hot Shot Hamish in Tiger and, later, Roy of the Rovers) used to manage it for Prince's Park on a regular basis," says Drew Savage. So far nobody has written in with a real-life example, so maybe Jonathon was just dreaming.

Can you help?

Every team that has won the World Cup has a star somewhere on their shirt to represent the number of times they have won. This was evident in France's strip for Euro 2000, where a single star appeared above their badge. Where is the star on England's shirt? asks Matthew Moore

Footballers are generally regarded as being a bit thick and people such as David Beckham and Robbie Fowler do nothing to improve this image. During Euro 2000 I noticed that there are several foreign footballers who are graduates. Are there any current Premiership players, British or foreign, who have a degree or even a couple of GCSE's? wonders Daniel Davies.

Sometimes as a ball is going out of play a player will prevent the opposition from reaching it by "shielding" the ball but without actually touching it. In any other circumstance this would be obstruction. Why isn't it in this case? asks Peter Hayes.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: A strike, A streaker and Assistance

fields.headline: A strike, A streaker and Assistance
fields.trailText: IF IT'S ABOUT SPAIN, IT MUST BE ABOUT MONEY
fields.body:
IF IT'S ABOUT SPAIN, IT MUST BE ABOUT MONEY

For some time, Citizen Fiver has been swotting up on the Barcelona rent strike of 1931, while rallying good union men and singing "the footballers united will never be defeated" to bemused onlookers outside the Camp Nou. Why? To support Comrade Rivaldo, of course! Because while the likes of Alessandro del Piero are driving their crazy cars and a earning a cool £75,000-a-week, Red Riv hasn't been awarded a pay rise since August 1997 and has had to scrimp a living on about half that amount.

And who says union action doesn't work? Because today the Brazilian Bolshevik (OK, we might be making that bit up) finally signed a new deal worth £85,000 a week after tax to stay at Barcelona until 2003. In other words, a cool £4.4m a year. Net. And wasn't he happy! "It's lucky that Nunez has gone," laughed Red Riv, having a pop at Barca's former president who reneged on a promise to give him an improved contract after two seasons. "But now Gaspart has been true to his word and I'm very happy, because I wanted to stay at Barca."

Of course he did. Which is why the rumours of a £29m Milan bid, and the reported sighting of Milan executive Adriano Galliani jetting off to Catalonia for more talks with Rivaldo, were completely wide of the mark. (we'll picket the house of anyone that says otherwise). But was Gaspart ecstatic about securing Red Riv's services for another three years? Well, surprisingly, he wasn't. "Barcelona have gone a bit mad to pay this money," he admitted, staring wistfully at his empty wallet, "but the important thing is that it has all finished and Rivaldo can go off happy and contented." Now that's what Citizen Fiver calls man management.

ADVERTISEMENT

Win a fantasy night for you and 5 of your friends courtesy of http://www.e-street.com - the essential new service for planning your shopping, eating and drinking in London.

DIAMOND LIFE

Last season, Airdrie fans had a dismal time of it. The team was rubbish, the results were worse and the club narrowly avoided both extinction and an even more unthinkable fate - a merger with Motherwell. In fact, according to the club's official website, the only highlight in a whole year of misery was "a streaker who evaded the police and proceeded to air his views on the handling of the club with various parts of his body".

But last month, things took a turn for the up when Steve Archibald took over, promising to inject new life into a dying club. Fans once again dared to dream, and they haven't been let down - this morning Archibald announced that he is attempting to sign Hristo Stoichkov! "There is a very real chance of Stoichkov coming," the Strathclyde saviour explained today after discussing a move with the 34-year-old Bulgarian legend on the phone. "I can tell you he was very interested. This is not an old pal's act or a publicity stunt - I believe Hristo could do a great job for the club."

The deal is far from completion, as Archibald must wait until the former European player of the year's contract with Chicago Fire runs out in December. The Diamonds boss is playing it cool, however. "I would be willing to bide my time before bringing him to Airdrie," he said today, out-Ridsdaling Peter Ridsdale, "and if I can get Hristo before then it would be a real bonus." Still, cool Steve won't mind if Airdrie's fans whip themselves up into a frenzy while they're waiting. Unless it's that streaker - we don't want him using his body parts to show us how excited he is, thank you very much.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I've always been hungry to get into the team. But now I'm hungrier than ever, starving you could say" - Liverpool captain Robbie Fowler confirms his newfound maturity by adding another word to his vocabulary.

MANAGING MY LIFE

The last time we heard from John Barnwell, vibrant head of the League Manager's Association, he was about to sit down with managers and referees to see just why they couldn't all get along. Two months later and, lo and behold, the FA come up with the biggest changes to disciplinary laws since King George V got scythed down by a scythe in a Buck House friendly. So what is John doing next? Clearing up the Jerusalem problem? Lobbying for a new Missile Defence System based on washing-up bottles? Hardly, he's off protecting those endangered managers instead.

"In football you're always going to get winners and losers, that's the nature of the game," Barnwell said today, at the launch of an initiative to help managers adjust to life outside the sheepskin. "But many people think managers leave one job and get back on the roundabout in a few months. Figures show this is not the case and we at the LMA have a responsibility to address the situation." Barnwell then produced a piece of paper which showed that of the 269 managers dismissed in the past six years only 91 are still involved in coaching. He then told a story about an ex-manager who couldn't afford to heat his house and simply "sat huddled in an overcoat listening to the windows rattling."

Barnwell went on to promise to "help improve the standard of coaching," and "educate managers better for the outside world." It was a bravura performance, the Fiver can assure you. But how will he put his thoughts into practice? Will he take Bruce Rioch into a shop and show him that, unlike in football, you don't pay £5 for 50p's worth of goods? Or help Bobby Gould start his own landscape gardening firm with a booster loan? We're not sure. But if anyone can help these poor, downtrodden, unqualified egotists back into the labour market - it's Mr John Barnwell.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Christian Ziege will decide whether to move to Liverpool "soon", according to Bryan Robson, after the Boro manager spoke with the player last night. "I've left it with Christian and I'm just waiting to hear from him. It's a very difficult decision for him. He's not sure in his own mind what he wants to do and that's why he wants to keep tight."

Aston Villa are to make another bid for Leicester's Neil Lennon. The combative midfielder is valued at £8m and any move Villa make will undoubtedly be matched by Martin O'Neill's Celtic. Villa have also completed the signing of German youth international Thomas Hitzelburger. The 18-year-old can play anywhere in both defence and midfield.

Rangers have had a £15m offer for Real Madrid's Fernando Morientes rejected.

Real Madrid have made an attempt to sign Thierry Henry from Arsenal, offering Steve McManaman in part exchange.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Coventry have bought David Thompson from Liverpool for £2.5m. The 22 year-old England U-21 midfielder will sign a four-year deal providing he passes a medical on Thursday.

Derby manager Jim Smith was in ebullient mood after completing the signing of Lens defender Youl Mawene for £500,000. "He's a tremendous talent," he said. "We expect him to be featuring in the first team at the start of the season."

Former Sunderland star Gary Bennett has been named as the new boss of Darlington following the resignation of David Hodgson and his assistant Ian Butterworth.

Fulham have signed French U-21 international Fabrice Fernandes from Rennes. The 20-year-old winger joins the Craven Cottage club for a year, with a view to a permanent move.

Ally McCoist looks poised to snub a move to Raith Rovers by signing a new one-year contract with Kilmarnock tomorrow.

The Hearts board has dismissed the latest proposal from former chairman Leslie Deans to take over the club.

A Singapore FA official has said four foreign players - including three Britons - have been arrested in a match-fixing scandal. fields.bodyText: IF IT'S ABOUT SPAIN, IT MUST BE ABOUT MONEY For some time, Citizen Fiver has been swotting up on the Barcelona rent strike of 1931, while rallying good union men and singing "the footballers united will never be defeated" to bemused onlookers outside the Camp Nou. Why? To support Comrade Rivaldo, of course! Because while the likes of Alessandro del Piero are driving their crazy cars and a earning a cool £75,000-a-week, Red Riv hasn't been awarded a pay rise since August 1997 and has had to scrimp a living on about half that amount. And who says union action doesn't work? Because today the Brazilian Bolshevik (OK, we might be making that bit up) finally signed a new deal worth £85,000 a week after tax to stay at Barcelona until 2003. In other words, a cool £4.4m a year. Net. And wasn't he happy! "It's lucky that Nunez has gone," laughed Red Riv, having a pop at Barca's former president who reneged on a promise to give him an improved contract after two seasons. "But now Gaspart has been true to his word and I'm very happy, because I wanted to stay at Barca." Of course he did. Which is why the rumours of a £29m Milan bid, and the reported sighting of Milan executive Adriano Galliani jetting off to Catalonia for more talks with Rivaldo, were completely wide of the mark. (we'll picket the house of anyone that says otherwise). But was Gaspart ecstatic about securing Red Riv's services for another three years? Well, surprisingly, he wasn't. "Barcelona have gone a bit mad to pay this money," he admitted, staring wistfully at his empty wallet, "but the important thing is that it has all finished and Rivaldo can go off happy and contented." Now that's what Citizen Fiver calls man management. DIAMOND LIFE Last season, Airdrie fans had a dismal time of it. The team was rubbish, the results were worse and the club narrowly avoided both extinction and an even more unthinkable fate - a merger with Motherwell. In fact, according to the club's official website, the only highlight in a whole year of misery was "a streaker who evaded the police and proceeded to air his views on the handling of the club with various parts of his body". But last month, things took a turn for the up when Steve Archibald took over, promising to inject new life into a dying club. Fans once again dared to dream, and they haven't been let down - this morning Archibald announced that he is attempting to sign Hristo Stoichkov! "There is a very real chance of Stoichkov coming," the Strathclyde saviour explained today after discussing a move with the 34-year-old Bulgarian legend on the phone. "I can tell you he was very interested. This is not an old pal's act or a publicity stunt - I believe Hristo could do a great job for the club." The deal is far from completion, as Archibald must wait until the former European player of the year's contract with Chicago Fire runs out in December. The Diamonds boss is playing it cool, however. "I would be willing to bide my time before bringing him to Airdrie," he said today, out-Ridsdaling Peter Ridsdale, "and if I can get Hristo before then it would be a real bonus." Still, cool Steve won't mind if Airdrie's fans whip themselves up into a frenzy while they're waiting. Unless it's that streaker - we don't want him using his body parts to show us how excited he is, thank you very much. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I've always been hungry to get into the team. But now I'm hungrier than ever, starving you could say" - Liverpool captain Robbie Fowler confirms his newfound maturity by adding another word to his vocabulary. MANAGING MY LIFE The last time we heard from John Barnwell, vibrant head of the League Manager's Association, he was about to sit down with managers and referees to see just why they couldn't all get along. Two months later and, lo and behold, the FA come up with the biggest changes to disciplinary laws since King George V got scythed down by a scythe in a Buck House friendly. So what is John doing next? Clearing up the Jerusalem problem? Lobbying for a new Missile Defence System based on washing-up bottles? Hardly, he's off protecting those endangered managers instead. "In football you're always going to get winners and losers, that's the nature of the game," Barnwell said today, at the launch of an initiative to help managers adjust to life outside the sheepskin. "But many people think managers leave one job and get back on the roundabout in a few months. Figures show this is not the case and we at the LMA have a responsibility to address the situation." Barnwell then produced a piece of paper which showed that of the 269 managers dismissed in the past six years only 91 are still involved in coaching. He then told a story about an ex-manager who couldn't afford to heat his house and simply "sat huddled in an overcoat listening to the windows rattling." Barnwell went on to promise to "help improve the standard of coaching," and "educate managers better for the outside world." It was a bravura performance, the Fiver can assure you. But how will he put his thoughts into practice? Will he take Bruce Rioch into a shop and show him that, unlike in football, you don't pay £5 for 50p's worth of goods? Or help Bobby Gould start his own landscape gardening firm with a booster loan? We're not sure. But if anyone can help these poor, downtrodden, unqualified egotists back into the labour market - it's Mr John Barnwell. webTitle: Profile: Tory defector Ivan Massow

fields.headline: What's the story, former Tory?
fields.standfirst:
After Ivan Massow dumped the Conservatives for new Labour, Julian Glover looks beyond the hype to find the real reasons why

Defector quits 'intolerant' Tories
Special report: the Tories in opposition
fields.trailText:
Wednesday, 3.45pm: After Ivan Massow dumped the Conservatives for new Labour, Julian Glover looks beyond the hype to find the real reasons why.
Defector quits 'intolerant' Tories
Special report: the Tories in opposition
fields.body:
Time was when an escapee from one party to another counted as something special. These days the currency of political defection has been devalued, as Ivan Massow, the charming millionaire who's dumped William Hague for Tony Blair, is about to learn.

He won't be happy when he finds out. Massow's expressed reasons for leaving the party ring true to those who know him, but one can't help guessing that he's driven by more.

Not by a crude need for publicity - though his defection was timed, perhaps by new Labour, to match the start of the silly season - but by his nature. Massow has always has been one for adventures.

Foxhunter; chair of the Institute of Contemporary Arts; would-be Tory MP; backer of Jeffrey Archer's bid to be mayor of London; mate of William Hague and pioneer in the world of gay finance when bigger players stood shy, he loves nothing more than doing the unexpected. Joining new Labour as it loses its shine is par for the course.

That is not to say he is wrong about the canker within his old party or anything other than genuine in his distress over it. Under William Hague, Massow says the party has "become less compassionate, more intolerant and, frankly, just plain nasty".

The evidence is on his side: above all, in Hague's public support for the retention of section 28, an invalid and discriminatory piece of legislation so badly-drafted it has never been used in court.

As a gay man whose business makes money from other gay men, one can understand that he found this hard to stomach.

But Hague's backing for section 28 - driven, one hopes, more by pre-election desperation than conviction - has been public for some time. It was the cause of Shaun Woodward's decision to cross the floor of the House at the end of last year and it has been a source of fierce debate within the party ever since.

Nothing has happened recently to suggest that Hague's stance on the issue has become more extreme.

So why has Massow left now? Changing parties is a painful thing and one can sympathise with Massow's plea that he's only stayed a Tory for so long because he thought he might be able to reform things from the inside.

But has he left because he has given up hope of doing so - in which case he is wrong - or just because, in the age of Hague's uber-Conservatism, it isn't much fun being a Tory? One suspects the latter.

What puzzles is why Massow was a Conservative in the first place. He dined with William Hague and delighted Margaret Thatcher, but one wondered whether he didn't see it all as a bit of a giggle.

Massow did matter in the party, though not to the extent his new Labour friends now claim. While he remained he was a sort of Tory talisman, a sign that interesting and rich young people like him could still be Conservatives. In that, he put the party in touch with the era of cool Britannia.

But he was not a politician in any deep sense. Conservatism was an occupation for an able and genuine man with a curious ability to occupy himself.

He will now prove an enthusiast in the prime minister's cause and will no doubt be wheeled out at election time to shore up the gay vote for new Labour. In defecting he has been neither a hypocrite nor a coward. But neither has his leap been as traumatic as it is for those for whom politics is everything.

And new Labour won't keep him occupied. There are already too many oddities in Tony Blair's big tent for Massow to stand out for long. Expect another sensation soon from this bewildering individual.

webTitle: Humour them

fields.headline: Humour them
fields.standfirst: Nurture your child's innate sense of humour and he or she will be happy for life, says  Pete May
fields.trailText: Nurture your child's innate sense of humour and he or she will be happy for life.
fields.body:
Dads are often unfairly derided as "only ever playing" with their children, as if this was some inconsequential part of childrearing. OK, it might be the enjoyable part of parenting and mothers might be exhausted from doing more work than "traditional" dads, but let's not downplay humour. Nurture a child's sense of humour and they will be happy for life. A diet of laughter is just as important as one of organic vegetables.

They say that the roots of all adult humour can be seen in toddlers. Indeed, during her first two years, my daughter Lola enjoyed blowing raspberries, wearing silly hats and pants on her head, knocking me over and seeing me deliberately drop her football. Knocking over a brick tower I had painstakingly built was even better. The sound of family flatulence caused her to chuckle and exclaim "Daddy's bottom!" And she laughed at me dropping my trousers when getting dressed. From the material I used to make my daughter laugh, most comics could probably furnish an entire act at the Comedy Store.

The first time your baby roars with laughter is a memorable moment, up there with the first "dada". For Lola, it was a hint of danger that set her off. To disapproving looks from some mothers and right-on dads I used to take her buggy racing, running along park pathways, steering the buggy one-handed or shouting "Look, no hands!" as I allowed it to freewheel downhill. At other times I'd pretend to throw her through the window or startle her with a "Boo!" during a game of peekaboo. According to people-watching guru Desmond Morris, it's not just Lola who laughs in the face of fear. This, he says, is the principle of the "safe shock". The baby realises that the action stops short of being dangerous because it is performed by a trusted parent.

"The repeated discovery that the threat is not serious is such a relief, that it brings with it a special kind of joy - the joy of establishing that a fear is unfounded," wrote Morris in Babywatching. He adds that this is the whole basis, the very origin of adult humour. "The comments of the professional comedian are basically frightening, but instead of scaring us they amuse us because we know all along that this man making the comments is not after all a policeman or a politician but a comic."

Indeed there are many parallels. Certainly children share our adult love of toilet humour. "I've noticed that my two-year-old daughter Anna likes making her dollies fart," says London mother Rachel Mooney. An animal pooing at the zoo will create a buzz of excitement among young visitors - an elephant defecating in the water will cause the chuckle register to go off the scale.

"Certainly odd things are happening to their bodies," says Dr Nigel King, reader in psychology at the University of Huddersfield. "Nobody tells them the rules, they have to work it out for themselves by testing boundaries. There's also an element of establishing power, of asking: 'Can I get away with it?'

"Humour at this age is to do with contravening expectations or having a forbidden tone. Slapstick is a kind of violation. It's seeing someone of higher status or power than you having their dignity exploded."

As kids get older this can become more pronounced. Comic Helen Lederer has noticed an anti-authoritarian tendency in her 10-year-old daughter. "She likes institutional comedy, things like Dinnerladies. Anything similar to their world being undermined is funny to children," she says. "I think they like authority being challenged. The other day she said, ironically, to a nice young community policeman: 'You're doing a great job.' There's no such thing as respect, which I guess is similar to a lot of comedy. Although perhaps you shouldn't ask me as my daughter says I don't understand what's funny!"

Young children love order, but conversely, another thing that makes toddlers laugh is when we, the adults, slip up. It proves that they know the rules. "The funniest thing in the world for my daughter, who is just two, is me or her dad making a mistake," says her mum Becky Roberts. "The other night, I handed Clare a grey rabbit and said: 'Here's pink rabbit.' For hours afterwards she lay in her cot laughing out loud and saying to herself, 'Mummy said pink rabbit!' I suppose we must seem omnipotent or something."

Another common joke is the deliberate contradiction. My daughter now enjoys calling mummy 'daddy' or, when holding a piece of orange, insisting: "It's not an orange it's a Shreddie!" Recently when I asked her if she was my daughter she replied "No!" When I looked shocked she gleefully exclaimed "I'm funny!" She made her first wordplay when her mum asked me: "Can you put Lola's dressing-gown on?" "It's not yours, it's my dressing-gown!" declared Lola, followed by an endearing "Is that funny?" (If only Jim Davidson asked such questions.)

"In a way the deliberate contradiction is a child showing its mastery," says King. "They know it's not true and they know that you know it's not true. Humour is a good barometer of social understanding. For example, people with autism are very poor at understanding humour. They have very obsessive interests, they're very bright in narrow areas but have trouble interacting socially."

Nurturing our children's sense of humour is surely an essential part of good parenting. Whatever their problems in adult life, the ability to diffuse tension through laughter will help them. As veteran comedian Ken Dodd said recently: "There's a lot of childishness in my act - we're all born with a spirit of play. I call it the chuckle muscle. Watch a baby with a bit of paper pretending it's something else. We're all born with this wonderful imagination but unfortunately some people as they get older - perhaps it's the pressures of life - they lose their chuckle muscle. It dries up and drops off."

King certainly agrees with Dodd in the case of younger children: "You don't want to say 'we're going to have a joke lesson' to older children because they'd find it embarrassing. But in the younger years, yes, try and encourage it. Humour is closely related to culture, and understanding morality and social convention is linked to jokes. You need to know the rule that says that a man doesn't usually wear a dress to know that it's funny. Rule transgressions can be useful. It's clear where things are meant as a joke, so don't be over punitive as it's probably quite useful if it's mild, although obvi ously I wouldn't encourage swearing or serious rule transgressions."

As parents, it's also important to remember that we aren't that different from our toddlers. "Although we add new humour repertoires as we get older we don't lose all the other forms of humour, we don't stop finding basic things funny," says King. "The word 'bottom' is hilariously funny to young kids but most adults find bottom jokes funny too. In a way we're all stuck at three."
