webTitle: As nature intended?

fields.headline: As nature intended?
fields.standfirst: Jerry Hall is clearly happy to strip naked in front of her children. But many of us still feel uncomfortable about it.  Dorothy Rowe  reports
fields.trailText: Jerry Hall is clearly happy to strip naked in front of her children. But many of us still feel uncomfortable about it.
fields.body:
The news that Jerry Hall has invited her two teenage children to see her performing naked on the London stage, albeit for a few brief, dimly lit moments, has caused considerable consternation. No doubt the Hall children have often seen their mother naked, and quite possibly they are proud that their mother is still so magnificently beautiful, but for some parents the prospect of being seen naked by their teenage children fills them with horror. Countless teenagers find the thought of seeing their parents naked - or worse still, having their parents' nudity aired in public - shameful and repulsive.

Nowadays, most parents want their children to grow up feeling at ease with nakedness, avoiding all those feelings of prudery and shame which might destroy their chances of finding sexual happiness. All teenagers get embarrassed by their parents, but the degree of that embarrassment depends on the nature of their relationship. When problems arise it is not necessarily the naked body itself that causes distress so much as what it signifies.

Teenagers worry about sex, getting old and dying, and the sight of a parent's naked, ageing body can raise all these issues. In families where everyone respects each other's need for privacy and where difficult issues are openly discussed, each person can discover what the others find intrusive and embarrassing and refrain from doing it. But in families where the parents have not respected the child's need for privacy and where sex, old age and death are still taboo, nudity can be a serious issue.

Nakedness was never revealed in my family. My parents were born in the Victorian era, so they regarded nudity as sinful and appropriate only when one was alone bathing or dressing. At least I did not have to cover the mirror in the bathroom when I had a shower, as well-brought-up Catholic girls were required to do. The current media obsession with nudity could persuade a visiting Martian that an acceptance of nudity was now the norm, but in fact we are as troubled by nakedness as my parents were.

Nakedness amounts to more than not wearing clothes. It always involves being held in our own gaze, and perhaps in the gaze of others, and as a result our sense of being an acceptable person can be called into question. Nakedness renders us vulnerable. The flesh of the young and the beautiful is revealed, while that of the old and the ugly must be decently covered. With our bodies we define our own sense of personal space, and when someone intrudes into that space - by coming too close, by touching us, by commenting on us, or simply by gazing at us - we feel threatened.

Parents have to recognise that there is a fine line between being open about nakedness and intruding into their child's precious sense of personal privacy. When my friend Kevin and his 10-year-old son Kieran were staying with me, the matter of Kieran having a much-needed bath arose. Kevin is a very wise and experienced child psychologist, so I was interested to see how he dealt with a boy who had reached the age where bodily accretions of dirt become impervious to water. A 10-year-old boy can emerge from a bath looking exactly as he did when he got in.

A parent who believes in a frank and hearty approach to nakedness might ignore his son's protests at being intruded upon and insist on helping with the scrubbing, but Kevin merely offered encouragement through the closed bathroom door: "Okay, then?" and "You might give your neck a bit of a rub." As much as Kevin would like his son to be glowingly clean, he regards a child's need for privacy as more important than society's expectation of a high standard of cleanliness. Kevin has always discussed sex with Kieran as the need arose, and death is something they talk about a lot now because Kevin's wife Hilary died not long ago. Consequently I suspect that when Kieran becomes a teenager his embarrassment with Kevin will amount to no more than some gentle teasing.

There are ways in which the relaxation of the rules about nakedness in the home have allowed some parents to overstep the boundaries to sexual behaviour which separate parents from children. The false memory debate, about adults remembering childhood instances of parental sexual abuse, was confounded by issues over just what was a sexual assault. Some of the accused fathers insisted quite rightly that they had never engaged in sexual congress with their daughter, but refused to acknowledge that their comments about their daughter's body, their intrusions into her privacy, and the way they looked at her were felt by the girl to be a sexual assault.

There is a great difference between the father who chances upon his teenage daughter going naked from bathroom to bedroom, looks at her as he would when she was fully dressed and says "Hi," or "If you don't hurry you'll be late," and the father who, unasked, enters the bathroom, sits on the edge of the bath while she is bathing and comments on her burgeoning bosom and sexual attractiveness, with the seething sexual gaze which, when undesired, terrifies every woman.

Nudity may be natural, but we have to be careful to avoid threatening children with it, making too much of it, or intruding into their own sense of privacy. In many families such dangerous intrusions are not so much physical as verbal, where conversations are riddled with relentless criticisms often directed at each others' bodies. One defence is to strive to be perfect. This defence can play quite a large part in the thinking of those young women who become anorexic or bulimic. Then, as people get older and the body sags, failing to resemble the Jerry Halls of this world or to match up to those unrealistic expectations of perfection only leads to misery, and being seen naked by one's more youthful teenager increases the torture. We have come a long way in ridding ourselves of the notion that nakedness is sinful and of the uncomfortable clothes which previous generations had to wear to cover their nudity, but we still have a long way to go in understanding what nakedness means to us.

Dorothy Rowe's latest book, Friends and Enemies, will be published by HarperCollins on September 11.

webTitle: Semi-detached reproduction

fields.headline: Semi-detached reproduction
fields.standfirst: Trying:  Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I hadn't noticed the sign on the door of the assisted conception unit before: "This is not the Early Pregnancy Unit nor the Delivery Suite." It certainly isn't. I had come for my egg retrieval operation. They'd discovered that my ovaries were so unusually high that they'd have to remove my eggs by inserting two large needles through my stomach.

I, of course, had carried my eggs in with me. But the sperm had to be produced. We live close enough to the hospital that my boyfriend could do "it" at home. "You'd have thought," he said, eyeing the narrow opening of the little plastic collection pot, "they'd have designed something better by now. Set Conran on to it." But I was appalled, embarrassed even, when the man with whom I've been living for years suggested that I joined in, that we turned "it" into a pleasurable moment. The cold medical procedure I'm going through is so dissociated from sex that the thought that they might be linked seemed shocking. It's like getting aroused about taking an aspirin.

A man's role in IVF treatment is not at all satisfying. It's up to the female partner to do everything. My boyfriend tried to become involved, asking me every couple of days if I'd remembered to sniff my Buserelin, or putting the needle in the syringe for my morning injection of FSH, but basically he was redundant, apart from this moment of producing the raw material. Perhaps that's why he wanted it to be special.

It's very lonely undergoing IVF. At the moment it's happening, it's practically impossible to tell anyone at all about it. Even in the waiting room there's no camaraderie. No one ever looks up towards another's eye. You just flick through old copies of Country Living, as if enthralled by the possibility of redesigning your patio, if you had one.

The very worst thing is knowing someone who's going through fertility treatment at the same time. I had a terror of meeting a friend, also having IVF at my hospital, in the waiting room. Perhaps they'd have already reached embryo transfer, when I wasn't sure I was going to have successful egg retrieval. It's not like sharing other intimacies about boyfriends, office troubles, illnesses even. It's an intense agony, with the faintest possibility of being followed by ecstasy. When I asked the doctor what chance I now had of getting pregnant she said around 40%, then corrected herself: "But it's either 100% or nil for you." She's right. There's nothing in between.

You'll find our fears and hopes in magazines devoted to infertile couples' tales of repeated attempts to have a child. These magazines are sore reading. One woman writes, after a failed IVF cycle in which she saw two embryos on a screen: "To help me cope I would like some acknowledgment, private and public, that my embryos were alive and were potential little people, but are no longer in this world. I would ask everyone who reads this letter to say a private goodbye to them, with a prayer if you are religious, to wish them well." The only comfort is in strangers.

I awoke from my egg retrieval woozy and with two plasters on my tummy. The nurse told me several times that they'd removed eight eggs. The knockout egg-retrieval drugs make you so forgetful that every patient repeats for hours afterwards: "How many eggs was it, then? How many?" The doctors seemed extremely pleased with my batch, adding that omnipresent "for your age". The average retrieval, I later discovered, is 10.

I staggered home, leaving my reproductive process behind me. Little bits of him and me were in dishes in a lab, as if it had nothing to do with us at all. The embryologist phoned the next day to say that all eight eggs had fertilised. I didn't ask if this was average "for my age". Soon there would be five or six cells in each dish. By the time it reaches eight, in a few days' time, they'll remove one cell from each to test for my chromosomal disorder.

I have nightmares about having a baby without a vital organ, or missing a head. When I wake in the morning, my boyfriend and I wonder how our dishes are doing.

leahwild@cswebmail.com

webTitle: Off the shelf

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child:   Ages 0-3:   Ages 4-7:   Ages 8-11:   Ages 12+
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child
fields.body:
Book of the month

The Seeing Stone by Kevin Crossley-Holland (Orion, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99 plus 99p p&p)

Caught on the cusp of one millennium and the next, living in an in-between place on the borders of England and Wales and caught between his own desires and the demands of those around him, young Arthur Caldicott sees both past and future in the strange black stone given to him by his father's friend, Merlin.

Crossley-Holland's novel, written in 100 brief chapters that are like tiny faded snapshots illuminating the past, may be set in medieval times but it has a remarkably contemporary feel as fantasy, history and Arthurian legend collide.

Almost the most enjoyable part of this dense, absorbing novel is the way it creates in detail every aspect of life and death in a medieval manor. But most of all, teenagers will identify with young Arthur, dreamer, poet and child on the brink of adulthood whose personal confusions and struggles to find out who he is and control his own destiny find him increasingly caught up with his namesake, King Arthur, the once and future king.

How to buy the books

Off the shelf is a monthly selection of the best new titles. It can be used in conjunction with the Guardian website (www.booksunlimited.co.uk) where you will find reviews of classic books to provide the backbone of a children's library. All the books can be bought directly from the website.

The titles below can also be ordered through the Guardian CultureShop at the discount indicated: freephone 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a UK cheque payable to The Guardian CultureShop, 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE. Please add 99p UK p&p per order.

Little Copy Cub by Catherine and Laurence Anholt (Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free)

Little Cub wants to be a grown-up like Big Golden Lion. So he becomes a copy cub, doing the things that big lions do. Hugging like Giggly Gorilla is OK, trying to fly like Round Brown Owl proves a bit of a mistake.

There are delicious pictures so cute you want to gobble them up, and a text that rolls off the tongue. But what really makes this book different is an interactive element - your little copycats are encouraged to copy little copy cub. This book is much too exciting for bedtime but perfect for those what-shall-we-do-now? moments and a reminder that the real pleasure of books has nothing to do with decoding text and everything to do with fun.

Through the Magic Mirror by Anthony Browne (Walker, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99, plus 99p p&p)

Toby is fed up and bored. His parents are either reading the paper or slumped in front of the TV. Then he walks through the mirror and is suddenly in a strange, surreal world where trees grow on top of buildings, dogs take their owners for walks, painters change the sky from day to night and flocks of choirboys fly overhead.

Browne's visually stunning book owes much to Magritte and Dali, but also has its own unique take on a world where everything is topsy-turvy, from the living room where Toby's parents appear all but dead, to the cat being chased by a gang of mice. This is one of those books that makes you view the world differently, and offers loads to discuss.

Do Not Read This Book by Pat Moon (Orchard, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 plus 99p p&p)

Finch lives with her mum, her adopted gran and the world's most intelligent rabbit, Graeme. She worries about her gran's smoking, the size of her chest, why God might be a she and whether she and her best friend will be in the same class when they start school. Most of all she is worried about Action Man, her mum's boyfriend.

This cunning little book captures the emotional intensity of being almost, but not quite, adolescent. Its diary format gradually reveals the manipulative possibilities of words and the way truth can be skewed. Girls who have read the complete Jacqueline Wilson oeuvre are likely to feel as passionate about this book as they do about transferable body art, saving the planet and beanie babies.

Dosh by Robert Swindells (Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free)

Child labour, exploitation and racketeering are the subject of Swindells' enjoyable novel that takes place in Britain here and now.

Most of the kids at Cottoncroft comp have part-time jobs, and they all know that 10% of their meagre earnings must be paid to Push, a gang of schoolkids controlled by small-time racketeer, Froggy Flitcroft. With the adults around them preferring to turn a blind eye, the teenagers find themselves pushed too far and start up a resistance organisation, Pull.

Swindells doesn't shirk from depicting the fear, bruises and the bloodletting as the kids seek justice, and the message is potent: stick together and maybe you will beat the bullies who make your life a misery.

Avocado Baby by John Burningham (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free)

New edition of 1982 classic that no household with children should be without. The Hargreaves are a family of weaklings and when their new baby arrives they fear it will also be weak. But when they start feeding it avocado pears, the baby gets stronger and stronger and is soon seeing off burglars and bullies. They have to put a notice on the gate saying: "Beware of the baby".

There is plenty of amusement for adults and children in Burningham's dead-pan tone, and there is something wonderfully liberating about a story in which the smallest member of the family is the strongest. The very least it will do is make everyone laugh and persuade the whole family to sample avocados.

The Hollyhock Wall by Martin Waddell, illustrated by Salley Mavor (Walker, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free)

Mary has no garden to play in so she makes her own out of an old cooking pot. She puts in a strip of blue ribbon for a stream, a bridge made from matches and paints a hollyhock wall around the rim of the pot. Then she makes Tom, a little boy of clay, to put in the garden.

Then, when Mary goes to bed, she finds herself in the garden with Tom. During a game Tom goes over the wall and out of the garden. Will she find him again? There are echoes in this strange, unsettling and enchanting story of classics such as Marianne Dreams, but it makes its own links between the conscious and unconscious, and Mavor's tactile collage-style illustrations cast their own spell.

The Doomspell by Cliff McNish (Orion, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 plus 99p p&p)

This is a gripping yarn about Rachel and her brother who are pulled through the cellar wall into a world ruled by the evil Dragwena, a witch with four sets of teeth when one would be quite enough.

What follows is a struggle between good and evil as the children find that they have unexpected powers and become the hope of all Dragwena's victims who dream of overthrowing her.

The writing is racy, not refined, and the situations and characters are familiar from every fantasy novel since Lucy went through the wardrobe and found Narnia. But no child to whom I have given it has complained; in fact, they have been fighting to borrow it.

Tightrope by Gillian Cross (Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free)

Ashley is quiet, independent and responsible, coping with schoolwork, a sick mother and living in a run-down community. But she releases the tension by taking risks. By night she is not dull, responsible Ashley but Cindi, graffiti artist extraordinare, whose daring exploits and ability to scale impossible heights are the talk of the town.

But somebody is watching her. She finds herself being stalked and discovers that you can't always be sure who your real friends are.

Well-written with a palpable sense of menace, it provides first-person commentaries at the end of each chapter in which the characters leave clues about their motivations. It provides a real bridge to adult fiction.

There are echoes in this strange, unsettling and enchanting story of classics such as Marianne Dreams, but it makes its own links between the conscious and unconscious, and Mavor's tactile collage-style illustrations cast their own spell. The Doomspell by Cliff McNish (Orion, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 plus 99p p&p) This is a gripping yarn about Rachel and her brother who are pulled through the cellar wall into a world ruled by the evil Dragwena, a witch with four sets of teeth when one would be quite enough. What follows is a struggle between good and evil as the children find that they have unexpected powers and become the hope of all Dragwena's victims who dream of overthrowing her. The writing is racy, not refined, and the situations and characters are familiar from every fantasy novel since Lucy went through the wardrobe and found Narnia. But no child to whom I have given it has complained; in fact, they have been fighting to borrow it. Tightrope by Gillian Cross (Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99, delivery free) Ashley is quiet, independent and responsible, coping with schoolwork, a sick mother and living in a run-down community. But she releases the tension by taking risks. By night she is not dull, responsible Ashley but Cindi, graffiti artist extraordinare, whose daring exploits and ability to scale impossible heights are the talk of the town. But somebody is watching her. She finds herself being stalked and discovers that you can't always be sure who your real friends are. Well-written with a palpable sense of menace, it provides first-person commentaries at the end of each chapter in which the characters leave clues about their motivations. It provides a real bridge to adult fiction.

webTitle: The panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: As a survey shows that over-eights have more say than ever in family decisions, we ask: are children being given too much influence?
fields.trailText: The Question: As a survey shows that over-eights have more say than ever in family decisions, we ask: are children being given too much influence?
fields.body:
Claire MacEvilly Nutrition scientist at the British Nutrition Foundation

It's encouraging to see that children are taking an active role in making food choices. But it's vital that parents still have a say, because it's no good for a child to be choosing chips five times a week - we all know that wouldn't be good for them. It's fine for parents to let children make the choice, as long as there's a real attempt to educate them. We know children's eating habits improve when they are taught about healthy eating, but the message has to be real to them - they need to know they'll look better and feel fitter now, not that they'll get cancer in 20 years.
Verdict: No

Richard Woolfson Psychologist and author of From Birth to Starting School

There's a difference between listening to what your children have to say, and giving them responsibility for making the decision. There's nothing wrong in asking their opinion - in fact, it's an important part of educating them in how to make decisions. But from what I've read, this survey isn't telling us whether children are being consulted, or are actually making decisions. If it's the latter, there is something wrong: family life isn't about giving power to the kids, it's about teaching them to develop strategies for dealing with what life throws at them.
Verdict: Possibly

Kate Calvert Editor of Family Travel magazine

I know some parents let their children make the decision about where to go on holiday, but I think giving kids carte blanche is a mistake. By all means let your children have a say, but make it within certain parameters: choose a handful of holidays you'd be happy with and ask for their views on which would suit them best. Just saying 'where do you want to go' opens the floodgates for a fortnight in a theme park, and who wants that? Listening to them is important, though - and serious objections need to be taken into account.
Verdict: Yes

Caroline d'Auria Mother of 10-year-old Charlie and Rowan, 19 months

When I was a child I wasn't given a choice about, for example, what I was getting for lunch, and it didn't do me any harm - in fact I think it was a good thing, and stopped children getting too fussy. I don't give Charlie choices over food - obviously I wouldn't cook anything he hated, but I don't ask him what he wants either. If you do that you're making a rod for your own back. Life is all about living within boundaries and knowing there are limitations, and if children don't get that message I don't think you're preparing them well for adult life.
Verdict: Yes

Kate Green Director of the National Council for One Parent Families

Lone parent families are among the poorest of all families, so for many there just isn't the option to give their children a choice about where to go on holiday, what car to buy or even what to eat. But they work hard to give their children a say where they can. They tell us that one of the hardest things about bringing up children on their own is not having an adult to share decision-making, but they know they have to tread carefully so as not to treat their children as substitute adults. They know there are some decisions that have to be taken by an adult.
Verdict: No

Michele Elliott Director of Kidscape, author of 501 Ways to be a Good Parent

The final decision on these issues must rest with the parents, and if the children are making them that's wrong. If it's a financial decision - such as where to go on holiday or what car to buy - then it seems only right that the parents make it, as they're the ones who are shelling out. If you're a parent, you sometimes have to make a decision that your children aren't happy with - and that's just life. Asking their views is one thing, but asking them to make big decisions at a young age is quite scary for them - they need guidance, and that has to come from you.
Verdict: Yes

webTitle: Chilean court 'votes to lift Pinochet immunity'

fields.headline: Chilean court 'votes to lift Pinochet immunity'
fields.standfirst:
Audio: Jonathan Franklin on how the news was leaked (2mins 05)
El Mostrador - site that leaked the news
fields.trailText: Chile's supreme court has reportedly voted to lift former dictator General Augusto Pinochet's immunity from prosecution in the country.
fields.body:
Chile's supreme court has reportedly voted to lift former dictator General Augusto Pinochet's immunity from prosecution in the country.

The decision, leaked in the Chilean press, means that the ageing despot may face trial in his country for political killings and other abuses committed during his 1973-90 dictatorship. The supreme court judges have refused to disclose their decision yet but legal sources suggest they voted 11-9 against the general.

Supreme court president Hernan Alvarez said that the judges had made a decision and would reconvene later in the week for a formal announcement, expected on Friday. Mr Alvarez had said that if there was a "compelling majority" the decision would be announced today, leading many to believe the margin is tight.

However, online newspaper El Mostrador said that the decision had gone 14-6 against the general.

The supreme court had opted to keep the verdict a secret, believing that one or more of the judges might change their minds before signing the verdict.

As a senator for life in the upper house of Chile's congress, Gen Pinochet has immunity from prosecution. Human rights lawyers claim that he should lose the protection because of his alleged involvement in a "death caravan" that slaughtered leftwingers after his forces deposed former president Salvador Allende in a coup in 1973.

webTitle: Older people will still have to pay for their long-term care

fields.headline: Mean, not meaningful
fields.standfirst: Older people will still have to pay for their long-term care
fields.trailText: Amid the generally positive reaction to the national plan for the NHS, a warier note has greeted the government's response to the report of the royal commission on long-term care.
fields.body:
Amid the generally positive reaction to the national plan for the NHS, a warier note has greeted the government's response to the report of the royal commission on long-term care.

Presenting this as part of the national plan for the health service overall could be said to illustrate genuinely joined up thinking. A less charitable, perhaps more cynical, interpretation is that the less-than-joyous news was tucked inside to deflect attention.

The costs of nursing care will be met by the state. That is good news, up to a point. But note the careful use of terminology: "nursing" care is not the same as "personal" care, which the royal commission recommended should be funded.

In deciding to fund nursing care, the government has removed some of the worst anomalies in the system, but left others intact. Far from removing the arbitrary boundary between health and social care, it has been firmly reinforced.

How does the definition of nursing care differ from that of personal care? The commission adopted a perhaps simplistic interpretation, regarding personal care as that which "directly involves touching a person's body". Such a definition would encompass nursing care, but crucially it went wider and also embraced care delivered by a range of people - health care assistants, personal care assistants, therapists, and so on.

The national plan definition, on the other hand, which restricts nursing care to the time a registered nurse "spent on providing, delegating or supervising care in any setting", plays tautological and semantic games but threatens to rule out vital areas of highly personal and intimate assistance routinely provided by a range of care staff not supervised by registered nurses. These would include providing help with bathing, dressing, using the toilet, managing incontinence and even with eating and drinking.

Some of the problems applying the definition in practice are immediately evident. In particular, who will decide whether or not a person has nursing care needs, and on what basis? There is by no means consensus on what assessment of need should be used, how it should be done, or by whom.

Beyond that, a new set of perverse incentives could be introduced into the system. At present, the split between residential and nursing homes is often fairly arbitrary.

Introducing a greater subsidy to those needing nursing care runs the risk of ratcheting up the level of assessed need, and rewarding homes for having more dependent residents. Far from resolving problems on the health/social care divide, moreover, it reinforces incentives for cost shunting between health and local authorities.

In other respects, the proposals are also mixed. Disregarding the value of a house from means-testing for up to three months could give some people the chance for recuperation and a return to their normal life. But three months may be inadequate, and rehabilitation will only work if there is the development of intermediate services and skills to provide the right support.

The three-month period must be more than just "a breathing space" (as the national plan puts it) to consider the possibility of returning home; people need to reacquire the independence and health that will allow this to be practicable. The skills and know-how to bring this about are not in abundant supply.

While a substantial increase in the capital limits used in the means test had been expected, there is to be merely a restoration to the 1996 value. Allowing people to hold on to a greater amount of equity could have been an important concession. There is evidence, however, that the best way to help the very poorest people in care homes would have been to raise significantly the personal allowance (the amount of income which people are allowed to retain as so-called pocket money) from the minimal £15.45 a week to at least £30.

It can be argued that this is essential in allowing people to retain dignity; to allow them to buy clothes when they need them, to buy personal toiletries and to continue to buy the gifts for their friends and family (particularly grandchildren) which are so fundamental to human relations.

It has been said that nobody will any longer be forced to sell their home against their wishes. This, too, would be good news if it were true. While new arrangements to introduce a scheme to release equity to older householders will in effect prevent the sale of a house during their lifetime, the house will still need to be sold at death to repay the loan.

So, on balance, what verdict should be offered on the plans for long-term care? This was never going to be an easy issue to resolve, and previous administrations shrank from taking unpopular and difficult decisions. To its credit, the government has attempted to put in place a compromise which removes some of the most glaring and unjust anomalies. But the core recommendation of the royal commission has been rejected, and that is a tragedy.

Melanie Henwood is an independent health and social care analyst

webTitle: The lack of sexual guidance for teenagers in care

fields.headline: Pregnant silence
fields.standfirst: The lack of sexual guidance for teenagers in care
fields.trailText: Everyone knows that teenagers in care have pretty grim prospects compared to other groups of young people. Not only do they face difficulties with education and employment, but research has shown they are more vulnerable than are their peers to sexually transmitted diseases and sexual exploitation. By age 16, one in four young women in care is pregnant.
fields.body:
Everyone knows that teenagers in care have pretty grim prospects compared to other groups of young people. Not only do they face difficulties with education and employment, but research has shown they are more vulnerable than are their peers to sexually transmitted diseases and sexual exploitation. By age 16, one in four young women in care is pregnant.

The government is trying to tackle the problem. It wants to cut Britain's overall teenage pregnancy rates - the highest in Europe - partly by increasing the information and advice on sex and relationships available to young people - especially to vulnerable groups including those in or leaving care.

But discussing sexual health and contraception with young people is a tricky business and evokes strong emotions. Last week, the House of Lords saw off the government's bid to delete clause 28 from the statute books. The clause which prevents local authorities "promoting" homosexuality also makes many staff feel they cannot talk to young people about any aspect of their sexuality.

When society at large ties itself in knots discussing sex, gay or straight, it is hardly surprising that those working with teenagers in care balk at the idea. But in Southampton, children's charity Barnardo's and the social services department have joined forces in an attempt to equip residential care home staff and foster carers to meet the sexual health needs of young people formerly and currently in the authority's care.

The "sexual health project" was set up in response to local research that revealed teenagers in care were putting themselves at risk. Project co-ordinator Jeanie Lynch, who led the research, discovered that young people in or leaving care had the youngest age of first sexual experience, the least access to sexual health information, no access to information on lesbian and gay issues, and that 68% never used condoms.

"Also many were only getting sex education from the people they were having sex with," says Lynch. "Depending on the dynamic of the relationship, that information could be OK or complete nonsense."

But it is not just finding out about sex from your peers that is the problem for young people in care. After all, the playground has provided sex education for years. Children in a residential unit may have been abused and the information they pass on may not be "healthy", says Mathew Airey, service manager for children and families at Southampton social services.

Constant disruptions may mean those in care miss out on sex education, Airey points out. They may have had multiple placements, and several social workers, and may have missed vital lessons at school. They may also suffer from a lack of role models or adults to trust.

One of the project's first tasks was to develop a sexual health policy for children in care. The team consulted care leavers to find out what information they would have liked when they were younger, and whom they relied on for advice.

The policy covers the legal and practical issues faced by staff and carers looking after children and tackles thorny problems such as how to work with under-16s, how to help young lesbians, gays and bisexuals, and how to talk about sex with young people who have been abused.

"If you've been sexually abused, mainstream sex education doesn't cut the mustard," says Lynch. "Sexual abuse skews young people's perceptions so staff have to be very sensitive when dealing with this group."

Also, young people have often witnessed domestic violence, or emotional abuse, and may need help to understand what constitutes a safe and understanding relationship. "We need to build their esteem and teach them that it's OK to stand up for their rights and say no to sex," says Lynch.

The policy deals with such sensitive issues that Lynch half expected the authority to throw its hands up in horror when the publication went to its social policy committee for approval. However, somewhat to her surprise, councillors were happy to approve it.

As corporate parents, local authorities are obliged to ensure young people have access to information and guidance on sex. In Southampton, staff and carers were aware of their obligations, but often at a loss as to how to broach the subject. "It is particularly difficult for those that have their own children. Not only do they face difficulties with education and employment, but research has shown they are more vulnerable than are their peers to sexually transmitted diseases and sexual exploitation. By age 16, one in four young women in care is pregnant. The government is trying to tackle the problem. webTitle: Despite cash for public transport, traffic remains a problem

fields.headline: Eyes fixed on the road
fields.standfirst:
Despite cash for public transport, traffic remains a problem

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: First the good news from the government's 10-year plan for transport. There will be serious money for the railways, driven by a strategic authority and long-term contracts which not even the Treasury can undo.
fields.body:
First the good news from the government's 10-year plan for transport. There will be serious money for the railways, driven by a strategic authority and long-term contracts which not even the Treasury can undo.

There is at last some sort of level playing field in analysing road and rail spending. The benefits of rail in terms of reducing road congestion and pollution are now taken into account. The government is also signed up to targets to increase the use of rail - 50% for passengers, 80% for freight.

There's more money for rural bus services, fuel duty rebate for community transport services and funding to bring buses back to poorer areas, supported by a target to increase bus use by 10%. Money is available for local road maintenance and for a range of local transport schemes: home zones, traffic calming, priority route networks for buses, pedestrians and cyclists, safe routes to schools, company travel plans and tram schemes.

The question is: will that spending go where it is meant to? For there is also more than a whiff of a return to road building. The money is there for 360 miles of trunk road widening, 100 bypasses and 130 other big local road schemes. Government models show that with that level of road building, congestion can be cut by 6%. This seems to ignore the extent to which new roads will generate new traffic, especially around black spots, and move congestion to the next pinch-points on the network.

Ministers have promised that roads will still have to be justified in the local transport plans of councils, or in studies that the government has set up to look at options for solving transport problems in particular areas.

By making it clear that money is available, ministers are likely to undermine attempts to find non-road building solutions. Councillors who have spent money and time lobbying for a bypass for Salisbury or Hastings, or the dualling of the A66 across the Pennines, are even less likely now to give serious attention to alternatives such as speed enforcement, bus priority or green commuter plans.

The 10-year plan, with its focus on big schemes, seems likely to sweep aside such small-scale projects. Councils and businesses will in practice focus on road projects rather than making streets fit for people, on speeding up traffic rather than bus priority, and on promoting car-based development near road junctions rather than making it easier to walk or cycle.

The plan emphasises cutting congestion and increasing mobility rather than dealing with traffic. It aims to cut congestion by 6% - but it is content to see traffic levels rise by 17%. The government view is that traffic levels don't matter - congestion and pollution are the problems to tackle. This ignores the fact that excess traffic severs communities and makes it more difficult for the old and the disabled to move around. People are less likely to walk and cycle or let their children do so if traffic levels and speeds are high. For many communities there is too much traffic now.

Ministers think that by holding out the carrot of road building and less congestion, they can keep motoring groups quiet. By doing so, they run the risk of new battles with middle England over old and destructive road schemes and over the failure to stem the rise in traffic.

Stephen Joseph is director of Transport 2000

webTitle: NHS: the legacy of contracting out

fields.headline: Dirty work
fields.standfirst:
Fines of £2m over the last three years have been levied against private companies working in the NHS

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Within three months of privatising its hospital laundry department, Basildon and Thurrock NHS trust in Essex realised it had made a big mistake. It quickly took steps to terminate the contract with the private cleaning company - and, in effect, levied a "fine" of just under £300,000.
fields.body:
Within three months of privatising its hospital laundry department, Basildon and Thurrock NHS trust in Essex realised it had made a big mistake. It quickly took steps to terminate the contract with the private cleaning company - and, in effect, levied a "fine" of just under £300,000.

The sum is believed to be one of the biggest penalties imposed on a private supplier of NHS ancillary services. For "legal" reasons, the trust will not explain why it cancelled the contract, or even who the contractor was. It will only say it withheld the cash because the company was "not meeting the contract requirements".

Nick Bradley, a regional official for the public services union, Unison, which represents staff at the laundry, believes the penalty was triggered by a collapse in service quality. He claims: "The laundry was not being delivered at the right time, or in the right quantity. In some cases the 'clean' laundry still had blood and faeces on it."

Zac Barratt, a director of Summit Group, was involved with Summit Laundry Services - now in liquidation - which ran the contract. He refused to discuss why the contract was cancelled. "I know why the contract was cancelled, but that's a matter for us and the trust," he said.

The Basildon case illustrates what many in NHS management are beginning finally to recognise: that privatisation is not a infallible cure for service inefficiencies; and that the relentless drive towards ever greater cost savings through contracting out has, in many cases, had a disastrous effect on service quality.

Recently, the NHS Confederation - trusts in membership of which have contracted out hundreds of millions of pounds of support services over the past 17 years - admitted that cost-cutting had directly led to the filthy NHS wards, dirty bed linen and inedible hospital food of public infamy. If the government's NHS modernisation plan was to work, it warned, the service would have to get the "basics" right. This meant providing clean wards, clean laundry, nutritious food for patients and proper training and personal development for support staff - even at the expense of "efficiency" savings.

Stephen Thornton, the confederation's chief executive, says: "In one hospital in the south-east, for example, there was an average of 131 duty hours available to clean each ward in 1982. Today there are only 70 hours. This is not untypical of the effect of market testing and reduced budgets."

A recent ministerial statement revealed that, over the past three years, private companies which have been contracted to provide support services to the NHS - including pharmacy and information technology, as well as ancillary services - have incurred more than £2m in penalties triggered by failure to meet performance standards.

The biggest group - just over a third - of the 63 penalties over that period involve ancillary services. These ranged from a £520 fine slapped on a private security firm by East Somerset trust, to £51,000 relating to a laundry contract let by Hinchingbrooke Health Care trust, Cambridgeshire.

A further 10 contracts for support services - mainly cleaning and laundry - at trusts across England were simply terminated, in the words of the minister, for "failure to perform to time or to standard".

In the case of Basildon, the trust claims it went through "a very detailed and robust tendering process" before awarding the contract to the company involved. It says: "The contract was awarded to them for all the right reasons - quality and value for money." Asked why its robust process evidently failed, a trust spokeswoman said: "Clearly we had no reason to believe they were not going to perform on quality and to standard."

The trust has confirmed that the laundry contract was subsequently awarded to the company that had offered the next lowest price in the original tendering process.

Nick Bradley doubts that trusts can afford to pay for quality: "There's a lot of verbiage talked about the commitment to quality," he says. "The problem is that there are such financial pressures, it [the tendering process] is driven by cost much more than quality."

Norman Rose, spokesman for the Business Services Association (BSA), which represents contractors in the support services industry, admits that NHS contracts have been bedevilled by what he calls "a stereotyped type of contract based on the lowest price". He believes that support services contracts are now increasingly geared to quality and that relationships between trusts and the private sector have improved over the past three years because there is a "better understanding of what each side is looking for".

Rose adds: "If over the last three years there have been only 50 to 60 contracts penalised, it shows that the public and private sectors are working well together."

Bradley believes that the 63 recorded contract penalties are the tip of the iceberg. In his experience, he says, trusts are notoriously bad at monitoring quality, and even when problems are identified, do not act. "It's got to be pretty dire before they do anything about it," he claims.

Rose believes that the cause of poor quality, particularly among contracted-out ancillary work, is low pay and poor working conditions. He says: "These services are highly labour intensive; the biggest area of expenditure is on labour. How do you get a quality service if you are spending less money on labour?"

The government's failure to stop privatisation of NHS support services has enraged health unions. Under the private finance initiative for hospital building, some £500m in service contracts has gone to private companies in the past three years, according to the BSA. Unions, if not all private contractors, are hopeful that imminent government plans to introduce new guidelines on contracting out - under the working title "better value" and based on the "best value" system in local government - will help put quality, rather than lowest price, centre stage.

This would squeeze contractors' profit margins even more. But Unison's national officer, Steven Weeks, believes it could force up standards - and not just because it might lead to more cleaning, catering and laundry services being brought back into the NHS.

"Where contractors can bundle together contracts [across trusts], there is still scope for them - especially if they are prepared to take a long-term view, rather than year-on-year savings," says Weeks.

"It will put contractors under a lot of pressure, but this will drive out the cowboys."

Broken trust

According to Hansard - the parliamentary record - penalties for failure to perform to time or to standard include £400,000 relating to a contract to provide agency nurses at St George's Healthcare trust, south London.

The trust refuses to confirm the figure or discuss why the penalty has been levied. Nor will it name the company that held the contract. It merely says "ongoing discussions" are taking place with the contractor.

Unofficial sources at the trust suggest that the contract related to supply of up to 200 agency nurses a day, at a cost of about £150 each, to St George's, which, in common with other hospitals in the south-east, has found it difficult to recruit enough staff.

The British Nursing Association, one of the largest nursing agencies, held a large contract with St George's during the period in question. Its managing director, Mike Horgan, confirms that it is "talking to the trust" about outstanding issues relating to the contract. But he says he knows nothing of any penalty clause. "We have never had a dispute with this trust in regard to quality or performance. We behave in line with the requirements of the contract."

Other penalties cited in Hansard include £461,000 paid out by an unnamed firm which ran an energy maintenance system at Havering Hospitals trust, Essex.

webTitle: Public Services:  Productivity  appraisal turns the tables

fields.headline: Leading questions
fields.standfirst: Public services have had a hard time from government. Now a tough appraisal turns the tables
fields.trailText: From the NHS to local government and beyond, ministers spent the last few days of the parliamentary session doing what they seem to like doing best: telling public service workers how better to do their jobs. Refreshing, then, that today they get a taste of their own medicine.
fields.body:
From the NHS to local government and beyond, ministers spent the last few days of the parliamentary session doing what they seem to like doing best: telling public service workers how better to do their jobs. Refreshing, then, that today they get a taste of their own medicine.

In a remarkably candid appraisal in a report by the public services productivity panel, Lord Simon, the prime minister's adviser on civil service reform, says the cabinet needs to show "more consistent leadership", focus on fewer objectives, improve delegation to junior ministers and set a clearer division of responsibilities between ministers and civil servants. "Synergy," he says, "can only be achieved with the help of visible, consistent leadership."

The sharp words from Simon, who has reportedly been urging Tony Blair to raise the government's game by setting up an inner cabinet, appear in an overview of the panel's work to date. The panel, established in 1998, brings together business and public sector leaders to "advise on ways of improving the productivity and efficiency of the public services and, in particular, help ministers achieve, and preferably outperform, their efficiency and PSA [public service agreement] targets".

Apart from Simon, a former chairman of BP, the 10-strong panel also includes John Mayo, finance director of Marconi, who was named last week as the telecommunications group's chief executive designate, John Makinson, finance director of media group Pearson, and Baroness Noakes, a partner in the accountancy and consultancy group KPMG, who, as Sheila Masters, was previously NHS finance director. They work to the treasury and have recently been asked to extend their role for at least a further two years.

Today's report, Public Services Productivity: Meeting the Challenge, says productivity in the private sector has been growing at about 2% a year. There are no comparable figures for the public sector because of the difficulty putting a monetary value on service outcomes, but if productivity in creased by 3%, public services would benefit to the tune of £6.3bn a year.

"Without freeing up resources to invest in priorities, public services will stand still, fail to meet user expectations and slow economic growth," says the report. "So productivity will be a deciding factor in the success or failure of our public services and our economy as a whole in the 21st century."

The panel's influence is hard to gauge, particularly as it stresses that it does not want its recommendations to burden services with the requirement of "a new set of action plans or reports". But some of its members are believed to have regular access at the highest levels of government and its thinking is reflected widely. As Blair said last week in his statement on the NHS national plan: "The best performers will be given greater freedom and flexibility and all will get access to additional funds tied to clear outcomes in performance."

Simon is believed to have had regular involvement in Downing Street discussions on development of the national plan. His observations in today's report will undoubtedly be read closely across Whitehall.

Culture change, he writes, is a marathon rather than a sprint. Improvement "will only be captured by intense commitment to change, both in the civil service leadership and through the system and in the government political management process". Change in the latter demands focused objectives - "there are currently too many and they change often" - as well as more consistent leadership by the cabinet, and clearer delegation to junior ministers, to define priorities for civil servants.

"The process by which cabinet government develops effective policy, and the civil service and executive agencies work to achieve improving results, is both complex and currently inadequately co-ordinated and reviewed," Simon declares.

The report sets out a performance management framework for the public services, based on five building blocks: "bold" aspirations, a coherent set of measures and targets, ownership and accountability, rigorous performance review and reinforcement - the latter to mean "real consequences at an individual level" for success and failure. Makinson, who has studied operations in the benefits agency, customs & excise, the employment service and inland revenue, has proposed a system of team bonuses for good performance and the report urges ministers to ensure managers have the necessary financial freedoms to act on his ideas.

According to Andrew Foster, controller of the audit commission, his fellow panel members from the private sector have been shocked at the tolerance of under-performance in public services. Foster himself led the panel's work on the quality of customer service in government transport agencies. Using "mystery shopper" techniques, he found that people had to try up to 20 times to get through to an inquiry phone line at the driver and vehicle licensing agency, merely to make a straightforward request. In another instance, information given callers was found to be inaccurate.

"Some would say that this is small beer," Foster writes, "but these are precisely the sort of problems that in the past have got the public sector a reputation for being too cumbersome and bureaucratic."

Foster says the panel has been struck by the dedication of most public service workers. "They were staggered at the extra 20% or 30% available from people for nothing, and they thought that kind of commitment was great. But on the crunch issue of failure and under-performance, they were surprised that there was not the kind of ruthlessness they were used to in the private sector."

Public Services Productivity is available free from The Public Inquiry Unit, Room 88/2, HM Treasury, Parliament Street, London SW1P 3AG, or at www.hm-treasury.gov.uk

The panel, established in 1998, brings together business and public sector leaders to "advise on ways of improving the productivity and efficiency of the public services and, in particular, help ministers achieve, and preferably outperform, their efficiency and PSA [public service agreement] targets". Apart from Simon, a former chairman of BP, the 10-strong panel also includes John Mayo, finance director of Marconi, who was named last week as the telecommunications group's chief executive designate, John Makinson, finance director of media group Pearson, and Baroness Noakes, a partner in the accountancy and consultancy group KPMG, who, as Sheila Masters, was previously NHS finance director. They work to the treasury and have recently been asked to extend their role for at least a further two years. Today's report, Public Services Productivity: Meeting the Challenge, says productivity in the private sector has been growing at about 2% a year. There are no comparable figures for the public sector because of the difficulty putting a monetary value on service outcomes, but if productivity in creased by 3%, public services would benefit to the tune of £6.3bn a year. "Without freeing up resources to invest in priorities, public services will stand still, fail to meet user expectations and slow economic growth," says the report. "So productivity will be a deciding factor in the success or failure of our public services and our economy as a whole in the 21st century." The panel's influence is hard to gauge, particularly as it stresses that it does not want its recommendations to burden services with the requirement of "a new set of action plans or reports". But some of its members are believed to have regular access at the highest levels of government and its thinking is reflected widely. As Blair said last week in his statement on the NHS national plan: "The best performers will be given greater freedom and flexibility and all will get access to additional funds tied to clear outcomes in performance." Simon is believed to have had regular involvement in Downing Street discussions on development of the national plan. His observations in today's report will undoubtedly be read closely across Whitehall. Culture change, he writes, is a marathon rather than a sprint. Improvement "will only be captured by intense commitment to change, both in the civil service leadership and through the system and in the government political management process". Change in the latter demands focused objectives - "there are currently too many and they change often" - as well as more consistent leadership by the cabinet, and clearer delegation to junior ministers, to define priorities for civil servants. "The process by which cabinet government develops effective policy, and the civil service and executive agencies work to achieve improving results, is both complex and currently inadequately co-ordinated and reviewed," Simon declares. The report sets out a performance management framework for the public services, based on five building blocks: "bold" aspirations, a coherent set of measures and targets, ownership and accountability, rigorous performance review and reinforcement - the latter to mean "real consequences at an individual level" for success and failure. Makinson, who has studied operations in the benefits agency, customs & excise, the employment service and inland revenue, has proposed a system of team bonuses for good performance and the report urges ministers to ensure managers have the necessary financial freedoms to act on his ideas. According to Andrew Foster, controller of the audit commission, his fellow panel members from the private sector have been shocked at the tolerance of under-performance in public services. Foster himself led the panel's work on the quality of customer service in government transport agencies. Using "mystery shopper" techniques, he found that people had to try up to 20 times to get through to an inquiry phone line at the driver and vehicle licensing agency, merely to make a straightforward request. In another instance, information given callers was found to be inaccurate. "Some would say that this is small beer," Foster writes, "but these are precisely the sort of problems that in the past have got the public sector a reputation for being too cumbersome and bureaucratic." Foster says the panel has been struck by the dedication of most public service workers. "They were staggered at the extra 20% or 30% available from people for nothing, and they thought that kind of commitment was great. But on the crunch issue of failure and under-performance, they were surprised that there was not the kind of ruthlessness they were used to in the private sector." Public Services Productivity is available free from The Public Inquiry Unit, Room 88/2, HM Treasury, Parliament Street, London SW1P 3AG, or at www.hm-treasury.gov.uk

webTitle: Opinion: Roy  Lilley on the NHS

fields.headline: Trapped in the twilight zone
fields.trailText: A visit to an accident and emergency department confirmed my worst fears. For all the fine words of the NHS national plan, for all the extra billions promised by the government, nothing will change unless reform starts with staff attitudes.
fields.body:
A visit to an accident and emergency department confirmed my worst fears. For all the fine words of the NHS national plan, for all the extra billions promised by the government, nothing will change unless reform starts with staff attitudes.

The A&E in question has had a £300,000-plus makeover. New furnishings, snazzy entrance hall, tasteful paint job. Same old lack of service. My friend had a cut finger. Not life threatening, but bad enough to need stitching. In the end, it involved seeing two nurses and a doctor. The process took two-and-a-half hours.

The nurse who first looked at the finger said: "Oh, nasty. I bet that hurt. You're going to need a few stitches." Would the nurse be carrying out the necessary embroidery? Oh, no. The rules required a doctor to see the injury first. So the wound was bandaged and the wait began.

Eventually another nurse removed the bandage and a doctor looked at the finger and said: "Oh, nasty. I bet that hurt. You're going to need a few stitches." The nurse prepared the needles and thread; the doctor stitched the wound. Then the nurse applied the final bandage. Tell me about NHS modernisation!

Why does our favourite public service live in the twilight zone? I can't think of any high street service that I would be prepared to wait two-and-a-half hours for. I can get a new exhaust on my car in 30 minutes. I can have my suit cleaned in an hour. I can have my eyes tested and get new spectacles made in under two hours.

What is it about the NHS that makes the staff, and the managers who run it, leave the real world behind when they come to work? They would be among the first to expose poor service elsewhere, yet they think nothing of the inconvenience to patients when admissions are cancelled, appointments overrun and clinics fail to start on time. They regard shopping at midnight as unexceptional, yet they resist opening primary care services at weekends.

The hallmark of successful service industries is a fanatical belief that the customer is the boss. But the NHS distances itself from its customers, fearing insatiable demand and the risk of litigation. It is the last remaining nationalised industry of its type, anywhere in the world.

The challenge is to get staff to bring their expectations to work, to create a culture of involvement and urgency and to regard professional demarcation - the kind that takes more than two hours to do five stitches - as the enemy.

Roy Lilley, a healthcare management adviser and a former NHS trust chairman, is the first in a series of guest opinion columnists

webTitle: DuPont attempts to influence anti-GM food campaigners

fields.headline: Sowing seeds of doubt
fields.standfirst:
DuPont attempts to influence anti-GM food campaigners

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: A leading GM company is trying to weaken a national campaign for a moratorium on the growing of GM crops in Britain by questioning whether some of the coalition's constituent organisations truly represent the views of their members.
fields.body:
A leading GM company is trying to weaken a national campaign for a moratorium on the growing of GM crops in Britain by questioning whether some of the coalition's constituent organisations truly represent the views of their members.

A UK representative of DuPont has sparked the behind the scenes row by attempting to persuade four of the largest and most influential partners in the five-year freeze to withdraw their support. The coalition, set up in February last year, now comprises over 100 national trade unions, religious, environmental, consumer and development groups, along with 500 local authorities and 100 companies. In total they represent over 3m people.

The coalition is calling on the government to introduce a freeze on the commercial growing of GM crops; on the imports of GM foods and crops and on the patenting of genetic resources for food and crops.

Now Unison, the Townswomen's Guilds, the Local Government Association and the National Federation of Women's Institutes have been approached by Martin Livermore, an external affairs manager for DuPont UK, asking them to stop supporting the freeze and join an alternative coalition.

He provoked an angry response by claiming that the rank and file members of these organisations might not really support the freeze. "I would ask you to consider whether this position at least truly reflects the opinions and best interests of your members," wrote Livermore to one organisation.

His letter added: "There is a common myth that there is overwhelming opposition to crop biotechnology and food derived from it in this country . . . I would urge you to reconsider your support for a campaign which has - in the absence of evidence - made up its mind, and seeks to prevent the general public coming to its own decision."

"These large membership organisations actually do have a very good democratic base for decision making," says Helena Paul, chair of the five-year freeze. All the organisations involved had consulted their members as to whether to join the freeze. In 1998 the Women's Institute conducted a survey on GMO's amongst its members and last year 8,000 WIs voted on a motion to support the freeze at its annual conference. Unison also voted to join at its national conference.

"The letter is based on insufficient knowledge and understanding of the issues," says a spokesperson for Unison, which has also published a report on GM crops and food production. "The report reflects our policy of support for the campaign, and a policy which is sceptical about the claims made by the GM companies about their technology.

Livermore is unrepentant. "We are not going to get acceptance of the technology without trying to build bridges. I feel it was worthwhile as an individual to make contacts to see if we could get dialogue going."

webTitle: RSPCA officers face an expanding caseload of abandoned horses

fields.headline: Born to be wild
fields.standfirst: Neglected and abandoned horses are now so common in Wales that boys ride them bareback around some estates
fields.trailText: High above Swansea city centre, on a piece of scrubland, a group of horses has been left to graze untended in the sun. Some of the animals are tethered. Some, including three tiny foals, are roaming free.
fields.body:
High above Swansea city centre, on a piece of scrubland, a group of horses has been left to graze untended in the sun. Some of the animals are tethered. Some, including three tiny foals, are roaming free.

It is the sort of scene - repeated elsewhere in the city and on common land in other parts of Wales - that haunts RSPCA officers as they seek to cope with an ever expanding caseload of abandoned and neglected horses and ponies across the country.

Elaine Spence, an RSPCA inspector based near the city, points to an untethered stallion among the group we are watching. It is, she says, a classic example of the problems they face.

As if on cue, the stallion begins to show an interest in a grey mare standing a short way off, a young foal by her side. Seconds later, the mare has been covered and the RSPCA inspector is left to contemplate the likelihood of at least one more wild horse being added to the equine population of a city in which young boys can often be seen riding bareback around the streets of some estates.

The local authority's environmental health officers collect and impound up to 20 free-roaming horses a month because of potential dangers to public health, including traffic accidents. Most are collected, despite the stiff penalties the council imposes.

But chief superintendent Kevin Manning, senior officer for the RSPCA in Wales, says the problem of unwanted horses is now reaching crisis point.

Indiscriminate breeding of the type we had just witnessed on waste ground in north Swansea is so widespread on mountains and common land where stallions have been turned loose that prices of horses and ponies are at rock bottom levels.

Some animals have been changing hands recently for as little as £1 each. That, in turn, is causing serious welfare problems as those who have been able to buy so cheaply balk at the expense of looking after their animals.

"People are not taking the long-term care of the animals into consideration when they buy them," says Spence, a former policewoman who joined the RSPCA 18 months ago.

"Horses are expensive to feed and keep. They need proper grazing and feeding and some form of shelter, but some people are even keeping them in their back gardens.

"The majority that we find abandoned have usually been on common land and on mountains where grazing is not as suitable as you would find on farmland."

Last year, the RSPCA in Wales took in more than 60 abandoned or ill-treated horses, double the previous year's figure. According to Manning, there is no sign of the problem receding. "There is a huge problem with over-breeding in some of the poorer parts of Wales and the signs we are seeing at the moment are very worrying. We can't ignore it and we have got to do something to turn the situation around. Neglect of horses has been a long-standing issue in Wales, but it has been thrown into sharper focus by the number of animals we have been taking in and by the fact that values have never been so low."

Finding a solution will be no easy task. But the society is considering a number of initiatives, including the possible introduction of a scheme to help owners with the cost of castrating stallions in a bid to control the problem of over-breeding.

Castration can cost around £100 and Manning recognises that those who have paid virtually nothing for a colt or stallion are unlikely to be prepared to stump up that sort of money.

The society is also liaising closely with local authorities in areas where lower standards of pony keeping are more common and is talking with national equine charities about the possibility of an "anti-worming round-up" to improve the condition of some untended animals.

The current problem, as the RSPCA acknowledges, is exacerbated by the difficulty it faces in identifying the owners of abandoned horses.

According to Spence, it is all too easy for those who have neglected or abandoned a horse or pony to deny any responsibility. "When horses go into a state of neglect and emaciation, owners are turning their backs on them," she says. "It's a great problem. We feel that people should be taking responsibility, but there is no system in place at the moment to identify ownership and it is very easy for someone to turn round and say the horse is not mine."

The depth of the current problem was best illustrated a few months ago, when RSPCA inspectors were alerted to the plight of two young foals found tethered to railings at Brecon market.

The foals - too young to be separated from their mother - had been abandoned at the market after failing to attract a buyer. With prices on the floor, the owner had apparently decided it was not worthwhile keeping them and continuing to feed them.

The task of looking after such cases falls to staff at the RSPCA's south Wales equine rehabilitation cente, where 40 horses and ponies are currently being cared for. Among the animals are 10 involved in four forthcoming prosecutions.

The stories behind many of the horses now being nursed back to health are distressing even to those used to rescuing neglected animals.

Two horses brought in recently were discovered in a barn; they were covered in lice and up to their knees in excrement. Both have recovered from their ordeal and there is a measure of satisfaction among staff that the owner was successfully prosecuted and banned from keeping any animals for five years.

One skeletal-looking mare currently being looked after at the centre is expected to take up to nine months to recover after being brought in in a severely emaciated condition.

Spence says that while the distress of seeing animals in such condition cannot be allowed to get in the way of carrying out her work, there is great satisfaction in seeing ponies recover and being re-homed.

That, she hopes, will be the outcome for the current star of the rehabilitation centre - a tiny foal named Maggot. The foal, then just a week old, was discovered last month by ramblers standing beside the dead body of its mother on hills outside Cardiff. It was carried by an inspector for two miles to the nearest road before being transferred to the centre.

The foal, now frisky and with a weakness for Polo mints, was so weak that staff were forced to stay up with it all night while it was kept on a drip.

"The mother was probably owned by somebody," says Spence. "But when something goes wrong nobody wants to know."

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Since my first encounter with Common Purpose three years ago, when my partner and I, both disabled people, were unable to access the programme's punishing timetable, I have always thought it unlikely to advance the cause of social justice very far.
fields.body:
Access all areas

Since my first encounter with Common Purpose three years ago, when my partner and I, both disabled people, were unable to access the programme's punishing timetable, I have always thought it unlikely to advance the cause of social justice very far.

Nothing I have heard or read since, including the grand claims and tales of individual catharsis (In for life, July 26), has altered my view that Common Purpose is not the common purpose of oppressed minorities; it is the common purpose of those with a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.

If redressing inequality was the agenda, rather than charging high-flyers hundreds of pounds to peer voyeuristically at the poor and disadvantaged, a much better idea would be to pay hundreds of pounds to the latter to look at how their (taxpayers') money is spent keeping them that way. I'm sure they would find the experience "so valuable".

It would at least be interesting to see to what extent the lives of disabled people might be transformed by shadowing charity sector fat cats - professionals with no interest in, or requirement to understand, the real needs and rights of their charities' beneficiaries. And social care tenants would leap at the chance to take a crash course in old-boy networking, spending time in the corridors of power to learn how contracts to provide social welfare services are won on the basis of relationships between those in the know - not on the basis of human and citizenship rights.

Throwing together disadvantaged people from diverse backgrounds would enable them to "forge links" and draw on each others' skills and expertise. With greater insight into what the commercial, statutory and voluntary sectors have in common (they look out for number one), oppressed people might start to rely on their own resources and strengths and begin to build real alliances with those truly in pursuit of equality. They could identify their own common purpose: to hold aspirations, to exercise choice and control in and over their lives, and to achieve self-determination.

Deborah Sowerby
Bristol

Service fault

David Starkey (Stark vision, July 26) reflects a distorted view of the manufacturing industry. While developing a customer-focused ethos is vital to the growth of successful businesses, this is not the same as developing a "service economy". Contrary to his view, wealth creation is caused by a vibrant engineering and manufacturing community. Service economies merely serve to recycle existing wealth, leading to stagnant economies, increasing poverty and unemployment. He mistakes the signs of a vibrant economy for its causes.

One just has to look at the explosion of confidence in cities like Glasgow, Manchester and Birmingham to see that their renewed optimism and expanding service sectors come off the back of a rejuvenated engineering base, serving the needs of modern society.

David Nicoll, senior careers development adviser
National Training Organisation for Engineering Manufacture, Watford

Potential damage

At a time when the government is about to launch a national recruitment campaign for foster carers, should we really be listening to those cynical people who should really know better (Time to get a life, July 26)?

I work for a recruitment advertising agency in Manchester on behalf of a number of local authorities in the north-west. The work we are undertaking in attracting more foster carers is finally starting to pay off, with inquiries from the public up from 100% in the past year.

Articles such as Jenny Sinclair's will ultimately put off potential carers and leave children who desperately need a loving and stable home environment with the prospect not pf a life, but of being passed from pillar to post, and ultimately being left on the shelf.

Stephen Kelly, account manager
TMP Worldwide, Manchester

Choice locations

In his article on social housing (End of "take it or leave it", July 26), Peter Hetherington says meeting the repairs backlog means driving through the transfer of council houses to other social landlords. Why does it mean this?

Later in the article, he supplies the answer: thus will new landlords be able to borrow on the open market to fund housing improvement programmes. But he does not mention that the only reason councils cannot do so is that they are prevented by government rules.

The convention at present is that in the UK (alone in western Europe), council spending is accounted as part of the public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR). But rules can be changed, and this one could be amended to allow councils to borrow on the market.

As regards Hetherington's assumptions about tenant choice, choice (meaning location, type of accomodation and style of property) is limited by resources, not by the quantity of social landlords. My council offers people a choice of place, size and design of property where possible, and also assists them to move to other council areas if they want. But we cannot guarantee to house them when they choose because we do not have enough houses. Financial constraints prevent us from building more.

We are more constrained still in helping people without homes, because we are not allowed to classify them as homeless on that account alone. People have to be "unintentionally homeless" before we are allowed to deal with them at all. That is a government rule, not ours.

Janet Mather, lead councillor for housing services
Vale Royal council, Cheshire
