Throwing together disadvantaged people from diverse backgrounds would enable them to "forge links" and draw on each others' skills and expertise. With greater insight into what the commercial, statutory and voluntary sectors have in common (they look out for number one), oppressed people might start to rely on their own resources and strengths and begin to build real alliances with those truly in pursuit of equality. They could identify their own common purpose: to hold aspirations, to exercise choice and control in and over their lives, and to achieve self-determination. Deborah Sowerby Bristol Service fault David Starkey (Stark vision, July 26) reflects a distorted view of the manufacturing industry. While developing a customer-focused ethos is vital to the growth of successful businesses, this is not the same as developing a "service economy". Contrary to his view, wealth creation is caused by a vibrant engineering and manufacturing community. Service economies merely serve to recycle existing wealth, leading to stagnant economies, increasing poverty and unemployment. He mistakes the signs of a vibrant economy for its causes. One just has to look at the explosion of confidence in cities like Glasgow, Manchester and Birmingham to see that their renewed optimism and expanding service sectors come off the back of a rejuvenated engineering base, serving the needs of modern society. David Nicoll, senior careers development adviser National Training Organisation for Engineering Manufacture, Watford Potential damage At a time when the government is about to launch a national recruitment campaign for foster carers, should we really be listening to those cynical people who should really know better (Time to get a life, July 26)? I work for a recruitment advertising agency in Manchester on behalf of a number of local authorities in the north-west. The work we are undertaking in attracting more foster carers is finally starting to pay off, with inquiries from the public up from 100% in the past year. Articles such as Jenny Sinclair's will ultimately put off potential carers and leave children who desperately need a loving and stable home environment with the prospect not pf a life, but of being passed from pillar to post, and ultimately being left on the shelf. Stephen Kelly, account manager TMP Worldwide, Manchester Choice locations In his article on social housing (End of "take it or leave it", July 26), Peter Hetherington says meeting the repairs backlog means driving through the transfer of council houses to other social landlords. Why does it mean this? Later in the article, he supplies the answer: thus will new landlords be able to borrow on the open market to fund housing improvement programmes. But he does not mention that the only reason councils cannot do so is that they are prevented by government rules. The convention at present is that in the UK (alone in western Europe), council spending is accounted as part of the public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR). But rules can be changed, and this one could be amended to allow councils to borrow on the market. As regards Hetherington's assumptions about tenant choice, choice (meaning location, type of accomodation and style of property) is limited by resources, not by the quantity of social landlords. My council offers people a choice of place, size and design of property where possible, and also assists them to move to other council areas if they want. But we cannot guarantee to house them when they choose because we do not have enough houses. Financial constraints prevent us from building more. We are more constrained still in helping people without homes, because we are not allowed to classify them as homeless on that account alone. People have to be "unintentionally homeless" before we are allowed to deal with them at all. That is a government rule, not ours. webTitle: A new roving police force is on trial in Lincolnshire

fields.headline: Flying squad
fields.standfirst: In response to fears of rising crime in rural areas, a new roving police force is on trial in Lincolnshire
fields.trailText: In response to fears of rising crime in rural areas, a new roving police force is on trial in Lincolnshire.
fields.body:
A new way of bringing assurance to rural areas, where village bobbies are rarely seen and patrol cars have to cover huge distances, is being successfully pioneered by Lincolnshire police. They are using a converted camper van for two-day and three-day visits to market towns to show people that the force is still with them.

The initiative comes amid fears of rising crime in a part of the country where locals, faced with a burglar or a poacher, sometimes take the law into their own hands.

Although Brian Ward's farm is within a mile of a market town with a police station, at Louth, it is isolated by dirt tracks and drainage dykes. When poachers turned up one night to hunt foxes - mesmerising them with a spotlight, then letting dogs loose - Ward reckoned police help would take too long to arrive. Instead of dialling 999, he tried to frighten off the trespassers with his air rifle. A warning shot hit one of them. In June, Ward was acquitted of unlawful wounding, though the judge said firing the gun had been an "extremely stupid" thing to do.

In another instance of citizen action, again questionable, two Kosovan refugees from a hostel in Skegness were apprehended breaking into houses in the village of Markby. According to one resident, they were "well roughed up" by the locals who caught them.

With police thin on the ground, as in many rural areas, Lincolnshire has become a vigilant county: it abounds with neighbourhood watches, car watches, farm watches. Around fenny Boston, where illegal coursing is rife, there is even a leveret watch, with 80 farmers protecting 50,000 acres and the resident young hares.

People living in small places lucky enough still to have a police station need to check the local paper for opening times, typically limited to a few hours a day. So it is in Louth and nearby Alford, which are among the places where the novel substitute for the beat bobby is being tried out.

Since the spring, with Home Office funding, a police camper van crewed by a sergeant and five PCs has been on a circuit of 10 market centres. Several other forces are interested in the project and its success will be analysed at a rural policing conference being hosted by Lincolnshire in November.

So far, the mobile unit operates only in the east of the county. However, Chief Superintendent Peter Davies, in charge of the east division, says the Home Office has been impressed and funds for 41 more officers have been promised.

"Most people assume Lincolnshire is a quiet backwater, and 95% of the time it is," says Davies. But along with the car crime, drugs and domestic disputes, there are big dramas. The only instance of a death caused by a letter bomb in the past 25 years, outside Northern Ireland, occurred not so long ago in Louth. Other offences fit more obviously with the profile of the area: rich, remote farm houses are targeted by thieves coming out from the inner cities; illegal immigrants from east Europe are supplied as cheap labour to local farms by unscrupulous gang-masters.

With redeployment and reorganisation, the east division faced a shortage of beat officers and a surfeit of unhappy villagers able to name their local bobbies of years gone by. There was no question of a return to a golden era of plentiful policing - whether real or imagined - but new thinking was needed. Hence the van. Davies says: "We were trying to provide reassurance to local communities, and tackle some of the crime and disorder problems which had a tendency to go by the board because of our other commitments."

The van was recently stationed for a couple of days in the market square in Alford. Before it arrived, team leader Sergeant Steve Bradley had phoned local councillors and scanned questionnaires distributed in post offices to find out what needed tackling: joyriders, said one woman, rowdiness outside a youth club said a shopkeeper. On a sleepy midweek afternoon, there was nothing more than a persistent car horn and a dog locked inside the vehicle; the situation was quickly resolved. That evening, though, officers would search the home of a suspected local drug dealer.

Bradley and his team work flexible hours: they are there if there is an early morning parking problem or working late at weekends if there is reported loutishness when the pubs close. What they provide, for two or three days every couple of months, is a degree of reassurance that small communities would like to have round the clock. But after the taskforce has gone, don't the problems return?

Davies says nobody is arguing that it is the same as having a full-time bobby. But because the task force is dealing with "persistent problems which can be sorted", it does make a difference.

There is no doubt that the taskforce is welcome: a bit of advice on locking the garden shed does not go amiss, neither does a warning to watch out for bogus salesmen. It is surprising how many Alford people, when asked, have been victim of petty pilfering, or witnessed incidents of violence. Grudgingly, they seem to realise it is now one of the perils of small town life.

And they seem to be accepting their role in an anti-crime partnership. Take that illegal hare coursing. Farmer Robert Caudwell says that the gangs which set their lurchers on the hares often intimidate farmers who try to stop them. There is big money involved: the "races", usually early on Sunday mornings, are videoed and shown in backstreet betting clubs.

The farmers accepted it was impossible for the law to catch the gangs red-handed in the vastness of Lincolnshire. So a group around Boston organised a rota and, armed with a camera and mobile phones, now patrols the area. With the evidence collected, the police are glad to bring offenders to court.

"The gangs seemed to think that the countryside was fair game," says Caudwell. Now, after the courts have imposed some heavy fines, that is perhaps a bit less the case.

Crime in the countryside

Crime in Lincolnshire is well below the national average and the county's police force was one of a minority recording a drop in the number of offences last year, according to statistics just published.

However, the rate of clear-up of offences in Lincolnshire slumped sharply last year from 40% to 28%. Three years ago, it was 46%. And the case of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer convicted of murdering a teenage burglar, has highlighted the vulnerability felt by many rural dwellers.

While the number of offences in Lincolnshire fell 1.1% last year, other shire counties did show increases: 4.0% in Norfolk, 8.6% in Suffolk and 9.2% in Bedfordshire.

In the wake of the Martin case, many rural dwellers said they no longer bothered reporting property crime. But the latest British Crime Survey, which should include non-reported offences, also showed burglaries less than half as common in rural areas as in cities.

webTitle: Councils are gearing up for referendums on elected mayors

fields.headline: Eyes on the prize
fields.standfirst: Councils are gearing up for referendums on elected mayors
fields.trailText: Ministers are already grandly calling it a new era for town and county halls. With the new Local Government Act finally on the statute book, the next 12 months could be the most exciting in the council chamber for quite some time.
fields.body:
Ministers are already grandly calling it a new era for town and county halls. With the new Local Government Act finally on the statute book, the next 12 months could be the most exciting in the council chamber for quite some time.

Authorities will soon be policed by a new ethical framework - overseen by a sleaze-busting "standards board" to crack down on junketing and worse - and will have additional economic powers. But all eyes will be on wider reforms that go to the heart of local democracy.

After the election of London's first mayor, England's big cities will shortly begin the task of organising referendums to test the concept of provincial mayors. The act lays the foundation for radical reforms in the way councils do business, formally sweeping aside old committee structures in favour of a cabinet style of civic government - preferably headed by an executive mayor, if local government minister Hilary Armstrong gets her way.

Approval of the legislation is a clear victory for the minister, who pressed ahead with a sweeping reform package in spite of the misgivings of her boss, John Prescott, who heads the sprawling Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. The deputy prime minister stated publicly that he was no fan of elected mayors.

With some big councils gearing up for referendums with varying degrees of enthusiasm, the dilemma facing Armstrong is when to hold the polls. Optimistic talk of a "big bang" exercise later this year is clearly wide of the mark. Next May, then? "Maybe," says the minister, "but I think the party will be so busy with a general election that decisions like that may have to come later."

So, realistically, we might be talking about autumn 2001 for referendum day in a selected number of cities - with actual mayoral elections in May 2002. With ministers desperate to avoid any repetition of the London selection debacle, Labour has decided that provincial candidates will be chosen by one-member-one-vote, with the discredited electoral college finally consigned to history.

"It will take us at least until the end of the year to get the secondary legislation in place," the minister says. "But there is activity in all but one of the big cities [Manchester]. That does not mean they are committed to an elected mayor, but it does mean that either the council, or the opposition, are saying they should have a referendum."

Armstrong cites the example of Newcastle upon Tyne, where officially the ruling Labour group seems to be against the mayoral concept (although some dissidents are already campaigning against the line) while still going along with the government's wishes. "They're saying: 'We don't believe a mayor is right for our city, but we know people want a referendum'," says the minister.

As well as being forced to drop plans to repeal Clause 28, as the price for the act's passage, ministers had to give ground to freedom of information campaigners. Two 11th-hour concessions were made: town hall cabinet meetings will have to be held in public; smaller district councils will be allowed to keep their old committees.

Armstrong says: "We now have a new era of local government . . . a framework which could take [it] into a new and different mould of being the civic leaders, very much working with people." Giving councils powers to promote local "economic, social and environmental well-being" could be far-reaching. "They will extend the scope of councils to work more closely together."

Critics are already pointing to one flaw in the new law: it will not, officially, give councils powers to raise money for new initiatives. However, some innovative authorities are no doubt already looking for ways round this problem.

webTitle: Partnerships set to improve social care

fields.headline: Two to tango
fields.standfirst:
Partnerships set to improve social care

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Plans for progressive merger of NHS and local authority responsibilities for social care were unveiled by Tony Blair last week in the national plan for the health service in England. But the outcome was not the "NHS takeover" that some in local government had feared.
fields.body:
Plans for progressive merger of NHS and local authority responsibilities for social care were unveiled by Tony Blair last week in the national plan for the health service in England. But the outcome was not the "NHS takeover" that some in local government had feared.

Ministers appear to be taking an evolutionary approach to strengthening partnerships between the NHS and social services departments, without downgrading the status of either. Even so, the evolution could be rapid: the first of a new generation of "care trusts" is intended to be in place by next year.

"In some parts of the country, health and social services are already working together extremely closely and wish to establish new, single, multi-purpose legal bodies to commission and be responsible for all local health and social care," the plan says.

The care trusts would be able to "commission and deliver primary and community healthcare, as well as social care for older people and other client groups".

The plan envisages a gradual and voluntary development of the care trusts in most parts of the country. But the small print includes a compulsory element in areas where services are deficient. "Where local health and social care organisations have failed to establish effective joint partnerships - or where inspection or joint reviews have shown that services are failing - the government will take powers to establish integrated arrangements through the new care trust," the document warns.

This looks like a big stick to drive through the first stages of integration in areas not yet making use of partnership arrangements under the 1999 Health Act.

The plan says: "In future, social services will be delivered in new settings such as GP surgeries, and social care staff will work alongside GPs and other primary and community health teams as part of a single local care network." This would facilitate joint assessment of patients' needs for health and social care and ministers want personal care plans to be provided on this integrated basis for all older people by 2002.

Compared with earlier speculation about social care services being handed wholesale to the NHS, the detail has come as something of a relief to many in local government.

John Ransford, head of social care, health and housing at the Local Government Association, says: "Given some of the doom and gloom that was around over the last few weeks, I think it's a reasonable outcome." Taken together with two aspects of the plan - local government's new scrutiny role in respect of the local NHS and the fresh emphasis on tackling health inequalities - the overall message was "pretty good".

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, says the joint working route is "consistent with the policies we have taken over the years" and will mean more effective, efficient services for older people. "It links them with transport, housing, education and wider social provision in ways that will continue to make the local authority contribution to their lives and welfare absolutely vital."

webTitle: A show tackling teenage health issues has won lottery cash

fields.headline: Dolls on drugs
fields.standfirst:
A show tackling teenage health issues has won lottery cash

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Punch and Judy shows may not exactly have paved the way for using puppets as agents of social change, but an innovative project by a West Yorkshire puppet theatre company to help local schools promote anti-drugs messages today receives a £276,000 lottery grant to tackle teenage health issues.
fields.body:
Punch and Judy shows may not exactly have paved the way for using puppets as agents of social change, but an innovative project by a West Yorkshire puppet theatre company to help local schools promote anti-drugs messages today receives a £276,000 lottery grant to tackle teenage health issues.

Drugs tsar Keith Hellawell has been among those to praise The Wright Stuff's drug awareness programme, Shot in the Dark, which is aimed at 13 and 14 year olds living in Kirklees. Research by the local health authority suggests that one in four 14 year olds has used illegal drugs, over a third are drinking alcohol once a week or more and a fifth are already smoking.

Shot in the Dark is the brainchild of 35-year-old Steve Wright, who set up The Wright Stuff in 1992 after doing a puppet show at his local summer fete. "Two old ladies knocked on the door one evening to ask whether I could do something for their fete, which was dead on its feet," he says. "When my wife and I got married, we visited India and had bought lots of puppets in Rajasthan, so I decided to put on a puppet show." Inspired by the positive response to the show, Wright quit his job as a landscape gardener to become a full-time puppet maker and master.

Two years ago, having established close links with local schools and community groups, Wright applied to the Home Office for a small grant to fund a drugs education pilot project. The result was Shot in the Dark, a travelling puppet show that uses Spitting Image-like characters such as Judge Dreadful and Buzz Lingo to present the issues surrounding drugs culture and young people. The performance takes the form of a game show, with the story line highlighting the costs - physical and financial - and the side effects of drug abuse.

"My character, Buzz shows the implications of getting a criminal record - risks to career or travel plans, for example," Wright says. Another character calculates that the cost of smoking until his mid-50s is £100,000 - equivalent to buying a house. "If you dissect issues like smoking from a financial angle, you get young people to look at them in a different way," Wright says.

Interactive workshops after the show enable young people to discuss the issues raised and to learn more. The doctor character shows his workshop how to put someone in the recovery position if they have collapsed, and talks about safe levels of water consumption related to misuse of ecstasy and LSD.

Teachers receive a follow-up pack, aimed at extending project work to cover related issues such as harm reduction and health. Students can also collect the set of Shot in the Dark character postcards, which all carry details of national and local drug helplines.

"Fourteen year olds aren't an audience normally associated with puppet theatre, but it's an engaging and flexible art form and the arguments are in the third person, so the audience isn't being lectured," says Wright.

Now in its second year, Shot in the Dark has already received financial support from local police and education services, including Kirklees community safety partnership. The lottery award, made by the New Opportunities Fund (NOF) under its healthy living centres initiative, will enable The Wright Stuff to extend the programme to older teenagers, tackling also bullying, racism, sexual health and relationships. These issues were highlighted by young people themselves in the feedback collected by the puppet company after performances. Based on working with around 25 schools in the Kirklees area, Wright estimates that 20,000 young people will have access to a performance each year.

The grant will also fund further support materials and external evaluation, which will involve a research study looking at young people who have been involved in the project and rates of school exclusion and drug treatment.

"We don't know for sure whether someone has refused drugs as a result of seeing the show, but feedback from young people and their teachers has been positive," says Wright. "When they are asked whether a puppet show is the appropriate way to deliver issues-based education, young people say that they enjoyed the show, that it made them laugh but also made them think."

Teachers have also responded favourably. "Young people are streetwise, so it's difficult to talk to them about drugs without sounding out of touch and falling into old-fashioned phrases like 'wacky baccy'," says Wright. "We come in from outside and our characters can say things that the teachers can't."

Today's lottery grant to The Wright Stuff demonstrates NOF's commitment to funding healthy living projects that are not just bricks and mortar. Launched in January last year, the £300m programme plans to create a network of healthy living centres and activities targeted at disadvantaged people and communities.

Another recent award was £6.4m to a joint project by the Countryside Agency and British Heart Foundation to encourage walking. The fund says it hopes to fund more projects like these. Its chair, Baroness Pitkeathley, says Shot in the Dark fits a brief for creative and innovative schemes to tackle health issues. "The project captures the imagination and uses humour and entertainment to convey very important messages that young people can immediately identify with and understand," she says.

Offering more young people access to these messages is Wright's next task. "When I was 15, I didn't know where to go for drugs," he says. "But today, young people know where the local dealer lives, know about drugs and hear what others who use them are saying. We're talking about those critical years between 13 and 18, and if someone sees the show and remembers what we were saying, they may just stay out of trouble."

Tempting fate

More than a quarter of all 15 year olds say they have used drugs in the last year, according to official figures. Almost all have used cannabis, with amphetamines and poppers (amyl nitrite) the next most common choices.

The findings come from an annual survey of more than 9,000 pupils in 340 schools, commissioned by the Department of Health from the Office for National Statistics. The research suggests that 12% of those aged 11-15 have used drugs in the last year. But while only 1% of 11 year olds have done so, the proportion rises to 28% at age 15.

Statisticians say the trend is one of small annual increases in drugs use among younger teenagers. Yet many young people seem to be resisting the temptation: as many as 34% of pupils aged 11-15 and 61% of 15 year olds, say they have been offered drugs.

The government is committed to cutting use by young people of drugs "which cause the most harm" by a quarter by 2005 and by half by 2008.

Last week, direct funding for drugs education and prevention programmes for young people was almost doubled from £63m this year to £120m in 2003-04.

webTitle: Founder and trustees at war over changes at Sue Ryder

fields.headline: At the crossroads
fields.standfirst: Founder and trustees at war over changes at Sue Ryder
fields.trailText: The Sue Ryder Foundation is the latest charity to suffer a bout of what the sector aptly, if unkindly, calls "founder member syndrome". Faced with a need to update, trustees and staff of the £37m-a-year organisation are smarting from an outspoken attack by Lady Ryder, who founded it in 1953 to care for long-term sick and disabled people.
fields.body:
The Sue Ryder Foundation is the latest charity to suffer a bout of what the sector aptly, if unkindly, calls "founder member syndrome". Faced with a need to update, trustees and staff of the £37m-a-year organisation are smarting from an outspoken attack by Lady Ryder, who founded it in 1953 to care for long-term sick and disabled people.

Ryder told the Sunday Times that ambitious trustees had hijacked the charity and betrayed its principles. She claimed to have been locked out of the charity's offices and forced to resign as a trustee while on an overseas fundraising trip two years ago. She also criticised a decision to "lavish" money on the charity's first offices in central London.

While paying tribute to Ryder's past contribution, Jane Nicholson, who chairs the charity's trustees, says: "I'm very saddened by her reaction." She fears that Ryder's strictures could harm the organisation at a critical time in its development.

The difficulty is that Ryder, widow of Group Captain Leonard Cheshire, is 77, in poor health and reluctant to accept that her personal, "hands on" approach is no longer appropriate. The foundation has grown to the stage where it is running 80 residential homes worldwide, with 500 charity shops to help fund them, and patently needs professional and modern management.

"She's done wonderful work, but she retired as a trustee in 1998 - she wasn't pushed," says Nicholson.

Several voluntary bodies are faced with a problem of an eponymous founder who insists on staying in charge, long after the organisation has outgrown their initial vision. Partings are not always peaceful, as the foundation has just learned.

The trustees thought that Ryder accepted the need for it to move on and, apparently, believed that with her increasing infirmity - Ryder is confined to her house in Suffolk - she was unlikely to make controversial interventions. But she was doughtier than they imagined.

Ryder may have been angered by the decision to move the charity's offices from her home to London. Nicholson says it was necessary for a body with a big turnover and a growing international role to have six staff in the capital.

The updating of the shops by professional managers also upset Ryder, who feared that the work of volunteers would be jeopardised. The charity says this is not the case, but argues that the shops were losing money and were run amateurishly.

But perhaps the most telling symptom of founder member's syndrome in this squabble is a planned autumn relaunch, after wide consultation. Nothing radical, says Nicholson, but the charity's work needs to be more focused. To that end, it will be concentrating on cancer and neurological cases, though not excluding other categories needing help.

The symbol chosen by Sue Ryder for the charity - a sprig of rosemary - will go in September after half a century's service. Nicholson declines to say what the new logo will be, but an olive branch is not thought likely.

webTitle: Keith Harper looks back at 25 years of trying to solve industrial conflict

fields.headline: When the chips are down
fields.standfirst: Ministers escaped endless nights of talks and fish suppers when Acas was born, initiating 25 years of trying to solve industrial conflict
fields.trailText: Ministers escaped endless nights of talks and fish suppers when Acas was born, initiating 25 years of trying to solve industrial conflict.
fields.body:
It was always evident when a strike was in the offing as Barbara Castle, then secretary of state for employment, would pop out to have her hair done. Her striking red hair had to look immaculate and she needed to put her best face forward.

During the subsequent few days, sometimes a week at a time, the television cameras and the media pack would squat outside her office in St James's Square, off Pall Mall in central London, while she struggled to prevent the nation from plunging into another economic crisis over a national engineering strike or a dispute involving the payment of an extra penny to 300,000 building workers. Yes, sometimes something as petty as that.

They were the far-off days, more than a quarter of a century ago, when the old ministry of labour traditionally acted as mediator whenever key pay negotiations between management and unions broke down and the national interest was supposedly threatened. Labour disputes were a familiar part of the industrial landscape, an almost everyday occurrence, and their progress was greedily witnessed by the media during countless day and night negotiations at St James's Square.

With both sides exhausted after endless nights of fish and chip suppers, Castle's chief spokesman would slip down to utter the immortal phrase - unacceptable and unthinkable today, of course - "Gentlemen, the Chinese electrician is at work." He meant there was a "chink of light" and the government had got a deal.

It was a situation that could not last. Successive ministers grew grizzled and grey in the job and Harold Wilson's incoming Labour government in March 1974 finally decided to act, having seen Ted Heath's Conservatives brought down by the miners after imposing a three-day working week. Thus was born the Conciliation and Arbitration Service - better known, after Advisory was later put at the front of the already clumsy title, as Acas - an organisation designed by Labour to establish an independent role that would remove the government from pay bargaining.

The first 25 years of Acas are recalled in a new book, Employment Relations in Britain, edited by Brian Towers and William Brown, which analyses the organisation's contribution to greater harmony and understanding in the workplace. The conclusion of Towers and Brown, professors of industrial relations at Nottingham Business School and Cambridge University respectively, is that Acas contributed significantly towards reducing labour conflicts.

Acas is one of the last relics of tripartite institutions set up by Labour under the Wilson government. Both the TUC and the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) put forward representatives who nominally reported to the employment secretary of the day. At the outset, ministers had some influence, largely due to the fact that Acas often had to operate within the limits of government pay policies, but over the years such external shackles have been removed.

Union leaders such as Jack Jones, of the transport workers, and Bill Simpson, a Labour Party chairman, were among those instrumental in setting up Acas. Its chairmen have been an ex-civil servant, a union leader, and several captains of industry, all renowned for their patience and industrial sagacity. They have included Pat Lowry, former head of personnel at British Leyland, and, more recently, John Hougham, who held a similar post at Ford.

In the early days, Acas occupied up-market offices in St James's Square. Then it was moved to new quarters in the National Coal Board (NCB), opposite the gardens of Buckingham Palace. It currently occupies more modest premises near London Bridge. Ironically, when it arrived at the NCB, it took over the coffin-shaped Room 16 - scene of countless showdowns between the board and the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM). It was the room where Sir Ian MacGregor, appointed by Margaret Thatcher as NCB chairman to bring down the NUM, confronted union president Arthur Scargill across the table, deliberately sparking the year-long miners' strike of 1984-85.

During that historic strike, Acas was used by both sides to try to engineer a settlement. Its failure to end the misery of tens of thousands of miners, hastening the collapse of the coal industry, was the fault not of its conciliators, but of the intransigence of the government of the day. Thatcher instructed MacGregor not to settle - and an astonished nation observed the NCB's chairman escaping from Acas headquarters with a paper bag over his head in an attempt to look inconspicuous.

Today, it may seem difficult to understand the obsessive nature of the media's interest in industrial relations during the 1970s and 1980s. But strikes were front page news even after the birth of an independent force such as Acas. A little local dispute, or a train drivers' work to rule at London Waterloo, were often portrayed as national disasters and gave the impression overseas of a strike-happy Britain.

But Acas was always there, a safe pair of hands, offering sanctuary and common sense to those who called for help. In all the important industrial upheavals of the past decades, it has been a quiet backdrop to events which sometimes got dangerously out of control.

Nowhere was this more evident than the 1978-79 "winter of discontent" which eventually did for the Labour government of Jim Callaghan, presaging the arrival of Thatcher and her popular mandate to introduce union reform. Acas's lights burned long into the night while rubbish mounted in the streets and hospitals were picketed, all because a smiling Callaghan obstinately stuck to a 5% pay limit. In the middle of the mayhem, he returned to the country after a heads of government conference in the West Indies and was famously reported as asking: "Crisis - what crisis?" Within months, he had been dumped by the electorate, while Acas went on against the odds to survive the Thatcher years - albeit uneasily at times.

Since Acas was established, as Towers and Brown point out, strikes have tumbled from the highest to the lowest levels ever recorded in Britain. Coverage of collective bargaining has halved and union membership has fallen by more than a third. Yet demand for Acas's services is greater than ever. Its energies are now devoted more to anticipating industrial disputes at an earlier stage - conciliation in disputes not having fallen in line with strikes - and to conciliating in individual cases. The number of the latter has almost tripled since 1979. Moreover, Acas staff are as busy as ever in propagating sound practice at the workplace.

There may never again be any need for ministers to spend countless hours in crumpled suits, on a diet of fish and chips, waiting for that elusive chink of light. But "going to Acas" will continue to hold a special place in the lexicon of British working life.

Keith Harper was the Guardian's labour editor from 1975 to 1995. Employment Relations in Britain: 25 Years of the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service is published by Blackwell at £14.99 and is available from Acas on 01455 852225

webTitle: US arms project warning

fields.headline: US arms project warning
fields.trailText: American plans for a national missile defence system are strongly criticised today by MPs who warn it would have a profound impact on international relations and present the British government with an acute dilemma.
fields.body:
American plans for a national missile defence system are strongly criticised today by MPs who warn it would have a profound impact on international relations and present the British government with an acute dilemma.

Members of the all-party foreign affairs select committee call on ministers to voice the strong concerns felt in Britain about the national missile defence system (NMD), which critics claim will fuel an arms race.

The US project - which would involve upgrading of the Fylingdales early warning system and the US eavesdropping station at Menwith Hill in North Yorkshire - is opposed by Britain's European allies.

The MPs say there are apparently contradictory views of the project between the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence.

webTitle: Call If You Need Me: The Uncollected Fiction and Prose by Raymond Carver

fields.headline: Call If You Need Me: The Uncollected Fiction and Prose by Raymond Carver
fields.trailText: Chapter one: Kindling
fields.body:
Chapter one: Kindling

It was the middle of August and Myers was between lives. The only thing different about this time from the other times was that this time he was sober. He'd just spent twenty-eight days at a drying-out facility. But during this period his wife took it into her head to go down the road with another drunk, a friend of theirs. The man had recently come into some money and had been talking about buying into a bar and restaurant in the eastern part of the state.

Myers called his wife, but she hung up on him. She wouldn't even talk to him, let alone have him anywhere near the house. She had a lawyer and a restraining order. So he took a few things, boarded a bus, and went to live near the ocean in a room in a house owned by a man named Sol who had run an ad in the paper.

Sol was wearing jeans and a red T-shirt when he opened the door. It was about ten o'clock at night and Myers had just gotten out of a cab. Under the porch light Myers could see that Sol's right arm was shorter than his other arm, and the hand and fingers were withered, He didn't offer either his good left hand or his withered hand for Myers to shake, and this was fine with Myers. Myers felt plenty rattled as it was.

You just called, right? Sol said. You're here to see the room. Come on in.

Myers gripped his suitcase and stepped inside.

This is my wife. This is Bonnie, Sol said.

Bonnie was watching TV but moved her eyes to see who it was coming inside. She pushed the button on a device she held in her hand and the volume went off. She pushed it again and the picture disappeared. Then she got up off the sofa onto her feet. She was a fat girl. She was fat all over and she huffed when she breathed.

I'm sorry it's so late, Myers said. Nice to meet you.

It's all right, Bonnie said. Did my husband tell you on the phone what we're asking?

Myers nodded. He was still holding the suitcase.

Well, this is the living room; Sol said, as you can see for yourself. He shook his head and brought the fingers of his good hand up to his chin. I may as well tell you that we're new at this. We never rented a room to anybody before. But it's just back there not being used, and we thought what the hell. A person can always use a little extra.

I don't blame you a bit, Myers said.

Where are you from? Bonnie said. You're not from anywhere around town.

My wife wants to be a writer, Sol said. Who, what, where, why, and how much?

I just got here, Myers said. He moved the suitcase to his other hand. I got off the bus about an hour ago, read your ad in the paper, and called up.

What sort of work do you do? Bonnie wanted to know.

I've done everything, Myers said. He set the suitcase down and opened and closed his fingers. Then he picked up the suitcase again.

Bonnie didn't pursue it. Sol didn't either, though Myers could see he was curious. Myers took in a photograph of Elvis Presley on top of the TV. Elvis's signature ran across the breast of his white sequined jacket. He moved a step closer.

The King, Bonnie said.

Myers nodded but didn't say anything. Alongside the picture of Elvis was a wedding picture of Sol and Bonnie. In the picture Sol was dressed up in a suit and tie. Sol's good strong left arm reached around Bonnie's waist as far as it would go. Sol's right hand and Bonnie's right hand were joined over Sol's belt buckle. Bonnie wasn't going anywhere if Sol had anything to say about it. Bonnie didn't mind. In the picture Bonnie wore a hat and was all smiles.

I love her, Sol said, as if Myers had said something to the contrary.

How about that room you were going to show me? Myers said.

I knew there was something we were forgetting, Sol said.

They moved out of the living room into the kitchen, Sol first, then Myers, carrying his suitcase, and then Bonnie. They passed through the kitchen and turned left just before the back door. There were some open cupboards along the wall, and a washer and dryer. Sol opened a door at the end of the little corridor and turned on the light in the bathroom.

Bonnie moved up and huffed and said, This is your private bathroom. That door in the kitchen is your own entrance.

Sol opened the door to the other side of the bathroom and turned on another light. This is the room, he said.

I made up the bed with clean sheets, Bonnie said. But if you take the room you'll have to be responsible from here on out.

Like my wife says, this is not a hotel, Sol said. But you're welcome, if you want to stay.

There was a double bed against one wall, along with a nightstand and lamp, a chest of drawers, and a pinochle table with a metal chair. A big window gave out onto the backyard. Myers put his suitcase on the bed and moved to the window. He raised the shade and looked out. A moon rode high in the sky. In the distance he could see a forested valley and mountain peaks. Was it his imagination, or did he hear a stream or a river?

I hear water, Myers said.

That's the Little Quilcene River you hear, Sol said. That river has the fastest per-foot drop to it of any river in the country.

Well, what do you think? Bonnie said. She went over and turned down the covers on the bed, and this simple gesture almost caused Myers to weep.

I'll take it, Myers said.

I'm glad, Sol said. My wife's glad too, I can tell. I'll have them pull that ad out of the paper tomorrow. You want to move in right now, don't you?

That's what I hoped, Myers said.

We'll let you get settled, Bonnie said. I gave you two pillows, and there's an extra quilt in that closet.

Myers could only nod.

Well, good night, Sol said.

Good night, Bonnie said.

Good night, Myers said. And thank you.

Sol and Bonnie, went through his bathroom and into the kitchen. They closed the door, but not before Myers heard Bonnie say, He seems okay.

Pretty quiet, Sol said.

I think I'll fix buttered popcorn.

I'll eat some with you, Sol said.

Pretty soon Myers heard the TV come on again in the living room, but it was a very faint sound and he didn't think it would bother him. He opened the window all the way and heard the sound of the river as it raced through the valley on its way to the ocean.

He took his things out of the suitcase and put them away in the drawers. Then he used the bathroom and brushed his teeth. He moved the table so that it sat directly in front of the window. Then he looked at where she'd turned the covers down. He drew out the metal chair and sat down and took a ballpoint out of his pocket. He thought for a minute, then opened the notebook, and at the top of a blank white page he wrote the words Emptiness is the beginning of all things. He stared at this, and then he laughed. Jesus, what rubbish! He shook his head. He closed the notebook, undressed, and turned off the light. He stood for a moment looking out the window and listening to the river. Then he moved to get into bed.

* * *

Bonnie fixed the popcorn, salted it and poured butter over it, and took it in a big bowl to where Sol was watching TV. She let him help himself to some first. He used his left hand to good effect and then he reached his little hand over for the paper towel she offered. She took a little popcorn for herself.

What do you make of him? she wanted to know. Our new roomer.

Sol shook his head and went on watching TV and eating popcorn. Then, as if he'd been thinking about her question, he said, I like him all right. He's okay. But I think he's on the run from something.

What?

I don't know that. I'm just guessing. He isn't dangerous and he isn't going to make any trouble. His eyes, Bonnie said.

What about his eyes?

They're sad eyes. Saddest eyes I ever saw on a man.

Sol didn't say anything for a minute. He finished his popcorn. He wiped his fingers and dabbed his chin with the paper towel. He's okay. He's just had some trouble along the way, that's all. No disgrace attached to that. Give me a sip of that, will you? He reached over for the glass of orange drink she was holding and took some. You know, I forgot to collect the rent from him tonight. I'll have to get it in the morning, if he's up. And I should have asked him how long he intends to stay. Damn, what's wrong with me? I don't want to turn this place into a hotel.

You couldn't think of everything. Besides, we're new at this. We never rented a room out before.

Bonnie decided she was going to write about the man in the notebook she was filling up. She closed her eyes and thought about what she was going to write. This tall, stooped-but handsome!-curly headed stranger with sad eyes walked into our house one fateful night in August. She leaned into Sol's left arm and tried to write some more. Sol squeezed her shoulder, which brought her back to the present. She opened her eyes and closed them, but she couldn't think of anything else to write about him at the moment. Time will tell, she thought. She was glad he was here.

This show's for the birds, Sol said. Let's go to bed. We have to get up in the morning.

In bed, Sol loved her up and she took him and held him and loved him back, but all the time she was doing it she was thinking about the big, curly headed man in the back room. What if he suddenly opened the bedroom door and looked in on them?

Sol, she said, is this bedroom door locked?

What? Be still, Sol said. Then he finished and rolled off, but he kept his little arm on her breast. She lay on her back and thought for a minute, then she patted his fingers, let air out through her mouth, and went off to sleep thinking about blasting caps, which is what had gone off in Sol's hand when he was a teenager, severing nerves and causing his arm and fingers to wither.

Bonnie began to snore. Sol took her arm and shook it until she turned over on her side, away from him.

In a minute, he got up and put on his underwear. He went into the living room. He didn't turn on the light. He didn't need a light. The moon was out, and he didn't want a light. He went from the living room into the kitchen. He made sure the back door was locked, and then he stood for a while outside the bathroom door listening, but he couldn't hear anything out of the ordinary. The faucet dripped-it needed a washer, but then, it had always dripped. He went back through the house and closed and locked their bedroom door. He checked the clock and made sure the stem was pulled. He got into bed and moved right up against Bonnie. He put his leg over her leg, and in that way he finally went to sleep.

These three people slept and dreamed, while outside the house the moon grew large, and seemed to move across the sky until it was out over the ocean and growing smaller and paler. In his dream, someone is offering Myers a glass of Scotch, but just as he is about to take it, reluctantly, he wakes up in a sweat, his heart racing.

Sol dreams that he is changing a tire on a truck and that he has the use of both of his arms.

Bonnie dreams she is taking two-no, three-children to the park. She even has names for the children. She named them just before the trip to the park. Millicent, Dionne, and Randy. Randy keeps wanting to pull away from her and go his own way.

Soon, the sun breaks over the horizon and birds begin calling to each other. The Little Quilcene River rushes down through the valley, shoots under the highway bridge, rushes another hundred yards over sand and sharp rocks, and pours into the ocean. An eagle flies down from the valley and over the bridge and begins to pass up and down the beach. A dog barks.

At this minute, Sol's alarm goes off.

Myers stayed in his room that morning until he heard them leave. Then he went out and made instant coffee. He looked in the fridge and saw that one of the shelves had been cleared for him. A little sign was Scotch-taped to it: MR. MYERS SHELF.

Later, he walked a mile toward town to a little service station he remembered from the night before that also sold a few groceries. He bought milk, cheese, bread, and tomatoes. That afternoon, before it was time for them to come home, he left the rent money in cash on the table and went back into his own room. Late that night, before going to bed, he opened his notebook and on a clean page he wrote, Nothing.

He adjusted his schedule to theirs. Mornings he'd stay in the room until he heard Sol in the kitchen making coffee and getting his breakfast. Then he would hear Sol calling Bonnie to get up and then they'd have breakfast, but they wouldn't talk much. Then Sol would go out to the garage and start the pickup, back out, and drive away. In a little while, Bonnie's ride would pull up in front of the house, a horn would toot, and Bonnie would say, every time, I'm coming.

It was then that Myers would go out to the kitchen, put on water for coffee, and eat a bowl of cereal. But he didn't have much of an appetite. The cereal and coffee would keep him for most of the day, until the afternoon, when he'd eat something else, a sandwich, before they arrived home, and then he'd stay out of the kitchen for the rest of the time when they might be in there or in the living room watching TV. He didn't want any conversation.

She'd go into the kitchen for a snack the first thing after she got in from work. Then she'd turn on the TV and wait until Sol came in, and then she'd get up and fix something for the two of them to eat. They might talk on the telephone to friends, or else go sit outside in the backyard between the garage and Myers's bedroom window and talk about their day and drink iced tea until it was time to go inside and turn on the TV. Once he heard Bonnie say to someone on the telephone, How'd she expect me to pay any attention to Elvis Presley's weight when my own weight was out of control at the time?

They'd said he was welcome anytime to sit in the living room with them and watch TV. He'd thanked them but said, No, television hurt his eyes.

They were curious about him. Especially Bonnie, who'd asked him one day when she came home early and surprised him in the kitchen, if he'd been married and if he had any kids. Myers nodded. Bonnie looked at him and waited for him to go on, but he didn't.

Sol was curious too. What kind of work do you do? he wanted to know. I'm just curious. This is a small town and I know people. I grade lumber at the mill myself. Only need one good arm to do that. But sometimes there are openings. I could put in a word, maybe. What's your regular line of work?

Do you play any instruments? Bonnie asked. Sol has a guitar, she said.

I don't know how to play it, Sol said. I wish I did.

Myers kept to his room, where he was writing a letter to his wife. It was a long letter and, he felt, an important one. Perhaps the most important letter he'd ever written in his life. In the letter he was attempting to tell his wife that he was sorry for everything that had happened and that he hoped someday she would forgive him. I would get down on my knees and ask forgiveness if that would help.

After Sol and Bonnie both left, he sat in the living room with his feet on the coffee table and drank instant coffee while he read the newspaper from the evening before. Once in a while his hands trembled and the newspaper began rattling in the empty house. Now and then the telephone rang, but he never made a move to answer it. It wasn't for him, because nobody knew he was here.

Through his window at the rear of the house he could see up the valley to a series of steep mountain peaks whose tops were covered with snow, even though it was August. Lower down on the mountains, timber covered the slopes and the sides of the valley. The river coursed down the valley, frothing and boiling over rocks and under granite embankments until it burst out of its confines at the mouth of the valley, slowed a little, as if it had spent itself, then picked up strength again and plunged into the ocean. When Sol and Bonnie were gone, Myers often sat in the sun in a lawn chair out back and looked up the valley toward the peaks. Once he saw an eagle soaring down the valley, and on another occasion he saw a deer picking its way along the riverbank.

He was sitting out there like that one afternoon when a big flatbed truck pulled up in the drive with a load of wood.

You must be Sol's roomer, the man said, talking out the truck window.

Myers nodded.

Sol said to just dump this wood in the backyard and he'd take care of it from there.

I'll move out of your way, Myers said. He took the chair and moved to the back step, where he stood and watched the driver back the truck up onto the lawn, then push something inside the cab until the truck bed began to elevate. In a minute, the six-foot logs began to slide off the truck bed and pile up on the ground. The bed rose even higher, and all of the chunks rolled off with a loud bang onto the lawn.

The driver touched the lever again and the truck bed went back to its normal place. Then he revved his engine, honked, and drove away.

What are you going to do with that wood out there? Myers asked Sol that night. Sol was standing at the stove frying smelt when Myers surprised him by coming into the kitchen. Bonnie was in the shower. Myers could hear the water running.

Why, I'm going to saw it up and stack it, if I can find the time between now and September. I'd like to do it before the rain starts.

Maybe I could dc it for you, Myers said.

You ever cut wood before? Sol said. He'd taken the frying pan off the stove and was wiping the fingers of his left hand with a paper towel. I couldn't pay you anything for doing it. It's something I was going to do anyway. Just as soon as I get a weekend to my name.

I'll do it, Myers said. I can use the exercise.

You know how to use a power saw? And an ax and a maul?

You can show me, Myers said. I learn fast. It was important to him that he cut the wood.

Sol put the pan of smelt back on the burner. Then he said, Okay, I'll show you after supper. You had anything to eat yet? Why don't you have a bite to eat with us?

I ate something already, Myers said.

Sol nodded. Let me get this grub on the table for Bonnie and me, then, and after we eat I'll show you.

I'll be out back, Myers said.

Sol didn't say anything more. He nodded to himself, as if he was thinking about something else. Myers took one of the folding chairs and sat down on it and looked at the pile of wood and then up the valley at the mountains where the sun was shining off the snow. It was nearly evening. The peaks thrust up into some clouds, and mist seemed to be falling from them. He could hear the river crashing through the undergrowth down in the valley.

I heard talking, Myers heard Bonnie say to Sol in the kitchen.

It's the roomer, Sol said. He asked me if he could cut up that load of wood out back.

How much does he want to do it? Bonnie wanted to know. Did you tell him we can't pay much?

I told him we can't pay anything. He wants to do it for nothing. That's what he said, anyway.

Nothing? She didn't say anything for a time. Then Myers heard her say, I guess he doesn't have anything else to do.

Later, Sol came outside and said, I guess we can get started now, if you're still game.

Myers got up out of the lawn chair and followed Sol over to the garage. Sol brought out two sawhorses and set them up on the lawn. Then he brought out a power saw. The sun had dropped behind the town. In another thirty minutes it would be dark. Myers rolled down the sleeves of his shirt and buttoned the cuffs. Sol worked without saying anything. He grunted as he lifted one of the six-foot logs and positioned it on the sawhorses. Then he began to use the saw, working steadily for a while. Sawdust flew. Finally he stopped sawing and stepped back.

You get the idea, he said.

Myers took the saw, nosed the blade into the cut Sol had started, then began sawing. He found a rhythm and stayed with it. He kept pressing, leaning into the saw. In a few minutes, he sawed through and the two halves of the log dropped onto the ground.

That's the idea, Sol said. You'll do, he said. He picked up the two blocks of wood and carried them over and put them alongside the garage.

Every so often-not every piece of wood, but maybe every fifth or sixth piece-you'll want to split it with the ax down the middle. Don't worry about making kindling. I'll take care of that later. Just split about every fifth or sixth chunk you have. I'll show you. And he propped the chunk up and, with a blow of the ax, split the wood into two pieces. You try it now, he said.

Myers stood the block on its end, just as Sol had done, and he brought the ax down and split the wood.

That's good, Sol said. He put the chunks of wood by the garage. Stack them up about so high, and then come out this way with your stack. I'll lay some plastic sheeting over it once it's all finished. But you don't have to do this, you know.

It's all right, Myers said. I want to, or I wouldn't have asked.

Sol shrugged. Then he turned and went back to the house. Bonnie was standing in the doorway, watching, and Sol stopped and reached his arm around Bonnie, and they both looked at Myers.

Myers picked up the saw and looked at them. He felt good suddenly, and he grinned. Sol and Bonnie were taken by surprise at first. Sol grinned back, and then Bonnie. Then they went back inside.

Myers put another piece of wood on the sawhorses and worked awhile, sawing, until the sweat on his forehead began to feel chill and the sun had gone down. The porch light came on. Myers kept on working until he'd finished the piece he was on. He carried the two pieces over to the garage and then he went in, used his bathroom to wash up, then sat at the table in his room and wrote in his notebook. I have sawdust in my shirtsleeves tonight, he wrote. It's a sweet smell.

That night he lay awake for a long time. Once he got out of bed and looked out the window at the mound of wood which lay in the backyard, and then his eyes were drawn up the valley to the mountains. The moon was partially obscured by clouds, but he could see the peaks and the white snow, and when he raised his window the sweet, cool air poured in, and farther off he could hear the river coursing down the valley.

The next morning it was all he could do to wait until they'd left the house before he went out back to begin work. He found a pair of gloves on the back step that Sol must have left for him. He sawed and split wood until the sun stood directly over his head and then he went inside and ate a sandwich and drank some milk. Then he went back outside and began again. His shoulders hurt and his fingers were sore and, in spite of the gloves, he'd picked up a few splinters and could feel blisters rising, but he kept on. He decided that he would cut this wood and split it and stack it before sunset, and that it was a matter of life and death that he do so. I must finish this job, he thought, or else ... He stopped to wipe his sleeve over his face.

By the time Sol and Bonnie came in from work that night-first Bonnie, as usual, and then Sol-Myers was nearly through. A thick pile of sawdust lay between the sawhorses, and, except for two or three blocks still in the yard, all of the wood lay stacked in tiers against the garage. Sol and Bonnie stood in the doorway without saying anything. Myers looked up from his work for a minute and nodded, and Sol nodded back. Bonnie just stood there looking, breathing through her mouth. Myers kept on.

Sol and Bonnie went back inside and began on their supper. Afterward, Sol turned on the porch light, as he'd done the evening before. Just as the sun went down and the moon appeared over the mountains, Myers split the last chunk and gathered up the two pieces and carried the wood over to the garage. He put away the sawhorses, the saw, the ax, a wedge, and the maul. Then he went inside.

Sol and Bonnie sat at the table, but they hadn't begun on their food.

You better sit down and eat with us, Sol said.

Sit down, Bonnie said.

Not hungry just yet, Myers said.

Sol didn't say anything. He nodded. Bonnie waited a minute and then reached for a platter.

You got it all, I'll bet, Sol said.

Myers said, I'll clean up that sawdust tomorrow.

Sol moved his knife back and forth over his plate as if to say, Forget it.

I'll be leaving in a day or two, Myers said.

Somehow I figured you would be, Sol said. I don't know why I felt that, but I didn't think somehow when you moved in you'd be here all that long.

No refunds on the rent, Bonnie said.

Hey, Bonnie, Sol said.

It's okay, Myers said.

No it isn't, Sol said.

It's all right, Myers said. He opened the door to the bathroom, stepped inside, and shut the door. As he ran water into the sink he could hear them talking out there, but he couldn't hear what they were saying.

He showered, washed his hair, and put on clean clothes. He looked at the things of his in the room that had come out of his suitcase just a few days ago, a week ago, and figured it would take him about ten minutes to pack up and be gone. He could hear the TV start up on the other side of the house. He went to the window and raised it and looked again at the mountains, with the moon lying over them-no clouds now, just the moon, and the snowcapped mountains. He looked at the pile of sawdust out in back and at the wood stacked against the shadowy recesses of the garage. He listened to the river for a while. Then he went over to the table and sat down and opened the notebook and began to write.

The country I'm in is very exotic. It reminds me of someplace I've read about but never traveled to before now. Outside my window I can hear a river and in the valley behind the house there is a forest and precipices and mountain peaks covered with snow. Today I saw a wild eagle, and a deer, and I cut and chopped two cords of wood.

Then he put the pen down and held his head in his hands for a moment. Pretty soon he got up and undressed and turned off the light. He left the window open when he got into bed. It was okay like that.
