We can reform the tax code, so that families can keep more of what they earn ...more dollars that they can spend on what they value, rather than on what the government thinks is important. We can restore the ideals of honesty and honor that must be a part of our national life, if our children are to thrive. When I look at the administration now in Washington, I am dismayed by opportunities squandered. Saddened by what might have been, but never was. These have been years of prosperity in our land, but little purpose in the White House. Bill Clinton vowed not long ago to hold onto power "until the last hour of the last day". That is his right. But, my friends, that last hour is coming. That last day is near. The wheel has turned ... and it is time...it is time for them to go. George W Bush will repair what has been damaged. He is a man without pretence and without cynicism. A man of principle, a man of honour. On the first hour of the first day...he will restore decency and integrity to the oval office. He will show us that national leaders can be true to their word...and that they can get things done by reaching across the partisan aisle, and working with political opponents in good faith and common purpose. I know he'll do these things, because for the last five years I've watched him do them in Texas. George W Bush came to the Governor's office with a clear view of what he wanted to achieve. He said he would bring higher standards to public schools, and he has. Walk into those schools today, and you will see children with better scores - classrooms with better discipline...and teachers with better pay. He pledged to reduce taxes, and he has. He did it twice, with the biggest tax reduction in state history. And not only is the budget in balance, it's running a surplus of more than $1bn. He promised to reform the legal system...to get rid of junk lawsuits - and he has. Today the legal system serves all the people, not just the trial lawyers. None of these reforms came easily. When he took office, both houses of the legislature were controlled by Democrats, and the house of representatives still is. But Governor Bush doesn't accept old lines of argument and division. He brings people together...reaching across party lines to do the people's business. He leads by conviction, not calculation. You will never see him pointing the finger of blame for failure...you will only see him sharing the credit for success. That is exactly the spirit that is missing from Washington. In the last eight years, that city has often become a scene of bitterness and ill will and partisan strife. American politics has always been a tough business - even in 1787 here in Philadelphia, when George Washington himself wondered if delegates could ever agree on a constitution. They did agree, as Americans always have when it mattered most - guided by the public interest and a decent regard for one another. But in Washington today, politics has become war by other means - an endless onslaught of accusation...a constant setting of groups one against the other. This is what Bill Bradley was up against, and others before him. The Gore campaign, Senator Bradley said, is "a thousand promises, a thousand attacks". We are all a little weary of the Clinton-Gore routine. But the wheel has turned. And it is time...it is time for them to go. In this election, they will speak endlessly of risk - we will speak of progress. They will make accusations - we will make proposals. They will feed fear - we will appeal to hope. They will offer more lectures, and legalisms, and carefully-worded denials. We offer another way - a better way - and a stiff dose of truth. For eight years, the achievement gap in our schools has grown worse - poor and disadvantaged children falling further and further behind. For all of their sentimental talk about children, Clinton and Gore have done nothing to help children oppressed by bureaucracy, monopoly, and mediocrity. But those days are ending. When George W Bush is president and I am vice-president, tests will be taken, results will be measured, and schools will answer to parents - and no child will be left behind. For eight years, Clinton and Gore have talked about social security reform - never acting, never once offering a serious plan to save the system. In the time left to them, I have every confidence they'll go right on talking about it. Those days are passing too. There will be no more spreading of fear and panic - no more dividing of generations against one another...no more delaying and excuse making and shirking of our duties to the elderly. George W Bush and I, with the united congress, will save social security. For eight years, Clinton and Gore have extended our military commitments while depleting our military power. Rarely has so much been demanded of our armed forces, and so little given to them in return. George W Bush and I are going to change that, too. I have seen our military at its finest...with the best equipment, the best training, and the best leadership. I'm proud of them. I have had the responsibility for their wellbeing. And I can promise them now - help is on the way. Soon, our men and women in uniform will once again have a commander-in-chief they can respect - one who understands their mission and restores their morale. And now, as the man from Hope goes home to New York, Mr Gore tries to separate himself from his leader's shadow. But somehow we will never see one without thinking of the other. Does anyone - Republican or Democrat - seriously believe that under Mr Gore, the next four years would be any different from the last eight? If the goal is to unite our country, to make a fresh start in Washington, to change the tone of our politics: can anyone say with conviction that the man for the job is Al Gore? They came in together. Now let us see them off together. Ladies and gentlemen, the wheel has turned, and it is time - it is time for them to go. This campaign will not be easy. Governor Bush and I face a real fight. We're ready for it. We know the territory, we know the opposition, and we know what's at stake. We will give all we have to this cause. And in the end, with your help, George W Bush will defeat this vice president, and I will replace him. Ladies and gentlemen, we are so privileged to be citizens of this great republic. I was reminded of that time and again when I was in my former job, as secretary of defence. I travelled a lot...and when I came home, my plane would land at Andrews air force base, and I'd return to the Pentagon by helicopter. When you make that trip from Andrews to the Pentagon, and you look down on the city of Washington, one of the first things you see is the capitol, where all the great debates that have shaped 200 years of American history have taken place. You fly down along the Mall and see the monument to George Washington, a structure as grand as the man himself. To the north is the White House, where John Adams once prayed "that none but honest and wise men [may] ever rule under this roof". Next you see the memorial to Thomas Jefferson, the third president and the author of our declaration of independence. And then you fly over the memorial to Abraham Lincoln...this greatest of presidents, the man who saved the union. Then you cross the Potomac, on approach to the Pentagon. But just before you settle down on the landing pad, you look upon Arlington national cemetery - its gentle slopes and crosses row on row. I never once made that trip without being reminded how enormously fortunate we all are to be Americans, and what a terrible price thousands have paid so that all of us - and millions more around the world - might live in freedom. This is a great country, ladies and gentlemen, and it deserves great leadership. Let us go forth from this hall in confidence and courage, committed to restoring decency and honour to our republic. Let us go forth, knowing that our cause is just, and elect George W Bush the 43rd president of the United States.

webTitle: Home on the stage

fields.headline: Home on the stage
fields.trailText: Former Hollywood child star Macaulay Culkin may be trying to resurrect his acting career with a performance on the London stage.
fields.body:
Former Hollywood child star Macaulay Culkin may be trying to resurrect his acting career with a performance on the London stage.

The Home Alone actor has auditioned for a leading role in the play Madame Melville which is to begin its run in October, says the Daily Express today.

Culkin, now 19, is in need of a serious hit to put his career back on track and believes this is the place to do it. Madame Melville, written by Richard Nelson, tells of a 16-year-old-boy who enjoys the amorous attentions of a 30-something French teacher. It is thought the play will be staged at either the Apollo or Albery theatres in the West End.

A production insider revealed that when Culkin's name was first mooted, "Richard was very reluctant because he's not exactly perceived as a serious actor and has hardly worked at all in the last five or six years but he auditioned last week and amazed everybody with his performance."

It is thought that 34-year-old French actress Irene Jacob, star of Three Colours Red and the Double Life of Veronique, has been approached to play the part of the French teacher.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's transfer news given a pat on the head and a bone to chew - we'll take them out for a walk later on
fields.trailText: Real Madrid want to get their hands on Thierry Henry and have offered Arsenal £25m and Spain striker Fernando Morientes. But Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein has insisted the French international is not for sale.
fields.body:
Real Madrid want to get their hands on Thierry Henry and have offered Arsenal £25m and Spain striker Fernando Morientes. But Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein has insisted the French international is not for sale.

Teamtalk today suggests that Middlesbrough are ready to offer Gareth Southgate a way out of Villa Park, although there is little in the way of evidence or facts to support their claim.

Celtic will finally make a concrete bid for Neil Lennon today. Martin O'Neill is expected to go back to his old club Leicester waving £8m, according to the Express. But the deal is not a shoo-in, because Aston Villa boss John Gregory is also interested in the Northern Ireland international. "I hope that I have got at least one more deal done by the time that we kick-off," he is quoted as saying on Teamtalk.

Aston Villa are about to sign German prodigy Thomas Hitzelburger, according to Teamtalk. The 18-year-old midfielder is set to shock Bayern Munich by leaving on a free transfer.

It's the latest news in the Christian Ziege to Liverpool story - please wake up. The player will decide if he wants to move "very soon", according to Bryan Robson. "It's a very difficult decision for Christian. He's not sure in his own mind what he wants to do and that's why he wants to keep tight," said the Middlesbrough boss, who will demand £8m for the German international.

Another man possibly leaving the Riverside is Brian Deane. Bradford are lining up a £2m bid after losing out to Manchester City in the race for Paulo Wanchope.

Wolves will offer Saudi Arabian champions Al-Hilal £2m for Sami Al-Jaber if the striker impresses in a friendly against Southampton on Saturday, according to the Sun. Al-Jaber will become the first Saudi player to play outside his country if the deal goes ahead.

Steve Archibald hopes to sign Hristo Stoichkov for Airdrie. Archibald suggested the move to the 34-year-old former Bulgarian international last week. "I can tell you he was very interested," Archibald insisted, "and this is not an old pal's act or a publicity stunt." However, shoud the deal go through, Airdrie fans will have to wait until December to see the former European footballer of the year turn out in the diamond shirt - that's when Stoichkov's contract with US club Chicago Fire expires.

webTitle: Play dough for M:I 2 star

fields.headline: Play dough for M:I 2 star
fields.trailText: Mission: Impossible 2 star Dougray Scott is the latest Hollywood actor to tread the boards at London's Donmar Warehouse theatre in a play to be directed by Sam Mendes.
fields.body:
Mission: Impossible 2 star Dougray Scott is the latest Hollywood actor to tread the boards at London's Donmar Warehouse theatre in a play to be directed by Sam Mendes.

The Scottish-born actor is to appear in To the Green Fields and Beyond, a play which centres on a British tank corps fighting in France during the first world war. He will play the role of Lt Childs.

Scott, who has just finished filming the spy thriller Enigma with Kate Winslet, will begin rehearsals today. The play is expected to open in late September and run until November 25th.

Mendes, who was named Best Director at this year's Academy Awards for his film directorial debut American Beauty, is renowned for his Donmar productions. His best known work there is The Blue Room which starred Nicole Kidman, whose performance was described by one theatre critic as 'Theatrical Viagra'.

Mendes had earlier made it clear that he wanted to return to the Donmar, where he is artistic director, before he directed another film but, according to Variety magazine, he has been working closely with Get Shorty writer Scott Frank on a script for a thriller called The Lookout.

webTitle: Ciao, bello

fields.headline: Ciao, bello
fields.standfirst: Everyone loved Marcello Mastroianni: movie-makers, their audiences and especially Catherine Deneuve. As the National Film Theatre prepares a major retrospective,  Tom Dewe Mathews salutes the much-missed Italian stallion
fields.trailText: Everyone loved Marcello Mastroianni: movie-makers, their audiences and especially Catherine Deneuve. As the National Film Theatre prepares a major retrospective, Tom Dewe Mathews salutes the much-missed Italian stallion.
fields.body:
He was 19, hiding out from the Nazis in a tailor's attic in Venice when he decided to make a bolt for it and take a night train from Mestre to the mountains in the north. "There was a threat of air raids," he remembered, "so trains travelled without lights. This train was packed with people crammed together and you couldn't see a thing. At one point I felt a female presence, a woman talking, perhaps, with friends. Despite the crush, being an inveterate smoker, I found a way of lighting a cigarette. And, as I lit it, it lit up my face. I was blinded by the light and didn't see who was opposite me. The woman came closer to me, brushed against me and we kissed... At the first stop, still in the darkness, the whole group got off. And I never knew who I kissed. In any case, the kiss was beautiful."

But not that surprising. Because the face that had been lit up belonged to Marcello Mastroianni, who would become one of the most romantic stars of post-war cinema. Nowadays, if you want to sum up Italian style, that sinuous Italian charm that is so easy on the ear and eye, then it's usually Mastroianni who comes to mind. In Italy they called him "Il Bel Marcello" and when he died nearly five years ago, the Trevi Fountain in Rome that he had made so famous in La Dolce Vita was switched off and draped in black crepe.

This month, however, Marcello is restored to us on celluloid with the screening of 22 of his films at the National Film Theatre. Yet not even this many movies can convey his full contribution to European cinema, since Mastroianni probably made more great films than any other actor. His breakthrough in the 1957 film White Nights also brought its director, Luchino Visconti, to world attention, and Mastroianni did the same for Antonioni in La Notte, as well as countless others such as Ettore Scola, Mario Monicelli, Marco Ferreri and the Taviani brothers. And that's just the Italian directors; he also worked with Roman Polanski, Louis Malle, Jaques Demy, Paul Ruiz and John Boorman.

However, the director with whom Mastroianni will always be associated is Federico Fellini, who regarded Marcello as a younger brother and cinematic alter ego. "He's gentle, open and intelligent," said Fellini. "He enters his character on tiptoes and never asks a question."

But the bond was not secured when they started work on their first film together, La Dolce Vita. Fellini had wanted to cast Paul Newman or almost any other big American star, while Mastroianni had a problem with being cast opposite the voluptuous Swedish ex-beauty queen Anita Ekberg, because she reminded him of "a Nazi soldier who arrested me during the war". Yet, against the odds, his role as a disconsolate observer of Roman consumption, egged on by Ekberg's pulchritude in the Trevi Fountain, was a triumph, to the extent that the film's title became virtually synonymous with post-war affluence.

And yet, though La Dolce Vita was responsible for reviving the fortunes of Italian cinema, the ever-ambitious Fellini persisted in trying to cast another big star - Charlton Heston or Laurence Olivier - as the lead in his next movie, 8 1/2. Mastroianni, meanwhile, set up camp in the foyer of Fellini's hotel, where he would nod and smile over his paper as the maestro passed by each day. Which is how he got the part, because, as the British director John Boorman points out, "Marcello did not insist, he did not protest, he did not plead. He was simply present."

Boorman, who directed Mastroianni in his 1970 film Leo the Last, adds: "I never felt the need to apologise to Marcello for making him wait during filming. He was the most relaxed person I've ever worked with. In fact, on Leo the Last, we were doing a scene where he was in bed and while we were altering the lights and lining up the camera, he fell asleep - just drifted off until we woke him up so that he could act being asleep again."

As Boorman remembers with obvious affection, "Marcello was such a consummate actor. He made your life so easy because he could find unlimited ways of expressing what you needed, and he did it with such ease. He'd arrive in the moring, put on his clothes and he would put on the character with the costume. Then he'd stay in character all day through lunchtime, when you could have put the camera on him. And then, when you called a wrap at the end of the day, he'd change back into himself and never give it another thought."

This is the key to Mastroianni's style, his apparently effortless acting. Though he was nearly always cast as the romantic lead, he approached every role as a character actor. As he explained, "With Fellini, there is usually nothing much to read but I read the script once, twice, three times, then I put it aside and never look at it again. I think about my character and start to creep up on him. The director can change the script but I'll still react in character - which is my job."

As with all his films, this searching out of a role came from an innate talent for observation. Boorman remembers how the character of Leo - "all his body movements and tics" - was based on "a prop man that we had. Marcello watched him all of the time and seemed to assume his shape." Sometimes, in the search for an object of imitation, his eyes would alight on his director, most famously Fellini on 8 1/2. He copied the cheek-sucking tic of Pietro Germi for that director's wonderful 1961 comedy Divorce Italian Style.

But for all Mastroianni's intuitive mimicry, his acting style was backed up by a solid technique learnt early in his career in Rome with a theatrical troupe led by Visconti. Here, over a 10-year apprenticeship, Mastroianni performed almost every classical role, from Astrov in Uncle Vanya to Stanley Kowalski in an acclaimed production of Tennessee Williams's A Streetcar Named Desire in 1952. There then followed another seven years working his way up from small roles in Italian movies, so that by the time he came to international prominence in La Dolce Vita, he was a 35-year-old screen veteran with over 40 films under his belt.

"There's so much behind that easy style," says Boorman. "So much depth, so much subtlety and sensitivity behind it. He was extraordinarily aware of everything. He's always thought of as this Latin lover type, but in fact he was really a very gentle, unassuming man. And then, of course, he had that charm."

That world-weary charm has now become so much a part of Mastroianni's image that it's almost impossible to disentangle it from the actual actor. But when pressed to define this quality, Boorman says it came from the fact that Mastroianni was prepared to reveal his vulnerability. "He made everyone feel sorry for him. I think women went to bed with him because they felt so sorry for him. They thought they could cure that melancholy, that overwhelming sadness that he had."

But then Boorman laughs as he remembers visiting him when he was living in Paris with Catherine Deneuve. "She had this beautiful modern apartment - glass tables, white furniture and chrome, that sort of thing. She went off to make coffee and as soon as she disappeared, Marcello turned to me and whispered, 'John, you have no idea what my life is like here. She is...' He gestured at the cool decor. 'So cold.' And then when she came back in he smiled sweetly, 'Aah, cara mia, grazie, grazie.' And there I was feeling sorry for Marcello because he had to live with the divine Deneuve."

But Boorman also believes that this all-embracing charm was touched by a Roman pragmatism that was bred into Mastroianni's bones. "He told me once about his father, who was a carpenter in Fontana Liri [a small town halfway between Rome and Naples] and how, when the fascists came to power in the 20s, they burst into his workshop in black shirts, shorts, the whole regalia. They banged on his workbench. "Are you a fascist?" they cried. "Are you a fascist?" His father looked up and said, "If you like."

Boorman thinks that this is "very much Marcello" and, after remarking that "everyone adored him," he claims that Mastroianni worked his magic by "taking you into his confidence. When he came over to do Leo, he said to me, 'John, it's a little embarrassing, but you know, in Italy it's necessary we have the contract.' I said, 'I know what you're saying - you need two contracts, the real one and the one to give to the taxman with half the amount.' 'It's a little more complicated than that,' he said. 'I need three - because the taxman knows we do this. So he comes to me and we argue and I cry. I say, 'No, no, this is the true,' and finally, finally, I pull out the other contract - which is still not the right one.' "

At the end of the day, Mastroianni had few interests outside cinema. He loved the companionship of making a movie, although he refused to lose any sleep over a film that did badly. In the end, he believed that everything was useful or, as he put it, "Tutto fa brodo" (everything makes soup). He didn't understand the myth of the suffering actor, the tortured soul unable to shed his character when he goes home for dinner. "Why do Americans find acting so difficult?" he asked Boorman. Then he supplied the answer, thus explaining why we will always love watching this warm, generous actor. "For me acting is like making love. While I am doing it I enjoy it, and when it is over, I hope I can do it again tomorrow." Grazie, bel Marcello.

The Marcello Mastroianni season starts at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), on August 6.

But for all Mastroianni's intuitive mimicry, his acting style was backed up by a solid technique learnt early in his career in Rome with a theatrical troupe led by Visconti. Here, over a 10-year apprenticeship, Mastroianni performed almost every classical role, from Astrov in Uncle Vanya to Stanley Kowalski in an acclaimed production of Tennessee Williams's A Streetcar Named Desire in 1952. There then followed another seven years working his way up from small roles in Italian movies, so that by the time he came to international prominence in La Dolce Vita, he was a 35-year-old screen veteran with over 40 films under his belt. "There's so much behind that easy style," says Boorman. "So much depth, so much subtlety and sensitivity behind it. He was extraordinarily aware of everything. He's always thought of as this Latin lover type, but in fact he was really a very gentle, unassuming man. And then, of course, he had that charm." That world-weary charm has now become so much a part of Mastroianni's image that it's almost impossible to disentangle it from the actual actor. But when pressed to define this quality, Boorman says it came from the fact that Mastroianni was prepared to reveal his vulnerability. "He made everyone feel sorry for him. I think women went to bed with him because they felt so sorry for him. They thought they could cure that melancholy, that overwhelming sadness that he had." But then Boorman laughs as he remembers visiting him when he was living in Paris with Catherine Deneuve. "She had this beautiful modern apartment - glass tables, white furniture and chrome, that sort of thing. She went off to make coffee and as soon as she disappeared, Marcello turned to me and whispered, 'John, you have no idea what my life is like here. She is...' He gestured at the cool decor. 'So cold.' And then when she came back in he smiled sweetly, 'Aah, cara mia, grazie, grazie.' And there I was feeling sorry for Marcello because he had to live with the divine Deneuve." But Boorman also believes that this all-embracing charm was touched by a Roman pragmatism that was bred into Mastroianni's bones. "He told me once about his father, who was a carpenter in Fontana Liri [a small town halfway between Rome and Naples] and how, when the fascists came to power in the 20s, they burst into his workshop in black shirts, shorts, the whole regalia. They banged on his workbench. "Are you a fascist?" they cried. "Are you a fascist?" His father looked up and said, "If you like." Boorman thinks that this is "very much Marcello" and, after remarking that "everyone adored him," he claims that Mastroianni worked his magic by "taking you into his confidence. When he came over to do Leo, he said to me, 'John, it's a little embarrassing, but you know, in Italy it's necessary we have the contract.' I said, 'I know what you're saying - you need two contracts, the real one and the one to give to the taxman with half the amount.' 'It's a little more complicated than that,' he said. 'I need three - because the taxman knows we do this. So he comes to me and we argue and I cry. I say, 'No, no, this is the true,' and finally, finally, I pull out the other contract - which is still not the right one.' " At the end of the day, Mastroianni had few interests outside cinema. He loved the companionship of making a movie, although he refused to lose any sleep over a film that did badly. In the end, he believed that everything was useful or, as he put it, "Tutto fa brodo" (everything makes soup). He didn't understand the myth of the suffering actor, the tortured soul unable to shed his character when he goes home for dinner. "Why do Americans find acting so difficult?" he asked Boorman. Then he supplied the answer, thus explaining why we will always love watching this warm, generous actor. "For me acting is like making love. While I am doing it I enjoy it, and when it is over, I hope I can do it again tomorrow." Grazie, bel Marcello. The Marcello Mastroianni season starts at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), on August 6.

webTitle: Israeli foreign minister resigns

fields.headline: Israeli foreign minister resigns
fields.standfirst: Government further weakened after peace talks row
fields.trailText: New elections are all but inevitable for Israel after the foreign minister, David Levy, resigned from the fractious coalition cabinet of the prime minister, Ehud Barak.
fields.body:
New elections are all but inevitable for Israel after the foreign minister, David Levy, resigned from the fractious coalition cabinet of the prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Mr Levy, a disaffected figure in Israeli politics well before his time in the present Barak coalition government, maintained that the prime minister had made too many concessions to the Palestinians at last month's Middle East summit brokered by President Clinton at Camp David. Although the summit failed, Mr Barak broke new ground by discussing possible compromises with the Palestinians over the future status of Jerusalem.

"I placed on the desk of the prime minister a letter of resignation, my resignation from the government," Mr Levy, 62, told a hastily called news conference.

As Mr Levy made his announcement, parliament began debate on legislation to call early elections. The opposition was expected to win a majority in a preliminary vote today, but the government is likely to carry on until at least October. Mr Levy refused to accompany Mr Barak to the Camp David summit. He said the prime minister had in effect agreed to division of Jerusalem, the city claimed by both Israelis and Palestinians as a capital. Mr Barak says he committed himself to no such thing.

But Mr Levy insisted: "At this summit, things were discussed that violated the basis on which we established our partnership." He was referring to the coalition deal he and Mr Barak made just before the May 1999 elections.

Mr Levy said he was "very, very worried" about the future.

webTitle: Israel's ultra-Orthodox fight skimpy summer clothes

fields.headline: Caught between Israel's big heat and the morality brigades' big cover-up
fields.standfirst: Halter tops and shorts in the streets of Jerusalem are prompting a modesty drive by ultra-Orthodox Jews, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: Halter tops and shorts in the streets of Jerusalem are prompting a modesty drive by ultra-Orthodox Jews, writes Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
The modesty patrols could not have chosen a crueller season. Seventy-two hours after temperatures in Jerusalem hit 41 degrees - the highest on record for more than a century - the saviours of the collective soul have decreed the real danger is not heat prostration, but sin.

Rarely have the streets of Jerusalem been filled with so many people wearing so little in an effort to beat the heat, and it seems that the guardians of religious mortality for the ultra-Orthodox are afraid for the sensibilities of their flock.

Despite the thermometer readings, ultra-Orthodox Jews have stoically maintained their year-round dress code. For men, this means black suits and hats every day of the week - with perhaps an additional layer of a long black silken overcoat, or a fur hat, for the sabbath and other festive occasions. For women, it is ankle-length skirts and long-sleeved blouses, heads covered and legs sheathed in tights.

Called Haredi - quite literally, "Those who tremble before God" - the ultra-Orthodox lead a life so self-contained as to be almost hermetically sealed. They live in enclaves where their neighbours are almost exclusively Haredi, and they send their children to religious schools. Contact with the outside world through television is banned, though they are allowed to use the internet under rabbinical supervision.

Their morality police are always alert against the dangerous influence of the profane world at the same time as they expand the parameters of their own.

And so it was that a few days ago, wall posters went up in some neighbourhoods in Jerusalem, delivering the Jewish equivalent of a Muslim fatwa - a religious decree issued by a cleric. It ordered the owners of clothing shops to cover up their mannequins; or better yet, decapitate them, lest passing ultra-Orthodox Jewish men be unduly titillated by the sight of a scantily clad shop dummy in the window

The anonymous modesty patrols, which prepared the posters, also banned the use by ultra-Orthodox women of shops that failed immediately obey the beheading command for all mannequins in their windows. They advised ultra-Orthodox Jewish women to buy only from a list of approved establishments, and to shun all other shops.

"Holiness obligates a kosher women to avoid going into clothing stores that have mannequins in the window, in order not to abet those who transgress," the posters read.

Perhaps it was that the self-proclaimed guardians of morality were pushed over the edge by such large legions of women appearing on the streets in shorts, halter tops, and slip dresses to try to counter the heatwave.

Or maybe it was the outright challenge from a woman riding a public bus in the religious Tel Aviv suburb of Bnei Brak. She had boarded a bus wearing a halter top, and sat clamly as the ultra-Orthodox passengers called her a whore and demanded the driver throw her off for offending their sensibilities. Then, when her stop approached, she took off her top. It took days for the ultra-Orthodox men aboard to get over the shock.

Across Israel, this is a summer where the effects of high temperatures and humidity are compounded by shortages of water and electricity, all of which adds to the discomfort level that gets people paring down their clothes.

Levels in the country's main reservoir, the Sea of Galilee have dipped dangerously low, and the power authorities have warned of system overload because of the heavy use of energy-guzzling air conditioners. Newspapers have had stories of deaths due to dehydration, and homicides due to shortened tempers.

But the ultra-Orthodox carry on in their sweltering garb. In Jerusalem, the influence of this Jewish community is growing. Thanks in part to a high birth rate, they are taking over parts of the city that were secular, imposing their old values on their new neighbourhoods.

The edict against clothing shops is merely the latest in a long line of such struggles, and Jerusalemites are so inured to the turf wars that the headless-mannequin campaign was covered in only one newspaper where it was relegated to the back page, between the weather map and the classified ads.

Secular residents of Jerusalem grumble that the ultra-Orthodox are destroying all hopes of modern life in the city.

They point out that women employed at the education ministry, which borders the Haredi stronghold neighbourhood of Mea Shearim, have had soiled nappies and rubbish hurled at them when they turn up for work in sleeveless tops. The ultra-Orthodox have also tried to enforce their dress code on Hollywood, and inanimate beings. A few months ago, advertisers withdrew a publicity campaign for the Disney film Tarzan from bus shelters, after ultra-Orthodox Jews complained that the jungle hero was only wearing a loin cloth.

webTitle: Comment: The decision on human embryos brings bleats from the religious right.

fields.headline: Getting sheepish on cloning
fields.standfirst:
The decision on human embryos brings bleats from the religious right

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The decision on human embryos brings bleats from the religious right.
fields.body:
This week the government gave the go-ahead for the cloning of human embryos. To illustrate this story the newspapers published the magnified image of a fertilised cell, prompting a flurry of calls from Downing Street to check that it wasn't an intrusively early photo of Leo Blair. The decision was announced by Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, and after a quick glance over the press release, journalists carelessly dashed off the surprising story "Sainsbury's to make human embryos available".

This was an announcement that has been coming ever since the birth of Dolly the sheep. Dolly, the first ovine clone, caused a media sensation a few years back, but has since rather failed to keep hold of the public's attention. She has just sacked her publicity manager and is now planning a relaunch as soon as she gets out of the Betty Ford clinic.

As soon as the concept of cloning human embryos was given the green light, the religious right started foaming at the mouth, while the producers of the Moral Maze simply passed out with the excitement. Opponents of these developments warn of a nightmare world in which whole groups of people would be exactly the same. It is almost impossible to imagine - benches of Conservative MPs, where they are all identical merchant bankers in their forties; WI meetings where the women are indistinguishable and hold exactly the same views; squaddies who all have the same physique, tattoos and moustaches. It doesn't bear thinking about. "God in his wisdom made each of us totally unique," said every single religious leader last week.

In the 1970s film The Boys From Brazil, it transpires that Nazi scientists have cloned a whole batch of young Adolf Hitlers whom they're grooming to become the new führers to take over the entire world, or failing that, the Lambeth Parking Permits office. The film was a sombre warning as to how science can go badly wrong, causing people to talk in unconvincing German accents and grow bizarre wonky moustaches. But who else might be recreated now that this technology is genuinely available? "The Girls from Grantham" has a chilling ring to it.

Perhaps in our lifetime we will be able to visit a historical theme park, where cloned figures from history will show us around: "Welcome to the Gettysburg Experience!" the clone of Abe Lincoln will say. "No photos please; if you want any souvenirs just ask Genghis Khan there in our gift shop." Perhaps Marilyn Monroe will be on the till if she's not locked in the store room with the clone of John F Kennedy. Of course any talk of the imminent cloning of humans to follow in the footsteps of Dolly the sheep is scaremongering and the cloning of humans remains illegal.

The biologists making these breakthroughs are only motivated by a desire to save human lives. Many of them feel they have been misrepresented in the media, though when I phoned one of them about this, his assistant Igor said master was busy up on the roof with the lightning conductor. The great breakthrough was apparently the discovery of "stem" cells. These are the cells that give chemical messages to other cells telling them to develop into a particular type of tissue. This is less reliable with male cells as they always forget to pass on the message.

Some cells turn into bone, some cells turn into brain, the unlucky ones turn into that bit of skin on your Adam's apple that you always cut when you're shaving. Soon biologists hope to be able to inject the appropriate cells to help the body produce its own tissue of exactly the desired type. This has the potential to help everyone from diabetics to people with damaged internal organs.

Even new limbs could be grown, although it may be too late to help the current England football team. The scientists are using fertilised cells which would perish anyway to help people who are already alive. An embryo is not a foetus, which is not a baby. The moment of fertilisation is just one milestone in the creation of human life; it is one of the stages in a long and gradual development to that joyful moment when a baby pops out and keeps you awake for two years. The embryos used in this research are less than a week old. Most couples will have lost fertilised cells without even knowing it before one finally attaches itself to the wall of the womb and makes its host start bursting into tears and eating pickled onions and ice-cream.

People who find the whole idea of cloning human embryos distasteful would probably prefer to put Alzheimer's and cancer to the back of their minds as well. This is a huge leap forward and the churches' reaction was depressing in its predictability. Now I understand why they were always against the cloning of Dolly. We don't need any more sheep when we already have everyone on the religious right bleating the same old objections.

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Summer blues
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

"Blues the healer, all over the world," sang John Lee Hooker. I'm sure the great bluesman did not have wildflowers in mind, but he might have if he was standing here. Up on the high fields of Wenlock Edge, where the oilseed rape has just been harvested and the grassy headlands are covered in a mulch of hay after also being cut, the local swifts are hunting in a rapid pack.

They work the startling blue skies in hot steamy sunshine between rains, field by field, feeding up for the manic, screaming charges to come. Wandering the lanes, road verges and uncut rough grass, is to pick up on the blue pulse flowering through high summer. Just as blue signals spring in the bluebell woods, blue is the colour of summer winding down from the solstice towards autumn.

The power of blue, which is strengthened by purples and even pinks, to strike a melancholy yet healing chord in us, was well understood by the doyenne of garden designers Gertrude Jekyll - a trick much imitated ever since by gardeners chasing that "nat ural" feel of summer. In the longer grass, nettle-leaved bellflower and field scabious initiate the blue pulse to the eye. There is a stretch of road verge just at the entrance to Much Wenlock which is a fabulous splash of blue- purple, full of black knapweed, greater knapweed and hundreds of pyramidal orchids - it has been an extraordinary year for them and they range from shocking pink to deep purple.

Across the road, down the lane and through the wood which grows on limestone spoil heaps, in scrubby, sunny glades kept open by rabbit grazing, is an even more spectacular display. Harebell, common milkwort, selfheal, scabious and bellflower are amazing but the pinks also have the blues like autumn gentian, marjoram, wild basil, thyme, common centaury and herb robert.

The pinky-purples, from pyramidal orchid to knapweed, thistles and even willowherbs are also blue- charged. In this wild, unplanned garden open to everyone, blue twangs the slow, heavy days of summer and heals the spirit.

webTitle: The shires revolt

fields.headline: The shires revolt
fields.standfirst:
Rural folk are restless over petrol prices, housing and poor public services - and Labour can no longer afford to ignore their concerns
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: John Prescott is heading for the byways of Britain. He is about to launch a pre-election campaign well away from Labour's traditional heartland - in territory his party could once afford to ignore.
fields.body:
John Prescott is heading for the byways of Britain. He is about to launch a pre-election campaign well away from Labour's traditional heartland - in territory his party could once afford to ignore.

No longer. The countryside shed its true-blue image in 1997. Some 100 key Labour seats can now be called rural. And the deputy prime minister has much ground to make up. With fuel prices driving some businesses - such as mobile shops - towards bankruptcy, the shires are in revolt. "Dump the pump" protests reflect wider concerns about an uncaring government presiding over a gradual withdrawal of services that city people take for granted.

More than half of all rural parishes now have no school or shop, let alone a decent bus service. Four hundred sub-post offices closed last year and the Countryside Agency says many of the remaining 9,000 are fighting to survive in the shadow of Whitehall plans to pay pensions and benefit payments through banks from 2003. Some 80% of villages have no GP. All suffer from a chronic shortage of affordable homes since the last government cut the stock of council and housing association dwellings by a third after selling almost 100,000 rural homes. That helps to explain why homelessness is rising in the countryside but falling in the cities.

With the disappearance of 60,000 agricultural jobs in the past decade and an accelerating drift from the land, farming is no longer the mainstay of the rural economy. Small and medium-sized towns are now the country's new growth centres, with the shire population rising twice as fast (10.3%) as England as a whole over almost two decades.

Many country dwellers travel considerable distances to work and it is here that John Prescott might have some explaining to do. Research just published for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation highlights transport as the major issue for many country folk, particularly those on modest incomes. (Cornwall, for instance, which is overrun with holiday homes - as well as being a retirement haven for the better-off - has the country's lowest average wages of £297 a week, compared with a national average of £405.)

Mark Shucksmith of Aberdeen University says "there is a fundamental contradiction at the heart of government thinking when fuel taxation and other policies designed to reduce car use serve to exacerbate rural exclusion and intensify barriers to employment". As one young unemployed woman told researchers, "the Job Centre doesn't look favourably on you if you're looking for work, live in a village and have no car... And no job - no money for a car."

The study's findings underline a recent report from the Countryside Agency which highlighted a deepening divide between the better-off and the poor. Because of poor public transport, the agency says low-income rural families are twice as likely to run a car as similar urban households - although they can often ill-afford the cost.

In an attempt to address the "hidden and dispersed nature of poverty" in rural Britain, the Rowntree research says that unemployed people trapped in the countryside without access to bus and train services should be offered government grants to buy a car and be given means-tested help towards the costs of road tax and insurance. It argues that public transport is unable to provide a comprehensive solution to accessibility in the countryside. "Cars are essential," it says.

Revenue from fuel duty in the countryside should go into a special fund to subsidise car-buying schemes, to keep village shops and schools open, and underpin bus and taxi services.

Significantly, the Countryside Agency has added its weight to the study by calling for a bold initiative from ministers. "For many rural people, access to a car is a necessity," said an official. "There is a case for targeted help for those in real hardship."

In response, Mr Prescott will naturally point to the chancellor's promise to increase a special rural transport fund from £60m to £95m in the recent spending review. He is also considering extra help to keep sub-post offices open. Beyond that, there are the various initiatives that will issue from the rural white paper to be published in the autumn.

They may include recommendations from the Countryside Agency, which calls for urgent action to address the shortage of low-cost accommodation. With younger people increasingly priced out of the rural market and unable to find rented accommodation, it estimates that 10,000 new low-cost homes are needed each year for the foreseeable future - four times more than the current provision - to meet demand.

The agency is not alone in its criticism. Last year, the Cabinet Office performance and innovation unit warned that, unless more affordable homes are built, "large parts of rural England risk becoming the near-exclusive preserve of the more affluent". Mr Prescott will warm to that theme. But he is likely to find that tub-thumping on the village green or in the marketplace will not be enough to satisfy restless country folk, or nervous (rural) Labour MPs. They want action and fast. That is why we can expect a string of promises to underpin rural services - or what is left of them.

webTitle: Leader: Ten years on, the Gulf war is still with us

fields.headline: The Saddam stalemate
fields.standfirst:
Ten years on, the Gulf war is still with us

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Ten years on, the Gulf war is still with us
fields.body:
The invasion of Kuwait by Iraq 10 years ago today was a geostrategic disaster for the west from which it has yet to recover. The US and British policy of arming and backing Saddam Hussein as a foil to revolutionary Iran lay in tatters. Western oil supplies seemed threatened as Saudi Arabia panicked and called for armed support. Saddam's subsequent missile launches against Israel raised the prospect of a region-wide conflict. The Arab world was deeply divided, with governments like that of Egypt at odds with a public opinion sympathetic to Saddam and with Syria, a long-time Soviet client, supporting the US-led military alliance. Operation Desert Storm even achieved the improbable feat of forcing Iran and Iraq, which fought a bitter war in the 1980s, into a temporary alliance of expediency. The bombing of Baghdad and other Iraqi cities deeply divided European opinion, too. And while the expulsion of Iraq's forces from Kuwait made George Bush, for a few heady weeks, the most popular president in US opinion poll history, it did not prevent him being tossed out of office the following year.

It remains a matter of debate whether the invasion could have been avoided. US diplomats in Baghdad were later accused of having sent the wrong signals to Saddam; US intelligence certainly misread clear evidence of hostile intent in the weeks and days preceding the attack. Others may say, with some justice, that the Gulf war was dramatic proof, if ever it were needed, of the unwisdom of buttressing dictators. Whatever the historical verdict may eventually be, the many consequences of this spectacular policy fiasco remain with us today.

Ten years on, Iraq's people still suffer grievously from sanctions which the US and Britain alone try to justify. Kuwait, despite billions spent on arms, remains as intrinsi cally indefensible, without massive external support, as it was in 1990. The aspirations of Iraq's Kurdish and Shia minorities remain unmet, despite the protection supposedly afforded by the "no-fly" zones. Similarly, the UN's objective of denying Saddam weapons of mass destruction is officially unfulfilled. The UN's inspectors have not been admitted since 1998, while controversy dogs the UN oil-for-food programme, notwithstanding an easing of its terms last December. Most evidently, Saddam remains in power. Despite real and imaginary internal coup attempts, CIA covert operations and unconfirmed reports of serious illness, he appears to be as much in charge now as he was a decade ago.

More so, in fact. When Mr Bush halted his tanks south of Basra in February 1991, he feared, among other outcomes, Iraq's disintegration as a unified state should they press forward to Baghdad and topple Saddam. This consideration remains very much to the point. With no sign of peaceful transition within Iraq, the potential consequences for neigbouring countries of a violent implosion are more worrying than the continuation of Saddam's rule. Several Middle Eastern states have reopened embassies or missions in Baghdad. Some neighbours connive at breaches of sanctions and oil smuggling. France, along with Russia and China, mindful as were the Americans and British pre-1990 of Iraq's economic potential, now press for an end to the UN embargo. Even the US, while profoundly wishing it, has given up calling for Saddam's overthrow. The brute reality is that there is no political will for a repeat military operation to finish the job. But nor is there a consensus on ending sanctions, thereby admitting that the policy of 10 years has failed. So this sorry stalemate goes on - and so does Saddam.

webTitle: Leader: High taxes could help fund solar research

fields.headline: Dump the hype
fields.standfirst:
High taxes could help fund solar research

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: High taxes could help fund solar research
fields.body:
The dump the pump protest against high petrol prices seems to have been dumped by consumers in most of the country. It was business almost as usual yesterday for most forecourts, as drivers either ignored the plea to keep away or filled up with extra fuel the day before. The AA reported a big decline in the number of cars running out of fuel, compared with normal. The subdued response probably did not worry the organisers because they succeeded in their primary aim - to draw the public's attention to the high taxation of petrol. The campaign claims that at 90p a litre, £4.10 a gallon, the motorist pays £37 of every £50 spent to the government. The campaign is running with a popular wind behind it as consumers in the UK, and even more so in the US (where petrol taxes are very low), react against high taxes.

What is less clear is whether discontented consumers are opposed to taxation in general being high or just petrol taxes. Because, if taxes have to be raised to fund the health and education services that people undoubtedly want, then taxing a scarce finite resource like petrol is a good way of doing it - as long as poorer people disproportionately affected are compensated. While it must be admitted that earlier scares about the world running out of oil within 20 or 30 years have proved to be unfounded (thanks to the discovery of more oil reserves) it will happen sooner or later. Future generations may well castigate the profligacy of American cheap energy policy, which is encouraging the accelerated consumption of a scarce resource. High energy prices discourage wasteful use and ought to boost alternative sources of energy, such as wind and direct solar power. This is not happening on the scale required. Maybe income from all future increases in the cost of petrol - whether caused by inflation or anything else - should be devoted to research into solar alternatives. Do not dump the pump, seize the sun.

webTitle: Britain's critical missiles dilemma

fields.headline: Britain's critical missiles dilemma
fields.standfirst: US plan puts Blair on spot, warn MPs
fields.trailText: MPs today condemn America's plan for a national missile defence system, dubbed the son of star wars, warning it would have a "profound effect" on international relations and strategic stability while presenting the British government with an "acute" dilemma.
fields.body:
MPs today condemn America's plan for a national missile defence system, dubbed the son of star wars, warning it would have a "profound effect" on international relations and strategic stability while presenting the British government with an "acute" dilemma.

In a report reflecting growing, as yet unstated, opposition within the cabinet to the US project, the Commons cross-party foreign affairs committee calls on ministers to "articulate the very strong concerns" expressed in Britain about the plan.

Under the multibillion dollar scheme - which would require new American radar bases in Britain - the US would protect itself with a battery of ground-based rockets designed to intercept incoming missiles.

President Bill Clinton has said he is in favour of a limited system designed to protect the US from what Washington used to call "rogue" states but now refers to as "states of concern" - North Korea, Iran, Iraq, and Libya. George W Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, says he wants a much more ambitious project closer to President Ronald Reagan's original "star wars" plan, to protect the US from any potential enemy.

The project, limited or not, would require amending the anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty signed by the US and the then Soviet Union in 1972 and widely regarded as a cornerstone of international strategic stability. The concept of the national missile defence system (NMD) challenges traditional notions of nuclear deterrence and will fuel an arms race, its critics say.

Vladimir Putin and Jiang Zemin, the Russian and Chinese presidents, warned last month that an American decision to go ahead with NMD would "pose the most grave adverse consequences".

The US project is also opposed by most of Britain's European allies, including France and Germany. The Guardian has learned that the French president Jacques Chirac and German chancellor Gerhard Schröder recently urged Tony Blair to adopt a common European approach urging the US to abandon the project.

The prime minister dismissed the idea, though many of his cabinet colleagues, notably the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, as well as Mr Blair's senior military advisers, are known to be strongly opposed to NMD.

The US plan relies on the up grading of the early warning station at Fylingdales on the North York moors and as well as the US eavesdropping station at Menwith Hill near Harrogate in North Yorkshire.

The US defence department, the Pentagon, also says it needs to build a new 14-storey X-band radar station in Britain - something Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, has pointed out, would be impossible to hide.

Other ministers have gone further. One with direct knowledge of the project told the Guardian that a US request to construct a new radar station here would be a "nightmare". He said Greenham Common - the US cruise missile base in Berkshire besieged by women peace protesters through the 1980s - would "look easy by comparison".

Opponents of the US project in Whitehall are now suggesting that John Prescott, the environment secretary, has told Washington it would need planning permission to build a new radar site - not a quick or easy procedure, especially if a national park, a likely location, is selected.

Though he has sidestepped questions about how he would respond to a Pentagon request to use bases here for the NMD plan, Mr Hoon has admitted that Britain would be a target of "rogue" states if the government acceded to it.

In today's report, the foreign affairs committee says it is incumbent on the government "as one of the five nuclear weapons states and as a close ally of the US", to make an early public statement on its analysis of NMD's likely impact on strategic stability and its assessment of whether this would be "in the overall security interests of this country".

That is all the more important, it says, because of "apparently contradictory views" from the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence. While the FO has made clear it wishes to preserve, even strengthen, the ABM treaty, the MoD is officially keeping open the possibility of acquiring a British national missile defence sys tem, the MPs say. Pointing to what they call the "uniquely close" nature of the US-UK relationship in the security field, they say a decision by Washington even to seek permission to upgrade Fylingdales would present the government with an "acute" dilemma. Refusal "would be unprecedented", says the report.

The MPs say that to turn down such an American request - possibly from a newly elected president committed to implementing NMD - "would have profound consequences for UK/US relations". They note that in his Commons statement on NMD after the recent G8 summit, Mr Blair said it was vital "to continue a dialogue on what will be one of the most important issues that we shall have to face over the next few years".

That, the MPs say, is precisely why the government - whose overall policy on arms control negotiations they praise - must impress on Washington that it cannot assume British support.

"The government must get over to Washington the extreme seriousness and implications [of NMD] including the depth of feeling and opposition to it," Phyllis Starkey, a Labour member of the committee, said last night. The attitude of advisers to George W Bush in discussions the MPs had in Washington "scared me rigid", she added.

The MPs recognise the potential threat from weapons of mass destruction. But that threat is unlikely to come from incoming missiles, they say. It could come, rather, from weapons hidden in delivery trucks or packing cases.

webTitle: Leader: Head teachers need this leeway

fields.headline: More exclusive
fields.standfirst:
Head teachers need this leeway

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Head teachers need this leeway
fields.body:
With its report two years ago on truancy and the expulsion of "problem children" from schools, the new Social Exclusion Unit showed its mettle. These children ended up homeless, addicted or criminal. Because they stopped learning, they were condemned to joblessness. The imperative was to keep them in school. With all the confidence New Labour then possessed, "overarching" targets were set. By 2002 numbers of excluded pupils would be cut by one-third from their 1998 level - 100,000 temporary and 13,000 permanent exclusions.

It was a consensus policy. Keeping children in (or near) school has to be right in principle. But it imposed tremendous burdens on individual schools and their teachers. Implementation has never been a Whitehall strong point. Numerical targets became straightjackets for the very people who daily must cope with recalcitrant, disruptive and sometimes violent children in schools. Heads became distracted by the appeals system. Set up with the admirable intention of giving parents a chance to query school decisions, it became an interference with the good conduct of classroom and corridor. Education policy has to balance parents' interests with those of the school: the safety and well-being, let alone the educational progress of pupils, sometimes depends on exclusions going ahead promptly. Yesterday the government recognised this, when Jacqui Smith announced what sounds like a sharp reduction in the ambit of the appeals tribunals - exclusion ought to become significantly easier. New "guidance" is being dispatched this month, which makes you wonder, a union leader said sardonically yesterday, quite how independent these appeals bodies ever were.

Yet only those determined to see nothing positive in Labour's education policies will deny the improvements the SEU report led to. Keeping children in school has become a priority, as it must be. On-site units have been set up. In some areas, referral units for excluded children, intensively and expertly staffed, now have some hope of putting disruptive children back on the path towards qualifications and jobs. True, progress is patchy. The huge cost of the tuition needed for such children has not been recognised. Chris Woodhead and his Ofsted teams want rid of local authorities, but where else is the money and effort going to come from to create units serving several schools across a given area?

webTitle: Defector quits 'intolerant' Tories

fields.headline: Defector quits 'intolerant' Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The running controversy over the repeal of section 28 took a fresh twist last night when Ivan Massow, the millionaire businessman and would-be mayor of London resigned from the Conservative party and joined Labour.
fields.body:
The running controversy over the repeal of section 28 took a fresh twist last night when Ivan Massow, the millionaire businessman and would-be mayor of London resigned from the Conservative party and joined Labour.

Mr Massow, who became a supporter of Steve Norris's bid to be London mayor after the maverick ex-minister won the Conservative nomination, said that, under William Hague's leadership, the Tories "cannot be trusted to govern Britain".

Mr Massow's defection, which was greeted with regret by a party spokesman,was not the only misfortune suffered by the Tory leadership last night. Howard Flight, a new MP promoted to the shadow Treasury team for his City background, was reported to have warned in March against his boss, Michael Portillo's efforts to water down Mr Hague's "tax guarantee" pledge which would have promised tax cuts in a Tory-run parliament regardless of wider economic circumstances.

Mr Massow used an interview in the Independent to signal his dismay - as a gay man, he stressed - at the growing intolerance and nastiness of the party he joined 18 years ago in Margaret Thatcher's heyday.

"Under William the sad truth is that the Tories have become less compassionate, more intolerant and frankly just plain nasty. The very things that led the electorate to reject them at the last election have been compounded since," he said.

He specifically cited the section 28 controversy which pitted Mr Hague and the Tory tabloids against their own liberal wing and the government over allegedly homophobic practices imposed on local authorities. Shaun Woodward, MP for Witney has already defected to Labour on the same issue.

The London businessman accused the Tory leader of surrendering his principles to the "lowest common denominator", adding that Tory policies were simply designed to "chime with the most base values and claw away at national insecurities". A Tory spokesman said: "Ivan has made a significant contribution to the party and we are sorry to learn he has decided to abandon the beliefs and principles which he has apparently supported in recent years."

Mr Massow admitted it had been a "mistake" not joining Labour when Tony Blair became leader because he feared Labour could not manage the economy.

"Way back in 1994 when Tony Blair became leader of the Labour party he talked the kind of language that I as a young gay businessman might have responded to immediately," he conceded.

Along with Mr Massow's complaint, the Conservatives suffered a mini-memo leak over economic policy, after a month in which Labour suffered its series of embarrassing leaks of memos to and from Tony Blair

"I appreciate the argument for seeking to neutralise the NHS issue at the general election ... but I do not think Blair's commitment is to be believed and if we position ourselves in so seeking, such that it undermines our tax credentials, I believe we will be the losers," the MP warned.

Mr Portillo eventually won that battle to make Tory policy more flexible and responsive and will sleep easy despite the hostility of Mr Flight, MP for Arundel, reported in today's Times. But the leak,which may have been designed to weaken Mr Portillo further on the Tory right, underlines how much the party is simultaneously being accused of hardheartedness on tax-and-spend by Labour - and just the opposite from its own hardliners.

Together with Mr Massow's complaint it adds up to a lack of clarity which will help restore Labour morale.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday inquiry delayed as former judge quits

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday inquiry delayed as former judge quits
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Lord Saville's inquiry into Bloody Sunday, investigating the shooting dead of 13 unarmed Catholics in Londonderry in January 1972, was hit by another delay yesterday after Sir Edward Somers, the   former New Zealand appeal court judge, left his three-man tribunal, citing "personal reasons" for quitting.
fields.body:
Lord Saville's inquiry into Bloody Sunday, investigating the shooting dead of 13 unarmed Catholics in Londonderry in January 1972, was hit by another delay yesterday after Sir Edward Somers, the former New Zealand appeal court judge, left his three-man tribunal, citing "personal reasons" for quitting.

Sir Edward, 72 next month, who was appointed when Tony Blair announced he was setting up the tribunal in January 1998, handed his resignation to Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary . He said he did so with "the greatest regret" but was unable to bring to the task the vigour needed over the remaining two to three years of the inquiry, which so far has only had oral evidence from Christopher Clarke QC, counsel for the tribunal, in his opening statement. Now, hear ings are postponed while a substitute for Sir Edward is sought.

Patricia McBride, of the Bloody Sunday Trust, which represents victims' families, called for a rapid appointment. "This inquiry is a traumatic time for the families: any delay can only make the situation more difficult."

webTitle: Dentists told of CJD risk in surgery

fields.headline: Dentists told of CJD risk in surgery
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Government scientists yesterday warned there was a theoretical risk that the human form of BSE could be spread by infected instruments used in dental surgery.
fields.body:
Government scientists yesterday warned there was a theoretical risk that the human form of BSE could be spread by infected instruments used in dental surgery.

They have already begun to study nerve tissues from the mouths of victims of bovine spongiform encephalopathy to assess whether these people carry the abnormal protein thought most likely to cause the disease.

The Department of Health has been asked to add an assessment of the risks caused by contaminated dental instruments to a wider survey of surgical equipment. A report this year will look at whether there is a need for expensive changes to procedures in operations and whether more instruments should be only used once rather than sterilised.

The scientists on the committee advising ministers on issues relating to BSE and its human equivalent, vCJD, stress that "there are no grounds for recommending changes to procedures involving dentistry". Present procedures do not completely remove all traces of the infective agent. But James Ironside, a committee member who works at the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh, said that conventional sterilisation, if done properly, could "achieve a substantial reduction in the levels of infectivity".

Dr Ironside said there was no evidence from comparative studies of vCJD victims that their dental treatment had differed from that of others. The nerves giving sensation to the mouth and gums were how ever closely linked to the brain, an area of high infectiveness.

There are about 25,000 dentists in the UK and the British Dental Association said there was already government guidance on procedures for patients in high risk groups. These methods might not be practical in high street surgeries and it advised members to refer high risk patients to a hospital or a clinic.

Opticians have already been told not to re-use contact lenses in patient tests, and disposable instruments are increasingly used in surgery. Instruments used on vCJD patients are routinely destroyed.

webTitle: Robbers slash pianist's hands

fields.headline: Robbers slash pianist's hands
fields.trailText: The pianist John Lill was recovering last night after both his hands were slashed by attackers who ambushed him on his way home from playing a concert for the Queen Mother.
fields.body:
The pianist John Lill was recovering last night after both his hands were slashed by attackers who ambushed him on his way home from playing a concert for the Queen Mother.

Mr Lill, 56, was only minutes from his home in Hampstead, north London, when two men in crash helmets set upon him in daylight.

When he refused to hand over his wallet they attacked him with what he called a "giant knife", causing deep wounds on his hands.

Mr Lill, who won the world's most prestigious piano prize, the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow 30 years ago, had just finished a series of concerts which culminated in a performance of Beethoven's Appassionata Sonata in the presence of the Queen Mother and Prince Charles in King's Lynn, Suffolk.

He was taken to the Royal Free hospital where doctors initially feared there might be nerve or tendon damage which would have ended his career.

But his agent, Gaetan Le Divelec, said no tendons were cut, and although he had severe swelling, he should make a complete recovery."The doctors are quite confident that if there is a normal healing process it will not be a career threatening injury. Obviously though it has been a very traumatic and damaging experience in other ways."

Mr Lill, a flamboyant and gifted musician who has claimed to have had out-of-body experiences during recitals and to have communed with dead composers, said he did not want to give in to the muggers without a fight when they pulled up alongside him on an unmarked motorbike. "It was a great shock but perhaps not all that surprising in this country where law and order appears to have broken down," he told London's Evening Standard newspaper."I put up some resistance and I'm glad that I did. It is incredible that this can happen in the middle of an afternoon in a leafy street. I'm sad to be so pessimistic but this is worse than any country I've ever been to."

He said last night that the swelling on his hand was still "quite bad ... it was severely infected" but he was slowly getting the movement back in his fingers after last Wednesday's attack. His agent said that if his "excellent recovery" continues he will be able to go ahead with a concert with the Hallé orchestra in Manchester in September.

The King's Lynn concert was to have been Mr Lill's last before his summer break.

Although he plays up to 100 concerts a year, Mr Le Divelec said he wanted to "recharge his batteries. He was taking an extended break anyway, so hopefully we will not have to cancel any of his engagements".

Mr Lill's concert career took off with his triumph in Moscow in 1970, having first made an impact nine years earlier while an 18-year-old student at the Royal College of Music.

He had taken up an open scholarship at the college a year earlier, leaving Leyton high school in east London after one sixth form year. His father was a machine operator and his mother worked around the clock to support her son's musical talent.

He admits he was not an easy student. "To be truthful, I've always felt that I learn by my own mistakes - I'm largely self-taught.

"I was very headstrong and argumentative."

webTitle: Mugabe mobilises army for huge farm invasion

fields.headline: Mugabe mobilises army for huge farm invasion
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe is mobilising its army to rapidly resettle several million black peasants on white-owned farms after the government said it will now seize about two-thirds of all white land.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Harare and  Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Zimbabwe is mobilising its army to rapidly resettle several million black peasants on white-owned farms after the government said it will now seize about two-thirds of all white land.

In a move that dashed hopes of a compromise, the vice president, Joseph Msika, confirmed that the government will dramatically increase the number of farms targeted for confiscation without compensation from the 804 earmarked in May to more than 3,000.

Robert Mugabe's administration says it plans to resettle 500,000 black families on the land before the beginning of the rainy season just a few weeks away. The local government minister, Ignatius Chombo, said Zimbabwe's 40,000 strong army will provide transport and other logistics for the operation.

"It has the vehicles needed to move people from one point to the other. It will also establish a communications centre to ensure decisions are made fast and are implemented," he told the state-run Herald newspaper.

Mr Chombo said the legal procedures to seize the first 211 farms will begin by Friday. That land will be used to resettle 37,000 families.

The move further antagonised the government's opponents ahead of a nationwide general strike today backed by trade unions, the main opposition party and white farmers to protest at the handling of land redistribution and the police's failure to respond to growing political violence.

The strike is expected to shut down all of Zimbabwe's major cities where there is growing anger at the president's heavy-handed response to the surge in opposition support in June's parliamentary election and disillusionment at the economic consequences of the government's policies. Long petrol queues have re-emerged since the election, agriculture and tourism are facing collapse, and power cuts loom.

The government plans to take 12m acres without compensation, about two-thirds of all agricultural land owned by whites. It is seizing farms under new legislation that demands that the UK pay the affected farmers on the grounds that they are of British descent.

There are strong doubts about the planned role for the army, particularly with so many of its resources tied up in the Republic of Congo. But it would only take a few dozen owners to be forced off their farms at gunpoint for many white landowners to give up any last hope of clinging to their land.

Earlier this week, the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents most of Zimbabwe's more than 4,000 white farmers, noted that soldiers had been spotted visiting farms, particularly in Mashonaland, where a high proportion of land has been ear marked for confiscation.

"At this stage, this seems to be little more than an intelligence-gathering operation," the union said.

The CFU is throwing its weight behind the strike led by the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions today to protest at the land confiscations and soldiers routinely beating up opposition supporters in townships.

But the union appeared to lose its nerve yesterday and scaled back a planned three-day action to just 24 hours, despite the powerful backing of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, which came close to beating the ruling party in June's elections.

The union said it did not want to do further damage to the economy.

"We want to give the government time to respond. If the government does not respond, we will go on a much longer strike," said Nicholas Mudzengerere, acting secretary-general. "We have taken this decision because we want to use the strike as a warning shot and we think one day would be adequate."

The MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, urged all Zimbabweans to support the strike and accused Mr Mugabe of pursuing a political vendetta against opposition supporters.

"There is no need to pursue political vendettas in a manner that destroys the social and economic fabric. There is no need for suicidal policies just because things did not go well for him during the elections," he said.

In London, the Foreign Office said the latest reports, if confirmed and acted upon, were "very disturbing". Foreign Office ministers are anxious not to become embroiled in another propaganda war with Mr Mugabe.

However officials warned last night: "Mass acquisitions would not help the people of Zimbabwe. We have always said we are willing to co-operate in a programme of genuine land reform, including by offering cash.

"However, mass acquisitions would not be fair to the farmers of Zimbabwe and not the fresh start that Zimbabwe so badly needs after the elections."

The farmers union had hoped to meet Mr Mugabe on Monday to reach a compromise on land distribution but the president cancelled the appointment.
