webTitle: Convicted stalkers may go on special register

fields.headline: Convicted stalkers may go on special register
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A national register of stalkers could be set up to help the police keep track of serial offenders, particularly the hard core of potentially violent men and women who target their victims indiscriminately, the Home Office revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A national register of stalkers could be set up to help the police keep track of serial offenders, particularly the hard core of potentially violent men and women who target their victims indiscriminately, the Home Office revealed yesterday.

It also disclosed that almost 6,000 people had been convicted of stalking offences in 1998.

The database would prevent stalkers going "underground" and would be modelled on the sex offenders register, which gives police limited powers to alert organisations, including schools, when an offender moves into the neighbourhood. If a similar list were introduced, stalkers would be ordered to tell the police if they changed their name or moved address.

Victims of stalking welcomed the proposal yesterday, but Liberty, the civil rights group, said the Home Office needed to move cautiously. John Wadham, its director, said stalking behaviour needed to be clearly defined so that only genuine offenders were included on the list.

The Home Office said it was determined to crack down on a growing problem. "Harassment can have a devastating effect on people's lives," said the Home Office minister Charles Clarke."It is something that must be tackled."

The department said yesterday that it had asked researchers to "establish the case" for a stalking register. Ministers and civil servants will then consult with police and relevant organisations, including Liberty, before deciding whether to press ahead.

"This is something that needs to be considered very carefully and we will not rush into it," a Home Office spokesman said. "We want to test the case for establishing a register. We want to make sure we are not missing out on a really useful tool."

The Home Office said it would distinguish between the non-violent stalker motivated by a failed relationship and the violent obsessive who targets strangers.

"The register would not apply to all people convicted of stalking offences. We have to be extremely careful not to lump everyone together."

The Home Office estimates the research and consultation could take up to 12 months.

One victim, Tracey Morgan, whose case triggered the introduction of the anti-stalking Protection from Harassment Act three years ago, said a register would give people "greater peace of mind".

She was stalked for seven years by former Royal Navy petty officer Anthony Burstow. Her ordeal began when she was working as a civilian clerical officer at HMS Collingwood in Fareham, Hampshire, and continued throughout the 1990s, even though Burstow was convicted on numerous occasions and sent to jail.

Liberty claimed the Protection from Harassment Act had been used to stifle public protest, and called on the Home Office to specify what information the register would require from offenders.

Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat shadow home secretary, added: "Registers of this type should focus on those who genuinely pose a threat, not registering people for the sake of it."

The announcement of plans to consider the stalking register coincided with the publication of guidelines to police forces for using their anti-stalking powers effectively.

The Home Office study revealed 5,800 people were convicted of stalking offences in England and Wales in 1998.

The majority - 4,300 - were convicted of the lesser charge of criminal harassment. The rest were convicted of putting victims in fear of violence, which has a maximum sentence of five years.

The study found 80% of victims were women, and 80% of stalkers were men. Nearly all of those convicted of stalking knew their victims. Only 4% were "stranger" stalkers.

Scotland Yard's Detective Inspector Hamish Brown, who researched and wrote the guidelines for the police, warned cyber-stalking was on the increase and feared victims, who are often bombarded with emails, were not coming forward. "I'm quite convinced that this is one area that is under-reported. It's so easy to push a delete button when you receive an email.

"It's not like reading a letter, which has to be opened. If someone is stalking you via the internet, get a hard copy of the email. Print it out.

"[An email] does not have to be that abusive but when they come repeatedly and they are anonymous it can get people down."

The Home Office study concluded some police officers were unclear about what constitutes harassment under the terms of the 1997 Act, and said many victims did not realise they were protected by new laws.

"Public awareness of the Act seems to be quite limited," said Jessica Harris, author of the Home Office study. "Victims do not always realise what is happening to them."

She said stalkers tried to make victims feel as if they were going mad.

"The register would not apply to all people convicted of stalking offences. We have to be extremely careful not to lump everyone together." The Home Office estimates the research and consultation could take up to 12 months. One victim, Tracey Morgan, whose case triggered the introduction of the anti-stalking Protection from Harassment Act three years ago, said a register would give people "greater peace of mind". She was stalked for seven years by former Royal Navy petty officer Anthony Burstow. Her ordeal began when she was working as a civilian clerical officer at HMS Collingwood in Fareham, Hampshire, and continued throughout the 1990s, even though Burstow was convicted on numerous occasions and sent to jail. Liberty claimed the Protection from Harassment Act had been used to stifle public protest, and called on the Home Office to specify what information the register would require from offenders. Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat shadow home secretary, added: "Registers of this type should focus on those who genuinely pose a threat, not registering people for the sake of it." The announcement of plans to consider the stalking register coincided with the publication of guidelines to police forces for using their anti-stalking powers effectively. The Home Office study revealed 5,800 people were convicted of stalking offences in England and Wales in 1998. The majority - 4,300 - were convicted of the lesser charge of criminal harassment. The rest were convicted of putting victims in fear of violence, which has a maximum sentence of five years. The study found 80% of victims were women, and 80% of stalkers were men. Nearly all of those convicted of stalking knew their victims. Only 4% were "stranger" stalkers. Scotland Yard's Detective Inspector Hamish Brown, who researched and wrote the guidelines for the police, warned cyber-stalking was on the increase and feared victims, who are often bombarded with emails, were not coming forward. "I'm quite convinced that this is one area that is under-reported. It's so easy to push a delete button when you receive an email. "It's not like reading a letter, which has to be opened. If someone is stalking you via the internet, get a hard copy of the email. Print it out. "[An email] does not have to be that abusive but when they come repeatedly and they are anonymous it can get people down." The Home Office study concluded some police officers were unclear about what constitutes harassment under the terms of the 1997 Act, and said many victims did not realise they were protected by new laws. "Public awareness of the Act seems to be quite limited," said Jessica Harris, author of the Home Office study. "Victims do not always realise what is happening to them." She said stalkers tried to make victims feel as if they were going mad.

webTitle: BAT accused in smuggling case

fields.headline: BAT accused in smuggling case
fields.standfirst: Ecuador takes British tobacco group to court
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco faces legal action in a Florida court over alleged tobacco smuggling in South America.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco faces legal action in a Florida court over alleged tobacco smuggling in South America.

The world's second-largest cigarette manufacturer, which is based in London, has been targeted by the government of Ecuador for "illegally avoiding the taxation of tobacco products".

BAT, along with a number of rival tobacco companies, is accused of engaging in a scheme "to frustrate Ecuadorian authorities by making false and deceptive representations".

Last week the European commission announced it would act against unnamed cigarette manufacturers to recover tax losses from smuggling. Anti-smoking groups in Africa are also calling for criminal action against cigarette manufacturers.

But the case filed in Miami is the first time lawyers have started to actively pursue BAT, which yesterday reported six-monthly profits of nearly £700m from brands such as Dunhill and Rothmans.

Operating profits in Latin America rose 42%, but BAT admitted a growing amount of money - £150m a year - is going on legal work to fend off cases involving smoking-related illnesses.

The tobacco group, which has former Tory chancellor Kenneth Clarke as deputy chairman, said it had not yet been served with papers by the Ecuadorian government.

But Neil Withington, BAT's head of legal services, confirmed action had started. "We are aware Ecuador has filed a case in the state court of Florida which names BAT and Brown & Williamson and the US tobacco industry generally," he explained.

Mr Withington dismissed suggestions the company might face a growing number of smuggling cases. He believed the threats from Africa were part of a propaganda exercise being coordinated by the UK-based anti-smoking campaign group Ash. "I would be surprised if there was a huge escalation [of legal action] in this area," Mr Withington said.

Clive Bates, director of Ash, said the noose was tightening on BAT and other top manufacturers. "Some people think it's absurd that these companies could have been guilty of smuggling. But the US racketeering laws being threatened in the Florida case and EC threats to take legal action suggest that is exactly what they have been doing."

He said the latest revelations would put further pressure on British ministers to order an inquiry into BAT. An all-party Commons health committee has already called for an investigation after the Guardian revealed how BAT exploited smuggling in South America and Asia.

BAT insisted it was confident it could successfully appeal against last month's $17.6bn award by a Miami jury for product liability in a class action case, named after the litigant Howard Engle.

The action ruled that US tobacco companies were liable for lung cancer and other ailments among an estimated 500,000 unidentified smokers in Florida. It has been moved to a federal court where BAT believes it had a better chance of victory.

Investors have been put off BAT by its legal problems and the company has under-performed the FTSE index of top 100 shares by 25% over the past 12 months.

webTitle: Gene hunters say patients are a bankable asset

fields.headline: Gene hunters say patients are a bankable asset
fields.standfirst:
Ethical problems arise as research effort intensifies
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: DNA Sciences , a Californian start-up, is introducing a website this week which will recruit DNA donors to help find genes that cause disease.
fields.body:
DNA Sciences , a Californian start-up, is introducing a website this week which will recruit DNA donors to help find genes that cause disease.

The company - which has James D Watson, a discoverer of the DNA double helix, as a director and James Clark, Netscape's founder, as an investor - hopes to get 50,000 to 100,000 people to contribute to its "gene trust" by appealing to their altruism. "The knowledge we gain from the gene trust has the potential to change medicine for ever," says a message on the site, DNA.com. "But we can't do it without your help."

The new effort reflects a big change taking place in genetics. Studies to link genes to disease are involving far more people than before. While such studies promise big medical advances, collection of genetic data on such a scale is raising ethical and privacy issues, particularly that genetic information could be used to deny people or their family members insurance or employment.

"It is essentially being developed and hitting the spotlight without a sense of rules, ethics and social norms," said Janlori Goldman, director of the health privacy project at Georgetown University.

With the recent unravelling of the human genome, scientists are cataloguing hundreds of thousands of differences in the genetic make-up of different individuals.

Working out which genes contribute to disease could help in developing drugs. Instead of the current practice of one drug fits all, patients might have their genes tested to see which drug would work best for them.

But to get to that point scientists must first determine which of hundreds of thousands of genetic variations contribute to which disease or to the effectiveness of a particular drug. That will require "disease association studies" - surveying many people to find statistical correlations.

In the past, scientists usually found disease-causing genes by studying a few families or an isolated village with high prevalence of a disease. Such genes have often been linked to rare inherited diseases in which a defect in a single gene is at fault.

But that technique is becoming less effective, said Neil J Risch, professor of genetics at Stanford University. The diseases of most interest to drug companies and the public health, he said, are common ones such as cancer, heart disease, diabetes, Alzheimer's and schizophrenia. It is believed many genes contribute to such diseases with each one having a small effect. To find these genes, hundreds or thousands of patients might be needed.

"This is not going to happen in some esoteric studies with a couple of families here and there," said Mihael Polymeropoulos, a vice-president of Novartis, the Swiss drug company. "We're going to need lots of people."

Just how many is a matter of debate. Some sceptics say the statistical links might be too weak to detect. "It's a blind leap of faith that this approach is going to work at all," said Joseph D Terwilliger, an assistant professor at Columbia University's genome centre.

Others say that even if the technique works in some situations, knowing the gene is often not enough to develop a drug. "You're asking why someone gets a disease, not what to do about it," said William A Haseltine, chief ex ecutive of Human Genome Sciences. He said there were many instances, such as cystic fibrosis, in which the gene has long been known but there is still no effective treatment.

Yet Glaxo Wellcome says it has already found genes associated with migraine, psoriasis, diabetes and Parkinson's disease. Genset, a French company specialising in studies on diverse populations, says it has found genes linked to prostate cancer and schizophrenia.

DNA Sciences is just one of the new companies preparing studies. Two had initial public stock offerings in the past two weeks: deCODE Genetics, which is making a database using medical records and DNA samples from most of Iceland's 275,000 people, and Gemini Genomics, a British company that has DNA samples and extensive medical records from thousands of pairs of twins.

Framingham Genomic Medicine was formed in June by Boston University and venture capitalists to analyse data from a project that has collected data and DNA samples from thousands of people in Framingham, Massachusetts.

The Baltic state of Estonia plans a genetic database of nearly all its 1.4m citizens.

Genomics Collaborative, a private company in Cambridge, Massachusetts, has a network of 250 doctors with the goal of getting as many as a million patients. It recently signed an agreement with Ameripath, which performs pathology services for 170 hos pitals and analyses nearly 3m biopsies a year. Under the agreement, hundreds of thousands of tissue samples will go into a bank for genetic studies.

The companies all say they obtain the informed consent of patients to have their DNA used and that they operate under the scrutiny of institutional review boards or ethics committees. They also say they "anonymise" the information.

But critics say hackers could access patients' identities, and assurances that data will not be sold to others such as insurance companies are not ironclad. Questions have already arisen about the ethics of deriving private profit from the Framingham data, which was collected in a federally financed project. DeCODE's activities in Iceland have also provoked controversy.

Kari Stefansson, chief executive of deCODE, argues that privacy advocates are slowing progress. "It is considered by some a right to deny science the ability to use information about us to help future generations," he said at a public forum on medical privacy recently.

He and others involved in such companies say many people are happy to help search for cures for diseases from which they or their descendants might suffer.

Under DNA Sciences' programme, volunteers answer online questionnaires about their medical history and that of their family. The firm will then send someone to homes or offices to collect blood samples. Healtheon/WebMD, the medical website, owns a stake in DNA Sciences and will be used to help recruit patients.

Donors will not be paid. There have been controversies arising from doctors or companies profiting from a diagnostic test or cell line developed from a patient's tissue without compensating the patient. But in this case, the companies say, huge statistical studies are being done in which the contribution of any one patient is insignificant.

Experts see two potential problems with DNA Sciences' approach. One is that volunteers' description of their medical histories might not be accurate. "There's garbage in and garbage out," said Jonathan M Rothberg, chairman and chief executive of Curagen, a company looking for disease genes. He said the company used data from Gemini Genomics because the twins in that database had undergone hours of standardised medical tests.

The second problem is that the people recruited by DNA Sciences might be too heterogeneous. Although large numbers are needed, there is still some advantage to relatively homogeneous populations such as Iceland's.

But DNA Sciences and some others say a broader population is better. "That gene might be great for Iceland but it's not the gene for New York City, and we sell far more drugs in New York City than Iceland," said Allen D Roses, international director of genetics for Glaxo Wellcome.

Another obstacle is cost: about $1 to test one patient for one variation of a single letter in the genetic code. Scientists have already found hundreds of thousands of variations, known as single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). Testing 100,000 SNPs in 1,000 patients would cost $100m.

• Go-ahead
Hong Kong internet firm Pacific Century CyberWorks and telecoms carrier Cable & Wireless HKT yesterday won court approval for their multi-billion-dollar merger, clearing the final hurdle for what PCCW bills as Asia's largest corporate merger.
fields.body:
 Go-ahead
Hong Kong internet firm Pacific Century CyberWorks and telecoms carrier Cable & Wireless HKT yesterday won court approval for their multi-billion-dollar merger, clearing the final hurdle for what PCCW bills as Asia's largest corporate merger.

Deal
Canada's CNortel Networks , the world's second largest network equipment supplier, said yesterday that it had won a $300m (£200m) deal to supply ClearData Communications with optical and data network equipment.

 Acquisition
Chip-maker Intel said it would buy privately held Trillium Digital Systems in a deal valued at $300m (£200m) in cash and unregistered Intel common stock, to bolster its telecoms and network package to customers.

 Clearance
Germany's telecoms watchdog said yesterday it had cleared France Telecom-backed Mobilcom and Swisscom-backed Debitell after its investigation disproved collusion in a German UMTS licence auction. The watchdog ordered a snap investigation after MobilCom's chairman was quoted by a newspaper as saying he might be open to cooperation with Debitel after the German mobile phone licence auction.

 Stake
Internet portal group Lycos has bought a 6.9% stake in internet search engine Fast Search & Transfer for $14.86m (£9.9m), Norwegian data storage group Opticom said yesterday.

 Safe
Almost three out of four film and television producers believe copyrights can be protected on the internet despite concerns about piracy, a survey conducted by Red Herring and the Hollywood Reporter r found.

webTitle: Redstone targets ISP purchase

fields.headline: Redstone targets ISP purchase
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Redstone Telecom , which provides voice services to small and medium sized businesses, said yesterday that it wanted to acquire an internet service provider after buying data group Fastnet for £40m.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom , which provides voice services to small and medium sized businesses, said yesterday that it wanted to acquire an internet service provider after buying data group Fastnet for £40m.

Graham Cove, Redstone chief executive said the company wanted to turn itself into a one-stop shop for its clients.

The aim is to offer a full range of services before the break-up of BT's monopoly over the local telephone network next year.

Mr Cove said any deal to acquire an internet service provider would focus on a specialist business to business company and the deal was likely be in the same price range as the Fastnet acquisition. He stressed, however, that nothing was on the table.

"Redstone wants a dominant share of the broadband access market for small and medium sized businesses providing voice, data and internet," Mr Cove said.

"The Fastnet deal really strengthens our offering - by taking us into the data markets in a big way. There will be more acquisitions as we work toward the bigger picture."

Redstone leases a backbone network across Britain from Fibrenet and has websites in 40 cities.

The company is now laying new cable from those points to local BT exchanges and will be able to take over the so-called last mile to customers' doorsteps once the market is open for competition.

Redstone plans to deploy DSL technology on BT's network which upgrades old copper wires for broadband use.

A rights issue last month raised £1,251m to fund the development of Redstone's network. Redstone also announced yesterday that it had secured a £50m credit facility through investment bank UBS Warburg.

Shares in Redstone climbed 4p to 252.5p but are still some way off their peak of 954p in February.

webTitle: Take note, Mr Byers, the pricing is right

fields.headline: Take note, Mr Byers, the pricing is right
fields.standfirst: Incomprehension or plain idiocy?
fields.trailText: Imagine a socio-microeconomic experiment in which technology was harnessed to create utter and complete transparency between suppliers and consumers. The buyer of any goods or services would be able to see at a glance the true cost of the "value" added by a supplier - such as transportation and packaging - before making a purchasing decision.
fields.body:
Imagine a socio-microeconomic experiment in which technology was harnessed to create utter and complete transparency between suppliers and consumers. The buyer of any goods or services would be able to see at a glance the true cost of the "value" added by a supplier - such as transportation and packaging - before making a purchasing decision.

There would be no room for cartels or hype or special offers that were not actually that special. The laws of demand and supply would operate in an uncontaminated commercial environment.

Let's be specific. Visualise aisle four at Tesco's in Lewisham. Go past the "stay fresh" bread stand but stop before the perennial turkey promotion. On the left you find the lamb chops. The label says: "These two prime cutlets cost Tesco 19.2p at market. If you want them, the price is £2.40."

Bizarrely, in Britain today, this theoretical idea of pure pricing transparency is being floated as a possible real outcome of the competition commission's investigation into supermarkets - the report on which landed on Stephen Byers' desk at the Department of Trade this week.

The suggestion that grocers should display both wholesale and retail prices on their shelves first appeared at the weekend, and initially appeared like a journalist's misunderstanding. Yesterday the idea was gaining wider circulation, suggesting perhaps that it is the result of some Whitehall kite-flying.

Either way, just in case the suggestion is in the competition commission's report and the superficial attraction catches Mr Byers' eye, it should be pointed out now that the idea of regulators imposing full pricing transparency on various sectors of the economy is a nutty suggestion. In fact, it could be downright dangerous.

For the Guardian newspaper it would not be too problematic - cost to you, 45p; cost to us, 45p minus a tiny fraction of a penny. But for the vast bulk of the country's producers and suppliers it would be quite unworkable.

It would also be highly deflationary - in the sense of shrinking the entire economy, not only supermarket prices.

Quite naturally, consumers would be drawn directly to low margin products, cutting innovation, product development, advertising, marketing, hygiene, heath and safety precautions, animal welfare and every other "intangible" in which supermarkets, like other businesses, invest in order to compete.

It is the sort of move that could create panic in the markets, with capital in all its forms fleeing a government which cannot avoid micromeddling.

Apocalyptic stuff, perhaps. But it says something, surely, about Mr Byers' department that the warning even needs to be made.

Beery quirks

Thankfully, however, the trade secretary is becoming worried about the great British pint. He has noted advice from the office of fair trading that Interbrew's attempt to snatch control of Britain's brewing industry by buying the beer operations of both Whitbread and Bass raises "competition concerns", and yesterday Mr Byers asked the European commission to let him "claw back" scrutiny of the Bass deal. Such requests are usually granted - the Brussels bureaucrats are only too happy to pass on work.

Interbrew, best known for making Stella Artois, will have a market share in Britain of 32% if it gets the green light, exceeding Scottish & Newcastle's 29%.

But the Belgian company's confidence that it can pull this off underestimates the strength of feeling surrounding the warm fizzy stuff in this country.

Several MPs have already expressed concern about the prospect of brewery closures, and it will have occurred to Mr Byers that the areas affected would be Labour heartlands such as Burton-upon-Trent and Birmingham.

Interbrew hotly denies the possibility of any job losses and points out that elsewhere, the biggest brewer has a far higher market share.

Its chief executive, Hugo Powell, can reel off the statistics by heart - in Germany, the biggest brewer has 82%, in France 40%, and in Denmark Carlsberg-Tetley has 71%.

However, two wrongs do not make a right - the fact that monopolies exist elsewhere is scarcely a reason for allowing them in Britain, where drinkers are used to a wide choice of both lagers and ales.

If successful, Interbrew will control Carling, Stella Artois and Tennents - the three dominant lagers. It has committed itself to developing local brands, but many industry watchers doubt if a foreign multinational can successfully reproduce quirks such as Bishop's Finger and Old Speckled Hen. The outcome, local brewers fear, is that big brands will squeeze out the rest.

There has already been speculation that the sale of Tennents could be the price Interbrew pays for the deal. If Mr Byers calls in the competition commission, the outcome could be even worse.

The buyer of any goods or services would be able to see at a glance the true cost of the "value" added by a supplier - such as transportation and packaging - before making a purchasing decision. There would be no room for cartels or hype or special offers that were not actually that special. The laws of demand and supply would operate in an uncontaminated commercial environment. Let's be specific. Visualise aisle four at Tesco's in Lewisham. Go past the "stay fresh" bread stand but stop before the perennial turkey promotion. On the left you find the lamb chops. The label says: "These two prime cutlets cost Tesco 19.2p at market. If you want them, the price is £2.40." The suggestion that grocers should display both wholesale and retail prices on their shelves first appeared at the weekend, and initially appeared like a journalist's misunderstanding. Yesterday the idea was gaining wider circulation, suggesting perhaps that it is the result of some Whitehall kite-flying. Either way, just in case the suggestion is in the competition commission's report and the superficial attraction catches Mr Byers' eye, it should be pointed out now that the idea of regulators imposing full pricing transparency on various sectors of the economy is a nutty suggestion. webTitle: BBC Resources merges with Granada Media

fields.headline: BBC Resources merges with Granada Media
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the BBC
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The move towards a more commercially minded BBC was further in evidence yesterday when the corporation's Manchester resources division was merged with the production facilities of rival Granada Media.
fields.body:
The move towards a more commercially minded BBC was further in evidence yesterday when the corporation's Manchester resources division was merged with the production facilities of rival Granada Media.

The new company, called 3sixtymedia, will be 20% owned by the BBC and 80% by Granada. Programmes produced by the combined operation will include many of the best known shows on both the BBC and ITV such as Coronation Street, the National Lottery Show, Stars in Their Eyes and Question of Sport.

Some 85 BBC Resources staff including camera operators, sound technicians, graphic designers and vision mixers will join the new company although an official warned there would be "up to 10" job losses.

The BBC Resources official said: "This is all part of meeting the extra £1.1bn that the government has told the BBC it needs to find. We hope that by combining with Granada we will create a magnet for further productions to the north-west which will increase the amount of money we are ploughing back into the corporation."

Culture secretary Chris Smith told the BBC it would need to find an extra £1.1bn for programme making by either cost cutting or seeking out new commercial opportunities in return for an inflation-busting increase to the licence fee.

BBC Resources was turned into a limited company two years ago allowing it to compete for contracts outside the corporation. It receives no funding from the licence fee but the savings achieved from the merger with Granada will be fed back indirectly into the corporation as higher profits.

The official said 10% of the profits made from 3sixtymedia would be awarded to the corporation, while prices charged to the BBC will be reduced a further 10%. BBC governors have approved the merger but it still needs to be rubber-stamped by Mr Smith.

Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, has already announced plans to shed 1,100 staff to save £750m.

About 340 staff will be joining the new business from Granada and the operation will be housed at existing Granada premises. Bectu, the broadcasting union, said it was seeking assurances on conditions and the threat of further job losses.

Last month Mr Dyke announced the creation of BBC Technology, a standalone business offering IT-related services to broadcast and new media companies. BBC Technology and the changes to BBC Resources are expected to deliver between £150m to £200m over the next six years.

webTitle: Chips are down for ARM

fields.headline: Chips are down for ARM
fields.trailText: Over the past year, microchip designer ARM Holdings has been one of Britain's biggest success stories. Its shares have rocketed on the back of the explosion in mobile phone usage. But yesterday they slumped 36p to 720.5p after analysts at UBS Warburg called its growth potential into question.
fields.body:
Over the past year, microchip designer ARM Holdings has been one of Britain's biggest success stories. Its shares have rocketed on the back of the explosion in mobile phone usage. But yesterday they slumped 36p to 720.5p after analysts at UBS Warburg called its growth potential into question.

The reason is, ironically, mobile phones. The introduction of next-generation phones (2.5G and 3G), which will require multiple ARM processors, was supposed to fuel ARM's continued growth. However, the disappointing take-up of Wap services and the delays in rolling out GPRS have led Warburg analysts to conclude that revenue from these phones will take longer to arrive, and when it does could be smaller than expected.

As a result the analysts, who still rate ARM a "buy", no longer think the shares will hit £10. They are saying that £8.40 is a safer assumption. Investors would do well to heed such advice.

webTitle: Toyota to boost UK output

fields.headline: Toyota to boost UK output
fields.trailText: Car maker Toyota is planning to step up production at its British plant by around 30% next year, according to reports from Tokyo.
fields.body:
Car maker Toyota is planning to step up production at its British plant by around 30% next year, according to reports from Tokyo.

It will spend "several billion yen" to transfer export production of the three-door Corolla hatchback to its plant at Burnaston, Derbyshire, according to the Kyodo news agency. A spokeswoman for the factory said she was unable to comment on the report.

Japanese-owned car plants in Britain have been affected by the strength of the pound against the euro but Toyota's proposal appears to be based on offsetting the strength of the yen.

Over the past two years the Japanese currency has risen from 146 to the dollar to 109.

The exchange rate for the pound has moved from 238 to 165.

Toyota officials believe a switch to Britain of production activity for the Corolla three-door hatchback will reduce risks from appreciation of the yen and raise the operating rate at the Burnaston plant.

"While [adverse] effects of exchange fluctuations are unavoidable to some extent we will reduce them by increasing local production," said Shinro Iwatsuki, Toyota's director in charge of the European market, according to the Japanese agency's report.

The British plant already produces the Avensis and the five-door Corolla. The switch to the three-door Corolla would lift annual output to 230,000 vehicles a year, according to the report.

The suggestion that Toyota is planning to boost British output comes close on the heels of talks between Tony Blair and Carlos Goshn, president of Nissan Motor Company, about Britain's policy towards membership of the single currency. There have been concerns that the strength of the pound in relation to the euro could persuade Nissan not to produce the new Micra at its plant in Sunderland.

The government is thought to be prepared to put up a £50m package to bring the Micra to the north-east - although other car manufacturers are likely to ask for similar help if Nissan does receive government support.

webTitle: At this price? GUS

fields.headline: At this price? GUS
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores (GUS) has been through a storming revival on the stock market since the turn of the year, out-performing other retailers by 45%. But Britain's biggest home shopping group saw its stock fall 12p to 429.5p yesterday as plans to sell non-core assets went awry.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores (GUS) has been through a storming revival on the stock market since the turn of the year, out-performing other retailers by 45%. But Britain's biggest home shopping group saw its stock fall 12p to 429.5p yesterday as plans to sell non-core assets went awry.

The Manchester-based company revealed it had failed to find a buyer for its financial services company, General Guarantee Finance (GGF), which provides cash for vehicle purchasing. GUS also announced it had sold off its Highway Vehicle Management (HVM) arm for slightly less than expected.

GUS had returned to City favour after a disastrous period up to early December when it reported a big fall in home shopping sales. But then came an upbeat Christmas trading statement and improvements in its Experian financial information business and Burberry luxury brand.

Combining retail operations in one business also suggested that GUS chief executive John Peace was back in control.

GUS put the two companies up for sale in April, saying they had combined assets of £1.29bn before deducting £830m of debt.

HVM was sold to First National, an offshoot of Abbey National. Merrill Lynch, which was helping to handle the sale, had offers for GGF, but they did not meet expectations.

This failure depressed the City and led to questions about other planned disposals. GGF will be wound down with the loss of 600 jobs, which will dilute the earnings of the parent group, analysts said.

In the year to March 2000, GGF's operating profit after funding costs was £24m. GUS expects that income earned by GGF as it winds down over three years will cover the cost of closure.

Mr Peace said he was unhappy about the wind-down, but that it was in the best interests of GUS. He said the group had won a good price for HVM.

GUS remains on a price/earnings ratio of 16, with trading improvements to come. "Hold" for now.

webTitle: $4bn windfall at Goldman

fields.headline: $4bn windfall at Goldman
fields.trailText: Former partners and current employees of Goldman Sachs were in the process of turning $4bn (£2.7bn) of stock into hard cash last night as a special share sale was being priced by Wall Street's most powerful investment bank.
fields.body:
Former partners and current employees of Goldman Sachs were in the process of turning $4bn (£2.7bn) of stock into hard cash last night as a special share sale was being priced by Wall Street's most powerful investment bank.

Analysts expected the price of the "secondary offering" to be in line with the company's market price yesterday. At midday, the shares at almost $99 had moved only slightly upwards since the offering was announced two weeks ago.

At this level, current and former employees would earn $3.96bn from the first offering of shares since the bank converted from a partnership to a listed company last year.

Among those who have indicated in advance their desire to sell up to 15% of their holdings is Gavyn Davies, the London-based chief economist. Mr Davies was tipped to sell 219,572 shares, worth $22m at yesterday's price.

Jon Corzine, the former chief executive who is a Democratic contender for a seat in the US Senate this year, was set to gain most from the sale. Mr Corzine, who was ousted from the board more than a year ago, has filed to sell 411,668 shares, worth $41m.

Mr Corzine has already entered the history books for spending more of his own money than any other candidate in a Senate race. Even after laying out over $37m on the campaign in New Jersey, Mr Corzine's personal wealth is estimated at more than $450m.

Among other Europe-based sellers is Peter Sutherland, a former boss of the World Trade Organisation who now chairs Goldman's European business. He has filed to sell more than $14m worth of shares held both individually and in a family trust. Simon Robertson, who joined Goldman nearly three years ago from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, is expected to make about $11m.

Wall Street analysts expect the share price to come under some pressure largely because the bank is planning further share sales.

Goldman is committed to increasing the percentage of its shares held by institutional investors rather than individuals in order to increase the volumes traded.

webTitle: Nomura ready to raise Hyder bid

fields.headline: Nomura ready to raise Hyder bid
fields.trailText: Nomura is poised to raise its bid for Hyder, the debt-ridden Welsh multi-utility, after the US group Western Power trumped the Japanese agreed bid of £495m with an offer of £526m.
fields.body:
Nomura is poised to raise its bid for Hyder, the debt-ridden Welsh multi-utility, after the US group Western Power trumped the Japanese agreed bid of £495m with an offer of £526m.

The Hyder board, which earlier unanimously backed the improved Nomura bid, up from 260p to 320p a share, was last night taking counsel on the higher WPD offer, raised from 300p to 340p.

"We will respond in due course," Hyder, owner of Welsh Water and Swalec, the electricity distribution business, said as its share price rose 24p on the day to close at 347p amid hopes that stockholders could extract even more value from a group with £1.8bn of debt.

"We are considering our options," a Nomura statement will say later today - although sources close to the deal indicated the Japanese bank was not out of the game.

The outcome of the bidding war is seen as critical to further consolidation in Britain's heavily regulated utilities sector and, more particularly, to recent proposals to return the assets of water companies to their customers and split these from day-to-day operational management.

WPD, owner of South-west Electricity (Sweb), has yet to win clearance for its complex plans to retain Welsh Water's assets and hand over daily operational control to United Utilities, itself in the throes of selling its Norweb electricity supply business.

Mike Kinski, chief executive-designate of Hyder under Nomura's bid, which has already been cleared, said his new offer now had the backing of the entire Hyder board. Its original bid, although recommended, produced one dissenter and one abstainer.

The battle for Hyder has cut to the core of Welsh political life, with the new national assembly and unions backing Nomura because the bank will keep the utility intact with its head office in Cardiff and original name, and will make no job cuts over and above the 1,000 set in train by the present board.

Mr Kinski, who is to embark on a fresh campaign to win shareholder and political backing, said the only difference under the new bid was that Nomura would consider exiting some of Hyder's stakes in non-Welsh infrastructure projects.

webTitle: Minister to make case for the activist state

fields.headline: Minister to make case for the activist state
fields.trailText: Government failure to invest has held back many businesses in Britain, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will admit later today as he sets out his blueprint for an active but non-interventionist industrial policy.
fields.body:
Government failure to invest has held back many businesses in Britain, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will admit later today as he sets out his blueprint for an active but non-interventionist industrial policy.

Mr Byers, a former Treasury chief secretary, says the government is able to invest in a growing economy because just 17p of every £1 of public spending goes on debt interest, unemployment benefit and social security spending - compared with 42p in 1997 when Labour took office.

"This investment shows that strong, high quality public services and support for our infrastructure must not be seen as a burden but can actually be a driver for economic growth," he will say.

Mr Byers has been attacked recently over the government's apparent inability to tackle the recent collapse in the manufacturing sector. However, figures out yesterday should have assuaged the trade secretary's critics, with manufacturing output rebounding last month.

The purchasing managers index rose to 51.8, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply - its highest reading this year. In June the index stood at 50.4, just above the critical 50 break-even level. Any number above 50 on the index marks an expansion while a figure below 50 indicates the sector is shrinking.

The institute said the pick-up in July had been driven by robust growth in new orders, mostly from within Britain. However, export order books are filling up as well, with the index at 51.0, back in positive territory.

The strength of the pound has ravaged industry - most notably it was blamed for leading to the botched sale of Rover by BMW, another stick used to beat Mr Byers.

The new figures also raised concerns that higher interest rates - which could see the pound strengthen - were on the way. Raw materials costs are rising at a faster rate than last month, which might alarm some members of the monetary policy committee who begin their rate-setting meeting today.

Drawing the lessons from Rover, Mr Byers will set out areas for an active industrial policy. One is helping older industries such as coal through a period of change imposed by government policy.

A second is high-risk areas with potential benefits such as the Airbus A3XX super-jumbo.

webTitle: Dutch may pay job takers £1,000

fields.headline: Dutch may pay job takers £1,000
fields.trailText: Unemployment in Holland has fallen to such low levels that the government is considering a plan that would offer those out of work a bonus of more than £1,000 if they sign up for a job.
fields.body:
Unemployment in Holland has fallen to such low levels that the government is considering a plan that would offer those out of work a bonus of more than £1,000 if they sign up for a job.

The Dutch social affairs ministry, which drafted the plan, is putting forward seemingly desperate measures in an effort to tempt potential workers into the job market.

With dole queues down to a 20 year low - the official unemployment rate is 2.4% - there are concerns that the labour market squeeze could start to have an impact on wages and inflation. Pay increases are running at around 4% - hefty by Dutch standards - although there are hopes that tax cuts will boost spending power and take some of the heat out of next year's pay bargaining.

But for unemployed people pondering a job offer the choice is often a tricky one. Many on low incomes receive additional benefits - from help with the rent to "city cards" which entitle them to discounts on a range of municipal services - which would be lost if they were to take a job.

"Accepting a job might imply that people had to work 35 hours a week and they might only get as much income as they did from benefits and other kinds of subsidies," according to Nico Klene, an economist at ABN Amro in Amsterdam.

Critics of the scheme suggest that all those with the skills to find a job have already done so and that the bonus scheme is hardly likely to produce large numbers of unemployed people with IT skills which are in high demand in Holland, as elsewhere in Europe.

However, others suggest that the scheme may tempt unemployed people to take jobs in others sectors like the construction industry where there is also an increasing shortage of labour.

If, as is widely expected, the bonus scheme does get the backing of the Dutch government, workers who sign up will still only get the first tranche of the 4,000 guilder payment after six months in the job and will have to keep it for a further 18 months in order to qualify for the full amount.

That is some way short of bonus schemes in the City, for example, where some investment bankers and fund managers are said to be getting "signing on" fees or loyalty bonuses running at 100% or more of their often six-figure annual salaries - usually payable upfront.

Even if every jobless person in Holland took a job - including those not claiming benefit - the government's bill would only be around £350m. You cannot buy a mobile phone licence for that these days.

webTitle: New York rescue Peptide assists search for West Nile vaccine

fields.headline: New York rescue Peptide assists search for West Nile vaccine
fields.trailText: The United States government has enlisted the aid of Peptide Therapeutics, the struggling Oxford-based vaccines company, in an attempt to tame West Nile disease, a deadly virus that is terrorising New York.
fields.body:
The United States government has enlisted the aid of Peptide Therapeutics, the struggling Oxford-based vaccines company, in an attempt to tame West Nile disease, a deadly virus that is terrorising New York.

The publicly funded US National Institutes of Health have awarded Peptide an immediate grant of $263,000 to be followed by $2.7m over the next two years to finance development of a vaccine.

The award comes a week after New York's mayor, Rudy Giuliani, ordered police to evacuate Central Park and spray Manhattan with pesticide in an attempt to rid the city of the mosquito-borne virus.

Peptide's chief executive, John Brown, said: "In America the disease has only just arrived, so no one's got any base level of immunity to it. That makes it all the more dangerous."

Peptide reckons it can come up with a vaccine for the disease based on an existing product in clinical trials for Japanese encephalitis, a degenerative disease widespread in Asia. Dr Brown said: "We know we've got the technology - all these viruses are from the same family."

West Nile disease surfaced in New York for the first time last year, killing seven people. Based on antibody surveys, the authorities believe 2.5% of the city's residents were infected to some degree.

Peptide has made big losses in recent years but is in bid talks with a British competitor, Cantab Pharmaceuticals.

webTitle: AstraZeneca hires 1,300

fields.headline: AstraZeneca hires 1,300
fields.standfirst: Drug firm bolsters sales force to promote new product and maintain prots
fields.trailText: AstraZeneca yesterday signalled its intention to ride out the demise of the world's best-selling prescription drug, Losec, by recruiting 1,300 extra sales staff and launching its follow-up product, Nexium, at a knock-down price.
fields.body:
AstraZeneca yesterday signalled its intention to ride out the demise of the world's best-selling prescription drug, Losec, by recruiting 1,300 extra sales staff and launching its follow-up product, Nexium, at a knock-down price.

Britain's second largest pharmaceuticals firm makes a third of its revenue from ulcer treatment Losec, which is about to lose its patent protection. Nexium, which will be launched in Sweden on August 14, is crucial to its hopes of maintaining its profits.

Chief executive Tom McKillop revealed that a 40mg dose of the new medicine would initially cost less than a 20mg dose of Losec. The new product has been greeted with scepticism by some experts, who say it offers little benefit over generic competitors.

Mr McKillop cited tough competition for the aggressive pricing strategy: "We want to ensure Nexium's taken up quickly. We don't want price to be a barrier to that."

"It's in no way a comment on the quality of the drug. Nexium is proven to be significantly better than existing treatments," he said.

However, some industry experts interpreted the low price as a vote of no confidence in the new product. One leading analyst said: "They're admitting they don't really have a product which shows a great deal of superior differentiation and which they can charge a premium price for."

The launch of Nexium will involve one of the biggest marketing campaigns the drugs industry has seen. AstraZen eca has devoted $200m (£133m) this year to "pre-launch costs" and is likely to spend more next year, when the product will become available in the US. It insists it is more effective, and faster acting, than existing treatments for stomach upsets.

A recruitment drive in the US will take the group's salesforce to around 6,000, ranking it third behind the merging groups Pfizer and Glaxo SmithKline.

Losec's first-half sales edged up 4% to $2.97bn amid tough competition in Europe and the US. AstraZeneca's interim pre-tax profits rose 19% to $2.44bn, helped by a recovery at its agrochemicals business, which is about to be spun off.

The figures were slightly ahead of forecasts, sending AstraZeneca's shares up 46p to £29.22.

Mr McKillop stressed that the group had far more in its pipeline than Nexium. He said AstraZeneca's performance had been driven by a list of "mega-brands" including schizophrenia drug Seroquel and prostrate cancer treatment Casodex. There are also high hopes for a new heart drug, ZD4522, which has shown impressive results in clinical trials and is likely to be launched within two years.

Analyst Michael King of SG Securities said: "The figures came in on target but they are in a pretty defensive position, with Losec losing protection."

Last year's merger of Astra and Zeneca has yielded greater savings than expected - the group expects $600m of benefits this year, rather than $500m. Finance director Jon Symonds said that the job losses resulting from the deal could number "a little bit more" than the expected figure of 6,000. He said that the extra savings would largely be in administrative areas.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
British bus makers merge

A decision by Britain's biggest bus makers, Mayflower and Henlys to merge operations yesterday will lead to redundancies among their combined workforce of 3,350.

The two companies will amalgamate their British bus and coach manufacturing units to create Europe's fourth biggest player with pro-forma revenues of some £460m.

Transbus International, which will be 70% owned by Mayflower and 30% by Henlys, is aiming to make both firms more competitive in Europe's bus and coach industry.

Go expands route network

British Airways' low-cost airline Go yesterday added Tenerife and Glasgow to its list of routes and will also soon fly to Belfast. The airline said it would resume flights from its base at London's Stansted airport to Munich and once again offer Lyon as a winter route. Four flights a day will be offered to Glasgow, with return fares from £48 starting on November 1. Flights to Tenerife will start on September 27 with return fares from £148.

Fund manager up for sale

Scottish fund manager Murray Johnstone has appointed Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to seek a buyer for its asset management business after reaching agreement with parent Old Mutual. Analysts said the fund group, which has assets under management of more than £4.2bn, could fetch around £100m.

Old Mutual acquired Murray Johnstone in June, when it paid $2.2bn (£1.5bn) for US fund group United Asset Management.

At the time of the UAM deal, Old Mutual said it was likely to rationalise the 40 asset management operations owned by UAM. Earlier in the year, Old Mutual also purchased London-based asset manager the Gerrard Group for £525m.

Pokémon hurts fantasy factory

Games Workshop, the manufacturer of monsters and fantasy figurines, intends to target older children after seeing its profits collapse due to the popularity of Pokémon cards among pre-teens.

The firm said children were vulnerable to toy fads and did not appreciate wargames, which required reading, painting and strategic thinking. It intends to alter its shops to attract more adolescents.

Full-year profits fell 47% to £6.5m, and the shares fell 17.5p to 147.5p. The company warned its first-half profits were likely to remain sluggish, falling short of last year's levels.

Daewoo sheds 113 jobs

Car maker Daewoo is to axe 113 jobs from its British technical centre under plans to cut costs, workers were told yesterday. The cutback at the Worthing site in West Sussex, which employs 750 people, is less than originally feared.

webTitle: BBC reins in Humphrys

fields.headline: BBC reins in Humphrys
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: John Humphrys is not exactly known for giving his guests on Radio 4's Today programme an easy ride, but BBC governors have decided that Britain's best-loved curmudgeon has overstepped the mark once too often.
fields.body:
John Humphrys is not exactly known for giving his guests on Radio 4's Today programme an easy ride, but BBC governors have decided that Britain's best-loved curmudgeon has overstepped the mark once too often.

In a strongly-worded ruling, they have criticised the presenter for constant interruptions during a discussion with the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson. The tone of his questioning was inappropriate, they added.

Lord Robertson, according to the governors' quarterly complaints report, felt Mr Humphrys had used the interview as a "platform for his own opinions". His "over-frequent interruptions had at times amounted to a critical running commentary".

The interview was broadcast in February, in the approach to the first anniversary of the Nato bombing campaign in Kosovo. According to Nato, Mr Humphrys suggested to Lord Robertson that the campaign had simply replaced one sort of ethnic cleansing with another, as the Kosovans drove out Serbs from the province.

It is understood that Lord Robertson, generally a robust interviewee, was irritated by "snorting" noises made by Mr Humphrys as he attempted to reply, and by an unusually large number of interruptions. The former defence secretary felt he was not given the opportunity to respond to the points being put to him.

After reviewing the interview, the governors ruled in favour of Lord Robertson. "Although the premises of Mr Humphrys' questions referred to views expressed by others rather than the opinions of his own, the tone of questioning was inappropriate at times, and the frequency of interruption was ill-judged," they concluded.

Mr Humphrys has become known for his aggressive interviewing style, which has drawn criticism and praise in equal measure. He once interrupted the Conservative chancellor Kenneth Clarke 32 times, and also upset Labour's former social security secretary, Harriet Harman. The gov ernors reveal that after the latest incident, the editor of Today, Rod Liddle, told Mr Humphrys that he expected a "different approach to be adopted when the subject was next covered".

A Nato spokesman welcomed the governors' ruling and the way the complaint was handled. "We are pleased. Lord Robertson is quite a robust sort of fellow, and he doesn't mind a bit of to-ing and fro-ing. But we felt that on this occasion it had gone too far." Also in the complaints bulletin, published yesterday, the presenter Jonathan Ross is reprimanded for two tasteless comments: one about the facial appearance of stroke victims on his Radio 2 show, and another about Romanian orphans made on his BBC1 quiz It's Only TV... But I Like It.

The governors upheld a complaint from a parent offended by explicit sexual references as she listened with her children to the Radio 1 DJ Chris Moyles at 10am on a Saturday, and censured Blue Peter for allowing its name to be associated with the website of an organisation opposed to the illegal trade in ivory.

The makers of two programmes may be asked to broadcast on-air apologies. An episode of the BBC2 documentary The Spying Game was judged to have been misleading, and a report on the Nine O'Clock News gave an "inaccurate" explanation of the euro's impact on the economy in Ireland.

Altogether, 36 complaints were upheld in the three months between April and June this year - 14 fewer than in the same period last year.

webTitle: French Concordes stay grounded

fields.headline: French Concordes stay grounded
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: British Airways last night announced that it plans to keep Concorde flying for at least another eight years, although there was no reason why the plane should not remain in service until 2015.
fields.body:
British Airways last night announced that it plans to keep Concorde flying for at least another eight years, although there was no reason why the plane should not remain in service until 2015.

Its plans for Concorde were confirmed as Air France made clear in Paris that its fleet of five Concordes would stay grounded until it knew the official reasons for the crash of flight AF 4590 from Charles de Gaulle airport in which 113 people died a week ago.

BA, which was part of the team which examined the crash debris, has finished taking part in the Paris talks between the British and French civil aviation authorities. It also exchanged information with Air France colleagues on maintenance and said there were no material differences between them.

Airframe and engine maufacturers, including Rolls Royce, are understood to have participated in yesterday's talks in Paris. Experts are unsure what extra safety measures should be introduced on the Air France fleet until the cause of the crash is determined.

"We are at the beginning of a difficult investigation," said Alain Monnier, head of the inquiry commission investigating the crash.

He added: "We have a certain number of elements that are certainties or quasi-cer tainties. But we still don't know how to construct a scenario that links all the events together." These elements include evidence that one or two of the Concorde's tyres exploded and one of the plane's engines shut down, followed by the shutdown of another engine.

In addition, the plane's undercarriage did not pull up and it had difficulty climbing into the sky, never achieving a sufficiently fast speed, said Paul Louis Arslanian, head of the French accident and inquiry office. "We also found evidence of fuel leakage. It was this leak that eventually caught fire. This was the cause of the fire," he added.

BA yesterday grounded the same Concorde that had to make an emergency landing at Heathrow on Saturday after a loud bang was heard inside the jet, caused by a mixture of fuel and air. Yesterday it was taken out of service for "minor adjustments" shortly before it was due to leave Heathrow for New York. The 33 passengers were switched to a back-up Concorde which took off at 12.56pm instead of the scheduled 10.30am. The company insisted that there were no grounds for concern over the plane's safety. A BA spokeswoman said the company was being "especially vigilant" about any technical irregularities.

BA said senior engineeers were not 100% happy with the aircraft after it had been inspected. The Concorde had just come out of the hangar after maintenance and pre-flight checks. The spokeswoman said: "It had an engine change and engineers wanted to make a few more checks on it. Rather than delay passengers even more, we took the decision to bring in another aircraft."

BA maintains a staff of some 200 engineers who regularly service the seven strong Concorde fleet. In the last year 37 official safety reports - called mandatory occurrence reports - have been filed to the Civil Aviation Authority from either pilots or air traffic controllers concerning Concorde. There have been more than 100 other minor incidents logged by BA which were not thought to be of sufficient importance to be passed on to the CAA. The CAA said: "Thirty-seven safety reports on seven aircraft over the past 12 months is not unusual and less than we would get for sub-sonic jumbos. It shows how seriously aircraft safety is regarded in Britain."

The house of a German couple who died in last week's crash has been ransacked by thieves. A police spokesman said intruders broke a police seal on the front door of the couple, Helga and Wolfgang Schnitter, at Potsdam, near Berlin. fields.bodyText: British Airways last night announced that it plans to keep Concorde flying for at least another eight years, although there was no reason why the plane should not remain in service until 2015. Its plans for Concorde were confirmed as Air France made clear in Paris that its fleet of five Concordes would stay grounded until it knew the official reasons for the crash of flight AF 4590 from Charles de Gaulle airport in which 113 people died a week ago. BA, which was part of the team which examined the crash debris, has finished taking part in the Paris talks between the British and French civil aviation authorities. It also exchanged information with Air France colleagues on maintenance and said there were no material differences between them. Airframe and engine maufacturers, including Rolls Royce, are understood to have participated in yesterday's talks in Paris. Experts are unsure what extra safety measures should be introduced on the Air France fleet until the cause of the crash is determined. "We are at the beginning of a difficult investigation," said Alain Monnier, head of the inquiry commission investigating the crash. He added: "We have a certain number of elements that are certainties or quasi-cer tainties. But we still don't know how to construct a scenario that links all the events together." These elements include evidence that one or two of the Concorde's tyres exploded and one of the plane's engines shut down, followed by the shutdown of another engine. In addition, the plane's undercarriage did not pull up and it had difficulty climbing into the sky, never achieving a sufficiently fast speed, said Paul Louis Arslanian, head of the French accident and inquiry office. "We also found evidence of fuel leakage. It was this leak that eventually caught fire. This was the cause of the fire," he added. BA yesterday grounded the same Concorde that had to make an emergency landing at Heathrow on Saturday after a loud bang was heard inside the jet, caused by a mixture of fuel and air. Yesterday it was taken out of service for "minor adjustments" shortly before it was due to leave Heathrow for New York. The 33 passengers were switched to a back-up Concorde which took off at 12.56pm instead of the scheduled 10.30am. The company insisted that there were no grounds for concern over the plane's safety. A BA spokeswoman said the company was being "especially vigilant" about any technical irregularities. BA said senior engineeers were not 100% happy with the aircraft after it had been inspected. The Concorde had just come out of the hangar after maintenance and pre-flight checks. The spokeswoman said: "It had an engine change and engineers wanted to make a few more checks on it. Rather than delay passengers even more, we took the decision to bring in another aircraft." BA maintains a staff of some 200 engineers who regularly service the seven strong Concorde fleet. In the last year 37 official safety reports - called mandatory occurrence reports - have been filed to the Civil Aviation Authority from either pilots or air traffic controllers concerning Concorde. There have been more than 100 other minor incidents logged by BA which were not thought to be of sufficient importance to be passed on to the CAA. webTitle: Petrol boycott dumped by apathetic drivers

fields.headline: Petrol boycott dumped by apathetic drivers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A boycott of petrol stations called in protest at high fuel duty failed to leave forecourts deserted yesterday, with fuel retailers reporting business as usual despite a widely publicised "dump the pump" protest.
fields.body:
A boycott of petrol stations called in protest at high fuel duty failed to leave forecourts deserted yesterday, with fuel retailers reporting business as usual despite a widely publicised "dump the pump" protest.

Protest organisers had hoped to render the nation's garages "no go areas" in a show of solidarity among motorists that chancellor Gordon Brown could not ignore.

In fact many motorists continued to pour petrol into their tanks and cash into Treasury coffers. Duty accounts for 72% of the price of fuel, making petrol prices in the UK the highest in Europe and the government, rather than the oil companies, the focus of discontent.

Organisers of the campaign expressed disappointment that more people did not choose to fill their tanks on Monday or today instead.

"The response has varied in different parts of the country and in some places we've had reports of 50% less sales, but this is just the start," said Russell Neave-Houghting of www.boycott-the-pumps.com, co-ordinators of the campaign.

"It's not been as good as we hoped, obviously, but we will go ahead with the boycott next Monday and every Monday afterwards." As well as the sight of busy forecourts, organisers had to endure humiliation as a planned blockage of Dover was abandoned when just 12 vehicles out of an expected 200 turned up. The rolling roadblock of six cars and six lorries set out from Ashford in Kent but came to halt just an hour later.

"We just stopped at Dover and had a cup of tea," said Len Johnson, chairman of the Hauliers and Farmers Alliance which organised the blockade.

"It sends all the wrong signals and makes the government think hauliers don't mind paying high tax on fuel."

Throughout the country, sales appeared to be barely affected, with any minimal losses offset by higher sales on Monday night.

"There has been a slight dip in sales today but our stations aren't empty," said a spokeswoman for supermarket giant Tesco, which has 308 garages in Britain.

"It was busier than normal last night, so the circumstantial evidence is that some people are stocking up for today."

The Retail Motor Industry Federation, which surveyed 350 garages across Britain, said the evidence showed the campaign had not really worked, despite dips of 10% in Scotland and south London and a 30% drop in trade in the north-west, where drivers are believed either to have been particularly irate, or to have relied on fuel smuggled to Merseyside from southern Ireland.

"For the most part, sales have been unaffected except for a few areas," said its spokesman, Jonathan Akerman. "Even where there have been dips, these have evened out as the day has gone on."

At the Rex service station in Taunton, Somerset, an Esso garage selling unleaded fuel at a knockdown 79.9p a litre, manager Harry Shand said business was normal.

"I've not noticed any difference. We were a bit busier last night but today it's been what you expect for this time of year," he said.

Mr Shand said he believed low prices had kept the custom flowing - a token offer of 2p off every litre was due to expire yesterday.

At the pumps it seemed a mixture of ignorance, indifference and pragmatism had brought motorists out despite the calls for militancy. All agreed that petrol could be cheaper but most were unsure whether the boycott would have any effect.

"I didn't know the protest was today," said local resident Timothy O'Donnell as he filled his silver Sierra Sapphire with unleaded.

"I don't think it will make a blind bit of difference. I'm not sure why people get so worked up about petrol. Everything gets more expensive, but put a few coppers and fuel together and blokes will talk about it for hours in the pub. I'd like to see it cheaper but it just won't happen."

Stuart Lambert, 24, a teacher with a blue Daewoo, said the motorist was in an impossible situation. "Petrol's too expensive, but I need fuel and it's too far to push the car home. People have to use cars and if we say we want cheaper fuel they say it has to come off the NHS or education. That pays my wages so I end up feeling guilty." Andy Aggus, a builder filling his Iveco tipper truck with £70 of diesel, recommended more extreme action.

"We should do what the French do, cause bloody havoc and close the country down, then someone might listen. I'm from Burnley originally and it costs around £100 to make the round trip from there."

Chris Priddy, owner of the independent, Four Pump Brendon Services in nearby Watchet, had been concerned that his operation would be hurt by any boycott. By lunch-time however, he had not noticed any downturn in trade.

"I sell about £1,400 of fuel a day but it's hardly worth it. I make £34 profit on every £1,000 of sales. If people pay by credit card I make only £16 because of the charges. I make more on a packet of fags than I do on petrol."

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 In the midst of all the hype about Viking helmeted barbarians in Blackpool, there is shocking news of further holiday mayhem. I suppose it was inevitable, but the latest group to reveal the thuggish underbelly to British society is - yes, you guessed it - gardening fans. Last Thursday at the Lost Gardens of Heligan, near St Austell in Cornwall ("Not to be missed", Daily Telegraph), some 500 plant watchers were inspecting the delightfully restored walled flower gardens when an enormous rain storm burst. Quickly, management opened the greenhouses and the tourists took shelter alongside a prized crop of several hundred delicious peaches ripening on the branch. You know the rest. Locusts, they were, these Heligan hooligans, and they stripped the branches clean. "The trees were heaving with fruit all ready for picking," says co-owner Candy Smit. "It was the most amazing crop we've ever had - and it went in minutes. It's incredible how the most well-heeled customer can resort to taking things." Indeed. How long now, I wonder, before outbreaks of lawlessness at Gardeners' Question Time imperil the life of Bob Flowerdew?

 From the neighbouring county of Devon, where Michael Winner and I spent the weekend (although not together), the Tavistock News Gazette carries a Letter of the Week contender. "The front page of last week's issue reports that... the sports minister demonstrated her skill at ping pong, yet the picture indicated Ms Hoey holding a table tennis bat," writes Derek Ellis. "If it was the sports minister who identified table tennis as 'ping pong' she should not be in the job. It if was your reporter... he, or she, should spend a week or two working with your sports editor." Marvellous. We hope to clarify the issue with Ms Hoey later today.

 Thank God Gordon Brown has no ego problems or he might be irked that in a survey of people aged 16-21, he who has done so much for youth employment was recognised by just 24%. Mr Tony Blair scored 91%, two behind Pokémon character Pikachu (an O'Mandy Mandelson figure, he says little but wields much power) and five behind Super Mario (96%). There is no figure for Treasury secretary Andrew Smith, whom we propelled into the cabinet by campaigning to raise his profile, but we like to think he would have given his boss a run for his money.

 Little has been heard of Richard Balfe MEP since his foolish radio intervention on Dobbo's behalf during the Labour mayoral fiasco. So it's good to see him keeping busy. Richard writes to Tribune in praise of the Ilisu Dam, which is "much needed . . . I am in no way intending to be an apologist for torturers but simply attempting to present a different and more balanced view." Indeed - so balanced, in fact, he neglects to mention that the Turkish government paid for his hotel during a trip last year when he was also treated to a journey to Northern Cyprus. Anyway, excellent timing to have the letter published such a short time before the government it is intended to suck up to decided to suspend funding of this "much needed" project. Do keep them coming, Richard. You always cheer us up.

 A reader writes concerning Gerald Kaufman Month. Do we not recall Gerald's appearance on Through the Keyhole, asks Graham McCann, which showed Loyd Grossman admiring Gerald's framed posters of the magical Hollywood musicals, "something of a shrine to Judy Garland". No, frankly, I don't. Gerald and I were constant companions at musicals before our falling out (once we were thrown out of Starlight Express when Gerald produced a pair of rollerskates and tried to storm the stage), so it's hurtful that he never mentioned going on the show. Come on BBC, give us another chance to see this classic episode!

webTitle: Sarah Payne suspect released

fields.headline: Sarah Payne suspect released
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting the killer of Sarah Payne yesterday released a man they had been questioning without charge.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting the killer of Sarah Payne yesterday released a man they had been questioning without charge.

Mechanic Roy Whiting, 41, was quizzed for the second time about the eight-year-old girl following his arrest on Monday. But after being questioned for 24 hours, Mr Whiting was released to the prison service, which is holding him on unrelated charges.

Pressure is increasing on detectives to find the person who abducted and murdered Sarah. Though one of her shoes was found, they still have no solid forensic evidence leading them to the killer.

Mr Whiting was first arrested on July 2, the day after Sarah vanished from fields close to her grandparents' home near East Preston, West Sussex, but was released three days later without charge.

After he was freed, the house in Crawley where he was thought to be staying was targeted by youths who hurled abuse and threw stones.

Mr Whiting appeared in court on Monday on unrelated motoring, theft and assault charges and immediately afterwards was re-arrested in connection with Sarah's murder - exactly a fortnight after the girl's naked body was found in a field beside the A29 near Pulborough, West Sussex.

Detective Superintendent Peter Kennett, who is leading the hunt for the killer, said that "fresh evidence" had come to light. He would not say what the new information was but it is understood that it was not forensic evidence. Police have carried out a massive hunt for Sarah's clothes, which could hold vital DNA clues.

There was speculation that Mr Whiting was to take part in an identity parade but well-placed police sources said this had not happened, suggesting that the new evidence had not come from somebody who had actually seen a possible suspect.

Mr Whiting could have been questioned for up to 96 hours before being charged or released. But yesterday afternoon Sussex police spokesman Nick Sandford said: "Police can confirm that a Littlehampton man in his 40s, held in connection with the Sarah Payne murder inquiry, is no longer being questioned by detectives. He has been released on police bail, pending further inquiries."

At a press conference on Monday to announce the re-arrest Mr Kennett, who has taken over from Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley in the last week, urged caution, saying: "Just because someone's arrested it doesn't mean to say they will be charged."

Sarah's parents, Sara and Michael, both 31, have been kept fully informed of the developments.

Yesterday they were discussing details of a memorial service to be conducted by the sub-dean at Guildford cathedral, Canon Maureen Palmer, on August 12.

A spokesman for the family said: "Sara and Michael's biggest worry is that there will not be enough room for all the people who want to attend, so they want to make sure provisions are made for anyone who cannot be inside the cathedral."
