webTitle: In praise of Winnie

fields.headline: In praise of Winnie
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Jacques Peretti
fields.trailText: The Unauthorised Vinnie Jones/Natural Born Fighters/A Many Splintered Thing
fields.body:
There's a song, and it goes something like this: "Vinnie Jones, Vinnie Jones, you better believe he's innocent, or else he'll break your bones". Given these options, I'd give Vinnie the benefit of the doubt, wouldn't you?

With or without the threat of limb-twisting violence, one would never deny Vinnie his wishes. If there's one man who deserves love, happiness and a giant house in the Hollywood Hills, it's "Jonah" (as everyone calls him). Swallowed a whale-sized bag of nails when he was a child and has been spitting them out ever since.

After his parents' marriage fell apart, the 16-year old Vinnie left home, dossing across the country, washing dishes in grim Victorian-built public schools for more fortunate children. His only comfort in the long workhouse nights: a bag of school boy footie trophies. Nothing to lose, the teenage Vinnie travelled to Sweden to pursue his football dream and The Unauthorised Vinnie Jones (C4) found a gem of an interview in his manager of the time: a man who proved the John Motson car-coat not just still alive, but the sartorial lingua franca of guv'nors across the globe.

"He came to Sweden a boy," he said, "and left (lump in throat) a man." How did Swedish football cause this transformation in the young Vinnie? "One match, it was one of centimetre of snowing on the pitch. All players have tracksuit bottoms, but one player have short trousers." And who was this player? "Winnie Jones," (dramatic pause) "a hard man."

Back in Blighty, Jonah joined the Crazy Gang, the Wimbledon team who conquered Liverpool in the '88 Cup Final. Dennis Wise, a little firecracker himself, disarmingly explained the truth about the team: "We were a load of players that hadn't done very well, released by other clubs, and that was it. Everyone had a point to prove." Watching Vinnie after the final whistle, threatening to throw the Cup to jubilant fans, hanging his winner's medal on his penis, is like watching Johnny Rotten at the 100 Club.

Despite the shepherding hand of the manager, Vinnie wouldn't have his actions mediated by the stilted protocol of the occasion. He was punk rock on a football pitch. The Cup Final Vinnie will soon be forgotten, and it's the One-2-One Family man (who occasionally beats a neighbour to within an inch of his life) that we'll remember. A disappointing end to a Dickensian tale.

Guy Ritchie, shot in a soft focus usually reserved for Joan Collins, talked us through the missing scene from Vinnie's next big film, Snatch: "Vinnie pisses in someone's pocket without them knowing - we've lost the scene, which is a pity, because it was a crowd pleaser."

Natural Born Fighters (C5) told the story of bare-knuckle fighting in Britain, not once mentioning the contribution of young Vinnie. In 1975, at Billy Smart's Circus, Roy "Pretty Boy" Shaw, who could "do two or three geezers at a time" met Donny Adams, the King Of The Gypsies, for the crown of hardest underground fighter.

The bout was billed as a fight to the death. Men would link arms round the fighters in order to prevent police from stopping the rivers of claret. There were just two rules: "no biting, and no gouging". Roy had fists like trucks - "they're a gift from God" - and before Pretty Boy had even broken sweat, the Gypsies had lost their king.

As children swung from Waltzers, Pretty Boy Shaw and Donny Adams celebrated the grand pugilistic tradition, stretching back before Lord Queensbury to a time (lump in throat) Before Rules. Here was a moment as revered in the history of illegal fighting as Vinnie's penis-medal moment in Wimbledon's long history of illegal fighting.

Alan Davies continued to fight women off with his hair in A Many Splintered Thing (BBC1). Davies is accompanied wherever he goes (bedrooms) by Motown records and a fat cardigan-wearing bloke (last seen advising on male commitment in Bread and Goodnight Sweetheart).

Writer Geoff Deane has finally given audiences what they want by having Davies nutted on the nose, and Davies has risen to the occasion, convincing as the nauseating star ("do you really think that hurting me will make you feel better?" Yes). Enjoyment is spoilt by the obligatory magic-realist happy ending.

I'd have preferred a bare-knuckle fight with Josie Lawrence, but TV is seldom perfect.

A disappointing end to a Dickensian tale. Guy Ritchie, shot in a soft focus usually reserved for Joan Collins, talked us through the missing scene from Vinnie's next big film, Snatch: "Vinnie pisses in someone's pocket without them knowing - we've lost the scene, which is a pity, because it was a crowd pleaser." Natural Born Fighters (C5) told the story of bare-knuckle fighting in Britain, not once mentioning the contribution of young Vinnie. In 1975, at Billy Smart's Circus, Roy "Pretty Boy" Shaw, who could "do two or three geezers at a time" met Donny Adams, the King Of The Gypsies, for the crown of hardest underground fighter. The bout was billed as a fight to the death. Men would link arms round the fighters in order to prevent police from stopping the rivers of claret. There were just two rules: "no biting, and no gouging". Roy had fists like trucks - "they're a gift from God" - and before Pretty Boy had even broken sweat, the Gypsies had lost their king. As children swung from Waltzers, Pretty Boy Shaw and Donny Adams celebrated the grand pugilistic tradition, stretching back before Lord Queensbury to a time (lump in throat) Before Rules. Here was a moment as revered in the history of illegal fighting as Vinnie's penis-medal moment in Wimbledon's long history of illegal fighting. Alan Davies continued to fight women off with his hair in A Many Splintered Thing (BBC1). Davies is accompanied wherever he goes (bedrooms) by Motown records and a fat cardigan-wearing bloke (last seen advising on male commitment in Bread and Goodnight Sweetheart). Writer Geoff Deane has finally given audiences what they want by having Davies nutted on the nose, and Davies has risen to the occasion, convincing as the nauseating star ("do you really think that hurting me will make you feel better?" Yes). Enjoyment is spoilt by the obligatory magic-realist happy ending. I'd have preferred a bare-knuckle fight with Josie Lawrence, but TV is seldom perfect.

webTitle: Faulty and costly but still it tempts Clinton

fields.headline: Faulty and costly but still it tempts Clinton
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has to make a decision by the autumn on whether to go ahead with what the administration has always called a limited version of the national missile defence system.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has to make a decision by the autumn on whether to go ahead with what the administration has always called a limited version of the national missile defence system.

The version under consideration involves installing some 100 interceptors at a site in Alaska - plus radar tracking stations in Britain, Greenland and the Aleutian islands - to guard against the possible launch of a missile aimed at any part of the US by "states of concern" - notably North Korea and Iran.

The administration's formal position on this version of NMD is that Mr Clinton will take his decision on the advice of the defence secretary, William Cohen, following the completion of the latest stage of the interceptor test programme.

The decision would take into account the workability of the programme, its cost, the international impact of such a decision, and an assessment of whether the programme was necessary in the light of the known threats. On almost every count, Mr Clinton has a strong case for abandoning the project.

The latest test of the interceptor, fired from the Marshall islands in the Pacific against a test missile launched from California in July, failed. The cost of the project is mounting rapidly and the international outcry is embarrassing. Even the threat now seems to be in question, following the gentle thaw in America's relations with North Korea.

Yet Mr Clinton is afraid of scrapping the NMD project, fearing that it would revive cold war arguments that the Democrats - especially his own Vietnam generation - are "soft" on defence.

He does not want to add further political burdens to Al Gore's attempts to win the presidency. As a result, he is in effect allowing the Republican party to call the shots. The Republicans already despise Mr Clinton's NMD project as timid and the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, wants an expanded version.

webTitle: The Republicans are convinced that their cuddly new image will take George W to the White House

fields.headline: Bush plays it sweet
fields.standfirst:
The Republicans are convinced that their cuddly new image will take George W to the White House

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Republicans are convinced that their cuddly new image will take George W to the White House.
fields.body:
If the father promised a "kinder, gentler" America, then the son has set his heart on a sweeter, lighter Republican party. Even the stodgiest of couch potatoes watching at home couldn't fail to get the message beamed out from the convention which tomorrow will crown George W Bush: after New Labour and the New Democrats, behold the New Republicans.

From the opening act, the pledge of allegiance delivered by a blind mountaineer, to the black woman who sang the Star-Spangled Banner, the Republican lovefest in Philadelphia has been bent on projecting a softer, cuddlier image. Gone is the red-meat rhetoric that sent the party crashing to defeat in 1992: at that year's convention, professional fire-breather Pat Buchanan declared a "culture war" in America, in which Republicans would "take back our country, street by street". Two years later Newt Gingrich was leading an army of angry white males in a Republican revolution that stormed the Congress. The result was a party with a persona that could be captured in a single adjective: mean-spirited.

This time Bush Jnr is determined to shake off that image. He wants to do for the Republicans what Tony Blair and Bill Clinton did for Labour and the Democrats: to ditch their old reputations for extremism and march towards the vote-rich centre. For Blair and Clinton, that meant keeping a safe distance from policies or people associated with the old left. For George W, it means inclusion and diversity. Or, put another way, shoving white males into the background and showing off everyone else.

The strategy is so blatant as to be almost comic. The three co-chairs of the convention just happen to be a black Oklahoman, a hispanic Texan and a white single mother. The headline speaker on Monday was the black former general and Gulf war hero, Colin Powell. Last night's prime-time hour kicked off with Condoleeza Rice, Bush's choice for national security adviser: she is black and a woman (and therefore a "twofer", quips one Republican strategist). The entertainment tonight will come from Harold Melvin (black) and Jon Secada (Cuban); tomorrow George W will be serenaded by Chaka Khan. Already delegates have swayed to a black gospel choir and been roused by a black, revivalist-style preacher in full throat. One of the few white males to make it has been Congressman Jim Kolbe, who won a decent speaking slot last night. But he had an advantage that outweighed his white-maleness: he is gay.

"Make no mistake about it," warns my Republican strategist. "Bush is personally obsessed with diversity." Besides his wife Laura, W has asked only one other Bush family member to speak in Philadelphia. It is not his brother Jeb, governor of Florida, nor even his father, the former president (whose defeat W is so determined to avenge in November). No, the invitation went to his nephew, George P, on the Mexican side of the family: he will deliver half his address tomorrow in English, half in Spanish.

What is George W playing at? Surely he does not expect to erode the decades-old Democratic lock on America's minorities and suddenly recruit black and hispanic Americans to the party of Nixon, Reagan and Gingrich? No, he is not as naive as that - though he reckons he has a chance to make inroads into the latino vote. Rather, the object of all this cuddly, compassionate conservative attention can be seen in the placards delegates are waving on the floor of the First Union Center. "W," they say, "stands for women."

Republican thinking is that not many black voters are likely to leave the party of Bill Clinton, famously hailed by novelist Toni Morrison as "our first black president". Instead, it is white suburban women, the floating voters known as "soccer moms", who may be persuaded to see the Republicans in a whole new light. Bush's advisers want to set women thinking, "If this party is friendlier to minorities, then perhaps it will be friendlier to me." (The chase for women's votes also explains the convention's constant emphasis on children: Powell's speech mentioned the word 37 times.)

If that's the logic, will it work? It has already paid dividends for the Republicans themselves. They are in more confident form in Philly than they have been for years - some say since Reagan's re-election convention of 1984. They believe they finally have a winner in Bush, and a winning game-plan: ditch the old, harsh rhetoric and sound sweet.

The trouble is that the image and reality don't quite match. Take the convention itself. For all the diversity on the platform, little more than 4% of the delegates in the hall are black. You could see that when the Bill Jolly gospel choir was in full flight: what the cameras picked up was an audience full of white folks, clapping out of time. You can see the same problem in the party's programme, formally endorsed on Monday: it still commits Republicans to a total ban on abortion and to adamant opposition to gay rights. You can see it in the reaction to the tougher, truth-telling passages in Powell's speech. When the general told Republicans they had to reach out to ethnic minorities, especially African-Americans, "not just during an election-year campaign" but "every day; it must be for real", the delegates paused. When he scolded them for opposing affirmative action, which had helped so many black youngsters, they held back their applause.

And you can see it most clearly in the biggest decision George W has yet had to make: his choice of running-mate. The former defence secretary, Dick Cheney, has been cast as a grey-haired Mr Gravitas, adding ballast to a featherweight candidate. But the choice of Cheney is more revealing than that: it shows that Bush is still more conservative wolf than compassionate sheep.

As a congressman, Cheney had one of the most consistently rightwing voting records of any Republican in the House. He voted against a gun-control measure that would have banned so-called "cop-killer" armour-piercing bullets; in 1986 he even voted against a call for the release of Nelson Mandela. In a TV interview this week, Cheney's wife Lynne denied that their daughter was living openly as a lesbian: she reacted as if it were an accusation. None of this will help make George W's Republican party look either kinder or gentler.

How all this pans out is not merely an American tale. If Bush becomes president it will sound alarm bells for both Tony Blair and William Hague. For Blair, it will signal an end to the third-way era, in which the PM could present himself as on the crest of an international, centrist wave. Suddenly the "new" in New Labour will look jaded: so 90s. For Hague, the worry is of a different order. If George W proves that conservatives win only when they project an image (whatever the reality) of diversity and inclusion, then where does that leave the party of section 28, the party that hounds asylum seekers? This week Hague, Blair and the rest of us should keep an eye on Philadelphia, the city of brotherly love.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Antz/Farewell My Lovely/Shirley Valentine/Le Bossu
fields.body:
Antz

(Eric Darnell, Tim Johnson, 1998)

12noon, Sky Premier

The DreamWorks' animated blockbuster starts hilariously, with the Woody Allen-voiced Z-4195 ("the middle child in a family of five million") on the psychiatrist's leaf, wondering if there's more to life than being a worker ant. There is. Romance with Princess Bala (Sharon Stone) and war with the termites is just around the corner. With Sly Stallone as a soldier ant and Gene Hackman as crazy General Mandible, this is inspired fun - even if the screen is at times stodgy with subterranean hues.

Farewell My Lovely

(Edward Dmytryk, 1945)

5.15am, Carlton Cinema

This adaptation of Raymond Chandler's novel marked the beginning of 1940s film noir and the reinvention of crooner Dick Powell as a serious actor. Lovingly crafted by Dmytryk, with sharp dialogue, gloomy photography and fine performances. Mike Mazurki was the definitive Moose Malloy, setting the private eye after Claire Trevor's marvellous Velma, spelt t-r-o-u-b-l-e.

Shirley Valentine

(Lewis Gilbert, 1989)

1.15am, Sky MovieMax

Pauline Collins is endearing as the downtrodden housewife who, fed up with talking to the wall rather than miserable Scouse husband Bernard Hill, jets off on a Greek holiday with giggly Alison Steadman. Then it's dusky romance with the poor woman's Zorba, Tom Conti, plus guilt, reconciliation and self-discovery, all ladled on by writer Willy Russell like meze for 12.

Le Bossu

(Philippe de Broca, 1998)

2.25am, Sky Premier

De Broca stages one of those breathless, beautiful swashbucklers the French do so well (La Reine Margot, Horseman On The Roof and all). It must be something to do with the Musketeers tradition. The ubiquitous Daniel Auteuil is Lagardère, a 17th-century swordsman. When his friend - the heroic, doltish Duc de Nevers (Vincent Perez) - is betrayed by his scheming cousin Gonzague (Fabrice Luchini), Lagardère is left to bring up the Duc's orphaned daughter and seek revenge.

webTitle: Blairs backtrack on family photocall

fields.headline: Blairs backtrack on family photocall
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was yesterday persuaded to change his mind about not staging a family photocall for the media at the start of his summer holiday in Tuscany next week after discreet arm-twisting by the Press Complaints Commission.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was yesterday persuaded to change his mind about not staging a family photocall for the media at the start of his summer holiday in Tuscany next week after discreet arm-twisting by the Press Complaints Commission.

He will allow television and newspaper photographers to train their lenses on all six family members, including 16-year-old Euan, who was recently found drunk and incapable after a teenage drinking spree, and his baby brother, Leo.

The decision by the prime minister and his wife, Cherie, to reverse their earlier stance amounted to a diplomatic success for the PCC's chairman, Lord Wakeham, the wily ex-cabinet minister whose "Mr Fixit" talents were honed as the Tory chief whip and the leader of both the Commons and the Lords.

In a statement, Lord Wakeham made clear that No 10 had called for his "guidance" after the weekend run-in over unauthorised photos of Leo's christening at a Catholic church in Mr Blair's Sedgefield constituency.

He promised wider consultation with the media and some new guidance in the PCC's code of practice, but offered a short-term compromise.

Noting the Blairs' "serious reservations about putting their children in the public eye", Lord Wakeham concluded that "the most constructive way to strike the balance between legitimate privacy and legitimate public interest in photos of the family is for them to undertake this photocall during the first few days of their holiday".

"No 10 agrees with me on this - and we hope that after the photocall has taken place the family will be able to complete its holiday in private."

The decision to cut out the Tuscan photocall predated the christening row and, in part, reflected the Blairs' anxiety that they will be accused of exploiting their children for political ends if they make them too accessible.

In reality, as the royal family has found, a balance which offends no one is almost impossible to maintain. No photos of Euan, Nicky, 14, or Kathryn, 12, were used in Sunday's christening photo.

Downing Street put a brave face on the tactical retreat and stressed that the photocall will be conducted at the media's request, not theirs.

"It is now well over a year since up to date photos of the older children were released; they have decided that all six of them will take part together in this photocall," a statement from Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press spokesman, added.

"This is a difficult area, in that the prime minister and Mrs Blair wish their children to enjoy as normal an upbringing as possible and to be able to grow up without the constant glare of the media spotlight.

"However, they also accept that given the prime minister's very high public profile there is bound to be an interest in his family, particularly since the arrival of the baby."

Last night a Conservative spokesman, Andrew Lansley, praised Lord Wakeham for common sense and consistency.

"It is only surprising that anything else should have been considered by Downing Street," he said.

webTitle: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What people in launderettes are watching
fields.trailText: What people in launderettes are watching
fields.body:
I. Franklyn: "I'm very much into the Crimewatch programmes and consumer affairs. Watchdog I think is excellent programming, it's what the BBC should be doing. I like Minder and The Bill and that sort of thing; I suppose I don't actually watch the Bill anymore, but they're repeating Minder. A lot of people told you that? Must be big news, girl, hahahah! Anything else? No, I like to watch TV then sit out in my garden and enjoy the peace. You need peace round here."

Jillie Fleurt: "I like the Proms and I like to watch any footage they show. I'm a big fan of classical, but you don't see it on TV so much now. I like Nigel Kennedy and - oh, I did see that Carol Vorderman programme on that Lesley Garrett and I thought she was a smasher. Very special person. So kind, and not a prima donna at all."

Tom Fard: "I can't see the TV for cats in my house - we've got six and they crawl over everything, including me and my dinner, and all I have is fur in my face. If I could watch the television I wouldn't know who was who because they all look the same. I watched a bit of that Big Brother nonsense and they're all the same, aren't they? Young and fit and everything, there's no old codgers like me! I could go and live there. Looks like they have to survive on my money and all. No cats though. But I wouldn't miss them, to tell you the truth."

Irene May: "I'm a big supporter of films on in the afternoon - sit down and have a cup of tea time. They've just had The Rebel on this afternoon and it really makes me laugh. Tony Hancock pretends to be an artist - well, he is an artist I suppose - and he goes to Paris and becomes famous. Wonderful film. A lot of pictures remind me of the rubbish about today. I went to Tate Modern with my daughter and I couldn't see anything for a start, but a lot of it was pap. I like Gilbert and George though - they make me laugh."

Sin Pattenden spoke to people in launderettes in Tufnell Park, North London.

Wonderful film. A lot of pictures remind me of the rubbish about today. I went to Tate Modern with my daughter and I couldn't see anything for a start, but a lot of it was pap. webTitle: Grandson in quest for Jews' ship of despair

fields.headline: Grandson in quest for Jews' ship of despair
fields.standfirst: Relatives plan tribute to 778 who died fleeing Holocaust in 'coffin ship' advertised as luxury liner
fields.trailText: In 1942 a wartime Jewish refugee sent his family in England a postcard from a ship called the Struma, telling them where his assets were.
fields.body:
In 1942 a wartime Jewish refugee sent his family in England a postcard from a ship called the Struma, telling them where his assets were.

But its underlying message was so clear that even today his British grandson can hardly bear to read it. "I don't think we're going to make it," Grigori Bucspan was saying.

The Struma was - as he had suspected - a "coffin ship", although Grigori and his wife Enta had paid $1,000 to travel on what was advertised as a luxury liner taking them to safety in Palestine. A few days later the rickety, overcrowded vessel on which they spent 71 nightmarish days exploded and sank in the Black Sea.

Some 778 passengers, 272 of them women and children, drowned in one of the worst tragedies of the flight from the Holocaust. Even amid the distractions of the war against Hitler, the disaster provoked furious questions in the Commons and Lords.

On Sunday the grandson, Greg Buxton, 35, from Birmingham, flies to Turkey in a long-planned personal mission. He hopes this will end in Kaddish - the Jewish prayers for the dead - being said over the sea graves of his grandparents and all the other victims for the first time in 58 years.

With a team of 13 others, he will dive more than 200 feet to investigate a series of wrecks near Istanbul. By what Mr Buxton said he regarded as "perhaps too much of a miracle", Turkish divers announced yesterday that they were convinced they had found the remains of the Struma this month. Levent Yuksel, a diver with Turkey's underwater research society, said all evidence pointed to it being the riverboat, which was built 132 years ago.

"Its length, its depth, its stern are identical to the Struma," Mr Yuksel said.

Mr Buxton said he hoped they could find and confirm the wreck in time for a memorial service due to be held for the dead in Istanbul on September 3. Nearly 40 of their relatives, who now mainly live in Israel and the United States, are expected to attend.

With them will be the Struma's only survivor, David Stoliar, who lost his girlfriend, schoolmates and friends from Romania on the ship. Mr Stoliar, 19 at the time, clung to debris in the sea to survive. Turkish men rowed out from a nearby lighthouse to save him 24 hours later. He is convinced the ship was torpedoed.

If it is found, the vessel will be left on the seabed as a mass grave. But Mr Buxton hopes material about the tragedy will be used in British schools by the Imperial War Museum, London, and the Holocaust Education Trust. Both are involved in the project to trace the vessel. Mr Buxton's names are an anglicisation of his grandfather's Romanian names. It was his father, Michael Buxton, who received Grigori and Enta's postcards from the Struma.

Michael was in England, where he had come in the 1930s to study as an engineer. He saw the news of the sinking while serving as a British soldier. He and his wife, now in their 80s, will fly out to the Istanbul memorial service.

Gregory Buxton, an IT systems manager, grew up familiar with his grandparents' story. But what fired him into action was a visit to Israel two years ago.

There he traced the plot of land which Grigori and Enta had bought to live on if their flight from persecution succeeded. They had had to flee twice in their lives: Grigori, originally a Russian Jew, had been economic adviser to the short-lived Kerensky government overthrown by Russian communists in 1917. "It moved me very much when I thought that this was the closest I could get to their graves," Mr Buxton said, "That was when the idea came to me that I ought to pursue this bit of my family history".

He discovered a story of financial exploitation by Romania of its fleeing Jewish minority and "profound hypocrisy" by Britain, which controlled wartime immigration to Palestine. From the onset of war, the Romanian port of Constanza seethed with thousands of Jewish people queuing at travel agencies for passages on what sometimes turned out to be "coffin ships".

In late 1941 Grigori and Enta, then in their 50s, were among those who saw a voyage advertised to Palestine on a luxury liner. Posters and brochures featured a picture of the Queen Mary.

In fact, the Nazis had requistitioned almost all waterworthy Romanian ships to carry food and cattle to Germany. The ramshackle Struma, only 155 feet long, without a single lavatory, abandoned in dock, was rated too old to risk cattle.

Renamed and re-registered, she horrified her Jewish passengers. But they were told they would be transferred to a cruise liner offshore. Instead, she reached Istanbul with a wonky engine and leaking hull. There passengers were stranded on board in pigsty conditions for 71 days because Britain maintained that its Palestine immigration quota did not cover "enemy aliens".

On February 23, Turkey ordered the Struma out of port. Next day she blew up. Placards appeared on London streets declaring that Sir Harold MacMichael, Palestine high commissioner, was wanted for "murder of 800 refugees".

Sir Harold was the only official punished after a parliamentary uproar. He was blamed for delays in telling Turkey about British willingness to admit children aged 11-16 on the ship to Palestine. Sir Harold was transferred to Malaya. After the war several attempts were made to assassinate him. He was wounded twice.

webTitle: McDonald's sued over hot drinks

fields.headline: McDonald's sued over hot drinks
fields.trailText: Solicitors will today launch an action against the McDonald's hamburger chain on behalf of more than 20 customers, most of them children, who claim they were burned by hot tea or coffee served in the company's restaurants.
fields.body:
Solicitors will today launch an action against the McDonald's hamburger chain on behalf of more than 20 customers, most of them children, who claim they were burned by hot tea or coffee served in the company's restaurants.

"Many of the children involved are toddlers," said Adrienne de Vos from the Manchester law firm Slater, Heelis, Collier, Littler, which represents 13 of the alleged victims.

About 20 more cases are in preparation and more inquiries are expected.

"I know that some would say such drinks are meant to be hot and that people should simply take more care," said Ms de Vos.

"This misses the point. Customers don't realise just how hot and dangerous these drinks are and the level of damage that can be caused."

The solicitors will argue that McDonald's knowingly served hot drinks at dangerously high temperatures in breach of both the Consumer Protection Act (1987) and the Occupiers Liability Act (1957).

Ms de Vos said most cases were the result of a spill. "Some have involved young children who have picked up a drink without knowing how hot it is and then spilled the contents down their chests," she said.

In other cases, it is alleged that customers have accidentally dropped or spilled drinks on children, causing them to suffer weeks of pain, and in one case, permanent scarring.

Ms de Vos claims evidence similar to that of her clients had satisfied an American jury.

In 1994 81-year-old Stella Liebeck was awarded $2.7m in punitive damages (later reduced to $480,000) and $160,000 in compensation after she spilled a cup of coffee in a McDonald's restaurant in New Mexico.

She spent seven days in hospital after being scalded on her groin, thighs and buttocks.

In a statement, McDonald's said yesterday that its first concern was the safety of its customers. "All our products, including drinks, are carefully prepared to precise specifications. All our hot drinks are served in cups fitted with a lid bearing the words 'Caution - hot'.

"We will be examining the proceedings once issued and made available to us. However it will not be possible for us to discuss any individual cases."

webTitle: Store claims to be beating salmonella in eggs

fields.headline: Store claims to be beating salmonella in eggs
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Sainsbury yesterday claimed a new technique of pasteurising eggs in their shells would go some way to eliminating the health risk that raw and lightly cooked eggs pose in pregnancy and for babies and the elderly.
fields.body:
Sainsbury yesterday claimed a new technique of pasteurising eggs in their shells would go some way to eliminating the health risk that raw and lightly cooked eggs pose in pregnancy and for babies and the elderly.

The heat treatment, which is said to kill salmonella bacteria in raw eggs, does not alter the taste or texture of the eggs, Sainsbury said. Consumer trials will be conducted before the eggs - which could be more costly for customers - go on sale next year.

The chain's move is the latest in the supermarket world to aim at the position of leader in food safety. Since the salmonella in eggs scare in the 1980s the industry has endeavoured to prove it can significantly cut the risks of food poisoning.

Sainsbury's chief microbiologist, Alec Kyriakides, said: "Developing a simple natural process which eliminates the risk is a major leap forward in food safety."

The British Egg Industry Council, however, questioned the need for pasteurisation given the move to vaccinate flocks. About 70% of the 27m eggs eaten by Britons daily are already covered by the Lion quality mark.

webTitle: Ms Bush nearly mentions C*****n

fields.headline: Ms Bush nearly mentions C*****n
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Laura Bush had been mainly silent, a smiling and reserved presence at the side of her aspiring husband, George W Bush. But on Monday night she delivered a speech that could have a profound impact on November's presidential election.
fields.body:
Laura Bush had been mainly silent, a smiling and reserved presence at the side of her aspiring husband, George W Bush. But on Monday night she delivered a speech that could have a profound impact on November's presidential election.

During her 10-minute, prime-time speech to her party's convention in Philadelphia, Ms Bush gave the US electorate its first serious look at the woman who could become America's "first lady".

What they saw was a slightly nervous but carefully choreographed debut, with Ms Bush, a former teacher, addressing the convention from in front of 20 inconceivably well-behaved schoolchildren. What they heard was a west-Texas drawl that could have come straight out of a Tennessee Williams play. But what most people surely must have thought was - "this sure ain't Hillary".

Explicit references to the current occupants of the White House have been ruthlessly written out of this week's convention; no one is allowed to attack either of the Clintons for fear of appearing mean-spirited. Yet Ms Bush came the closest of any speaker to highlighting a contrast between the two candidates that lies close to the surface of this election - especially in Republican minds.

When people come up to her husband, Ms Bush told the audience in Philadelphia, "they say to George, 'I'm counting on you. I want my son or daughter to respect the president of the United States of America."

It was by far the most pointed remark in Ms Bush's otherwise down-home style speech - and the hall erupted in the biggest and most prolonged demonstration of enthusiasm of the evening.

Ms Bush is such a conspicuous contrast with Ms Clinton that it is hard not to suspect that the introverted, home-focused, quietly wifely persona which she projects has been crafted by a Republican focus group. Yet the reality seems to be as it appears.

The former first lady Rosalynn Carter would have daily policy lunches with her husband, Jimmy; Nancy Reagan would intrigue for and against her favourites in the White House staff; Ms Clinton headed the administration's health-policy reform team and is now running for the Senate.

But when the Bushes were interviewed together recently, and Laura was asked to assess her own influence, she said: "I don't give him a lot of advice. I really don't think George wants a lot of advice from me."

That's not true, her husband protested. "Well I don't want a lot of advice from him," she retorted.

webTitle: Legal aid threat to home owners

fields.headline: Legal aid threat to home owners
fields.trailText: The government is planning to virtually abolish the remnants of the civil legal aid system for most home owners in England and Wales in a move to finance greater access to free legal advice for people with little or no capital assets.
fields.body:
The government is planning to virtually abolish the remnants of the civil legal aid system for most home owners in England and Wales in a move to finance greater access to free legal advice for people with little or no capital assets.

In a move denounced by the Law Society as "catastrophic" in its effects - and condemned by some libertarian MPs - the lord chancellor's department has issued a consultation document which would deny full legal aid to anyone with more than £3,000 of equity in their property.

Under the proposals they would not have to sell their homes before taking legal action but the government would claim its costs when the owner eventually sold up - charging "commercial rate" interest in the meantime.

It would "effectively abolish legal aid for all owner occupiers", said the Legal Aid Practitioners Group.

But the government insists that a slightly higher proportion of households - 49% instead of 48% - will now be eligible for some legal aid because of other proposals.

The "capital eligibility limit" of £1,000 in bank accounts will be raised to£3,000.

Currently anyone with up to £100,000 tied up in their home can qualify for legal aid. The average first time buyer had £11,780 of equity last year - £25,000 in the case of existing owners moving house.

Ministers defend another squeeze on "middle class perks" - the trade-off for lower direct tax rates - as a way to fund the extension of the government's community legal service.

It gives free, early advice to low income groups - especially on social welfare issues such as benefit disputes and employment law.

David Lock, the junior minister in charge of the service, called the change a means of "providing a fairer system for people who need the help most" as well as ensuring that "there is a balance between those receiving publicly funded help and those funding their cases themselves." The proposals amount to a deterrent to litigants whose claims are not well founded - they would have to bear all or part of the cost.

But lawyers' groups say it would also "deny an awful lot of people any real chance of access to justice." Critics, including Labour MPs and peers who tried to resist the 1999 Access to Justice Act - Lord Irvine's reform of legal aid - complain that the exercise is chiefly about saving money on a very expensive system.

Legal aid doubled in just six years to £1.5bn by the time Labour returned to power in 1997, £700m for civil legal aid. Government supporters argue that many beneficiaries of the system include the better off and legal aid lawyers, a problem which bedevils the criminal courts where sophisticated crooks salt away huge assets and claim legal aid.

Robert Marshall-Andrews QC, the Labour MP for Medway, said: "This proposal is entirely consistent with what has transparently been the government's policy for some time, that is to say an end to civil legal aid and its replacement by the no win, no fee contingency fee system, something very close to the American ambulance chasing system."

During the passage of the access to justice bill, the MP and his allies failed to ensure that children, pensioners and the disabled would retain legal aid to sue companies and other better funded litigants.

Under pressure from lawyers, Lord Irvine made an exception for medical negligence, which is famously costly and is still funded by legal aid for lower income claimants.

But most personal injury cases, for example car accident claims, must be funded personally or from no win, no fee or insurance based arrangements.

Lord Irvine's concern to get most help to the neediest commands widespread support, but some lawyers say his preoccupation with benefit and employment law reflects the priorities of his own legal practice - Cherie Booth QC is based there.

webTitle: Byers orders carmakers to give discounts worth £1bn a year

fields.headline: Byers orders carmakers to give discounts worth £1bn a year
fields.trailText: British consumers penalised by "rip off" prices in the motor industry gained a partial victory yesterday when the government announced plans to cut the average cost of a car by £1,100.
fields.body:
British consumers penalised by "rip off" prices in the motor industry gained a partial victory yesterday when the government announced plans to cut the average cost of a car by £1,100.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the change would save car buyers an estimated £1bn a year - about 10% on the price of a car.

His announcement was broadly welcomed, but the Consumers' Association - while estimating savings could be as high as 25% on some cars - still described it as "only a limited step forward".

Until the car industry was no longer exempt from competition law - which bans manufacturers from fixing different prices for dealers in separate countries - British consumers would still be penalised, it warned.

The announcement follows the publication in April of a competition commission report which found British consumers were paying around 10% more for a new car compared to their European coun terparts. A subsequent European Union survey, released last month, revealed British buyers were paying up to twice as much for some makes - with 65 of the top 73 models being more expensive in Britain than in any other country in Europe.

The April findings prompted price-cutting among manufacturers, with Mitsubishi, Porsche and Land Rover slashing prices by 10%, and Ford, Peugeot and Renault making cashback offers of up to £1,500.

But the flurry of activity could not disguise the discrepancies and yesterday Mr Byers, who has spearheaded the campaign against "rip off Britain", insisted these should be tackled more permanently.

Under a new legal order - which will come into force on September 1, the day of the next number plate change - suppliers must offer the same discounts to individuals as they do to fleet buyers.

They will also be prevented from paying bonuses or giving preferences to dealers who pre-register cars (under this system, dealers inflate their "sales" figures by registering them in their own names and then sell them to genuine purchasers later); and they will be required to publish information about the number of cars pre-registered - thus discouraging the industry from being able to sell them as "nearly new" and so keep other prices artificially high.

The minister acknowledged that he had set a "demanding" timetable, but added: "I believe it is more important for the industry to bring prices down quickly and give consumers the confidence to buy."

The motor industry pointed out that prices had fallen by more than 6% in the past year, and warned buyers not to expect a massive reduction immediately.

"The Consumers' Association have come up with a figure of 25% but we've no idea where that's come from. There's no way we can cut prices by a quarter," said Rob Halloway, of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. "As it is, this is demanding legislation, although it's reasonably fair."

But private car dealerships - which have not been offered the discounts available to fleet buyers previously - welcomed the measures.

"At last the consumer can visit their car dealer with total confidence, assured that they will get the best deal around when purchasing their new car," said David Evans, chief executive of the Retail Motor Industry Federation.

"This order will deliver lower prices quickly, and restore consumer confidence."
fields.bodyText: British consumers penalised by "rip off" prices in the motor industry gained a partial victory yesterday when the government announced plans to cut the average cost of a car by £1,100. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the change would save car buyers an estimated £1bn a year - about 10% on the price of a car. His announcement was broadly welcomed, but the Consumers' Association - while estimating savings could be as high as 25% on some cars - still described it as "only a limited step forward". Until the car industry was no longer exempt from competition law - which bans manufacturers from fixing different prices for dealers in separate countries - British consumers would still be penalised, it warned. The announcement follows the publication in April of a competition commission report which found British consumers were paying around 10% more for a new car compared to their European coun terparts. A subsequent European Union survey, released last month, revealed British buyers were paying up to twice as much for some makes - with 65 of the top 73 models being more expensive in Britain than in any other country in Europe. The April findings prompted price-cutting among manufacturers, with Mitsubishi, Porsche and Land Rover slashing prices by 10%, and Ford, Peugeot and Renault making cashback offers of up to £1,500. But the flurry of activity could not disguise the discrepancies and yesterday Mr Byers, who has spearheaded the campaign against "rip off Britain", insisted these should be tackled more permanently. Under a new legal order - which will come into force on September 1, the day of the next number plate change - suppliers must offer the same discounts to individuals as they do to fleet buyers. They will also be prevented from paying bonuses or giving preferences to dealers who pre-register cars (under this system, dealers inflate their "sales" figures by registering them in their own names and then sell them to genuine purchasers later); and they will be required to publish information about the number of cars pre-registered - thus discouraging the industry from being able to sell them as "nearly new" and so keep other prices artificially high. The minister acknowledged that he had set a "demanding" timetable, but added: "I believe it is more important for the industry to bring prices down quickly and give consumers the confidence to buy." The motor industry pointed out that prices had fallen by more than 6% in the past year, and warned buyers not to expect a massive reduction immediately. "The Consumers' Association have come up with a figure of 25% but we've no idea where that's come from. There's no way we can cut prices by a quarter," said Rob Halloway, of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. "As it is, this is demanding legislation, although it's reasonably fair." But private car dealerships - which have not been offered the discounts available to fleet buyers previously - welcomed the measures. "At last the consumer can visit their car dealer with total confidence, assured that they will get the best deal around when purchasing their new car," said David Evans, chief executive of the Retail Motor Industry Federation. "This order will deliver lower prices quickly, and restore consumer confidence."

webTitle: George Bush senior is back, basking in republican adulation

fields.headline: Eat your heart out Hillary, Laura's playing Mrs America
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The blond moppet on the giant video screen was just telling the country that "responsibility is picking the clothes off the floor in your room", when the least spontaneous collection of delegates to grace a party convention since the death of Stalin broke into wild cheering.
fields.body:
The blond moppet on the giant video screen was just telling the country that "responsibility is picking the clothes off the floor in your room", when the least spontaneous collection of delegates to grace a party convention since the death of Stalin broke into wild cheering. There he was, flapping his hands in the usual damp embarrassment. There she was in her iron girdle, standard black dress and whiter than white hair. Welcome Mr President and Mrs Bush.

Old George and old Barbara, of course. Winning any office in America hands you the title for life, free. Young George is still wending his way to Philadelphia, but ma and pa are back, basking like arthritic seals in the adulation and starring in their own video of golden presidential terms.

This is, to put it mildly, rich. Four years ago, George senior was zero hero, the great unmentioned, the wimp who'd squandered Ronnie's inheritance. Now, the Republican spin doctors assert, "he's a legend - though George W is his own legend, too." Some tonnes of artefacts from the memorial library have accordingly been shipped north from Texas for lavish public display.

You can see a parachute "from the same production run" as the one which happily opened when George bailed out over the Pacific, the inevitably black dress and pearls worn by Barbara at a state banquet for the president of Yemen, a thank you note from Arnie Schwarzenegger for a "great Camp David weekend", a fawning letter - signed "Respectfully, Francis Albert" - from Sinatra, which rails against the "torching of the ultimate symbol of decency and freedom in the world". (That flag again).

Are the Bushes reborn as the new Kennedys? It's a funny old world. Enter Laura Bush, George junior's wife, playing, I suppose, a kind of downhome Ethel. "When I married him, George told me I'd never have to make a speech." Promises, promises.

Laura, in lime, talks literacy non-stop (though "Barbara is the First Lady of Literacy"). She can - just about - manage an autocue. She seems to be touchingly ordinary. "George and I grew up in Midland, Texas, a small town in a vast desert, where neighbours had to help each other because any other help was too far away."

Just ordinary oil millionaires passing the water bucket and dreaming of summer in Maine at the Bush Towers North, Kennebunkport. It really is the most terrible tosh. But any convention that features a black gospel choir that far outnumbers the blacks on the floor, a quiz show with Miss Diabetic America, two rock bands and a national anthem from New Mexico's answer to Charlotte Church is hardly going to turn picky. Politicians (save for an edgily eloquent Colin Powell) are off this agenda. The show is a compassion-soaked rum baba.

Laura comes from a land "with a big sky full of stars". She believes in kids, and pictures of kids - America's future. "Moms and dads and grandparents bring those pictures to parades and picnics. They hold them out and they say to George: 'I'm counting on you ... I want my son or daughter to respect the president of the United States'." Or, if possible, be the president.

Eat your heart out Hillary. Laura's playing Mrs America. Back in that travelling library, though, there are other exhibits. "Fate '92", it says dolefully. "Presidential campaigns, like footballs, can take a bounce" - a kind way of saying: whatever happened to old George's 91% approval rating?

One minute you're up, the next you're Bob Dole, another lost leader, wheeled out to creakily honour veterans of the second world war. The Chelsea pensioner detail. One minute you're the epitome of "courage, dedication and service", the next you're the packet of elephant-shaped "Dog Treats" bought yesterday.

The first book on the shelf at a stand called the Laura Bush reading room is Touch and Feel. Touchy, feely? Yucky, creepy?

webTitle: Not enough to stop the brain drain

fields.headline: Not enough to stop the brain drain
fields.trailText: We are delighted that you have put science on the map for the Guardian manifesto (Money can keep British science in the race, July 31). We have been pushing these issues within the Labour party for over five years and can claim some success. We need scientists within the other parties to do likewise.
fields.body:
We are delighted that you have put science on the map for the Guardian manifesto (Money can keep British science in the race, July 31). We have been pushing these issues within the Labour party for over five years and can claim some success. We need scientists within the other parties to do likewise.

One issue which neither the government's science white paper (Universities to get funds to encourage genius, July 27) nor the Guardian has tackled adequately is the unattractive career prospects for young post-doctoral scientists. We shall be pressing the government to deal with this more radically - if we don't get this right our scientific heritage could be in jeopardy.
Prof Willie Russell
Chair, Scientists for Labour wcr@st-andrews.ac.uk

The government's white paper announcement to improve salaries of the top few scientists and help stem the "brain drain" is just pitiful. There was more hype and money for the new Football Foundation.

The government should be concerned about all scientists, their salaries and career structures - and 30,000 researchers on fixed-term contracts. This announcement is totally inadequate to stop our scientists helping the economies of other nations.
Dr CP Plestedand 13 others
Nuffield department of obstetrics and gynaecology, University of Oxford

The science white paper, published last week with minimal media coverage, had nothing to say on energy technology opportunities - although, as environment minister Michael Meacher often points out, and your own manifesto suggests, the renewable energy market has a huge potential for growth.

Also last week, just before parliament went into recess, an early day motion was tabled by Labour MP Paul Flynn. It contrasts "the enormous subsidies to the plutonium fuel industry with the total annual research, demonstration and development investment into renewable energy of £31m; and calls on the government to halt all further support for plutonium fuel production in the UK in favour of a robust support for renewable energies." It will be interesting to see how many MPs will endorse it.
Dr David Lowry
Stoneleigh, Surrey dlowryrmb@compuserve.com

webTitle: No time limit

fields.headline: No time limit
fields.trailText: There is no reason why the countryside bill should be thrown overboard to meet a self-imposed deadline of a November Queen's Speech (Leader, August 1).
fields.body:
There is no reason why the countryside bill should be thrown overboard to meet a self-imposed deadline of a November Queen's Speech (Leader, August 1).

Erskine May makes it clear that the duration of a session is determined by the government. Apart from election years, the Queen's Speech falls in October or November, but this there is no requirement that it must - it is simply a convention. Before 1928, the state opening of parliament was held in January or February. There are also precedents for summer sittings, such as in 1909 when both houses dealt with the so-called People's Budget. In 1926, both houses sat on various dates in August and September. The notion that a "modernising" government should cling to this November tradition and abandon a flagship bill is preposterous. The current session should run for as long as it takes to get the countryside bill passed.
Gordon Prentice MP

webTitle: Immigration forecasts wide of the mark

fields.headline: Immigration forecasts wide of the mark
fields.trailText: I was shocked to be quoted as endorsing recommendations which are, in fact, those put forward by the UN commission on population (Europe 'should accept' 75m new migrants, July 28). I suggested to my colleagues at the European ministers' meeting last Friday in Marseille that they consider the long-term immigration prospects for Europe - prompted by misunderstandings generated by the publication last March of the UN's population growth forecasts to the year 2050.
fields.body:
I was shocked to be quoted as endorsing recommendations which are, in fact, those put forward by the UN commission on population (Europe 'should accept' 75m new migrants, July 28). I suggested to my colleagues at the European ministers' meeting last Friday in Marseille that they consider the long-term immigration prospects for Europe - prompted by misunderstandings generated by the publication last March of the UN's population growth forecasts to the year 2050.

These forecasts, based on an absurd assumption that north-south population growth imbalance and shrinking birth rates in western countries can be rectified by importing foreign populations, generated the incongruous figures in your article. It was therefore necessary for the ministers in charge of immigration in EU member states to restore a level-headed vision.

The introductory document to our discussions, quoted by your article, noted that there are still three main flows into our countries: the inflow of migrant workers, which has never stopped completely - and which is particularly high in the UK; political asylum seekers; and reuniting of families, which is the first step towards integration. Assessing these long-term trends is not advocating the resumption of a proactive immigration policy for workers and families - as recommended by some people who ignore the high unemployment rates still plaguing Europe.

I believe that neither the unemployment figures nor the far-fetched hypotheses of some demographers give us any cause to question the three lines of action on immigration already identified by the council of ministers in October 1999: cooperation with the countries of origin; control of the migratory flow and continuing the fight against illegal immigration networks; and, lastly, integration of foreigners legally settled in our countries and abiding by our domestic laws. Such integration will automatically lead to mixed marriages. The eventual interracial mix will herald the success of that process.

The council of ministers meeting reaffirmed the commitment to achieve long-term harmonisation based on these policies .
Jean-Pierre Chevènement
Minister of the Interior
Paris

webTitle: Time to see the truth about ourselves and Iraq

fields.headline: Time to see the truth about ourselves and Iraq
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Denis J Halliday: Here we are in the middle of the millennium year and we are responsible for genocide in Iraq.
fields.body:
Here we are in the middle of the millennium year and we are responsible for genocide in Iraq. Saddam Hussein certainly gave Bush and Thatcher a gift when he invaded Kuwait in 1990. He facilitated the opening of the much-needed respectability of a UN umbrella for a US-led alliance to destroy Iraq.

Why? Because despite the costly debacle of the war with Iran, Saddam Hussein remained the only Arab head of state capable of providing Arab leadership and resistance to neo-colonial US/UK and western domination of the Middle East, and its oil.

The war was always about controlling oil supplies, and never really about Kuwait. But Saddam's invasion of Kuwait, in breach of international law, provided the opportunity for showing American military muscle, damaged by the Vietnam defeat; for experimentation with depleted uranium; and for the destruction of Iraq, combined with impoverishment of the rich Arab world .

All of us that live in the silent democracies are responsible for sustained genocide in Iraq. Today the prime minister, Tony Blair, is on the defensive on a range of largely domestic issues. He does not appear to be on the defensive over genocide. His unending endorsement of the Clinton/Albright programme for killing the children of Iraq is seldom mentioned.

Have decision-makers learned nothing from the Pinochet humiliation? Or do they still feel immune under international law for crimes against humanity?

What does that say about us all? Does it say that, after 10 long decimating years of the UN economic embargo on the people of Iraq, we simply do not care? We do not care when Unicef reports that 5,000 children under five years old die each month unnecessarily from embargo-related deprivation. And Unicef does not count the teenagers, the adults and the aged that die.

Do we not care that the UN allies, in breach of Geneva conventions, destroyed the lives of civilians through direct bombing and destruction of electric power capabilities, clean water systems, sanitation and health care?

Do we not care that Iraqi society, culture and learning, rooted in the cities of Mesopotamia, is dying alongside its people? Are we really that racist? Are we really that anti-Islamic? Could Britain stand by and watch the same holocaust within a white Christian state?

What can be done? Why not set aside US propaganda and demonisation and do a Nixon to China, or a Clinton-Putin outreach to Pyongyang - ie, communicate. Begin to understand what is happening in Iraq, and begin perhaps to influence change and better relations within the Middle East.

Why not address the concerns of the Kuwaiti and Saudi leadership, who fear a resurgence of Iraqi regional ambition, by encouraging their political collaboration with Baghdad? At the same time ease fears through control of purchasing by, and sales to, Iraq of offensive weapons of mass or other forms of destruction. Demand the removal of weapons of mass destruction from the region, including Israel, as in the US-drafted paragraph 14 of UN Resolution 687.

Critically, end the economic embargo and allow the Iraqi economy to resurface. End malnutrition and high child mortality rates. Get people back to work. Re-establish the dinar and its purchasing power. Repair the power, water and urban sewage systems. Rebuild agricultural production, health care and education.

End the killing now. Remove any excuse that Baghdad has today for the ongoing catastrophe. End human rights abuses by the UN via the embargo. Demand an end to civil and political rights abuses by Baghdad.

Acknowledge we have reduced the Iraqis to refugees in their own country, being fed inadequately despite use of their own oil revenues.

Let us not be blinded by wasteful expenditures on palaces or luxury cars. Should we expect a higher standard in Iraq when the UK spends millions of pounds on a dome while British people are homeless and hungry?

Let us be honest. We do not care for democracy in the Middle East as much too threatening to that oil cow Saudi Arabia and its offspring Kuwait. Admit the US/UK governments want country stability so that they can invest profitably and be sure of oil but regional instability so that demand for arms manufacturing and sales is sustained.

Let us invest in people and peaceful coexistence in the world, including the Middle East. Let's rally around the world as the one small threatened unit it is today, just as the Iraqis have rallied around Saddam Hussein under western attack.

Let us recognise the calamity of the US/UK- driven UN economic embargo on Iraq. Calamitous not only for Iraq and its people, but for us all, including the very survival of the UN itself as a credible instrument for peace and security.

Let us take some risks. Let us even remain ultimately self-serving and yet visionary - by responding to such global crises as Africa, global poverty, HIV-Aids, the environment, globalisation ills - the things that really matter, while allowing the children of Iraq to live.

 Denis J Halliday, a visiting professor at Swarthmore college in Pennsylvania, is a former UN assistant secretary general and UN humanitarian coordinator in Iraq 1997-98

webTitle: Saddam casts long shadow on Kuwait

fields.headline: Saddam casts long shadow on Kuwait
fields.standfirst:
Iraq's invasion, a decade ago today, has left a whole nation traumatised
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Today, the trauma helplines in Kuwait will be busy. It happens every year on the anniversary of the invasion, and the government-run telephone counselling service lays on extra staff to cope with calls.
fields.body:
Today, the trauma helplines in Kuwait will be busy. It happens every year on the anniversary of the invasion, and the government-run telephone counselling service lays on extra staff to cope with calls.

"People have flashbacks," says Dr Humoud al-Qashan of the Social Development Organisation, which has dealt with 15,000 cases since it opened in 1992. Television programmes, newspaper articles, even chance events can trigger panic attacks.

Two years ago, on August 2, there was a wedding party where someone fired a gun, as happens at some traditional Arab weddings. One of the guests, convinced that the Iraqis were back, went berserk and ended up in hospital.

Phobias, depression, marital violence, suicide attempts, crime, drug abuse, delinquency. Dr Qashan has a long list of problems which have become worse since the invasion.

It is not just the shock of war in one of the least militaristic Arab countries that has left these scars, but the calculated cruelty of the Iraqi forces.

"Before the war, Kuwaitis weren't used to seeing blood," says Dr Badria al-Awadhi, a lawyer. She tells of one man who was executed in front of his home. The Iraqis would not let his relatives take the body inside for six hours, to make sure that the neighbours would see it and take heed.

In another case, Adel Ibrahim had borrowed a car from his brother, Rashid. The Iraqis stopped and searched it, and found his brother's military ID card. They phoned his home, offering to release Adel if Rashid came to the police station. Rashid went, and neither son returned. Adel had only one kidney and needed regular medication. His father took the medicine to the police station but they refused to accept it. Weeks later, they asked him to send it. That was the last he heard of either son.

During the last three weeks of the war, thousands of Kuwaitis were rounded up randomly in the streets and mosques. The Iraqis knew they were going to be driven out and wanted hostages to trade, Kuwaitis believe. A decade later, 605 are still un accounted for. Iraq says it does not know what happened to them.

The experience of 10 years ago has shaken Kuwait's conservative values, and old social taboos have gone, especially among the young. Some refuse to wear the traditional white robe. Others try to look like Americans, their heroes. A popular haircut is "the marine". And, Dr Qashan says, "there is no shame nowadays if you say 'I have a girlfriend'."

Perhaps this would have happened anyway. Kuwait is a cosmopolitan place, where around 65% of the 2.3m inhabitants are foreigners. But most of them are guest-workers from poorer countries - India, Pakistan, Egypt, the Philippines - and are unlikely role models for young Kuwaitis.

The increased openness also has a political side which can be traced directly to the war. In 1986, the emir, Sheikh Jaber al-Sabah, dissolved parliament and suspended the constitution. "People feared that that might be the end of democracy," says Hassan Jawher, now a Shia member of parliament.

The turning point came in 1990, after the invasion, when the exiled emir called a national gathering in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. "We needed internal unity to face the Iraqi regime. Any fifth column would have been a disaster," Mr Jawher says.

The result was a commitment to restore democracy, which kept the Kuwaitis united and helped to bolster international support for their cause.

Today Kuwait is the only Arab country in the Gulf with an elected parliament - though women, along with police officers and the military, are not allowed to vote. The 50-member assembly is notoriously assertive. Last year parliament threw out an emergency decree made by the emir during a recess which granted women the vote.

Kuwait now faces a situation, also noticeable in other Arab countries such as Jordan and Morocco, where reform is driven not from the grass-roots but from the top - in this case by the emir and a highly-educated liberal elite - and resisted by conservative elements in parliament and among Islamists.

It is late evening and Ahmad Baqer, an Islamist MP, is holding a diwaniya, a uniquely Kuwaiti institution which has survived from the Bedouin days. The walls of the vast, marble-floored reception room are lined with sofas and small tables. Some 30 men, dressed in identical white robes, sit talking. Most have beards. A male servant plies glasses of tea and thimbles half-filled with bitter coffee.

Diwaniyas were once an elite gathering where the most wealthy could show off their largesse and everyone could speak freely. Sometimes the emir would drop in, because in the days before parliament it was a way of tapping public opinion. Today, everyone with social aspirations holds them.

Some describe them as Kuwait's "second parliament", but they are also a place for business talk, not to mention rumours and disinformation. Diwaniyas have been known to move stock markets.

The talk at Mr Baqer's diwaniya is of oil. He describes the investigation into a refinery accident, and how such things might be prevented. An old man produces a map showing oil fields straddling the border with Saudi Arabia. Mr Baqer explains how the revenues are apportioned.

Several men are looking to Mr Baqer to solve their problems. A young man is looking for work. There is a brief phone call to one of the princes but, sorry, no job.

By now, Mr Baqer is on to one of his favourite themes: why women should not have the vote. There is no point, he says. Women, obviously, would vote the way their husbands told them. God ordained that a woman's duty is to care for her family, not to get involved in politics. If more women would stay at home there would be no need for all these foreign servants. In any case, he adds, women do not understand politics because they do not attend the diwaniyas.

There is, in fact, one mixed-sex diwaniya, founded some years ago by the emir's cousin, Princess Rasha al-Sabah. But the nearest thing to an all-woman diwaniya is the Women's Cultural and Social Society. Here, eight women, in western clothes, are gathered round a table. They speak flawless English, and most have postgraduate degrees and professional careers.

They ridicule Mr Baqer's views on women's voting rights, and laugh at one of the male arguments against allowing women into parliament: that women's periods would cloud their judgement.

As for women staying at home to do the cooking, they all agree that servants are essential: there are no crèches or playgroups. How else could wives go out to work?

The important thing, they all say, is to treat servants properly. Everyone has heard stories of servants being ill-treated, but there are others of servants returning early from holidays in the Philippines, or staying with the same family for 20 years.

No, they agree, Filipinos do not earn the minimum Kuwaiti wage of 400 dinars (£870) a month. But they do get free food and lodging.

Statistics of a conflict

Casualties of the Gulf war
The US estimates more than 100,000 Iraqi soldiers died, 300,000 wounded, 150,000 deserted, and 60,000 taken prisoner. Human rights groups claimed much higher numbers of Iraqis killed in action. The US suffered 148 killed and 458 wounded.

Impact of sanctions
Per capita spending in Iraq on health before 1990 was about $90: 10 years later it is $12. $230m a year was invested in education in 1990. It has fallen to $23m.

Equipment and losses in liberation of Kuwait
Tanks: Iraq lost 4,000 out of 4,230; allies lost four out of 3,360. Artillery: Iraq lost 2,140 out of 3,110; allies one out of 3,633. Armoured personnel carriers: Iraq lost 1,856 out of 2,870; allies nine out of 4,050. Helicopters: Iraq lost seven out of 160; allies 17 out of 1,959. Aircraft: Iraq lost 240 out of 800; allies 44 out of 2,600.

Weapons of mass destruction
Until 1991 Iraq stockpiled various chemical weapons containing sarin, tabun, soman, VX and possibly hydrogen cyanide, and biological weapons containing anthrax and typhoid.

The military coalition against Iraq in 1991
Afghanistan, Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belgium, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Egypt, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Honduras, Italy, Kuwait, Morocco, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Niger, Norway, Oman, Pakistan, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Spain, Syria, Turkey, the UAE, Britain and the US.

Sanctions
Between 1945 and 1990 the UN imposed sanctions on two countries: Rhodesia and South Africa. Since 1990 it has imposed sanctions on 13 countries.

webTitle: Gay slur embarrasses French left

fields.headline: Gay slur embarrasses French left
fields.trailText: France's Radical Left party, a minor member of the ruling Socialist-led coalition, has expelled a former junior cabinet minister for describing homosexuals as "abnormal destroyers of humanity".
fields.body:
France's Radical Left party, a minor member of the ruling Socialist-led coalition, has expelled a former junior cabinet minister for describing homosexuals as "abnormal destroyers of humanity".

Senator François Abadie, a former mayor of Lourdes and minister for tourism who now sits in the French upper house for the Hautes-Pyrénées region, was ejected from the party yesterday after telling a protesting parliamentarian to "go bugger" himself.

The Radical Left's chairman, Jean-Pierre Baylet, said he had no choice but to sever all ties with the outspoken septuagenarian whose "homophobic views are diametrically opposed to all our values". The party was "thoroughly ashamed of such words", he said.

The scandal started earlier this month when Mr Abadie, wrote in Le Nouvel Observateur magazine that he "could not be favourable to those destroyers of humanity, those who do not secure the future". He said homosexuality was "contrary to all norms" and posed "a permanent danger of paedophilia".

When the Liberal Democrat MP, Sebastian Chenu, wrote to protest, saying Mr Abadie's views were a disgrace to the Republic, the senator could not contain himself. "My sad, sad sir," he wrote in reply. "Go bugger yourself and do not attempt to make any more hay out of this. I despise you too much to use more polite vocabulary."

The Radical Left, which has 14 MPs in the national assembly and five senators in the upper house, is best known as the party of Bernard Kouchner, founder of the international medical charity, Médecins Sans Frontières. He is currently the UN's civilian head of mission in Kosovo.

The party may not yet be free of the embarrassment Mr Abadie has caused it. Jean-Luc Romero, a regional counsellor and Aids worker, said the senator's remarks were "the rudest, most insulting and most anti-gay ever uttered by an elected official of the Republic". He has demanded that Mr Abadie be prosecuted for incitement of homophobia. The senator was not available for comment.

webTitle: Phantom news

fields.headline: Phantom news
fields.trailText:
Venezuela ring any bells? Leading oil exporter to the US, holds the presidency of Opec, which has forced up the price of petrol to record heights. Ex-colonel Hugo Chavez, the most significant new figure in Latin American affairs since Fidel Castro, re-elected as president on Sunday in a stunning victory that surprised the pollsters. A little news item too much to hope for?
Richard Gott
London

Ex-colonel Hugo Chavez, the most significant new figure in Latin American affairs since Fidel Castro, re-elected as president on Sunday in a stunning victory that surprised the pollsters. A little news item too much to hope for?
Richard Gott
London

I read (Tara and Tamara, G2, July 28) that my next venture is to be about the It girls. In fact my next musical, The Beautiful Game, which opens on September 26, has book and lyrics by Ben Elton and is about youngsters in Belfast in 1969. My following excursion into musical theatre will be as producer of Bombay Dreams, a musical by the Hindi composer AR Rahman.
Andrew Lloyd Webber
London

Leaks of confidential memos from No 10 and the latest Guardian reader offer (July 31) is for an electronic paper shredder. That's what I call good marketing.
Margaret McLay
Stockport, Cheshire

Not all is lost for the future of the monkey puzzle tree (Letters, August 1). Last year we collected four self-sown seedlings from beneath our tree. They all survived the winter and are 5cm tall. Only 100 years to wait.
David Swaysland
Stourbridge, W Mids.

Mr Smith (aged 83) is not alone in championing the metric system (Letters, August 1). For the past 10 years my grandfather (aged 87) has told me how many miles his car will go on a litre of petrol.
Jonathan Darby
London

Yesterday, I boycotted the pumps. I do this every day. I call that commitment (Letters, August 1). Join me.
David Harvie
Dumbarton
