They were also worried by the lack of clarity about what part of the extra lottery cash the dome has received was a loan, and what was made as grants. The report comes as the dome had its best month since it opened in January, with 606,519 visitors in July. However, even with that turnout it is still short of the 21,600 a day it needed to reach its 6m visitor target. With only four months before it closes, only 3.7m have visited it. However, Lord Falconer was bullish despite the further blows to its battered image in the report. "For the committee to say that there is no 'wow' factor at the dome seems, to me, to be wrong. "I defy people not to be amazingly impressed by the millennium show and the proof of the pudding is in the eating with the dome, as people who go to it definitely enjoy it." The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said the report had been too soft and criticised the committee for being "unable to get to the bottom of crucial issues". He added: "We are not much nearer any answers ... this report throws up little that was not already in the public domain." "Ministers have drawn a cloak of secrecy round issues such as funding, design costs and division of the sale proceeds. More than 70 parliamentary questions on the dome have not been answered."

webTitle: United fans find Mecca at club store

fields.headline: United fans find Mecca at club store
fields.trailText: Crowds gathered beneath the statue of Sir Matt Busby at Old Trafford yesterday to witness the latest stage in Manchester United's quest for world domination - the opening of the club's megastore, an 18,000 sq ft testament to the boundless creativity of merchandising consultants and, somewhat secondarily, to football.
fields.body:
Crowds gathered beneath the statue of Sir Matt Busby at Old Trafford yesterday to witness the latest stage in Manchester United's quest for world domination - the opening of the club's megastore, an 18,000 sq ft testament to the boundless creativity of merchandising consultants and, somewhat secondarily, to football.

Hardened fans had been camping out at the megastore since Monday evening for a midnight preview opening and a glimpse of the 19th new club strip in eight years.

Thousands more descended on the ground yesterday to choose club branded goods, ranging from stereo systems and mobile phones to romper suits, lampshades and the Three-dimensional Goal Mouth Alarm Clock ("Wake up to the sound of glory, glory Man United and watch the floodlights flash on and off!" - a comparative bargain at £25).

The shoppers were rivalled only by the hordes of burly security guards, some of whom had to pull over-enthusiastic, young supporters from the crush to see Alex Ferguson, the club's manager, cut the ribbon in the company of players Wes Brown, Denis Irwin, Jesper Blomqvist, and David May.

The plateglass and metal store is the flagship in a large scale expansion of the £1bn club's retailing activities, which includes up to 22 shops run in partnership with the Allsports chain, and dedicated Manchester United areas inside Woolworth stores.

A new strip is hardly an event for United followers, but the latest - marking a new £30m sponsorship deal with Vodafone - sets a technological departure. The clothing is manufactured with Sportswool, a high performance variety of merino wool developed for Australian athletes, that draws moisture from the body to keep the wearer warm in cold temperatures and cool in the sun.

The price tag of the strip, £29.99 for children and £39.99 for adults, attracted the usual frowns from parents, but most were unwilling to let that interrupt the day's commercial frenzy.

One adult, Paul Neal, from Lincoln, said: "I'd give the club even more if I could afford it." He had blown more than a quarter of his £400 annual budget on United merchandise within an hour of the store's opening. "The more I can pump in and the more the players get, the better, as far as I'm concerned."

Kinsun Yuen, one of many foreign visitors at the event, had brought his sons, Sibor and Sida, from Hong Kong to stock up on the new strip and footballs. "It is a pilgrimage for us. The Millennium Dome was quite interesting," he said. "But this is something totally different. This is Mecca."

 Sports websites are attracting more hits than most other internet locations including those dedicated to shopping, hobbies and careers. In June, more than a million people in the UK visited a sports website, said MMXI Europe analysts yesterday.

In the same month, the official site for the European Football championships received 111,000 visits from people in the UK.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Arms dealer faces extradition

A court in Augsburg ruled yesterday that the self-exiled German arms dealer Karlheinz Schreiber, who is regarded as a key figures in the slush-fund scandal surrounding the former chancellor Helmut Kohl, should stand trial for bribes allegedly paid in connection with the German government's sale of 36 tanks to Saudi Arabia during the Gulf war.

Mr Schreiber, who is in Canada, has refused to return to Germany to answer the charges, but state prosecutors said they were optimistic of securing his extradition early next year.

He is alleged to have paid £1.2m to a defence ministry official, Holger Pfahls, to secure the Saudi arms sale.

The deal is one of the key issues in the slush-fund affair. Prosecutors and a parliamentary inquiry are trying to establish whether Mr Kohl's government took bribes in return for political favours. Mr Kohl has repeatedly denied the accusation.

Tony Paterson, Berlin

Italian teachers on the take

Police wire-taps have uncovered rampant bribery, exam-rigging and fraud in Italian schools and universities.

The education minister, Tullio de Mauro, has ordered investigations into claims that teachers and principals in several schools in the central province of Lazio demanded gifts and cash from colleagues.

In Rome, the police discovered that teachers seeking professional qualifications and jobs were asked to pay bribes of cash, jewellery, designer clothes or perfume.

Others were ordered to leak exam questions to pupils related to their superiors.

A recruitment commissioner, three colleagues, and four candidates have been charged with corruption.

The police said that Silvio Barsi, a secondary school head placed under house arrest at the weekend, was accused of earning £80,000 from private tutorials for temporary teachers seeking permanent posts.

Rory Carroll, Rome

Hindu pilgrims shot in Kashmir

Suspected Islamic guerrillas fired at unarmed Hindu pilgrims and Muslim porters in Kashmir yesterday, killing more than 20 and injuring 25, the police said. It was the first time guerrillas have killed pilgrims on their way to the Amarnath Cave, a Hindu shrine.

There are 20,000 pilgrims in Pahalgam, the starting point for the 30-mile walk to the cave, where the attack occurred.

Meanwhile 14 militant groups fighting Indian rule in Kashmir refused to join peace talks in New Delhi, describing them as an Indian trick.

Agencies, Srinagar and Muzaffarabad

Berlin toughens line on racism

Junior ministers from the German departments of justice, the family and the interior began reviewing government measures against racism yesterday in the light of a bomb blast in Düsseldorf last week in which six Jewish immigrants and four other people were hurt.

"Those responsible must feel the full force of the law," the deputy interior minister Cornelie Sonntag-Wolgast said.

Reuters, Berlin

Pinochet ruling next week

The Chilean supreme court began sitting behind closed doors yesterday to decide whether to allow General Augusto Pinochet's appeal against a lower court decision to strip him of his immunity from prosecution for human rights offences.

A decision will not be be given before next week.

AP, Santiago

Fiji charges rebel leader

The Fijian rebel leader George Speight and several of his supporters have been charged with a series of criminal offences, the police said yesterday.

Possible charges of treason against Mr Speight were still being considered, they said.

Reuters, Suva

Prayer role for Iranian women

Iranian religious jurists have lifted the ban on women leading payers - but only congregations of women - for the first time in the history of Shi'ite Islam, the state news agency IRNA said yesterday.

An education ministry official said the decision helped "solve a problem in mass prayers in girls' schools. It is useful in persuading schoolgirls to pray".

Reuters, Tehran

Settlers' tunnel to Jerusalem

Israeli engineers completed a tunnel yesterday joining Jerusalem to Maaleh Adumim, the biggest Jewish settlement in the West Bank.

The hardline Jerusalem mayor, Ehud Olmert, said it made sure the settlement's 25,000 residents were "an integral part of Jerusalem".

AP, Jerusalem

Congolese flee bombing raids

Congolese government jets are bombarding rebel-held towns in northern Congo, forcing thousands to flee to the neighbouring Central African Republic, UN officials said.

AP, Bangui

webTitle: Jakarta terror

fields.headline: Jakarta terror
fields.standfirst: Two die as bombers target Philippines envoy
fields.trailText: A powerful bomb exploded in central Jakarta yesterday outside the residence of the Philippines ambassador as he was approaching by car. It killed two people and injured at least 21, including the ambassador and his driver.
fields.body:
A powerful bomb exploded in central Jakarta yesterday outside the residence of the Philippines ambassador as he was approaching by car. It killed two people and injured at least 21, including the ambassador and his driver.

The lunch-time blast was felt more than half a mile away. It damaged much of the house, the Bulgarian ambassador's home next door and the headquarters of Indonesia's general elections institute across the street. Dozens of vehicles were badly damaged and screaming passers-by fled.

Doctors said the ambassador, Leonides Caday, was stable last night after an operation for fractures to his left leg. His driver was described as being in a much more serious state.

The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, blamed Muslim separatists from the southern Philippines, but the main rebel group, the Moro Islamic Revolution Front, denied it planted the bomb.

A bomb also exploded yesterday during a fiesta in the town of Monkayo in the southern Philippines, killing three people and injuring dozens.

webTitle: The sex appeal of sweat goes on sale

fields.headline: The sex appeal of sweat goes on sale
fields.trailText: Women in nightclubs may at last be saved the question "do you come here often?", as old-fashioned chat-up lines are replaced with the latest scientific shortcut to sex: the pheromone face wipe.
fields.body:
Women in nightclubs may at last be saved the question "do you come here often?", as old-fashioned chat-up lines are replaced with the latest scientific shortcut to sex: the pheromone face wipe.

A London biotechnology firm yesterday launched a brand of moist tissues soaked in the scent of 50 human pheromones - the sweat molecules responsible for sex appeal.

Kiotech claims the Xcite! facial wipes make people appear more attractive to the opposite sex within a three foot radius for up to 12 hours.

George Dodd, a biochemist and "smell scientist", developed the wipes from 30 years of pheromone research.

He said: "Our studies in nightclubs show that this pheromone combination dabbed across the wrist and neck makes people appear more confident.

"Users were described as 'friendlier, warmer and more inviting' with a more attractive smile." The wipes could make a person more influential in business meetings, he said. For people in their 50s and 60s, they could also save relationships.

"The Viagra pill gets the machinery working but does nothing to get you interested. Pheromones actually increase sexual attraction," he said.

The wipes will be sold in his and hers versions for £1 each. They will be marketed to teenagers in clothes shops such as Top Shop and Miss Selfridge, and sold from condom machines in pubs and clubs.

Dr Dodd said the wipes worked best on white heterosexuals, the focus of most pheromone research.

Nick Neave, a biological psychologist at Northumbria University, said the effect may be limited. "Pheromones come from clean sweat. Once the wipes have mingled with the sweat produced on a dance floor, they might be as unappealing as the urine-like stench of stale body odour."

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Gable collapse kills worker
A workman was killed when a gable collapsed on him and his colleague at Longsands Lane, near Preston, Lancashire police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Gable collapse kills worker
A workman was killed when a gable collapsed on him and his colleague at Longsands Lane, near Preston, Lancashire police said yesterday.

Police said the condition of his companion was not known.

Lords statues to get a clean-up
Two statues of barons of the Magna Carta are set to get their first spruce-up for 150 years as part of a £16m programme of works in the Houses of Parliament.

Since the 1840s, the models of the barons of Gloucester and Winchester have stood in the Lords. But gas and candle fumes in those early days, plus general corrosion, have damaged the metal forms.

Mild judged Britain's best
Moorhouse's Black Cat, brewed in Burnley, Lancashire, a "well-balanced" mild with a "fruity aroma", was yesterday rated Britain's best beer at the British Beer Festival, London.

North top for hi-tech gadgets
The north of England has more hi-tech household appliances than the south, the Department of Social Security family resources survey 1998-99 said yesterday. But in London and the south-east people are more likely to own computers.

Scaffolding honoured
Residents in Kemp Town, Brighton, have held a ninth birthday party for scaffolding in their street. There was a cake, balloons and banners and the stoical residents sang "happy birthday, dear scaffolding".

Big Brother evictions
Former sex aid seller Caroline has been nominated to be kicked out of the Big Brother house for the second week running, Channel 4 said yesterday. The Brummie and Londoner Andrew were selected for eviction by their housemates in the top-rated TV series.

Ladyboy's fear of flying
Poh, a 24-year-old transvestite star of the Ladyboys of Bangkok, was so afraid his breast implants would explode that he would fly to the Edinburgh Festival only once they were insured for £300,000, promoter Phillip Gandey said yesterday.

webTitle: Lawyer cites human rights to escape fine

fields.headline: Lawyer cites human rights to escape fine
fields.trailText: A barrister who used European human rights law to challenge a parking fine issued by Westminster city council in London has been told he does not have to pay it.
fields.body:
A barrister who used European human rights law to challenge a parking fine issued by Westminster city council in London has been told he does not have to pay it.

The council dropped an £80 fixed penalty notice after Jeremy Rosenblatt complained that the procedure it had undertaken went against the European convention on human rights, which comes into force in England and Wales in October.

Westminster city council operates a system of halving the fine if it is paid within 14 days. But Mr Rosenblatt argued that this was contrary to article six of the convention, which guarantees the right to a fair trial.

Mr Rosenblatt, 39, a family law barrister, said: "If somebody threatens you with doubling the fine then you aren't being given the right to a fair trial. I decided to fight this for the human rights of the common man, as well as looking after mine."

He was given two fixed penalty notices when his car was clamped in a parking bay near his home in a Westminster square.

The second ticket was issued some hours after the first when the car had not been moved, said a council spokeswoman.

Mr Rosenblatt paid his £125 clamping fee and second penalty notice, but said he was not aware of the first until after the 14 day period had passed.

After investigating his claim, the council wrote to Mr Rosenblatt yesterday to cancel the £80 ticket.

But councillor Louise St John Howe, chairman of the transportation and highways committee, said there was "no question" that the parking fine was cancelled because it was illegal under European human rights law.

She said: "Anyone who receives a parking ticket is entitled to contest it. If a second ticket is issued for the same offence, on the same day and in the same place, the city council may cancel one of these tickets."

Mr Rosenblatt said: "I didn't expect the council to acknowledge it was because of the European human rights convention because it would set a precedent, but I am sure it was."

webTitle: CPS admits 'terrible' error after convicted killer freed

fields.headline: CPS admits 'terrible' error after convicted killer freed
fields.standfirst: Appeal date missed by one day because of miscalculation
fields.trailText: The crown prosecution service apologised unreservedly yesterday for a "terrible" legal slip-up which meant it missed the deadline for lodging appeal papers over a quashed murder conviction.
fields.body:
The crown prosecution service apologised unreservedly yesterday for a "terrible" legal slip-up which meant it missed the deadline for lodging appeal papers over a quashed murder conviction.

Michael Weir, from Hackney, east London, was jailed for life in 1999 for the murder of 79-year-old war veteran Leonard Harris, after being linked to the crime by a DNA sample he had provided in 1997 in relation to other offences.

In May the court of appeal overturned his conviction, ruling that the DNA evidence was inadmissible because it was gathered in connection to unrelated offences.

The CPS had planned to appeal to the House of Lords - but missed the deadline for lodging the papers by one day.

Yesterday Mr Harris's son, Frank, said it was "unbelievable" that such a serious crime had not been pursued by the CPS.

The shadow Home Office minister, David Lidington, said: "It is inexcusable. I would have thought there was a pressing case for the attorney general to mount an inquiry into what on earth went wrong and take appropriate action to ensure there is no repetition."

Weir had appealed against his conviction for murder, burglary and assault, for which he was sentenced to life imprisonment at the Old Bailey in July 1999. He was linked to Mr Harris's murder in north London in January 1998 by a DNA sample taken after he was charged with drug offences in 1997. But the drug charges were discontinued. Police made the connection after running a DNA profile from blood found on a glove left outside Mr Harris's home through their database.

Mr Harris died nearly six months after the attack. Both he and his wife Gertrude, also 79, had received severe head injuries.

Chris Newell, CPS director of case work, said yesterday that he could understand the feelings of betrayal.

"I should like to apologise first to Mr Harris, his family and to the public generally for this terrible mistake.

"The CPS deeply regrets that we miscalculated by one day the time for lodging the appeal papers in the House of Lords. There is not any leeway in the legislation."

Mr Newell said it was necessary to find out "exactly how the miscalculation occurred and to check our systems and ensure there is no repetition."

He added: "There are many time limits in which different stages in the criminal justice system have to be completed."

He said that a "speedy" inquiry was under way to find out at what stage in the process the mistake was made.

In an unrelated case, the court of appeal ruled in May that a man accused of raping a 66-year-old woman could not be convicted because the DNA samples linking him to the crime had been gathered in connection with other, unrelated offences.

A DNA profile obtained by taking swabs from the victim, who was raped in 1997, was put on the national DNA database.

When the accused was arrested for an unrelated burglary in January 1998, a DNA sample was obtained. But in August that year the man was acquitted of the burglary. The appeal judges ruled that the Old Bailey judge was right to disallow the evidence.

The decisions prompted Mr Lidington to call at the time for a review of laws on DNA evidence after judges ruled that the two men could not be convicted despite "compelling" evidence against them.

The Police and Criminal Evidence Act decrees that DNA samples taken from suspects must be destroyed if they are acquitted or the case discontinued, and cannot be used in any other investigation.

Yesterday Mr Harris's son, Frank, said it was "unbelievable" that such a serious crime had not been pursued by the CPS. The shadow Home Office minister, David Lidington, said: "It is inexcusable. I would have thought there was a pressing case for the attorney general to mount an inquiry into what on earth went wrong and take appropriate action to ensure there is no repetition." Weir had appealed against his conviction for murder, burglary and assault, for which he was sentenced to life imprisonment at the Old Bailey in July 1999. He was linked to Mr Harris's murder in north London in January 1998 by a DNA sample taken after he was charged with drug offences in 1997. But the drug charges were discontinued. Police made the connection after running a DNA profile from blood found on a glove left outside Mr Harris's home through their database. Mr Harris died nearly six months after the attack. Both he and his wife Gertrude, also 79, had received severe head injuries. Chris Newell, CPS director of case work, said yesterday that he could understand the feelings of betrayal. "I should like to apologise first to Mr Harris, his family and to the public generally for this terrible mistake. "The CPS deeply regrets that we miscalculated by one day the time for lodging the appeal papers in the House of Lords. There is not any leeway in the legislation." Mr Newell said it was necessary to find out "exactly how the miscalculation occurred and to check our systems and ensure there is no repetition." He added: "There are many time limits in which different stages in the criminal justice system have to be completed." He said that a "speedy" inquiry was under way to find out at what stage in the process the mistake was made. In an unrelated case, the court of appeal ruled in May that a man accused of raping a 66-year-old woman could not be convicted because the DNA samples linking him to the crime had been gathered in connection with other, unrelated offences. A DNA profile obtained by taking swabs from the victim, who was raped in 1997, was put on the national DNA database. When the accused was arrested for an unrelated burglary in January 1998, a DNA sample was obtained. But in August that year the man was acquitted of the burglary. The appeal judges ruled that the Old Bailey judge was right to disallow the evidence. The decisions prompted Mr Lidington to call at the time for a review of laws on DNA evidence after judges ruled that the two men could not be convicted despite "compelling" evidence against them. The Police and Criminal Evidence Act decrees that DNA samples taken from suspects must be destroyed if they are acquitted or the case discontinued, and cannot be used in any other investigation.

webTitle: Solar power helps ospreys make a happy return

fields.headline: Solar power helps ospreys make a happy return
fields.trailText: One of the world's most striking birds of prey is about to start breeding in England after 150 years' absence, with the help of a solar-powered backpack designed to track its annual migration to sub-Saharan Africa.
fields.body:
One of the world's most striking birds of prey is about to start breeding in England after 150 years' absence, with the help of a solar-powered backpack designed to track its annual migration to sub-Saharan Africa.

Six young ospreys, second only to the golden eagle in wingspan, were fitted with the £2,000 gadgets yesterday on Lax Hill in Rutland where the first colony south of Hadrian's Wall has established nests overlooking Rutland Water reservoir.

Wiped out in the 1850s by hunting, the dramatic fish-hunting raptors have colonised the site from Speyside in Scotland, where a conservation programme has seen 130 nests develop after Britain's last wild breeding pair of ospreys were saved in 1954.

Chicks brought from Scotland have stayed loyal to the Midlands site after release over the past two years.

The solar-powered trackers will fit in the final piece of a complex jigsaw, which sees the young birds vanish for between two and four years in West Africa before returning unerringly to the site where they were fledged.

Tests suggest that the monitors, which weigh less than 2% of the bird's body weight, will be ignored by the ospreys while reliably sending back daily position, speed of flight and route data. "We think the only thing which can go wrong would be an osprey deciding to settle down and spend the rest of its life under a bush," said Helen Dixon, head of the project. "The data will all go straight on to our website, so anyone interested can track the birds and, like us, find out what they do after arriving in Africa."

Previous trackers have relied on batteries which have failed after the migration's first year, leaving a question mark over when the ospreys are likely to return and by which route. The information is key to the hopes of establishing a permanent colony in Lax Hill, protected by a thick copse planted in the civil war to screen roundhead cannon bombarding the nearby royalist stronghold of Burley-on-the-Hill.

"Rutland Water is a regular stopping-off point for ospreys migrating between Scotland and Africa," said Tim Atherton of the Leicester and Rutland Wildlife Trust, gripping a hooded young bird while its backpack harness was stitched and superglued round its body.

"The vital thing is for males released here to have the chance of enticing female birds on their way back to Scotland to stop and settle in Rutland instead.

"We already had some examples - they catch a fish and then fly up incredibly high with it and put on a tremendous courting display."

The two-inch solar transmitters, which are sponsored by Anglian Water, have not disrupted coupling and may even add to the males' attractions, with their extra bulk and flexible five-inch metal antennae which glint in the sun.

The backpacks also appear to have no effect on the ospreys' most dramatic habits, which draw thousands of visitors to Speyside and Rutland Water - their steep dive ending in a brief underwater struggle with their prey.

webTitle: Society facts: defining the workforce

fields.headline: Defining the workforce
fields.trailText:
How many people work?
The three official counts give sharply different results, showing variation of up to 2m. As the Radical Statistics Health Group explains in a new edition of Official Health Statistics - An Unofficial Guide (Arnold, £16.99), it all depends how you do the sums. The labour force survey (LFS) covers everyone who does an hour's paid work a week, the workforce in employment (WiE) series relies on employers' figures and the national insurance contributions (NIC) tally excludes some part-timers.

webTitle: The future for Acas in the workplace

fields.headline: In place of strife
fields.standfirst: The future for Acas in the workplace
fields.trailText: Acas has been in continuous existence over a period which can claim to have been among the most turbulent and transforming in modern British industrial relations history, comparable with the two decades before the first world war and the period after it, culminating in the general strike.
fields.body:
Acas has been in continuous existence over a period which can claim to have been among the most turbulent and transforming in modern British industrial relations history, comparable with the two decades before the first world war and the period after it, culminating in the general strike.

That Acas survived the 1980s was remarkable. It had all the hallmarks of an era which the government was at pains to discredit: it was pragmatic and pluralist; it gave equal legitimacy to the claims of business and unions; and it had a governing council which, in its tripartite composition, recognised that there were more ways than one of looking at important issues.

Yet survival has not required the agency to pay too high a price. That it has changed the time and resources allocated to its traditional, dispute-resolution work is without doubt. But this was largely reactive, in response to the long-term decline in collective bargaining and, in the 1990s, the dramatic fall in industrial disputes.

Where is Acas going today? The new, statutory duty in the Employment Relations Act 1999 restores industrial relations to its old prominence - although it is not clear, through omission, how far collective bargaining has also been restored as at least one instrument of improvement. An obvious limitation is the greatly diminished scope of collective bargaining compared to the mid-1970s, or even the beginning of the 1990s.

Some of this ground may be made up over the next decade, but a return to earlier levels is highly improbable.

However, Acas's future may lie in other directions. First, the agency is well equipped - both through experience and inclination - to carry out a key role under the act's union recognition procedure. It is a role which may keep it very busy, as it is likely that union applicants for recognition will wish to exhaust the negotiated recognition possibilities before seeking the automatic and ballot routes. It may also be that, more often than not, employers will see advantages in voluntary outcomes.

Second, conciliation in employment relations has been a major growth area since Acas was founded. New jurisdiction relating to working time and the minimum wage has recently been added to the list, and unfair dismissal cases are likely to resume their growth following the reduction in the qualifying period for applications from two years to one.

Third, the government and the act are firmly committed to encouraging partnership at work, although in both academic and practitioner circles there is as yet no consensus as to its meaning. Acas has some experience of promoting partnership through its advisory mediation work, and this route may provide scope for the agency to develop its proactive profolio.

Finally, but very speculatively, the government may have firmly set its face against the EU-wide extension of national works councils, but this does not necessarily exclude their future implementation.

The present proposals apply to workplaces of 50 or more employees, which fits uneasily with the small firms' exclusion of fewer than 21 under the current rules. But such problems are resolvable.

An Acas involvement in facilitating the implementation of national works councils would not be wholly unlike its original duty to encourage collective bargaining - or, at least, to provide a complement to it. That would indeed be a full turn of the wheel.

Brian Towers is professor of industrial relations at Nottingham Business School and emeritus professor at Strathclyde University

webTitle: Councils gear up for referendums on elected mayors

fields.headline: Councils gear up for referendums on elected mayors
fields.trailText: Ministers are already grandly calling it a new era for town and county halls. With the new Local Government Act finally on the statute book, the next 12 months could be the most exciting in the council chamber for quite some time.
fields.body:
Ministers are already grandly calling it a new era for town and county halls. With the new Local Government Act finally on the statute book, the next 12 months could be the most exciting in the council chamber for quite some time.

Authorities will soon be policed by a new ethical framework - overseen by a sleaze-busting "standards board" to crack down on junketing and worse - and will have additional economic powers. But all eyes will be on wider reforms that go to the heart of local democracy.

After the election of London's first mayor, England's big cities will shortly begin the task of organising referendums to test the concept of provincial mayors. The act lays the foundation for radical reforms in the way councils do business, formally sweeping aside old committee structures in favour of a cabinet style of civic government - preferably headed by an executive mayor, if local government minister Hilary Armstrong gets her way.

Approval of the legislation is a clear victory for the minister, who pressed ahead with a sweeping reform package in spite of the misgivings of her boss, John Prescott, who heads the sprawling Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. The deputy prime minister stated publicly that he was no fan of elected mayors.

With some big councils gearing up for referendums with varying degrees of enthusiasm, the dilemma facing Armstrong is when to hold the polls. Optimistic talk of a "big bang" exercise later this year is clearly wide of the mark. Next May, then? "Maybe," says the minister, "but I think the party will be so busy with a general election that decisions like that may have to come later."

So, realistically, we might be talking about autumn 2001 for referendum day in a selected number of cities - with actual mayoral elections in May 2002. With ministers desperate to avoid any repetition of the London selection debacle, Labour has decided that provincial candidates will be chosen by one-member-one-vote, with the discredited electoral college finally consigned to history.

"It will take us at least until the end of the year to get the secondary legislation in place," the minister says. "But there is activity in all but one of the big cities [Manchester]. That does not mean they are committed to an elected mayor, but it does mean that either the council, or the opposition, are saying they should have a referendum."

Armstrong cites the example of Newcastle upon Tyne, where officially the ruling Labour group seems to be against the mayoral concept (although some dissidents are already campaigning against the line) while still going along with the government's wishes. "They're saying: 'We don't believe a mayor is right for our city, but we know people want a referendum'," says the minister.

As well as being forced to drop plans to repeal Clause 28, as the price for the act's passage, ministers had to give ground to freedom of information campaigners. Two 11th-hour concessions were made: town hall cabinet meetings will have to be held in public; smaller district councils will be allowed to keep their old committees.

Armstrong says: "We now have a new era of local government . . . a framework which could take [it] into a new and different mould of being the civic leaders, very much working with people." Giving councils powers to promote local "economic, social and environmental well-being" could be far-reaching. "They will extend the scope of councils to work more closely together."

Critics are already pointing to one flaw in the new law: it will not, officially, give councils powers to raise money for new initiatives. However, some innovative authorities are no doubt already looking for ways round this problem.
